0	"Gun control advocates often cite the statistic that 90 percent of Americans support expanding background checks for gun purchases.
President Barack Obama just did it in his Jan. 1
column3: weekly address.

column1: But conservative radio talk show host Laura Ingraham says that statistic is not accurate.
The 90 percent statistic of supporting background checks
column2: that's been debunked
column3: Ingraham said on Fox News Sunday on Jan. 3. ""Lots of the myths about gun ownership are perpetrated by people who never much liked the Second Amendment in the first place and who have a vested interest in amassing more power in Washington

column1: PolitiFact has rated this 90 percent statistic True as recently as October. So we decided to try and figure out what Ingraham was talking about when she said this is a myth that has been debunked.
Go to the polls
Under current law
column2: background checks are required in sales by federally licensed gun dealers
column3: but the checks are not required for gun sales by private sellers.

column1: National polls conducted in 2015 consistently show that around 90 percent of Americans support some sort of expanded background checks for gun purchases. Here are a few examples:
Quinnipiac University poll
column2: conducted Dec. 16-20: ""Would you support or oppose a law requiring background checks on people buying guns at gun shows or online?"" Support: 89 percent. Oppose: 9 percent. Unsure/No answer: 1 percent.

column1: CBS/New York Times poll
column2: conducted Oct. 21-25: ""Do you favor or oppose a federal law requiring background checks on all potential gun buyers?"" Favor: 92 percent. Oppose: 7 percent. Unsure/No answer: 1 percent.

column1: Gallup poll
column2: conducted Oct. 7-11: ""Would you favor or oppose a law which would require universal background checks for all gun purchases in the U.S. using a centralized database across all 50 states?"" Favor: 86 percent. Oppose: 12 percent. Unsure: 2 percent.

column1: Quinnipiac University poll
column2: conducted Sept. 17-21: ""Do you support or oppose requiring background checks for all gun buyers?"" Support: 93 percent. Oppose: 6 percent. Unsure/No answer: 1 percent.

column1: Pew Research Center poll
column2: conducted July 14-20: Do you favor or oppose ""making private gun sales and sales at gun shows subject to background checks""? Favor: 85 percent. Oppose: 13 percent. Unsure/Refused: 2 percent.

column1: Pew found that support for background checks spans all partisan and demographic groups
column2: and it is also favored by a majority of households that own guns and those that do not.

column1: So are all of these polls wrong? We reached out to Ingraham’s producers and didn’t hear back.
We couldn’t find any sort of definitive debunking of this stat
column2: but we did find that some gun rights advocates have taken issue with this statistic for reasons such as the survey questions referring to the general idea of background checks rather than specific legislation.

column1: For example
column3: polls found that 90 percent of Americans supported expanded background checks. However
column4: when Congress failed to pass a popular bill that would have increased background checks
column5: 47 percent were disappointed or angry that it failed
column6: while some 39 percent were relieved or very happy
column7: according to a Washington Post/Pew Research Center poll.

column1: Some gun rights activists took this as proof that the 90 percent figure was phooey.
This highlights an odd discrepancy: While people overwhelmingly support specific gun policy ideas
column2: like universal background checks and banning suspected terrorists from buying guns
column3: the support is not as robust when it comes to actually expanding gun control.

column1: The same October CBS/New York Times poll that found 92 percent support for expanded background checks also shows 46 percent of Americans think laws covering gun sales should be either made less strict or stay the same. Just 51 percent said the laws should be made more strict.
People don't seem to like the idea of ‘gun control
column2: ’ but they still want the government to do more to keep guns out of the hands of criminals and the mentally ill
column3: said Adam Winkler
column4: a law professor at the University of California Los Angeles and author of Gunfight: The Battle over the Right to Bear Arms in America.

column1: Our ruling
Ingraham said
column2: ""The 90 percent statistic of supporting background checks
column3: that's been debunked.""

column1: Numerous respected polls from 2015 show around 90 percent support for some sort of expanded background checks for gun purchases.

While there are some questions as to what inferences can be made from these findings — such as whether that 90-percent support translates into support for specific legislation — there hasn’t been a definitive debunking of the statistic.
We rate Ingraham’s claim False."	['https://static.politifact.com/CACHE/images/politifact/mugs/sessions_1/73e2cab8d0d2feb2eedc2c8b9ca40e56.jpg'

column1: 0	"The following is a transcript of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr’s remarks after being introduced as Senator Barack Obama’s vice-presidential running mate in Springfield
column2: Ill.
column3: as recorded by CQ Transcriptions:

column1: Well
column2: it's great to be here! On the steps of the old State House in the land of Lincoln. President Lincoln once instructed us to be sure to put your feet in the right place. Then stand firm. Today
column3: Springfield
column4: I know my feet are in the right place. And I am proud to stand firm for the next president of the United States of America
column5: Barack Obama. Folks
column6: Barack and I come from very different places
column7: but we share a common story. An American story. He was the son of a single mom
column8: a single mom who had to struggle to support her son and her kids. But she raised him. She raised him to believe in America. to believe that in this country there is no obstacle that could keep you from your dreams. If you are willing to work hard and fight for it. I was different. I was an Irish-Catholic kid from Scranton with a father who like many of yours in tough economic times fell on hard times
column9: but my mom and dad raised me to believe
column10: it's a saying Barack you heard me say before
column11: my dad repeated it and repeated it. Said champ
column12: it's not how many times you get knocked down
column13: it's how quickly you get up. It's how quickly you get up. Ladies and gentlemen
column14: that's your story. That's America's story. It's about if you get up

column1: That's the America Barack Obama and I believe in. That's the American dream. And ladies and gentlemen
column2: is there no ordinary times
column3: and this is no ordinary election. Because the truth of the matter is
column4: and you know it
column5: that American dream under eight years of Bush and McCain
column6: that American dream is slipping away. I don't have to tell you that. You feel it in your lives. You see it in your shrinking wages
column7: and the cost of everything from groceries to health care to college to filling up your car at the gas station. It keeps going up and up and up
column8: and the future keeps receding further and further and further away as you reach for your dreams. You know
column10: it is not a mere political saying. I say with every fiber of my being I believe we cannot as a nation stand for four more years of this. We cannot afford to keep giving tax cuts after tax cuts to big corporations and the wealthiest Americans while the middle class America
column11: middle class families are falling behind and their wages are actually shrinking. We can't afford four more years of a government that does nothing while they watch the housing market collapse. As you know
column12: it's not just the millions of people facing foreclosure. It's the tens of millions of your neighbors who are seeing the values of their homes drop off a cliff along with their dreams.

column1: Ladies and gentlemen
column2: your kitchen table is like mine. You sit there at night before you put the kids -- after you put the kids to bed and you talk
column3: you talk about what you need. You talk about how much you are worried about being able to pay the bills. Well
column4: ladies and gentlemen
column5: that's not a worry John McCain has to worry about. It's a pretty hard experience. He'll have to figure out which of the seven kitchen tables to sit at. Folks
column6: again
column7: it's not political sloganary when I say we literally can't afford four more years of this non- energy policy written by and for the oil companies
column8: making us more and more dependent from hostile nations on our ability to run this country and literally
column10: literally putting America's security at risk
column11: we can't afford four more years of a foreign policy that has shredded our alliances and sacrificed our moral standing around the world.

column1: Ladies and gentlemen
column2: that's the bad news. But there is good news
column3: America. We don't have to have four more years of George W. Bush. And John McCain. The next President of the United States is going to be delivered to the most significant moment in American history since Franklin Roosevelt. He will have such an incredible opportunity
column4: incredible opportunity
column5: not only to change the direction of America
column6: but literally
column7: literally to change the direction of the world. Barack Obama and I believe
column8: we believe with every fiber in our being that our families
column10: there's not a single solitary challenge we cannot face if we level with the American people. And I don't say that to say it; history
column11: history has shown it. When have Americans ever
column14: let their country down when they've had a leader to lead them?"	['https://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/images/icons/defaultPromoCrop.png']	https://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/images/icons/defaultPromoCrop.png	Senator Biden’s Remarks in Springfield

column1: 0	"Earlier today Josh Caplan at The Gateway Pundit posted on Gloria Allred’s last ditch effort to swing the Alabama senate race to Democrat Doug Moore.
WE CALLED IT! Gloria Allred Accuser **ADMITS** She Tampered With Roy Moore’s Yearbook ‘Signature’ (VIDEO)
Allred dragged out discredited Moore accuser Beverly Nelson to Good Morning America to hit Judge Roy Moore one last time before Tuesday’s vote.
Nelson admitted on ABC’s “Good Morning America” on Friday that she tampered with and added “notes” to what she claims is Moore’s signature inside her yearbook.
TRENDING: Praying For an Easter Miracle - Remember Miracles Do Happen!
The story is solid. The statements were made by Beverly Nelson this morning. The yearbook signature has been discredited as reported by ABC’s GMA this morning.
But after we posted the story this morning Facebook shut down our story.
The far left website Politifact said our story was not accurate and Facebook the shut it down. No one will be able to see our story on Facebook.
Breitbart wrote a similar post and it was also blocked by Facebook.
Facebook is TRASH. pic.twitter.com/KHy5Qfykg6 — Gab: Free Speech Social Network (@getongab) December 8
So Facebook shut down the story on Judge Roy Moore’s accuser.
Facebook is picking sides."	['https://www.thegatewaypundit.com/wp-content/uploads/allred-nelson.jpg'

column1: 0	"China yesterday announced that Premier Wen Jiabao will attend the Copenhagen climate summit and that he will bring with him a target for China of reducing carbon intensity by 40 to 45 percent from 2005 levels by 2020. Coming a day after the announcement across the Pacific that President Obama will attend the beginning of the summit
column2: bringing a commitment to reduce U.S. emissions ""in the range of 17%"" from 2005 levels by 2020
column3: this means that we now know what the world's two largest emitters will be bringing to the table when the world's countries gather in Copenhagen.

column1: The official announcement (in Chinese here) notes that on November 25
column2: Premier Wen Jiabao and the State Council standing committee met and decided upon the 2020 target and corresponding measures to achieve it. Of note are the following points:

column1: 1.) What exactly does the carbon intensity target cover? China will reduce its carbon intensity
column2: the CO2 emitted per unit GDP
column3: by 40 to 45 percent from 2005 levels by 2020. This carbon intensity target will measure only the CO2 emissions from energy consumption and industrial activity
column4: the source of most of China's emissions
column5: and does not take into account efforts to reduce emissions or increase sinks from land use and forestry. This makes sense given that estimating emissions from land use and forestry is less precise than measuring emissions from fuel combustion and industrial activity
column6: both of which are also more tightly linked to GDP than land use and forestry.

column1: China will reduce its carbon intensity
column2: the CO2 emitted per unit GDP
column3: by 40 to 45 percent from 2005 levels by 2020. This carbon intensity target will measure only the CO2 emissions from energy consumption and industrial activity
column4: the source of most of China's emissions
column5: and does not take into account efforts to reduce emissions or increase sinks from land use and forestry. This makes sense given that estimating emissions from land use and forestry is less precise than measuring emissions from fuel combustion and industrial activity
column6: both of which are also more tightly linked to GDP than land use and forestry. 2.) How will this be implemented? In order to measure the progress it is making in achieving this target
column7: China will include the carbon intensity target in its medium and long-term social and economic development plans and develop corresponding statistics
column8: monitoring and evaluation systems to measure progress. Thus
column9: we can expect that the next five year plan (2010-2015) will include systems for monitoring and evaluating officials' and enterprises' performance in meeting the specific carbon intensity reduction targets allocated to them
column10: similar to how the government implemented its target setting and official evaluation system for the twenty percent energy intensity reduction target in the current 11th Five Year Plan.

column1: In order to measure the progress it is making in achieving this target
column2: China will include the carbon intensity target in its medium and long-term social and economic development plans and develop corresponding statistics
column3: monitoring and evaluation systems to measure progress. Thus
column4: we can expect that the next five year plan (2010-2015) will include systems for monitoring and evaluating officials' and enterprises' performance in meeting the specific carbon intensity reduction targets allocated to them
column5: similar to how the government implemented its target setting and official evaluation system for the twenty percent energy intensity reduction target in the current 11th Five Year Plan. 3.) Will the target be binding internationally? At the moment
column6: the carbon intensity target is only a voluntary action and is not intended to be binding internationally. However
column7: the carbon intensity reduction targets will be mandatory (""约束性"") domestically for provinces and enterprises within China
column8: similar to how the current energy intensity targets are mandatory
column9: with consequences for officials of provinces and enterprises who do not meet their assigned targets.

column1: At the moment
column2: the carbon intensity target is only a voluntary action and is not intended to be binding internationally. However
column3: the carbon intensity reduction targets will be mandatory (""约束性"") domestically for provinces and enterprises within China
column4: similar to how the current energy intensity targets are mandatory
column5: with consequences for officials of provinces and enterprises who do not meet their assigned targets. 4.) Is the 40 - 45% target significant? Although there is debate about how much of a reduction this 40 to 45 percent carbon intensity reduction target is from a ""business as usual"" scenario
column6: we should keep in mind a few points. First
column7: how we define ""business as usual"" matters. As part of its current 11th Five Year Plan
column8: China took on a goal of reducing its energy intensity by 20% from 2006-10
column9: which has led to a coordinated energy efficiency program that includes actions such as closing down smaller
column13: and improving the efficiency of the Top 1
column14: 000 energy consuming enterprises. If China succeeds in reducing its energy intensity by 20% by 2010
column15: this would result in the avoidance of a billion tons of CO2 emissions. China should be given credit for these efforts and not penalized for taking early action.

column1: Second
column2: the International Energy Agency has noted that the commitments from China and the US are roughly in line with the actions they have estimated to be necessary to reach a concentration of 450 parts CO2 per million
column3: what scientists have deemed is necessary to keep global temperatures from rising more than two degrees Celsius. While we would hope that both China and the U.S. will seek to raise the level of their ambition
column4: both proposals are substantial and require real improvements in energy efficiency and low-carbon energy to achieve.

column1: The other important thing to remember is the significance of the carbon intensity target for creating the proper framework and incentives for reducing emissions. As noted above
column2: a carbon intensity target will require each province and major enterprise to measure
column3: report and reduce their CO2 emissions and energy consumption
column4: year-on-year
column5: acting as a driver for greater efficiency and renewables. In this way
column6: the carbon intensity target is similar to the US greenhouse gas mandatory reporting rule or the cap-and-trade system in the current climate legislation before Congress
column7: which put in place the proper incentives and systems to transition to a low-carbon
column8: clean energy economy. Provinces
column9: local governments and enterprises will need to establish and improve systems for measuring and reporting emissions
column10: and there will be increasing pressure on these enterprises and provinces to enact measures within their development plans for making continuous improvements in energy efficiency and renewable energy. At the national level
column11: China will need to continue and accelerate its policies to boost energy efficiency and renewables
column12: and it will need to build its capacity to measure and report emissions for its national greenhouse gas inventory on a yearly basis (something which EPA and China's National Development and Reform Commission have recently agreed to cooperate on).

column1: Just as important as the targets they have set for themselves
column2: China and the US must continue to accelerate their efforts to develop low carbon economies based on energy efficiency
column3: renewables
column4: and the development of clean technologies such as smart grids and electric vehicles. Both countries stand to benefit from the transition to a clean energy economy
column5: by growing new clean industries and jobs
column6: reducing their independence on dirty fossil fuels
column7: and reducing their contribution to climate change and environmental damage. China can achieve a substantial reduction in its carbon intensity while continuing to grow its economy and providing an improved standard of living and a better environment for its citizens.

column1: China's carbon intensity target is certainly a step in the right direction
column2: and it provides the right incentives for future improvements in reducing emissions. Following the U.S.'s own emissions reduction announcement and the recent bilateral clean energy initiatives announced during President Obama's visit
column3: we are beginning to see the outlines for a meaningful framework agreement in Copenhagen and a foundation for both countries to demonstrate leadership in addressing climate change."	['https://web.archive.org/web/20100330081658im_/http://switchboard.nrdc.org/media/icon-twitter.png'

column2: Missouri – Parents of a three-month old baby were horrified to discover their babysitter had turned into a crystal meth-smoking cannibal when they found the remains of their child cooked in the microwave.

column1: According to police report
column2: the young parents
column3: were out at the movies before they came back home to find a confused babysitter under the influence of alcohol and crystal meth who had lost consciousness and was covered in blood in the family’s living room.

column1: Moments later
column2: the parents made the gruesome discovery when the young mother saw something moving in microwave.

column1: The 16-year-old babysitter named ‘Anna Ritchie’
column2: claims she had brought some crystal meth and only took a few hits before she became hungry and eventually lost consciousness.

column1: “I just took a few hits because I was bored and wanted to stay awake
column2: ” she told Officer Robert. “All I remember is that I started getting really hungry
column3: ate some chicken wings and passed out” recalls the police officer
column4: visibly traumatized by the latest events.

column1: The 3-month-old child was found in the microwave
column2: covered in barbecue sauce
column3: and was rushed to Springfield’s Mercy Hospital where doctors do not fear for his life.

column1: “Apparently
column2: the baby sitter tried to cook the baby in the microwave oven but she was unable to do so
column3: and was probably disoriented and lost consciousness moments later
column4: ” explained Sheriff Deputy Anderson James of the Jefferson County Police Department. “Teeth marks were found on the baby’s arms and legs but luckily he is unharmed” he acknowledged
column5: visibly distraught by the whole affair.

column1: The state of Missouri has led
column2: for more than a decade
column3: the nation in methamphetamine busts. A recent 2015 state-wide study revealed that more than 60% of adults aged 21 and higher have tried crystal meth at least once and close to 40% of respondents believed crystal meth should be decriminalized as a schedule 2 drug for medical use in treatment." column1: 0	"HOUSTON
column2: TEXAS – Anti-apartheid and human rights activist Archbishop Desmond Tutu has died in Texas at the age of 86.

column1: His wife Leah Tutu told reporters that the couple were in Texas for holiday and had plans of greeting George H.W Bush who lost his wife few days ago.
According to Leah Tutu
column2: Desmond Tutu was rushed to hospital in the wee hours of Saturday morning where he passed on. The cause of his death is not immediately known.

column1: In August 2016
column2: Tutu’s daughter Thandeka Tutu-Gxashe he was in the hospital for treatment of a recurring infection.

column1: Zimbabwean leader Robert Mugabe may have described him as “evil”
column2: but Archbishop Desmond Tutu remained a much-loved figure across the world – principally for his role in South Africa’s struggle against apartheid.

column1: During the long years that Nelson Mandela was in prison
column2: Archbishop Tutu spoke out against the regime – and won the Nobel peace prize in 1984 for his efforts.

column1: He was chosen by President Mandela to chair South Africa’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission and investigate the crimes committed by all sides during the apartheid regime.
Before his demise
column2: “the Arch” – as he was known – had remained irrepressible and influential both in his native South Africa and on the global political stage.

column1: He was chairman of a group of former world leaders called The Elders
column2: launched on Nelson Mandela’s 89th birthday in 2007 with the aim of tackling some of the world’s most pressing problems.

column1: 0	"Please click here to view the video of this statement.
Like millions of Americans I learned of the tragic events in Arizona on Saturday
column2: and my heart broke for the innocent victims. No words can fill the hole left by the death of an innocent
column3: but we do mourn for the victims’ families as we express our sympathy.

column1: I agree with the sentiments shared yesterday at the beautiful Catholic mass held in honor of the victims. The mass will hopefully help begin a healing process for the families touched by this tragedy and for our country.
Our exceptional nation
column2: so vibrant with ideas and the passionate exchange and debate of ideas
column3: is a light to the rest of the world. Congresswoman Giffords and her constituents were exercising their right to exchange ideas that day
column4: to celebrate our Republic’s core values and peacefully assemble to petition our government. It’s inexcusable and incomprehensible why a single evil man took the lives of peaceful citizens that day.

column1: There is a bittersweet irony that the strength of the American spirit shines brightest in times of tragedy. We saw that in Arizona. We saw the tenacity of those clinging to life
column2: the compassion of those who kept the victims alive
column3: and the heroism of those who overpowered a deranged gunman.

column1: Like many
column2: I’ve spent the past few days reflecting on what happened and praying for guidance. After this shocking tragedy
column3: I listened at first puzzled
column4: then with concern
column5: and now with sadness
column6: to the irresponsible statements from people attempting to apportion blame for this terrible event.

column1: President Reagan said
column2: “We must reject the idea that every time a law’s broken
column3: society is guilty rather than the lawbreaker. It is time to restore the American precept that each individual is accountable for his actions.” Acts of monstrous criminality stand on their own. They begin and end with the criminals who commit them
column4: not collectively with all the citizens of a state
column5: not with those who listen to talk radio
column6: not with maps of swing districts used by both sides of the aisle
column7: not with law-abiding citizens who respectfully exercise their First Amendment rights at campaign rallies
column8: not with those who proudly voted in the last election.

column1: The last election was all about taking responsibility for our country’s future. President Obama and I may not agree on everything
column2: but I know he would join me in affirming the health of our democratic process. Two years ago his party was victorious. Last November
column3: the other party won. In both elections the will of the American people was heard
column4: and the peaceful transition of power proved yet again the enduring strength of our Republic.

column1: Vigorous and spirited public debates during elections are among our most cherished traditions. And after the election
column2: we shake hands and get back to work
column3: and often both sides find common ground back in D.C. and elsewhere. If you don’t like a person’s vision for the country
column4: you’re free to debate that vision. If you don’t like their ideas
column5: you’re free to propose better ideas. But
column6: especially within hours of a tragedy unfolding
column7: journalists and pundits should not manufacture a blood libel that serves only to incite the very hatred and violence they purport to condemn. That is reprehensible.

column1: There are those who claim political rhetoric is to blame for the despicable act of this deranged
column2: apparently apolitical criminal. And they claim political debate has somehow gotten more heated just recently. But when was it less heated? Back in those “calm days” when political figures literally settled their differences with dueling pistols? In an ideal world all discourse would be civil and all disagreements cordial. But our Founding Fathers knew they weren’t designing a system for perfect men and women. If men and women were angels
column3: there would be no need for government. Our Founders’ genius was to design a system that helped settle the inevitable conflicts caused by our imperfect passions in civil ways. So
column4: we must condemn violence if our Republic is to endure.

column1: As I said while campaigning for others last March in Arizona during a very heated primary race
column2: “We know violence isn’t the answer. When we ‘take up our arms’
column3: we’re talking about our vote.” Yes
column4: our debates are full of passion
column5: but we settle our political differences respectfully at the ballot box – as we did just two months ago
column6: and as our Republic enables us to do again in the next election
column7: and the next. That’s who we are as Americans and how we were meant to be. Public discourse and debate isn’t a sign of crisis
column8: but of our enduring strength. It is part of why America is exceptional.

column1: No one should be deterred from speaking up and speaking out in peaceful dissent
column2: and we certainly must not be deterred by those who embrace evil and call it good. And we will not be stopped from celebrating the greatness of our country and our foundational freedoms by those who mock its greatness by being intolerant of differing opinion and seeking to muzzle dissent with shrill cries of imagined insults.

column1: Just days before she was shot
column2: Congresswoman Giffords read the First Amendment on the floor of the House. It was a beautiful moment and more than simply “symbolic
column3: ” as some claim
column4: to have the Constitution read by our Congress. I am confident she knew that reading our sacred charter of liberty was more than just “symbolic.” But less than a week after Congresswoman Giffords reaffirmed our protected freedoms
column5: another member of Congress announced that he would propose a law that would criminalize speech he found offensive.

column1: It is in the hour when our values are challenged that we must remain resolved to protect those values. Recall how the events of 9-11 challenged our values and we had to fight the tendency to trade our freedoms for perceived security. And so it is today.

Let us honor those precious lives cut short in Tucson by praying for them and their families and by cherishing their memories. Let us pray for the full recovery of the wounded. And let us pray for our country. In times like this we need God’s guidance and the peace He provides. We need strength to not let the random acts of a criminal turn us against ourselves
column2: or weaken our solid foundation
column3: or provide a pretext to stifle debate.

column1: America must be stronger than the evil we saw displayed last week. We are better than the mindless finger-pointing we endured in the wake of the tragedy. We will come out of this stronger and more united in our desire to peacefully engage in the great debates of our time
column2: to respectfully embrace our differences in a positive manner
column3: and to unite in the knowledge that
column4: though our ideas may be different
column5: we must all strive for a better future for our country. May God bless America.

column1: 0	"Chief Justices
Associate Justices
Notes: The acceptance of the appointment and commission by the appointee
column2: as evidenced by the taking of the prescribed oaths
column3: is here implied; otherwise the individual is not carried on this list of the Members of the Court. Examples: Robert Hanson Harrison is not carried
column4: as a letter from President Washington of February 9
column5: 1790 states Harrison declined to serve. Neither is Edwin M. Stanton who died before he could take the necessary steps toward becoming a Member of the Court. Chief Justice Rutledge is included because he took his oaths
column6: presided over the August Term of 1795
column7: and his name appears on two opinions of the Court for that Term.

column1: The date a Member of the Court took his/her Judicial oath (the Judiciary Act provided “That the Justices of the Supreme Court
column2: and the district judges
column3: before they proceed to execute the duties of their respective offices
column4: shall take the following oath . . . ”) is here used as the date of the beginning of his/her service
column5: for until that oath is taken he/she is not vested with the prerogatives of the office. The dates given in this column are for the oaths taken following the receipt of the commissions. Dates without small-letter references are taken from the Minutes of the Court or from the original oath which are in the Curator’s collection. The small letter (a) denotes the date is from the Minutes of some other court; (b) from some other unquestionable authority; (c) from authority that is questionable
column6: and better authority would be appreciated.
