column1: 0	"June 13
column2: 2010  -- TAPPER (voice-over): Good morning
column3: and welcome to ""This Week.""

column1: It keeps getting worse in the gulf
column2: while the nation asks
column3: who's in charge and when will it end?

column1: OBAMA: We talk to these folks so I know whose ass to kick.
TAPPER: And Congress turns up the heat on BP. Our headliners this morning
column2: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer.

column1: HOYER: We need to get it stopped.
TAPPER: And Minority Leader John Boehner.
BOEHNER: Figure out what the hell went wrong.
TAPPER: Hoyer and Boehner
column2: a ""This Week"" debate.

column1: Then
column2: he revolutionized computing
column3: and now he wants to do the same for energy. In a ""This Week"" exclusive
column4: Microsoft co-founder and chairman Bill Gates outlines his vision for a clean energy future...

column1: GATES: The government playing a strong role is critical and urgent.
TAPPER: ... and what it will cost.
Plus
column2: the roundtable looks at a big night for women in politics. That and all the week's politics with George Will
column3: Democratic strategist Donna Brazile
column4: former Republican Congressman Tom Davis
column5: and former Labor Secretary Robert Reich.

column1: And as always
column2: the Sunday funnies.

column1: COLBERT: Eighty-two billion dollars lost. God. It would be such a tragedy if any pelicans owned BP stock.
(END VIDEO CLIP)
ANNOUNCER: From the heart of the nation's capital
column2: ""This Week"" with ABC's senior White House correspondent
column3: Jake Tapper
column4: live from the Newseum on Pennsylvania Avenue.

column1: TAPPER: And joining me now is House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer and House Minority Leader John Boehner. Gentlemen
column2: thanks so much for joining me.

column1: HOYER: Thank you.
BOEHNER: Hey
column2: good morning.

column1: TAPPER: So you got a letter last night -- I actually think I got it before you guys did...
HOYER: I think you did.
TAPPER: ... but from President Obama requesting $50 billion in emergency spending for state and local governments. Leader Hoyer
column2: you have said that there is spending fatigue on Capitol Hill. Can you get this passed?

column1: HOYER: Well
column2: I think it's accurate that there's spending fatigue
column3: not only on Capitol Hill
column4: but around the country. People are concerned about the debt level
column5: and we are
column6: as well. But clearly
column7: you cannot not continue to stimulate an economy that is still struggling to get out of the deep ditch that we found it in about 18 months ago.

column1: What the president is saying is
column2: we need to expend additional dollars to make sure that we don't have significant layoffs in the next few months
column3: which will again depress the economy
column4: so that -- I understand what he's saying. I have asked the White House to look at the package that we -- the Recovery and Reinvestment Act that we passed
column5: approximately $800-plus billion. There are clearly funds in there that have not been expended to see whether or not there are some available for this more immediate priority than some that may not be quite as immediate.

column1: TAPPER: Leader Boehner
column2: the president said in his letter that if this does not pass
column3: the economy -- there's a risk that the economy will slide back into recession. Do you agree?

column1: BOEHNER: Listen
column2: I'm concerned about the plight of teachers
column3: firemen
column4: policemen who face the real possibility that they may be laid off
column5: but to send this letter up here on a Saturday night with no opportunity to cut spending elsewhere in the budget strikes me as a little different. Steny and I and other leaders were at the White House on Thursday
column6: and this subject never came up.

column1: There was no indication this was going to happen. And I'm asking myself
column2: why is this happening on Saturday night?

column1: Fact is that the spending spree in Washington is continuing to run unabated. The American people are screaming at the top of their lungs
column2: ""Stop!"" And -- and to move this without finding other offsets in spending
column3: I think
column4: is irresponsible. It's just putting more debt on the backs of our kids and our grandkids
column5: and it really begs the question is
column6: why don't we have a budget this year?

column1: You know
column2: we've not cut -- the House has failed -- not failed in the modern era to move a budget. And this appears to be the first time in the modern era that the House is not even going to consider a budget.

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: Leader Hoyer
column3: if I could...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: ... if I could say
column2: one of the -- the theory is that you don't want to make vulnerable Democrats vote for another spending bill
column3: and that's why for the first time since 1974 there isn't going to be a House budget. Is that not true?

column1: HOYER: Whatever -- whatever the theory may be
column2: Jake
column3: the fact of the matter is
column4: my friend
column5: Mr. Boehner
column6: voted for $2 trillion during the Bush administration of unfunded spending. So when he says this cascade of spending

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: But you agree that this should be offset with spending cuts?
HOYER: I would hope that we could do that
column2: yes. However
column3: what I said was
column4: money that has already been appropriated in the Recovery and Reinvestment Act that has not yet been spent could be spent now on these priority items. Nobody wants to see $300
column5: 000 teachers or fire and police laid off. That's not good for the economy; it's not good for our kids; it's not good for the safety of our communities.

column1: So the president's absolutely right in terms of this being critically important spending
column2: and we're going to work on getting that. I personally believe that if we have dollars that are not yet expended in the Recovery Act that we can apply to this immediate need and then look to later expenditures in the long term for investments
column3: I think we ought to do that. But we can't -- we can't stimulate and depress at the same time.

column1: TAPPER: I'd like to -- I'd...
BOEHNER: Jake
column2: every family knows that in a tough time it's more important to have a budget
column3: not less. And if you think that they're going to move a budget on Capitol Hill
column4: you must obviously believe that Elvis is still alive.

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: I'd -- I'd like to move on to another topic...

column1: HOYER: I know you do...
TAPPER: ... other than Elvis.
HOYER: ... but as you know
column2: the Republicans didn't have a budget in '02

column1: BOEHNER: The House has never failed to pass a budget in the modern era.
HOYER: And the American public had no idea about that
column2: budgets that pass...

column1: BOEHNER: Well
column2: this is a great opportunity...

column1: HOYER: ... and spending bills that follow (ph).
BOEHNER: ... to cut spending and to get the economy going again.
HOYER: And we're doing that.
BOEHNER: That's why I gave the president...
HOYER: Let me close with this.
BOEHNER: ... a letter this week with -- 100 economists signed a letter saying that cutting spending now will
column2: in fact
column3: help get the economy moving again
column4: get jobs back...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: I would like -- in terms of getting things moving again
column2: I would like to move to another topic...

column1: HOYER: Look
column2: can I conclude on the deficit? Because the president -- we've adopted statutory PAYGO
column3: which they jettisoned.

column1: BOEHNER: And you've ignored it every time you've had a chance to use it.
TAPPER: All right
column2: guys...

column1: HOYER: The president sent down a freeze in spending. And he established a commission to look at long-term spending control. All of that is positive movement.
TAPPER: Let's move on to the oil spill.
BOEHNER: The American people want spending cut now.
TAPPER: Got it. Let's move on to the oil spill
column2: because I want to get your reaction. On Tuesday
column3: the BP chief operating officer
column4: Doug Suttles
column5: told the Associated Press that the flow ""should decrease to a relative trickle by Monday or Tuesday."" That's by tomorrow or the day after that
column6: Doug Suttles said that.

column1: I don't know what a relative anything means when it comes to this oil spill
column2: but there's no indication that there's going to be -- it's only going to be trickling by tomorrow or the next day. And I just want to know
column3: as the leaders of your respective parties on Capitol Hill
column4: are you finding it tough to believe anything these guys from BP have to say anymore?

column1: HOYER: Certainly BP has not been accurate in its representations. It has been misleading in its representations. What has happened is outrageous
column2: and the American public are correctly very
column3: very angry. And the administration has been marshalling every asset that we have available to work on this program.

column1: I hope he's right. The American public hopes he's right. A trickle. I don't know what a trickle is. But certainly a very
column2: very substantial reduction. BP said they could handle a 250
column3: 000-barrel spill. They have -- weren't able to handle what they said was initially a 5
column5: which was -- what then went to 20
column7: 000 and now we think is a much greater spill than that.

column1: BOEHNER: Well
column2: Steny
column3: guess what? I agree wholeheartedly with you. The American people want this oil leak stopped now. They want to know what happened. They want the gulf cleaned up. And they want it all done now.

column1: And I just think that BP ought to be held responsible for all of the costs that are involved in this. I've said that right from -- from the beginning. And I continue to believe that.
I'm sure that the federal government
column2: though
column3: was -- isn't also responsible. The laws that were in place
column4: the -- the materials that should have been in place for a spill this size were not
column5: and the reaction
column6: I think
column7: on the part of the administration has been slow. But having said that
column8: it's time to get this thing stopped now.

column1: TAPPER: All right
column2: just to...

column1: HOYER: The only thing I would say to that
column2: Jake...

column1: TAPPER: ... just to clear up what you said earlier this week
column2: on Thursday
column3: you said that -- that BP and the federal government should take full responsibility. To clarify that
column4: you think BP needs to pay?

column1: BOEHNER: I've said from the beginning
column2: BP needs to pay for the entire cost of this. But the federal government -- this is a failure of government. Government is there to protect our shores
column3: to protect our environment. And there's been a real failure here.

column1: We've been asking for 55 days
column2: where's the inspection reports from this rig? The administration won't give them to us.

column1: TAPPER: The Democrats are pushing a bill to lift the liability. Right now
column2: it's at $75 million. Democrats are pushing a bill to lift the liability cap. Do you support that?

column1: BOEHNER: I believe that lifting the liability cap on BP and for this spill is appropriate. I have concerns...
TAPPER: So lift it entirely for BP?
BOEHNER: Absolutely. They should be held responsible for every dime of this cost.
HOYER: Let me -- let me -- let me say a few words here. First of all
column2: the Republicans have been holding up lifting the cap in the Senate from the $75 million
column3: minuscule sum
column4: as we see
column5: to $10 billion.

column1: Secondly
column2: I think John Boehner is right in this respect: The psychology of neglect in terms of regulatory oversight that was pursued in the Bush administration
column3: which led to the banking failure
column4: insurance prices going way up
column5: and oil companies thinking they could do whatever they wanted because the ""drill
column6: baby
column8: all they wanted them to do was to drill.

column1: So I think John's right. I think the regularly psychology of the last administration was not appropriate
column2: and there was mistakes made in this administration
column3: as well.

column1: BOEHNER: How long are you going to blame the Bush administration? Come on. What's going on over at MSS...
HOYER: As long as they're responsible
column2: whether it's the economy...

column1: BOEHNER: No
column2: that's -- listen...

column1: HOYER: ... or their lack of oversight
column2: John
column3: I'm going to do that.

column1: BOEHNER: Where -- where -- when is someone...
HOYER: As appropriate (ph).
BOEHNER: ... in Washington going to -- Washington going to take responsibility for what they are in charge of?
TAPPER: I want to move on...
HOYER: And the administration has done that.
TAPPER: I want to move on to some foreign policy questions
column2: but before I do
column3: I just -- there -- there was a poll recently this week indicating that the American people rate the federal response to this oil spill as worse than the federal response to Katrina
column4: 69 percent negative for the gulf oil spill
column5: 62 percent negative for the government's response to Katrina. Do you rate the government's response to this oil spill as negative or positive?

column1: HOYER: Absolutely not. I think that that's -- the American public are angry
column2: rightfully so. BP was on site. The folks who own the rig
column3: Halliburton
column4: who constructed the piping
column5: the concrete down there
column6: they are responsible with the federal government was (ph).

column1: Immediately upon this incident happening -- immediately...
TAPPER: So you think the government's responsible?
HOYER: ... the Coast Guard -- the Coast Guard was on site. Unfortunately
column2: tragically
column3: we lost 11 lives
column4: but saved over 100 lives on site. Thad Allen
column5: the admiral
column6: immediately put in charge
column8: 500 National Guard troops on duty right now.

column1: TAPPER: OK.
HOYER: So there's been a vast response here. A natural disaster came along in Katrina
column2: and
column3: frankly
column4: there were months before there was adequate response.

column1: TAPPER: Leader Boehner
column2: turning to Israel
column3: a member of your leadership team
column4: Congressman Mike Pence of Indiana
column5: said this on Thursday.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
PENCE: Remarkably
column2: yesterday
column3: the president said it was time for Israel to sharply limit its effective blockade in Gaza
column4: saying
column5: quote
column6: ""The situation in Gaza is unsustainable."" The truth is
column8: your policy in Israel is unsustainable. The American people are on the side of Israel and Israel's right to defend herself. Mr. President

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Leader Boehner
column2: is expressing concern about the humanitarian crisis in Gaza the same thing as being anti-Israel?

column1: BOEHNER: Well
column2: I think the Israelis have a clear right to -- to defend themselves. When you look at this flotilla that came over
column3: the first five ships that were inspected
column4: there was no -- there was no problem at all. It's pretty clear to many of us who've looked into this that this last ship was intended to be a problem
column5: intended to cause a conflict.

column1: And this is part of a much bigger problem that we see with the administration
column2: where we've -- we've coddled our enemies and -- and pushed our friends aside in the process...

column1: TAPPER: Leader Hoyer?
BOEHNER: ... raising a lot of doubts around the world
column2: including the people of Israel
column3: who are having serious doubts about our commitment to them
column4: our closest ally in the Middle East.

column1: HOYER: And I think one of the problems is
column2: when you see Mr. Pence and you hear Mr. Boehner
column3: this is not a partisan difference. Mr. Cantor and I had a colloquy on Thursday
column4: which as John knows
column5: I strongly support Israel's actions.

column1: They told these folks
column2: come here
column3: you're not going to break the blockade. Why are you not going to break the blockade? Because Hamas
column4: a terrorist organization
column5: continues to attack civilians
column6: men
column8: in Israel.

column1: And it is appropriate to have a blockade to make sure they don't get the weapons or other materials to effect those kinds of attacks
column2: which are criminal
column3: which are terrorist acts. So I think they did exactly the right thing in stopping that.

column1: And in fact
column2: in my view
column3: the sixth ship
column4: as John has pointed out
column5: we agree on this
column6: five ships were stopped without incident. This sixth ship was stopped. There's some reason to believe that that's exactly what they intended to do. Al Jazeera television showed attacks on the boarding party

column1: Turkey knew that if these ships came
column2: it was going to be a problem. And the Israelis offered to allow the -- those ships to be offloaded at an Israeli port and all the humanitarian gear go into Gaza. That was the appropriate thing to do.

column1: TAPPER: We only have one minute left
column2: and I want to get your predictions for the midterm elections
column3: literally one minute left. So...

column1: HOYER: History says we're going to lose a few seats
column2: but we're going to retain the House.

column1: TAPPER: You're going to keep the House?
HOYER: We're going to keep the House.
TAPPER: Sir?
BOEHNER: Our goal is to take the majority in the House...
TAPPER: Not your goal. What's going to happen? Prediction. Prediction. You've said 100 seats. Can you do it?

BOEHNER: We've got -- we've got 100 seats in play. We have a real shot at winning a majority so that we can put a check on this administration and all the spending that's out of control here in Washington
column2: D.C.

column1: HOYER: Jake
column2: they said that about Mark Critz in the 12th District of Pennsylvania. He won by 8 points.

column1: TAPPER: All right.
HOYER: We're going to keep the House.
TAPPER: Leader Hoyer
column2: Leader Boehner
column3: thanks so much for joining us. I appreciate it.

column1: TAPPER: Joining me now
column2: Microsoft co-founder and chairman
column3: Bill Gates.

column1: Mr. Gates
column2: thanks so much for joining us.

column1: BILL GATES
column2: MICROSOFT CO-FOUNDER & CHAIRMAN: Great to be here.

column1: TAPPER: Obviously
column2: the oil spill in the Gulf makes your proposal for $11 billion in energy innovation all the more resonant
column3: all the more relevant. But I'm wondering
column4: some are criticizing the president's handling of the federal response to the spill by saying he doesn't have executive experience and that's why he hasn't been able to -- to really get the federal bureaucracy moving the way it needs to.

column1: As a former CEO
column2: do you think there's anything to that at all?

column1: GATES: Well
column2: I think in any crisis like this
column3: the key thing is to avoid them happening in the future. And I'm not an expert on oil recovery. BP is certainly incented to try and minimize the damage here in a very complex situation.

column1: But how did we get an ener -- energy infrastructure that is this fragile?
You know
column2: we've got a supply chain where we send a billion dollars a year overseas and you can imagine that there will be disruptions. When there have been in the past
column3: we've always said
column4: no
column5: let's put a solution in place. But
column6: in fact
column7: the only real solution is to take American ingenuity and fund R&D to get energy in different forms that we're not sending this much money away and -- and that it's stable and reliable.

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: let -- let's talk about that. Obviously
column3: your proposal for $11 billion in additional spending for energy innovation
column4: there's not a huge appetite right now among the American people for more spending with the record deficits we have.

column1: Forgetting the merits of your proposal for a second
column2: how politically feasible is it?

column1: GATES: Well
column2: I would distinguish between spending and investment. What we're talking about is about 1 percent of what the United States spends on energy
column3: being devoted to R&D. And so if you find a way out of the energy sector to raise that 1 percent
column4: which is not some huge increase in the costs there
column5: then you can tap into the unique ability in this country
column6: through its universities
column8: to give us a form of energy that is both cheaper
column9: not dependent on foreign supply and is environmentally designed so that we're not emitting carbon and getting into the climate change problem.

column1: The only way you get those things is through the breakthroughs. And I'm optimistic they're there
column2: but we're not making the investment. Today we spend only about $4 billion on energy R&D compared to $30 billion on health
column3: $80 billion on -- on defense.

column1: TAPPER: So that's your pitch.
How receptive have you found lawmakers?
GATES: Well
column2: there is obviously a -- a tight budget. And it would be tough to say that this money should come from existing categories.

column1: The question is can the energy sector finance its own revolution and create these great R&D jobs here in America?
TAPPER: What's the risk if -- if President Obama and Congress and the American people don't do this?

GATES: The problem we'll run into is that we'll have more crises like the oil spill and we'll have the supply disruption. We'll start to see more and more effects of the -- the climate problem. The costs will go up because you're looking for oil in harder and harder places.
So you'll just be paying more and more. And so it's an implicit tax. If you don't innovate
column2: it's this gigantic cost that we'll be paying.

column1: TAPPER: You know
column2: some experts believe that the only way to spur the kind of innovation and investment in these alternative forms of energy is to dissuade the American people and American enterprise from using oil and gasoline. Do you think that a gas tax is necessary?

column1: GATES: The -- that's not specifically necessary. You need some source of funding for this R&D. And
column2: you know
column3: so you would take some parts of the energy sector and -- and raise the money there. If you -- if you want people to switch
column4: there's two ways to do it. One is to invent something that's lower cost. The other is to raise the cost of the thing that's forcing us to fund the military or creating climate problems and -- and help the new technology. The bulk of what's missing right now that will force us
column5: at some point
column6: to go for a very expensive alternative because we haven't done invention
column7: is the -- this -- this R&D piece isn't getting done.

column1: TAPPER: Why do you think that the innovation and technology that's part of the oil industry hasn't advanced enough in the last 30 years
column2: I mean to -- to plug this hole in the Gulf
column3: they're using basically the same technology as they used 20 or 30 years ago?

column1: Why have -- hasn't that advanced?
GATES: Well
column2: certainly
column3: in retrospect
column4: they needed to invest more in these deep sea operations. Deep sea operation is fairly complicated in terms of pressures and temperatures how materials behave down there. And obviously
column5: you know
column6: now they're seeing the cost of not doing that. That will be reinforced in a lot of ways.

column1: So that particular innovation will happen. But you're going to get oil in very hard places. With other energy sources
column2: over time
column3: you wouldn't have to try that hard you wouldn't have to be bringing most of it out of the Middle East
column4: where
column5: you know
column6: the chance of something disrupting that in the years ahead is -- is very measurable and -- and we're not -- we're not setting ourselves up to get rid of that over time.

column1: TAPPER: So tell us what areas you're looking at.
GATES: Well
column2: the idea of the Council's report is that you -- you fund R&D very broadly with an open mind. You don't just pick and say it will be synthetic fuels or hydrogen or fuel cells
column3: but you get behind all of those things and you create metrics. In the solar area alone
column4: there's so many different approaches -- solar thermal
column5: solar chemical
column6: solar electric -- and many different scientists. And that's the beauty of America
column7: is you -- you can have hundreds of teams pursuing those things. And as they meet milestones
column8: they can get more funding.

column1: TAPPER: The economic recovery has been slow and relatively jobless.
What do you think President Obama needs to do?
GATES: Well
column2: the president can't just pull the levers and -- and make the economy take off. You know
column3: the right emergency steps were taken and...

column1: TAPPER: So you support the stimulus and the TARP program?
GATES: Well
column2: you don't -- I don't think I need to get into the particulars. And it's easy looking back to say
column3: OK
column4: you could have tuned this or that. The incredible measures needed to be taken to make sure there wasn't a collapse
column5: both in terms of stabilizing the financial system and then priming the pump of the economy
column6: because it had been slowed down so much.

column1: Now
column2: we're seeing the benefits that those things have been done. Now this is an international problem.

column1: And so everybody's dad is coming in
column2: you know
column3: are -- are those governments over spending?

column1: You know
column2: our own government is looking at when do you cut back?

column1: And it's a tricky thing
column2: because almost everybody agrees we need to keep spending up
column3: you know
column4: not take all country deficits to zero right away. But over time
column5: you have to move in that direction. And so getting the timing right on this is -- is a very tough challenge.

column1: TAPPER: So do you think that there needs to be another stimulus to keep spending up?
GATES: In terms of the U.S. in particular
column2: lots of people
column3: you know
column4: have views that plus and minus on that in terms of if you did a -- a smaller stimulus
column5: where exactly would you target?

column1: You know
column2: our $16 billion for energy R&D
column3: that's a type of stimulus. That is creating jobs and it's a -- a nice investment in the future. So where you get a twofer like that
column4: that feels particularly attractive that -- that you can do that.

column1: TAPPER: Do you think the health care legislation is going to do enough to contain costs and control the deficit?
GATES: Well
column2: the -- the health care bill broadened coverage. And there's a lot of...

column1: TAPPER: Yeah
column2: but beyond that
column3: do you think it's going to contain...

column1: GATES: Well
column2: in terms of cost containment
column3: that step alone
column4: in my view
column5: is at most the start of how we look at not letting medical costs continue to go up. The projection is they'll continue to go up.

column1: And it creates a dilemma that if the government is funding those costs and if you're -- you know
column2: you feel your taxation levels are going to hit some -- some limit
column3: then what are you taking money away from?

column1: You're not going to take it away from your Social Security. You're not going to take it away from paying the debt.
It's a tough problem.
So if we could innovate to reduce those increases in costs that would be great. And I think there's a lot of work to be done there
column2: you know
column3: people – In some respects may be tired of hearing about health care
column4: but in terms of really reducing the costs
column5: no. The -- the years ahead
column6: that's going to -- a lot of experts and politicians are going to have to -- to think about how that's achieved.

column1: TAPPER: Last month
column2: Apple passed Microsoft in market capitalization
column3: making -- it marked a historic moment where -- where Microsoft lost its status as the largest tech company in the world.

column1: Why did this happen?
And -- do you still have confidence in CEO
column2: Steve Ballmer?

column1: GATES: Oh
column2: Microsoft is doing a lot of great stuff. I mean the software industry
column3: you know
column4: the opportunities are -- are pretty phenomenal. You know
column5: the way that people think about TV
column6: the way they think about reading
column8: software is going to revolutionize that. Our company and our stock has gone up
column12: not the most valuable. It -- you know
column13: that's -- that changed and it will change again and again and again.

column1: There's room for more than one company to succeed in the industry. I -- I happen to like the things that Steve's -- Steve's doing. It's not my full-time work
column2: but as a -- a board member
column3: you know
column4: I -- I see a lot of great things going on.

column1: TAPPER: Bill Gates
column2: thanks so much for joining us.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
LENO: Eighty-nine-year-old White House reporter Helen Thomas is retiring. I'm going to be the first to say
column2: ""Mazel tov.""

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
(UNKNOWN): The Democratic Senate nominee in South Carolina
column2: Alvin Greene...

column1: (UNKNOWN): Oh
column2: Alvin.

column1: (UNKNOWN): ... is a mystery man.
GREENE: So we should be pro-South Carolina
column2: rather than anti-Greene
column3: and speaking of me.

column1: SMITH: Where'd you get the $10
column2: 000 grand to file?

column1: GREENE: From my own personal money.
(UNKNOWN): Where did he come from
column2: and how did he win?

column1: OLBERMANN: How do you think the people voted for you on Tuesday knew who you were or even that you were running?
GREENE: You know
column2: I think that they -- they saw -- I think that they -- you know
column3: I just think that they recognize -- I think they -- they heard of my name.

column1: (UNKNOWN): This is for real?
(UNKNOWN): Yes
column2: I am for real.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: The quizzical stylings of Al Greene
column2: the Democratic Senate candidate in South Carolina
column3: one of many topics we'll get to with our roundtable
column4: starting with George Will
column5: former Republican Congressman Tom Davis
column6: from the University of California at Berkeley
column8: the former Clinton labor secretary

column1: Thanks
column2: one and all
column3: for being here. Let's start with the oil spill this week. The fallout from the oil spill became transatlantic
column4: George. Check the headlines that we see here. ""Obama killing all our pensions."" ""Cameron fails to back BP in fight with Obama."" ""Back off
column5: Obama."" This is how the British press is treating this disaster. BP
column6: obviously
column7: the biggest company in the U.K.

column1: Do they have a point?
WILL: Well
column2: sure
column3: they do. This is a reminder to Americans at all time that when they attack Wall Street and big business
column4: they're attacking the people who are supporting their pension funds. I don't know how many Americans depend also on BP
column5: but a lot of them do. It's an internationally traded stock.

column1: So when you turn on the company
column2: the liability of which is unclear at this point
column3: but Congress
column4: according to the interview you just conducted
column5: is thinking of passing something that looks awfully like a bill of attainder
column6: which is to single out for punishment with specific legislation a particular corporation. This is going to -- to ripple through people's 401(k)s and elsewhere.

column1: TAPPER: Tom
column2: when you were in Congress
column3: you were for a time the head of the National Republican Congressional Committee in charge of electing Republicans to Congress
column4: so you were focused on the mood of the public. What does this oil spill do to the mood of the public?

column1: DAVIS: Well
column2: it adds to the narrative where the big institutions have failed us
column3: government
column4: Wall Street
column5: BP. The anger out there
column6: I think
column7: is greater than we've seen in at least a generation
column8: and this adds to the narrative of government sitting there powerless
column9: just making speeches. It's let them down.

column1: TAPPER: Professor Reich
column2: on -- on Wednesday
column3: when President Obama and other White House officials meet with BP executives -- do you like that
column4: that I called you ""professor""?

column1: REICH: I do
column2: actually
column3: yes.

column1: TAPPER: You're smiling. When he meets with BP executives
column2: one of the things he'll be pushing for is a -- is an escrow account
column3: a third-party escrow account for BP to put money in
column4: and then a third party will give out this money to people whose lives have been impacted by the spill. Where do you see this headed?

column1: REICH: Well
column2: look
column3: Jake
column4: BP does not have unlimited resources. It has a lot. But inevitably
column5: there is going to be a clash
column6: because the costs of this clean-up
column7: the costs of containing the oil spill damage
column8: the costs of plugging that hole are going to be in the tens of billions of dollars. And the question is
column9: how much of this is going to be borne by the American taxpayer and how much by BP?

column1: But the present spectacle of the Coast Guard asking BP to speed up this clean-up is absurd. I mean
column2: the federal government needs to be in charge. The president needs to be in charge of this. Use BP's expertise. Use BP's resources. But the president must be in charge of all of this. Otherwise
column3: he looks like he's just standing on the sidelines.

column1: BRAZILE: Well
column2: the administration has been constrained by the Oil Pollution Act of 1990
column3: which basically gives the responsible party the lead role in trying to not only fix the problem
column4: but contain the problem. That has been the problem from day one. They've waited for BP to come up with the answers
column5: and we know that BP continues to mislead people.

column1: I don't have any sympathy -- and I -- and I probably have some stock or something in BP
column2: because I have mutual funds
column3: so let me just put that aside and say
column4: all the people of Great Britain
column5: this is not personal. This is not about your national identity.

column1: This is about a big region of our country that now has to deal with an oil spill that will go on for years and years and years
column2: threatening the livelihood of human beings
column3: marine life
column4: sea life
column5: and a way of life for people who make that their homes
column6: 14 million Americans.

column1: So when it comes to sympathy
column2: angry
column3: love (ph)
column4: go down to the Gulf Coast
column5: because we have all of it. And we're angry. Tomorrow
column6: the BP directors will meet. I hope that they hold that money in escrow. I hope...

column1: TAPPER: The dividend -- the dividend money?
BRAZILE: Absolutely. They made $6.8 billion in profit as of March 31st. Hold it in escrow until the investigation is completed. And while they're at it
column2: process these claims.

column1: People are waiting
column2: waiting in line now in St. Bernard Parish for food because they cannot go out and fish. They can't hunt
column3: so they can't feed their families. They can't pay their mortgage. I have a lot of anger. I don't want my president to be angry. I have it for him.

column1: REICH: Go beyond escrow. Go into temporary receivership.
TAPPER: You think that the Obama administration should take control of BP or BP America?
REICH: BP America
column2: absolutely
column3: Jake. Otherwise
column4: not only is this a political disaster-in-waiting
column5: because this is going to get larger and larger
column6: and the president looks like he's waiting on the sidelines
column8: secondly
column9: we have no way of knowing as American people that BP is actually telling the truth
column10: that all of its resources are being put to the appropriate use
column11: and that it is appropriately balancing the health and safety of Americans against the cost of doing this clean-up.

column1: This is a for-profit organization
column2: BP
column3: that is answerable to its shareholders
column4: not to the American people.

column1: TAPPER: President Obama is going down to the gulf
column2: Alabama
column3: Mississippi and Florida
column4: tomorrow. And when he gets back
column5: he's going to give an address to the nation from the White House Tuesday at 8 o'clock. Last time he went down
column6: his own White House video cameras caught him talking to residents down there
column7: and this is what he had to say.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
OBAMA: I can't just dive down there and plug the hole. I can't suck it up with a straw. All I can do is make sure that I put honest
column2: hard-working
column3: smart people in place
column4: like Thad
column5: to implement this thing.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Congressman
column2: this is the president being confronted with the limits of his own abilities
column3: even though he's been a big proponent of government and the ability of government
column4: but here he is saying
column5: ""I can't do this. I can't suck up the oil with a straw."" This is a dilemma for him.

column1: DAVIS: It is. You know
column2: I did the Katrina report
column3: too
column4: the same kind -- it was an unforgiving storm. And even if you did everything right
column5: there was going to be a lot of anger
column6: a lot of disappointed people. You have the same circumstance here.

column1: But you have to ask yourself
column2: where was MMS? We've known this has been a dysfunctional organization for years.

column1: TAPPER: The Minerals Management Service.
DAVIS: Absolutely. I held hearings on this when I was in Congress
column2: calling for reorganization and moving it back and forth. There's probably more culpability here than we see. We haven't gotten to the bottom line. It's easy to just blame BP
column3: put it all on them
column4: but I think a thorough investigation is going to show that there was a breakdown all through.

column1: TAPPER: George?
WILL: Well
column2: if there is a breakdown all through
column3: I don't know why he thought it was a propitious moment to start a criminal investigation of a company that is in charge of this and that Bob wants the government to take over on the principle that the government will run another corporation well. I don't understand any of what's going on.

column1: The president -- and I don't know why he's coming back to talk to us again. He's been talking about this nonstop for five weeks.
BRAZILE: Well
column2: some people believe that he hasn't said enough
column3: George
column4: and that this is his fourth visit.

column1: TAPPER: What could he possibly say
column2: though?

column1: BRAZILE: Well
column2: I -- I do believe that he needs to answer some of the questions that have been raised about the containment of the current spill
column3: whether or not there are enough federal resources to contain what has already been in the gulf
column4: to make sure that the states have the proper boomers
column5: the skimmers
column6: and all of the other resources they need -- they need in order to contain the spill.

column1: I think he needs to update us on everything he understands. Look
column2: he may be able to split the sea
column3: but I don't think he can cap the well. And I think it's even foolish to think that the president can -- can split the sea
column4: but politics is in this
column5: and it's draining his political capital
column6: so I think he needs to address this and talk about our addiction to oil
column7: because there are some longer-term issues here
column8: including a moratorium

column1: TAPPER: Bob
column2: I want to turn briefly
column3: if I could
column4: just to the other crisis that the country is facing. That's the economic crisis. Retail sales figures came out
column5: and I know you wanted to say something about this. They're actually down 1.2 percent during this time that the economy is supposedly recovering. What do you think the significance is?

column1: REICH: Well
column2: this is very unusual
column3: Jake. Hopefully
column4: this is just an aberration
column5: but we have this on top of 41
column6: 000 private jobs being created in May...

column1: TAPPER: Not a lot. Not a lot of jobs.
REICH: No. At this stage of recovery
column2: particularly from this deep a recession
column3: you need a lot of job growth
column4: and you also need a lot of retail sales growth.

column1: The fact is
column2: American consumers just can't afford it. They're coming out from under huge debt loads
column3: and many of them are still facing the prospect of joblessness.

column1: This is why it is so important -- given the private sector's and consumers' inability to spend more -- for the public sector to spend more
column2: at least in the short term. I mean
column3: the public is not being told -- and here's where presidential education is very important
column4: Donna -- the president is not being -- the president is not educating the public and the public is not being told that there is a huge difference between short-term spending to stimulate the economy and get the economy going again and dealing with the long-term structural deficit
column5: which is mostly about health and Medicare. And these are two different animals entirely.

column1: TAPPER: All right
column2: I want to move to politics now. You guys can talk more about the economy in the green room in the green room segment we have later
column3: but we had some really amazing primaries that happened on Tuesday. In California
column4: especially
column5: where you hail from
column6: Bob
column7: there is the Fiorina versus Boxer race is setting up for the Senate. Carly Fiorina
column8: former HP chairperson
column9: just won the Republican nomination for Senate.

column1: And here
column2: right out of the box
column3: is Carly Fiorina's greatest hits while she was wired for sound before a TV interview.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
FIORINA: Laura (ph) saw Barbara Boxer briefly on television this morning and said what everyone says. God
column2: what is that hair?

column1: (LAUGHTER)
So yesterday. You didn't...
(END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: So
column2: Bob
column3: forget the hair. Forget Barbara Boxer's hair for a second. There is a possibility that Barbara Boxer will be so yesterday. She is vulnerable.

column1: REICH: She is vulnerable. I think that what we are seeing in California
column2: again
column3: if you look at the history of this country
column4: everything that is good and everything that's bad starts in California. And what we see in California is a huge
column5: huge amount of spending
column6: Republicans going through the gauntlet of that right-wing Republican primary
column7: forcing Fiorina and also Whitman to the right.

column1: Now
column2: we're not going to have primaries to kick around anymore or parties in California after this year
column3: because Californians
column4: in a -- in a flight of just desperation
column5: said we can't stand it anymore and we're getting rid of parties
column6: especially.

column1: TAPPER: Tom
column2: you wrote a memo to the -- your successor at the National Republican Congressional Committee
column3: Pete Sessions
column4: outlining the lay of the land
column5: what you -- what you think voters are doing right now
column6: what they're thinking right now. What -- what did you tell him?

column1: DAVIS: Well
column2: it's very clear anger today is worse than it was in 1994
column4: when Congress flipped hands. I mean
column5: that's clear. And the Republicans have had a better recruiting year
column6: I think
column7: than any party has in the last generation
column8: in terms of recruiting challengers. That's on the plus side for the Republicans.

column1: On the down side is
column2: they still have a party branding issue. The voters threw the Republicans out in 2006 and threw them out in 2008. And when you ask which party is more acceptable
column3: I mean
column4: neither one is
column5: but Democrats actually rank slightly higher than Republicans.

column1: The Democrats are prepared for this. They have -- all of their candidates have over $1 million in the bank. They've seen this wave coming. They've constructed a high seawall.
You don't have the open seats the Republicans had in -- in 1994 to shoot out or the Democrats had in 2006. And instead of a wind at your back
column2: it's kind of a crosswind. And if you can be Scott Brown and get your sail up and hoist it right
column3: you can ride it into shore
column4: but just relying on
column5: ""They're the other guys
column6: we're not

column1: The Republicans have got to take this anger and translate it in districts across the country if they're going to win. They have a possibility of taking the House back. This is not an automatic. This is one of those strange years that voter anger is deep
column2: and all these things we're talking about just add to that narrative.

column1: TAPPER: George
column2: what do you see from Tuesday's results that you find interesting? What conclusions did you draw
column3: if any?

column1: WILL: How hard it is to draw national conclusions about this. In California
column2: Barbara Boxer
column3: 69 years old
column4: running with Jerry Brown
column5: 72 years old
column6: is not a youth movement out there. But Barbara Boxer got more votes
column8: than Carly Fiorina and her principle challenger
column11: even though there was a hotly contested gubernatorial and Senate primaries on the Republican side to bring out the vote.

column1: In Arkansas
column2: a right-to-work state
column3: out of 1.1 million workers in Arkansas
column4: only 41
column5: 000 are unionized workers. Unions went in
column6: spent $10 million
column7: accusing Blanche Lincoln of being insufficiently subservient. And
column8: surprise
column11: she starts out 20 points behind her Republican opponent.

column1: And in Nevada
column2: Harry Reid might
column3: on a good day
column4: get to 43 percent in Nevada. So he has to figure out in his canny way how to win with 43 percent. Here's how you do it: You spend a lot of money to take down your most -- what you think is your strongest opponent. You pick your opponent.

column1: There are six other lines on that ballot
column2: independent candidates. That'll disperse the vote. And there's a none-of-the-above in Nevada. You can vote
column3: ""I don't like any of these people."" So in that sense
column4: he may have brought down to 43 percent the winning total and his -- his threshold of victory.

column1: TAPPER: Let's talk about that Arkansas primary
column2: because Senator Blanche Lincoln did finally defeat Bill Halter
column3: who had been supported by labor unions. And that night that she beat him in the run-off
column4: a White House official -- an anonymous White House official -- called our friend
column5: Ben Smith
column6: at Politico and said
column8: ""Organized labor just flushed $10 million of their members' money down the toilet on a pointless exercise. If even half that total had been well targeted and applied in key House races across the country
column9: that could have made a real difference in November.""

column1: Asked about the quote
column2: here's what White House press secretary Robert Gibbs had to say. He said
column3: ""First of all
column4: I should say that the president wouldn't agree with that characterization

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GIBBS: I think that whether or not that money might have been better spent in the fall on closer elections between somebody -- between people who cared about an agenda that benefited working families and those that didn't
column2: that money might come in more -- more handy then.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Donna
column2: is the White House risking alienating labor with that kind of talk?

column1: BRAZILE: I think
column2: for the most part
column3: labor decided to ignore those comments
column4: although some of them were a little bit -- they were not too satisfied with that comment.

column1: Look
column2: organized labor does not exist to elect Democrats. They exist to help workers
column3: to improve their jobs
column4: their benefits
column5: their pay. So I think the White House needs to be careful in alienating labor
column6: because without organized labor
column7: we don't have the sea legs to go knocking door to door to get the few Democrats that they support elect to office. And I know that from being out there for more than 30 years electing Democrats.

column1: That said
column2: look
column3: she ran a great campaign. Blanche Lincoln ran a great campaign. She ran against Washington. Labor
column4: the money did make her the outsider. She was able to reconnect with her base
column5: and she pulled her base out. She still has trouble in the general election
column6: but she ran a very smart

column1: And Bill Clinton helped her. He is popular. Ninety percent of the people in the state still love him. And he was able to pull out the stops to get her elected.
This was ladies' night across the country on Tuesday night
column2: ladies' night. It was double or nothing in many states. We have now more female candidates running for governor and senator as a result of the -- the voter anger out there
column3: and so that's a good -- that's a good sign for women candidates.

column1: That said
column2: not all women are equal in this battle. I thought Carly Fiorina's comments about Barbara Boxer was catty. It was old-school. And we've long since stopped talking about women's hair
column3: headlines (ph)
column4: coat jackets
column5: et cetera. We don't talk about male grooming or their ties
column6: so she should get better on her message.

column1: TAPPER: I get comments about my ties all the time.
BRAZILE: Well
column2: that's because you're married to a smart woman.

column1: But
column2: you know
column3: the Republicans spent a lot of money to -- to win in California
column4: $100 million. That's a lot of...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: You know
column2: let me -- let me...

column1: REICH: And it was their -- and it was their own money. Let me just say that in that gubernatorial race
column2: in that primary
column3: we had two candidates who spent $100 million of their own money.

column1: TAPPER: And let's talk about that for one second
column2: because -- because the other CEO running for governor
column3: as opposed to Senate with Fiorina
column4: is Meg Whitman from eBay. And here's Jerry Brown. He is the Democratic gubernatorial candidate
column5: and he told a local reporter
column6: ""You know
column7: by the time Whitman's done with me two months from now
column8: I'll be a child-molesting"" -- he let the line trail off. ""She'll have people believing whatever she wants about me. It's like Goebbels. Goebbels invented this kind of propaganda. He took control of the whole world. She wants to be president. That's her ambition
column9: the first woman president. That's what this is all about.""

column1: Bob
column2: regardless of the tastelessness of comparing Meg Whitman to a Nazi propagandist
column3: Jerry Brown has a point in the sense -- not the Goebbels part of it -- but in the sense that she has a lot of money. She spent $70 million of her own money just in the primary.

column1: REICH: Well
column2: again
column3: California is the future. It means that
column4: essentially
column5: the ground war
column6: the organizing on the ground
column7: is really less and less important. And if you can spend a huge amount of money -- or you
column8: like Jerry Brown
column9: have a brand-name recognition -- you can get through and possibly be elected. But if you don't have a lot of money of your own and don't have brand-name recognition

column1: WILL: But California also has a history of very rich candidates losing. There is such a thing as declining marginal utility of the last dollar spent
column2: and the Republicans may be reaching that.

column1: DAVIS: And we're seeing campaign finance reform
column2: really
column3: that parties are -- they -- they no longer have the value. What's happened is the money has moved away with the political parties with the new (ph) -- out to the Tea Party
column4: the Club for Growth
column5: MoveOn.org
column6: to labor. So the party establishments don't have the kind of power they once did.

column1: REICH: But connect the dots. I think this is a very important point
column2: Tom. I mean
column3: we've got so much anger in the electorate. Why? Because
column4: A
column5: we've got an economy that is not functioning for many people. B
column6: we have a lot of physical representation of things out of control
column7: such as the blow in the -- in -- in the gulf.

column1: And
column2: thirdly
column3: we have political parties that people now feel are not representing them at all. So there's this kind of anti-establishment earthquake going on in the country
column4: and politicians ought to be aware. It's not just incumbents.

column1: TAPPER: Donna
column2: I just -- we only have 30 seconds. You just talked to the South Carolina Democratic Party chair
column3: Carol Fowler
column4: about this bizarre nomination of Alvin Greene. Very quickly
column5: what did she tell you?

column1: BRAZILE: It's a mystery. No one understands it. They can't -- no one can explain it. And there are all kind of conspiracy theories out there. Some of them I might ascribe myself to at some point. This guy came from nowhere
column2: walked in with a cashier's check with his name scrawled on it
column3: went back home to his dad's house
column4: never campaigned
column5: never cut a radio spot
column6: a robo-call

column1: TAPPER: OK
column2: well
column3: the roundtable will continue in the green room on abcnews.com
column4: where later you can also find our fact checks. We've teamed up with PolitiFact to fact check the show."	['http://abcnews.go.com/ThisWeek/week-transcript-hoyer-boehner-bill-gates/null'

column1: 0	While the school choice movement can trace its lineage to the very genesis of the United States civil society
column2: the concept of parental choice in education began to more fully mature through the work of Nobel Prize winning economist Milton Friedman. Just one year after the landmark Brown v. Board of Education case
column3: Friedman explained a plan for student school vouchers that would enhance and diversify K-12 education across the country. Friedman’s plan
column4: and much of the scholarship that it inspired
column5: focused on the means by which all students would have access to equal and excellent educational opportunities. In 1990
column6: the movement took a substantial step forward with the creation of the nation’s first publicly financed urban school choice program
column7: the Milwaukee Parental Choice Program.(link to page with state choice programs) Several similar initiatives were established in the years following
column8: utilizing both the voucher and the tax credit model
column9: with publicly funded and supported choice programs developing in areas such as Arizona
column13: Cleveland and Ohio. With the development of these programs came the institution of multiple state-based and national organizations (link to allies page) whose function was the protection and expansion of school choice. In 2002
column14: the movement earned a momentous triumph with the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision on the constitutionality of the Cleveland scholarship program in the 2002 Zelman v. Simmons-Harris decision. Throughout this period of tremendous growth
column15: it became increasingly clear that the school choice movement would need to develop a national infrastructure and vision in order to achieve sustainable success. With this in mind
column18: philanthropists and activists discussed the creation of a single
column20: high capacity initiative that could lead school choice into its most exciting era. After significant research and planning
column22: 2004 – the 50th anniversary of Brown v. Board of Education – this initiative became a reality
column23: as the Alliance for School Choice was launched. The Alliance for School Choice is the only national policy organization devoted exclusively to promoting school choice programs that expand private sector opportunities
column24: primarily for economically disadvantaged children. Together with its sister lobbying organization
column25: Advocates for School Choice – and in close collaboration with state and national allies – the Alliance is devoted to assisting local efforts to implement successful and transformative school choice programs throughout the country. The Alliance for School Choice is the legacy of many years of advancing the cause of educational opportunity. Standing on the shoulders of giants such as Milton Friedman
column26: strengthened by the pioneering work of countless allies
column27: and empowered by the promises set forth in Brown v. Board of Education
column28: the Alliance is committed to the work of leading school choice into a new era – one that will ultimately see the vision of educational opportunity become a reality.	['https://web.archive.org/web/20051210114606im_/http://www.allianceforschoolchoice.org/images/spacer.gif'

column1: President John H. Cox? President Dal Lamagna? These names might not sound familiar
column2: but these guys have also reported raising money for a presidential bid this cycle—and in some cases have actually collected more than (slightly) better-known candidates. Cox
column3: a Republican described as a ""Reagan fiscal and social conservative"" on his website
column4: has raised $586
column5: 080 this year
column6: which is more than Alan Keyes has raised
column7: and Cox has more cash on hand than the newcomer. Lamagna
column8: a ""progressive activist"" who has produced three documentaries about the Iraq war
column11: which is more than Mike Gravel raised. Both Cox and Lamagna
column13: have accrued pretty significant debt. Cox is in the hole $1.1 million
column14: almost twice more than he's brought in
column16: 000. But because they are both funding their own campaigns
column17: they owe the money to themselves. Other lesser-known candidates are libertarians or members of other third parties. Military Continues to Give to Paul

column1: Despite his anti-war stance
column2: or perhaps because of it
column3: Ron Paul continues to collect more money from members of the U.S. military than any other presidential candidate
column4: including John McCain
column5: a Vietnam War prisoner who backs the administration's policy in Iraq. Paul brought in at least $53
column6: 670 from the uniformed services
column8: 000. Democrat Barack Obama
column9: who opposed the resolution to go to Iraq from the start
column10: is the number-two recipient with at least $45
column11: 200. This trend may exemplify growing dissatisfaction among members of the military with the administration's handling of foreign policy
column12: especially in Iraq. Democrats have received 35 percent of the total $319
column13: 000 in contributions from uniformed service members this year. By comparison
column15: the last presidential race before the Iraq war began
column16: Democrats received only 18 percent of contributions from the military. *Read a Capital Eye story from September about military giving: The Other Iraq Surge Battle of the Sexes (10/19/07

column1: Hillary Clinton
column2: the only woman running for president
column3: is bringing in more money from female donors than any other candidate. But she doesn't have the largest number of female donors. That distinction belongs to Democrat Barack Obama
column4: who has so far collected money from at least 22
column5: 045 women giving more than $200
column6: compared to Clinton's 17
column7: 539. (Only donors who give more than $200 are itemized in campaign finance reports
column8: so it's impossible to determine a gender breakdown for smaller donors.) Clinton is nearly tied with Democrat Dennis Kucinich in the percentage of total funds coming from women—about 44 percent for both of them. Among Republicans
column9: a larger number of women have given to Mitt Romney than any other candidate in the party
column11: 801 donors giving a total of $12.1 million
column12: or about 32 percent of his total. But with about 35 percent of his funds from women
column13: dropout Sam Brownback's receipts from females make up the largest percentage of his total compared to all other GOP candidates. Hedge Funds and Private Equity Invest in Giuliani

column1: As senators
column2: Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama are debating legislation that would significantly increase taxes on hedge funds and private equity firms. As presidential hopefuls
column3: the two are raking in money from the industry
column4: while Mitt Romney
column5: who made his fortune in private equity
column6: is seeing a decline in contributions from them. Nearly 61 percent of the $5.7 million in donations from hedge funds and private equity firms went to Democrats during the third quarter. Although Romney brought in $597
column7: 800 during the 1st Quarter—more than any other candidate from either party—he is down to $76
column8: 350 for the 3rd Quarter and $944
column9: 275 for the year. Clinton has collected $966
column11: 000 in the last nine months. The real winner of hedge fund and private equity money seems to be Republican Rudy Giuliani. He has amassed $1.1 million from the wealthy industry so far. 0	"Hillary Clinton had a third and most-likely fatal heart attack this afternoon after spending the morning being told she’d be getting better. It almost seems fitting that the last thing she hears is a lie about her own well-being.
The Butcher of Benghazi will meet her maker
column2: says Doctor Eugene Icsa of Westchester Memorial Hospital in upstate New York
column3: as the damage to her heart is irreparable at this point:

column1: “Secretary Clinton fought hard but today her fight is over. We predict she’ll be at rest within hours.”

The Clinton family has asked for privacy and wouldn’t answer questions about whether or not they had to decide to “pull the plug” or if they’re simply being told nothing can be done. Chelsea Clinton was seen entering the hospital in tears shortly after noon
column2: according to a new report from LLOD correspondent Skip Tetheluda:

column1: “Chelsea came alone and was obviously distraught. She made no comment to the press but did stop to tell one photographer to have some respect while she ‘visits a great woman for the last time.’ She hasn’t come out and is presumably sitting and waiting to say goodbye. Bill Clinton is sitting on the front porch of the Chappaqua mansion drinking what looks like either tomato juice or a Bloody Mary.”

We’ll update you as soon as we confirm that Clinton has gone on to answer for her crimes with an eternity in Hell."	['https://web.archive.org/web/20170731052757im_/http://politicspaper.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/muslims-80x80.png'

column1: 0	"Mitt Romney’s pick of U.S. Rep. Paul Ryan as his running mate has rekindled a heated debate over Medicare.
Ryan
column2: R-Wis.
column3: is the head of the Budget Committee in the U.S. House of Representatives and the architect of a plan to dramatically restructure Medicare.

column1: Today
column2: Medicare operates as a government-run health insurance plan for Americans over age 65.

column1: Ryan’s idea is to eventually move Medicare toward private insurance companies by giving people a set amount to buy their own health insurance plans. The new system would be for people who are under age 55 now
column2: and it would give them voucher-like credits to buy traditional fee-for-service Medicare or competing private insurance plans. (The credits are sometimes called ""premium support."")

column1: Though House Republicans voted overwhelmingly for Ryan’s plan
column2: polling shows public opinion is mixed
column3: with older voters the most wary of the plan.

column1: The Republican response to attacks on the Ryan plan has been to attack back
column2: saying President Barack Obama has cut ""$700 billion"" out of Medicare. And the Democratic response to that: Well
column3: Paul Ryan cuts that amount
column4: too!

column1: For this check
column2: we’re looking specifically at what Obama campaign spokeswoman Stephanie Cutter said on Face the Nation when debating Romney spokesman Eric Fehrnstrom.

column1: You know
column2: I heard Mitt Romney deride the $700 billion cuts in Medicare that the president achieved through health care reform
column3: Cutter said. ""You know what those cuts are? It’s taking subsidies away from insurance companies
column4: taking rebates away from prescription drug company. Is that what Mitt Romney wants to protect? And interestingly enough Paul Ryan protected those cuts in his budget.""

column1: It’s a lot to digest if you’re not already a Medicare policy wonk
column2: so let us sort it out for you. For now
column3: we are going to put aside the question of whether it is accurate to call them ""cuts"" -- a claim we're checking in another item -- and focus on the question of whether Cutter is correct that Ryan relies on those same reductions in his budget.

column1: $700 billion in Medicare cuts?
Because we’re wonks ourselves at PolitiFact
column2: our ears pricked up at the claim in recent days that Obama cut $700 billion out of Medicare. Just a few weeks ago
column3: the oft-cited number was $500 billion. How did he manage to cut another $200 billion when no one was looking?

column1: Well
column2: there are cuts and then there are CUTS. Neither Obama nor his health care law literally ""cut"" a dollar from the Medicare program’s budget.

column1: Rather
column2: the health care law instituted a number of changes to reduce the growth of Medicare costs. At the time the law was passed
column3: those reductions amounted to $500 billion over the next 10 years.

column1: What kind of spending reductions are we talking about? They were mainly aimed at insurance companies and hospitals
column2: not beneficiaries. The law makes significant reductions to Medicare Advantage
column3: a subset of Medicare plans run by private insurers. Medicare Advantage was started under President George W. Bush
column4: and the idea was that competition among the private insurers would reduce costs. But in recent years the plans have actually cost more than traditional Medicare. So the health care law scales back the payments to private insurers.

column1: Hospitals
column2: too
column3: will be paid less if they have too many re-admissions
column4: or if they fail to meet other new benchmarks for patient care.

column1: Still
column2: the overall Medicare budget is projected to go up for the foreseeable future. The health care law tries to limit that growth
column3: making it less than it would have been without the law
column4: but not reducing its overall budget. So claims that Obama would ""cut"" Medicare need more explanation to be fully accurate. In the past
column5: we’ve rated similar statements Half True or Mostly False
column6: depending on the wording and context.

column1: Because Medicare spending gets bigger every year
column2: the cost-saving mechanisms in the health care law also get bigger. Also
column3: it takes a few years for the health care law’s savings mechanisms to kick in. In fact
column4: the effects of time are the main reason the $500 billion number has turned into $700 billion.

column1: The CBO determined in 2011 that the federal health care law would reduce Medicare outlays by $507 billion between 2012 and 2021. In a more recent estimate released this year
column2: the CBO looked at the years 2013 to 2022 and determined the health care law affected Medicare outlays by $716 billion.

column1: So it’s timing that’s making the ""cuts"" bigger
column2: not changes to Medicare.

column1: Does the Ryan budget ‘protect those cuts’?
Now onto our second question: Does Ryan’s budget keep the reductions in Medicare spending? The short answer is yes.
Here’s what Ryan said in an interview with George Stephanopolous of ABC News in June
column2: before his selection as Romney’s running mate:

column1: Stephanopoulos: ""You know
column2: several independent fact-checkers have taken a look at that claim
column3: the $500 billion in Medicare cuts
column4: and said that it's misleading. And in fact
column5: by that accounting
column6: your budget
column8: which Gov. Romney has endorsed
column9: would also have $500 billion in Medicare cuts.

column1: Ryan: ""Well
column2: our budget keeps that money for Medicare to extend its solvency. What Obamacare does is it takes that money from Medicare to spend on Obamacare. ..."" (Read the full exchange.)

column1: So Ryan has confirmed his budget includes the Medicare savings.
The Romney campaign got questions on this point the day after Cutter’s remarks
column2: and issued a statement saying that Romney intended to fully repeal the federal law
column3: including the savings for Medicare.

column1: Mitt Romney and Paul Ryan have always been fully committed to repealing Obamacare
column2: ending President Obama’s $716 billion raid on Medicare
column3: and tackling the serious fiscal challenges our country faces
column4: said Lanhee Chen
column5: Romney’s policy director
column6: in a statement reported by NBC News. ""A Romney-Ryan administration will restore the funding to Medicare
column7: ensure that no changes are made to the program for those 55 or older
column8: and implement the reforms that they have proposed to strengthen it for future generations.""

column1: Cutter
column2: though
column3: was talking about the Ryan budget. We should point out that the Ryan budget is a congressional resolution that doesn’t have the force of law. And its plan for Medicare hasn’t been turned into legislation that could be analyzed in detail by the Congressional Budget Office.

column1: Still
column2: Ryan himself said his plan did include the reductions in future spending that were part of the federal health care law.

column1: That’s because both sides agree on one point: Medicare spending is growing too rapidly
column2: and it needs to reined in.

column1: Our ruling
Cutter said that Romney attacked Obama for cutting $700 billion out of Medicare
column2: but ""Paul Ryan protected those cuts in his budget."" Again
column3: with this item we are not addressing whether they are cuts
column4: but simply whether she is correctly characterizing Ryan's plan.

column1: Cutter is correct that the Ryan budget plan included cost savings that were part of the future health care law. Just recently
column2: the Romney campaign backed away from that play
column3: saying Romney’s plan would restore the spending that the health law is set to curtail
column4: such as extra funding for private insurers under the Medicare Advantage plan.

column1: Still
column2: Cutter was right about the Ryan plan. We rate her statement True."	['https://static.politifact.com/CACHE/images/mugs/Cornyn/66c5f66b92a1f7a6b5059ca005af57f1.JPG'
