column1: 0	"As Delivered

Today we are asked whether to give the President of the United States authority to use force in Iraq should diplomatic efforts fail to dismantle Saddam Hussein's chemical and biological weapons and his nuclear program.
I am honored to represent nearly 19 million New Yorkers
column2: a thoughtful democracy of voices and opinions who make themselves heard on the great issues of our day especially this one. Many have contacted my office about this resolution
column3: both in support of and in opposition to it
column4: and I am grateful to all who have expressed an opinion.

column1: I also greatly respect the differing opinions within this body. The debate they engender will aid our search for a wise
column2: effective policy. Therefore
column3: on no account should dissent be discouraged or disparaged. It is central to our freedom and to our progress
column4: for on more than one occasion
column5: history has proven our great dissenters to be right.

column1: Now
column2: I believe the facts that have brought us to this fateful vote are not in doubt. Saddam Hussein is a tyrant who has tortured and killed his own people
column3: even his own family members
column4: to maintain his iron grip on power. He used chemical weapons on Iraqi Kurds and on Iranians
column5: killing over 20 thousand people. Unfortunately
column6: during the 1980's
column7: while he engaged in such horrific activity
column8: he enjoyed the support of the American government
column9: because he had oil and was seen as a counterweight to the Ayatollah Khomeini in Iran.

column2: Saddam Hussein invaded and occupied Kuwait
column3: losing the support of the United States. The first President Bush assembled a global coalition
column4: including many Arab states
column5: and threw Saddam out after forty-three days of bombing and a hundred hours of ground operations. The U.S.-led coalition then withdrew
column6: leaving the Kurds and the Shiites
column7: who had risen against Saddam Hussein at our urging
column8: to Saddam's revenge.

column1: As a condition for ending the conflict
column2: the United Nations imposed a number of requirements on Iraq
column3: among them disarmament of all weapons of mass destruction
column4: stocks used to make such weapons
column5: and laboratories necessary to do the work. Saddam Hussein agreed
column6: and an inspection system was set up to ensure compliance. And though he repeatedly lied
column8: and obstructed the inspections work
column9: the inspectors found and destroyed far more weapons of mass destruction capability than were destroyed in the Gulf War
column11: large volumes of chemical and biological stocks
column12: a number of missiles and warheads
column13: a major lab equipped to produce anthrax and other bio-weapons
column14: as well as substantial nuclear facilities.

column2: Saddam Hussein pressured the United Nations to lift the sanctions by threatening to stop all cooperation with the inspectors. In an attempt to resolve the situation
column3: the UN
column4: unwisely in my view
column5: agreed to put limits on inspections of designated ""sovereign sites"" including the so-called presidential palaces
column6: which in reality were huge compounds well suited to hold weapons labs
column8: and records which Saddam Hussein was required by UN resolution to turn over. When Saddam blocked the inspection process
column9: the inspectors left. As a result
column12: ordered an intensive four-day air assault
column14: on known and suspected weapons of mass destruction sites and other military targets.

column2: the United States also changed its underlying policy toward Iraq from containment to regime change and began to examine options to effect such a change
column3: including support for Iraqi opposition leaders within the country and abroad.

column1: In the four years since the inspectors left
column2: intelligence reports show that Saddam Hussein has worked to rebuild his chemical and biological weapons stock
column3: his missile delivery capability
column4: and his nuclear program. He has also given aid
column5: comfort
column6: and sanctuary to terrorists
column8: though there is apparently no evidence of his involvement in the terrible events of September 11

column1: It is clear
column2: however
column3: that if left unchecked
column4: Saddam Hussein will continue to increase his capacity to wage biological and chemical warfare
column5: and will keep trying to develop nuclear weapons. Should he succeed in that endeavor
column6: he could alter the political and security landscape of the Middle East
column7: which as we know all too well affects American security.

column1: Now this much is undisputed. The open questions are: what should we do about it? How
column2: when
column3: and with whom?

column1: Some people favor attacking Saddam Hussein now
column2: with any allies we can muster
column3: in the belief that one more round of weapons inspections would not produce the required disarmament
column4: and that deposing Saddam would be a positive good for the Iraqi people and would create the possibility of a secular democratic state in the Middle East
column5: one which could perhaps move the entire region toward democratic reform.

column1: This view has appeal to some
column2: because it would assure disarmament; because it would right old wrongs after our abandonment of the Shiites and Kurds in 1991
column3: and our support for Saddam Hussein in the 1980's when he was using chemical weapons and terrorizing his people; and because it would give the Iraqi people a chance to build a future in freedom.

column1: However
column2: this course is fraught with danger. We and our NATO allies did not depose Mr. Milosevic
column3: who was responsible for more than a quarter of a million people being killed in the 1990s. Instead
column4: by stopping his aggression in Bosnia and Kosovo
column5: and keeping on the tough sanctions
column6: we created the conditions in which his own people threw him out and led to his being in the dock being tried for war crimes as we speak.

column1: If we were to attack Iraq now
column2: alone or with few allies
column3: it would set a precedent that could come back to haunt us. In recent days
column4: Russia has talked of an invasion of Georgia to attack Chechen rebels. India has mentioned the possibility of a pre-emptive strike on Pakistan. And what if China were to perceive a threat from Taiwan?

column1: So Mr. President
column2: for all its appeal
column3: a unilateral attack
column4: while it cannot be ruled out
column5: on the present facts is not a good option.

column1: Others argue that we should work through the United Nations and should only resort to force if and when the United Nations Security Council approves it. This too has great appeal for different reasons. The UN deserves our support. Whenever possible we should work through it and strengthen it
column2: for it enables the world to share the risks and burdens of global security and when it acts
column3: it confers a legitimacy that increases the likelihood of long-term success. The UN can help lead the world into a new era of global cooperation and the United States should support that goal.

column1: But there are problems with this approach as well. The United Nations is an organization that is still growing and maturing. It often lacks the cohesion to enforce its own mandates. And when Security Council members use the veto
column2: on occasion
column3: for reasons of narrow-minded interests
column4: it cannot act. In Kosovo
column5: the Russians did not approve NATO military action because of political
column6: ethnic
column7: and religious ties to the Serbs. The United States therefore could not obtain a Security Council resolution in favor of the action necessary to stop the dislocation and ethnic cleansing of more than a million Kosovar Albanians. However
column8: most of the world was with us because there was a genuine emergency with thousands dead and a million driven from their homes. As soon as the American-led conflict was over
column9: Russia joined the peacekeeping effort that is still underway.

column1: In the case of Iraq
column2: recent comments indicate that one or two Security Council members might never approve force against Saddam Hussein until he has actually used chemical
column3: biological
column4: or God forbid
column5: nuclear weapons.

column1: So
column2: Mr. President
column3: the question is how do we do our best to both defuse the real threat that Saddam Hussein poses to his people
column4: to the region
column5: including Israel
column6: to the United States
column8: and at the same time
column9: work to maximize our international support and strengthen the United Nations?

column1: While there is no perfect approach to this thorny dilemma
column2: and while people of good faith and high intelligence can reach diametrically opposed conclusions
column3: I believe the best course is to go to the UN for a strong resolution that scraps the 1998 restrictions on inspections and calls for complete
column4: unlimited inspections with cooperation expected and demanded from Iraq. I know that the Administration wants more
column5: including an explicit authorization to use force
column6: but we may not be able to secure that now
column7: perhaps even later. But if we get a clear requirement for unfettered inspections
column8: I believe the authority to use force to enforce that mandate is inherent in the original 1991 UN resolution
column9: as President Clinton recognized when he launched Operation Desert Fox in 1998.

column1: If we get the resolution that President Bush seeks
column2: and if Saddam complies
column3: disarmament can proceed and the threat can be eliminated. Regime change will
column4: of course
column5: take longer but we must still work for it
column6: nurturing all reasonable forces of opposition.

column1: If we get the resolution and Saddam does not comply
column2: then we can attack him with far more support and legitimacy than we would have otherwise.

column1: If we try and fail to get a resolution that simply
column2: but forcefully
column3: calls for Saddam's compliance with unlimited inspections
column4: those who oppose even that will be in an indefensible position. And
column5: we will still have more support and legitimacy than if we insist now on a resolution that includes authorizing military action and other requirements giving some nations superficially legitimate reasons to oppose any Security Council action. They will say we never wanted a resolution at all and that we only support the United Nations when it does exactly what we want.

column1: I believe international support and legitimacy are crucial. After shots are fired and bombs are dropped
column2: not all consequences are predictable. While the military outcome is not in doubt
column3: should we put troops on the ground
column4: there is still the matter of Saddam Hussein's biological and chemical weapons. Today he has maximum incentive not to use them or give them away. If he did either
column5: the world would demand his immediate removal. Once the battle is joined
column6: however
column8: he will have maximum incentive to use weapons of mass destruction and to give what he can't use to terrorists who can torment us with them long after he is gone. We cannot be paralyzed by this possibility
column9: but we would be foolish to ignore it. And according to recent reports
column10: the CIA agrees with this analysis. A world united in sharing the risk at least would make this occurrence less likely and more bearable and would be far more likely to share with us the considerable burden of rebuilding a secure and peaceful post-Saddam Iraq.

column1: President Bush's speech in Cincinnati and the changes in policy that have come forth since the Administration began broaching this issue some weeks ago have made my vote easier. Even though the resolution before the Senate is not as strong as I would like in requiring the diplomatic route first and placing highest priority on a simple
column2: clear requirement for unlimited inspections
column3: I will take the President at his word that he will try hard to pass a UN resolution and will seek to avoid war
column4: if at all possible.

column1: Because bipartisan support for this resolution makes success in the United Nations more likely
column2: and therefore
column3: war less likely
column4: and because a good faith effort by the United States
column5: even if it fails
column6: will bring more allies and legitimacy to our cause
column8: after careful and serious consideration
column9: that a vote for the resolution best serves the security of our nation. If we were to defeat this resolution or pass it with only a few Democrats
column10: I am concerned that those who want to pretend this problem will go way with delay will oppose any UN resolution calling for unrestricted inspections.

column1: This is a very difficult vote. This is probably the hardest decision I have ever had to make -- any vote that may lead to war should be hard -- but I cast it with conviction.

And perhaps my decision is influenced by my eight years of experience on the other end of Pennsylvania Avenue in the White House watching my husband deal with serious challenges to our nation. I want this President
column2: or any future President
column3: to be in the strongest possible position to lead our country in the United Nations or in war. Secondly
column4: I want to insure that Saddam Hussein makes no mistake about our national unity and for our support for the President's efforts to wage America's war against terrorists and weapons of mass destruction. And thirdly
column5: I want the men and women in our Armed Forces to know that if they should be called upon to act against Iraq
column6: our country will stand resolutely behind them.

column1: My vote is not
column2: however
column3: a vote for any new doctrine of pre-emption
column4: or for uni-lateralism
column5: or for the arrogance of American power or purpose -- all of which carry grave dangers for our nation
column6: for the rule of international law and for the peace and security of people throughout the world.

column1: Over eleven years have passed since the UN called on Saddam Hussein to rid himself of weapons of mass destruction as a condition of returning to the world community. Time and time again he has frustrated and denied these conditions. This matter cannot be left hanging forever with consequences we would all live to regret. War can yet be avoided
column2: but our responsibility to global security and to the integrity of United Nations resolutions protecting it cannot. I urge the President to spare no effort to secure a clear
column3: unambiguous demand by the United Nations for unlimited inspections.

column1: And finally
column2: on another personal note
column3: I come to this decision from the perspective of a Senator from New York who has seen all too closely the consequences of last year's terrible attacks on our nation. In balancing the risks of action versus inaction
column4: I think New Yorkers who have gone through the fires of hell may be more attuned to the risk of not acting. I know that I am.

column1: So it is with conviction that I support this resolution as being in the best interests of our nation. A vote for it is not a vote to rush to war; it is a vote that puts awesome responsibility in the hands of our President and we say to him - use these powers wisely and as a last resort. And it is a vote that says clearly to Saddam Hussein - this is your last chance - disarm or be disarmed.
Thank you
column2: Mr. President.

column1: 0	"Kyle Kondik is managing editor of Sabato’s Crystal Ball
column2: a nonpartisan political newsletter produced by the University of Virginia Center for Politics. He also directs the center’s Washington
column3: D.C.
column4: office.

column1: If Republicans capture control of the U.S. Senate
column2: there will be many explanations for their victory: President Obama’s poor numbers
column3: a great Senate map filled with attractive opportunities
column4: a generally strong slate of candidates
column5: the success of establishment-backed Republicans in primaries and others.

column1: But one of the biggest factors will have hardly anything to do with the national political climate or
column2: really
column3: the campaign as a whole. Five Democrats
column4: all of whom are old enough to be eligible for Medicare
column5: decided not to run for another term in the Senate. Their decisions
column6: all announced before May 2013
column7: are a huge but largely forgotten boon to GOP hopes.

column1: Advertisement
The five retirements were: Max Baucus of Montana
column2: Tom Harkin of Iowa
column3: Tim Johnson of South Dakota
column4: Carl Levin of Michigan and Jay Rockefeller of West Virginia. (A sixth
column5: Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey
column6: had announced his retirement
column7: but he later died: Sen. Cory Booker
column8: a Democrat
column9: now holds the seat after a special election last year.)

column1: Retirements present a challenge for the incumbent party because it’s easier for a party to hold a Senate seat when an incumbent runs for reelection. Significantly easier.
Over the past half-century
column2: about 85 percent of incumbent senators running in the general election were reelected. In open seats
column3: during the same time period
column4: the incumbent party held the seat just about 60 percent of the time. So not having an incumbent in a Senate race substantially reduces the odds of victory.

column1: The importance of open seats to GOP Senate hopes is particularly pronounced because of the party’s recent inability to defeat Democratic incumbents.

column2: Republicans beat an eye-popping nine Democratic incumbents on Election Day to capture control of the Senate for the first time in a quarter-century. Since then
column3: the GOP has not defeated more than two Democratic Senate incumbents in any general election. The party’s best recent Senate years
column5: were built largely on winning open seats (six in 1994
column6: and four in 2010). Democrats
column8: have had more success: They beat seven and six incumbent Republicans
column10: in recapturing the upper chamber in 1986 and 2006. The latter year
column12: was notable in that Democrats did not capture a single open seat in netting the six seats they needed to eke out a narrow 51-49 Senate edge.

column1: Republicans seem likely to beat more than two Democratic Senate incumbents this November for the first time in almost 35 years: Sens. Mark Begich of Alaska
column2: Mary Landrieu of Louisiana and Mark Pryor of Arkansas all have less than 50-50 odds of winning
column3: according to the University of Virginia Center for Politics’ Crystal Ball ratings
column4: which I help formulate. Sen. Mark Udall of Colorado is right at 50-50
column5: and Sens. Kay Hagan of North Carolina and Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire are both in tough races too.

column1: But in all likelihood
column2: the foundation for this year’s GOP gains will be built on winning open seats. That’s why the Democratic exits loom so large in the upcoming election.

column1: An election where these five senators chose to run for another term would look significantly different: There would probably be more competitive races
column2: and Democrats would have a greater number of redoubts to hold off the Republican advance.

column1: Let’s assume
column2: for the purposes of this “what if” exercise
column3: that all five retirees were healthy enough and eager enough to have run for reelection
column4: which is of course a big assumption for a group whose average age is 74 years old:

column1: West Virginia: Rockefeller might still be an underdog to Rep. Shelley Moore Capito (R)
column2: who entered the race before the incumbent retired. But that race would have been much closer
column3: presumably
column4: than Capito’s largely sleepy contest against West Virginia Secretary of State Natalie Tennant
column5: and the National Republican Senatorial Committee would not have been able to just take a pass on the race
column6: as it has this cycle. Capito’s strong performance as a candidate is an often overlooked bright spot for Republicans this cycle – she’s done so well
column7: in a state where the GOP hasn’t won a Senate seat in more than a half century
column8: that the race never became obviously competitive – but running in an open seat has made her job easier. The Crystal Ball rating here is Safe Republican; with Rockefeller in the race
column9: we’d probably rate it just Leans Republican or maybe Toss-up. A few polls before Rockefeller retired suggested Capito would have started the race with a narrow lead
column10: and Rockefeller did himself no favors by not being 100 percent pro-coal in recent years
column11: a political problem in a state where coal is still king.

column1: Montana: Baucus
column2: like Rockefeller
column3: would have been in for a very tough race in 2014 if he had run. The Democratic polling firm Public Policy Polling found him trailing 49 percent to 44 percent in early 2013 against Rep. Steve Daines
column4: who eventually became the GOP nominee. Baucus announced his retirement in April 2013
column5: and then later resigned to become ambassador to China. Gov. Steve Bullock appointed then-Lt. Gov. John Walsh
column6: a fellow Democrat
column7: to fill the vacancy. Walsh’s campaign
column8: of course
column9: fell apart over the summer under the weight of plagiarism. Now Democrats are stuck with little-known nominee Amanda Curtis
column11: and Daines is a huge favorite.

column1: Had Baucus run
column2: would Daines have stood down? He was just elected to his first term in the House in 2012 and might have thought twice about challenging a sitting senator. Baucus versus Daines would have been a lot more competitive than the current race
column3: more like a Toss-up than a Safe Republican pickup
column4: as we assess it now. (Another what if: Former Gov. Brian Schweitzer contemplated running
column5: but then decided against it. He might have been a better candidate than Baucus
column6: who according to that PPP poll trailed Schweitzer by 19 points in a possible primary.)

column1: South Dakota: Given the difficulties that Mike Rounds
column2: the Republican former South Dakota governor
column3: has had putting away this three-way battle for this open seat
column4: it’s not hard to imagine him having a hard time against Johnson
column5: who won a very competitive race in 2002 against now-Sen. John Thune (R) in another Republican-leaning year nationally. After Johnson retired
column6: former Rep. Stephanie Herseth Sandlin or Johnson’s son
column8: both would have made good candidates here
column9: but neither ended up running. Democrats were left with Tom Daschle disciple Rick Weiland
column11: along with former Republican Sen. Larry Pressler
column12: is giving Rounds fits despite being given the cold shoulder by Harry Reid. If Johnson had run again
column13: or his son or Sandlin became the nominee
column14: the race would probably be a Toss-up. That said
column15: one also has to give a tip of the cap to Rounds
column18: announced his run for the seat only weeks after the 2012 election. Rounds and Capito running probably helped nudge Johnson and Rockefeller out the door.

column1: (It’s worth noting that
column2: in the case of Senator Johnson
column3: assuming health and an eagerness to run is a leap: He suffered a brain hemorrhage in late 2006 that left him partially paralyzed
column4: though he won an uncompetitive reelection bid in 2008.)

column1: Iowa: Of all the retirements
column2: here’s where an incumbent running most clearly could have meant the difference between defeat and victory for Democrats. Harkin
column3: a five-term incumbent
column4: only won in a blowout once
column5: getting 63 percent in 2008
column6: but he also did not have any razor-thin wins: His previous winning percentages were 54 percent
column8: 54 percent and 55 percent. He probably would not be completely safe if he were up for reelection this year
column9: but he’d almost assuredly be in better shape than the Democrat trying to hold on to the seat
column11: who is a slight underdog to Republican state Sen. Joni Ernst. Interestingly
column12: many top Iowa Republicans took a pass on this race even though Harkin was retiring
column13: but Ernst—who has proven herself to be a much better candidate than almost anyone expected—might win the seat anyway.

column1: Michigan: It appears that Rep. Gary Peters
column2: the Democrat running to replace Levin
column3: is going to keep the Wolverine State blue. In this he owes a considerable amount of thanks to Republican candidate Terri Lynn Land
column4: a widely panned nominee (national Republicans tried to find another candidate to run here). Levin’s retirement did put this race on the map
column5: however
column6: and Democrats and Democratic-affiliated outside groups have spent nearly $17 million to back Peters and attack Land. One has to imagine that with Levin on the ballot
column7: that money would have gone elsewhere. This race is a likely Democratic hold now
column8: and it’s a bright spot for Democrats that could have gone the other way in spite of Michigan’s Democratic leanings. But it would have been more like a sleepy Safe Democratic seat with Levin running.

column1: Overall
column2: it’s pretty clear that Republicans got the better of Democrats this year in the retirement department.

column1: Yes
column2: Republicans have had a few retirements of their own this cycle. But the only one that matters for the general election is Georgia
column3: which Sen. Saxby Chambliss is leaving after two terms. Although the GOP is probably a tiny favorite to retain the seat
column4: the race between David Perdue (R) and Michelle Nunn (D) now looks likely to go to a January runoff. Chambliss
column5: so long as he survived his primary
column6: would be a bigger favorite than the untested Perdue
column8: a good Democratic recruit
column9: might have passed on a contest against an incumbent.This is not intended to second-guess the decisions of these Democrats to retire: It’s obviously up to them and only them to determine whether they want to run again
column10: and they also deserve some credit for not overstaying their welcomes
column11: as so many other senators have done over the years. Rather
column12: it’s just to illustrate the electoral challenges that these retirements created for Democrats.

column1: To summarize
column2: the likeliest outcome in these five open Democratic Senate seats here in the real world is the following: Republicans win Montana
column3: South Dakota
column4: West Virginia and
column5: likelier than not
column6: Iowa (although that race is very

column1: In the alternate history world above
column2: Democrats hold Iowa and Michigan
column3: and while Republicans still have a good chance to take Montana
column4: South Dakota and West Virginia
column5: they have to spend big money in each in order to do so. In other words
column6: those states would have remained at the front of the line of Democratic dominos
column7: but they would have been harder to knock over than they are now.

column1: That potentially could have affected other races. For instance
column2: after the Obamacare launch fiasco
column3: Republicans added two strong candidates to their roster of Senate candidates: Rep. Cory Gardner in Colorado and former Massachusetts Sen. Scott Brown in New Hampshire. The national perception at the time they announced back in March and April was that Republicans had three pickups in the bag already
column4: and could thus expand the map. Maybe Brown or Gardner would have been less keen to run in states President Obama won in 2008 and 2012 if the GOP had not already made significant inroads in locking up three states won by Mitt Romney in 2012
column5: freeing up resources that could then be promised to Brown and Gardner.

column1: So what’s the upshot? Without the retirements
column2: Republican odds of taking the Senate
column3: now good
column4: would be lower. It’s impossible to know how much lower – in an election with so many moving parts
column5: there’s an endless list of “what ifs.” But this much is clear: If the GOP wins the Senate on Nov. 4
column6: the post-mortem analysis needs to note that Democratic retirements played a significant role in that victory."	['data:image/gif;base64

column1: 0	"Rep. Joe Kennedy III (D-MA) claimed the host-city of his response to President Donald Trump’s State of the Union address
column2: Fall River
column3: Massachusetts was “built by immigrants.”

column1: Fact-Check: MOSTLY FALSE
What is now Fall River was first established in the 1600s by English settlers who were not “immigrants” but colonists. A native-born family
column2: the Bordens ran a mill in what became the town for generations before and after the American revolution. Industrialization began when Col. Joseph Durfee
column3: a native-born Revolutionary War hero built the first factory in 1811. Later
column4: at the end of the 19th Century a wave of immigrants swelled the town’s population. Immigrants
column5: however
column6: never made up a majority of the population of Bristol County
column8: even at their early 20th Century peak."	['https://media.breitbart.com/media/2020/03/GettyImages-1171541953-200x150.jpeg'

From the country’s major political and policy issues to diplomacy on the global stage
column2: State of the Union with Candy Crowley brings in the world’s top newsmakers and analysts to deliver the smartest
column3: most comprehensive look at what matters most to you. Sundays at 9am and Noon ET.

column1: 0	"In Tbilisi
column2: the two-room rented apartment Mr. Latsabidze shares with his younger brother is an unlikely offshore outpost of America’s fake news industry. The two brothers
column3: both computer experts
column4: get help from a third young Georgian
column5: an architect.

column1: They say they have no keen interest in politics themselves and initially placed bets across the American political spectrum and experimented with show business news
column2: too. They set up a pro-Clinton website
column3: walkwithher.com
column4: a Facebook page cheering Bernie Sanders and a web digest of straightforward political news plagiarized from The New York Times and other mainstream news media.

column1: But those sites
column2: among the more than a dozen registered by Mr. Latsabidze
column3: were busts. Then he shifted all his energy to Mr. Trump. His flagship pro-Trump website
column4: departed.co
column5: gained remarkable traction in a crowded field in the prelude to the Nov. 8 election thanks to steady menu of relentlessly pro-Trump and anti-Clinton stories. (On Wednesday
column6: a few hours after The New York Times met with Mr. Latsabidze to ask him about his activities
column7: the site vanished along with his Facebook page.)

column1: “My audience likes Trump
column2: ” he said. “I don’t want to write bad things about Trump. If I write fake stories about Trump
column3: I lose my audience.”

column1: Some of his Trump stories are true
column2: some are highly slanted and others are totally false
column3: like one this summer reporting that “the Mexican government announced they will close their borders to Americans in the event that Donald Trump is elected President of the United States.” Data compiled by Buzzfeed showed that the story was the third most-trafficked fake story on Facebook from May to July.

column1: So successful was the formula that others in Georgia and other faraway lands joined in
column2: too
column3: including Nika Kurdadze
column4: a college acquaintance of Mr. Latsabidze’s who set up his own pro-Trump site
column5: newsbreakshere.com. Its recent offerings included a fake report headlined: “Stop it Liberals…Hillary Lost the Popular Vote by Several Million. Here’s Why.” That story
column6: like most of Mr. Latsabidze’s work

column1: Mr. Latsabidze initially ran into no problems from all his cutting and pasting of other people’s stories
column2: and he even got ripped off himself when a rival in India hijacked a pro-Trump Facebook page he had set up to drive traffic to his websites. (He said that the Indian rival had offered $10
column3: 000 to buy the page
column4: but that he had reneged on payment after being provided with access rights and commandeered it for himself.)"	['https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/11/26/world/26FAKE2/26FAKE2-articleInline.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale'
column5: 'https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/11/26/world/26FAKE2/26FAKE2-facebookJumbo.jpg']	https://static01.nyt.com/images/2016/11/26/world/26FAKE2/26FAKE2-facebookJumbo.jpg	Inside a Fake News Sausage Factory: ‘This Is All About Income’	https://www.nytimes.com

column1: 0	"London (CNN) Britain's Queen Elizabeth II has lost the last descendant of her original corgi after 14-year-old Willow was put down at Windsor Castle on Sunday following a battle with cancer
column2: according to UK media reports.

column1: Willow was the last in a long line of royal corgis owned by Britain's longest-serving monarch
column2: reported British newspaper the Daily Mail.

column1: Buckingham Palace declined to comment on the dog's death
column2: telling CNN it was a private matter.

column1: The Queen's fondness for corgis is well known
column2: with Willow and the monarch even appearing beside James Bond actor Daniel Craig for a sketch shown during the 2012 London Olympic opening ceremony.

column1: Queen Elizabeth II has reportedly owned more than 30 corgis during her reign.
While the Queen still reportedly owns several other dogs
column2: Willow was the only remaining descendant of Susan
column3: the original corgi given to then-Princess Elizabeth on her 18th birthday in 1944.

column1: 0	"The Democrat Party is up to their usual dirty tricks as Republican senate candidate Roy Moore fights against their cheating ways in an effort to become Alabama’s next senator.
According to the Birmingham Press
column2: polling officials caught what appears to be a “van full of illegals” who traveled to at least 7 polling locations with fake identification to vote for Moore’s opponent Doug Jones.

column1: “Law enforcement stopped the vehicle at Santa Recto Middle School in Wilmington as 13 Hispanic men were seen piling into a van after voting
column2: ” the Santa Recto Observer reported Tuesday afternoon. “The same men were also seen in Smithfield
column3: Birmingham
column4: La Croix
column5: and Mobile and were reported as suspicious by voting officials.”

column1: Members of the State Election Integrity Board began investigating the group of men at around 9 a.m. and tracking them around the state. Police arrested 10 of the men and three were able to run to safety before police grabbed their friends. Investigators determined that the men were responsible for “dozens of fake votes” around the state and officials are working to invalidate those votes as we speak.
This is typical of Democrats: when even fake news about Moore “molesting” a young woman fail
column2: they try to cheat. This is
column3: of course
column4: similar to a situation in California on Election Day 2016 when illegal aliens were busted trying to vote for Hillary Clinton.

column1: All but one of the men were “undocumented” immigrants from Mexico
column2: San Salmos
column3: and Puerta Gorda. The last
column4: Marcos Ramos
column5: is a U.S. citizen and faces up to 13 years in prison for election fraud.

column1: How many other dirty tricks will be exposed?"	['https://web.archive.org/web/20171213122934im_/http://nofakenews.online/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/ssas-678x381.jpg'

column1: 0	"Today marks four years since U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services began accepting requests for President Obama’s 2012 Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) policy. DACA provides deportation relief and two-year work permits for young people aged 15–30 who came to the United States as children
column2: allowing you to live without fear of being torn away from the only country you’ve ever really known.

column1: And that’s exactly who I want to talk to today: all of you who’ve benefited from DACA
column2: all of you who can still apply
column3: and all of you who are still fighting for a path to citizenship for you and your families.

column1: I’m sure this election has been stressful for you.
It can’t be easy to hear a presidential candidate demonize immigrant families and blame you for our nation’s problems. That’s not fair
column2: it’s not kind
column3: and it’s also just not true. In every state in this country
column4: immigrants are starting small businesses
column5: growing our economy
column6: and making our communities and our country stronger.

column1: Many of you have told me how horrible it felt to be treated differently from other kids when it was time to apply for college. You’ve told me about the feeling of knowing you couldn’t be like your friends
column2: even though you are just as American as they are.

column1: I want you to feel proud of your country
column2: and of the countless ways you have contributed to it. And I want you to feel confident in your future and your ability to achieve anything you dream. In America
column3: the place of your birth should never be a barrier that stops you from reaching your God-given potential — that’s what makes our country great
column4: and that’s the promise I’m going to fight to fulfill.

column1: So here’s my request: For all of you who are still eligible to request consideration for DACA 2012
column2: I hope you’ll head to uscis.gov right now to learn more and apply for DACA benefits. Experts estimate almost half a million people are still eligible
column3: particularly in the Asian American and Pacific Islander community. I want each and every one of you to feel safe and secure in this country — and that’s what DACA can provide.

column1: But I know that’s not enough — we have to do more for you and your families. That’s why as president
column2: I’m going to introduce comprehensive immigration reform with a pathway to full and equal citizenship within my first 100 days in office.

column1: While we fight for comprehensive immigration reform
column2: I’ll do everything I can to keep families together. That means defending DACA from partisan attacks and fighting to implement the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans (DAPA) policy. The Supreme Court’s deadlocked decision on DAPA was a heartbreaking reminder of how high the stakes are in this election. I believe DAPA is squarely within the president’s authority and won’t stop fighting until we see it through.

column1: So today
column2: let’s celebrate DACA 2012 and the more than 700
column3: 000 people it’s helped so far — and let’s also recommit to making this a safer
column4: more welcoming country for all families
column5: including yours.

column1: We have always been a nation of immigrants — those of us whose families came here a little longer ago can sometimes forget that. But I won’t forget it
column2: and I won’t forget you.

column1: Thank you — and keep being brave
Hillary"	['https://miro.medium.com/fit/c/96/96/1*D8kWZdDVO7h1CIvB5bVquA.jpeg'
column2: 'https://miro.medium.com/fit/c/160/160/1*jwy21sK7cNCsZfbFIZfgMg.png'
column3: 'https://miro.medium.com/fit/c/160/160/1*D8kWZdDVO7h1CIvB5bVquA.jpeg'

column1: 0	"Wednesday
column2: August 27

column1: Beau
column2: I love you. I am so proud of you. Proud of the son you are. Proud of the father you’ve become. And I’m so proud of my son Hunter
column3: my daughter Ashley
column4: and my wife Jill
column5: the only one who leaves me breathless and speechless at the same time.

column1: It is an honor to share this stage tonight with President Clinton. And last night
column2: it was moving to watch Hillary
column3: one of the great leaders of our party
column4: a woman who has made history and will continue to make history: my colleague and my friend
column5: Senator Hillary Clinton.

column1: And I am honored to represent our first state—my state—Delaware.
Since I’ve never been called a man of few words
column2: let me say this as simply as I can: Yes. Yes
column3: I accept your nomination to run and serve alongside our next President of the United States of America
column4: Barack Obama.

column1: Let me make this pledge to you right here and now. For every American who is trying to do the right thing
column2: for all those people in government who are honoring their pledge to uphold the law and respect our Constitution
column3: no longer will the eight most dreaded words in the English language be: “The vice president’s office is on the phone.”

column1: Barack Obama and I took very different journeys to this destination
column2: but we share a common story. Mine began in Scranton
column3: Pennsylvania
column4: and then Wilmington
column5: Delaware. With a dad who fell on hard economic times
column6: but who always told me: “Champ
column8: get up. Get up.”

column1: I wish that my dad was here tonight
column2: but I am so grateful that my mom
column3: Catherine Eugenia Finnegan Biden
column4: is here. You know
column5: she taught her children—all the children who flocked to our house—that you are defined by your sense of honor
column6: and you are redeemed by your loyalty. She believes bravery lives in every heart and her expectation is that it will be summoned.

column1: Failure at some point in everyone’s life is inevitable
column2: but giving up is unforgivable. As a child I stuttered
column3: and she lovingly told me it was because I was so bright I couldn’t get the thoughts out quickly enough. When I was not as well dressed as others
column4: she told me how handsome she thought I was. When I got knocked down by guys bigger than me
column5: she sent me back out and demanded that I bloody their nose so I could walk down that street the next day.

column1: After the accident
column2: she told me
column3: “Joey
column4: God sends no cross you cannot bear.” And when I triumphed
column5: she was quick to remind me it was because of others.

column1: My mother’s creed is the American creed: No one is better than you. You are everyone’s equal
column2: and everyone is equal to you.

column1: My parents taught us to live our faith
column2: and treasure our family. We learned the dignity of work
column3: and we were told that anyone can make it if they try.

column1: That was America’s promise. For those of us who grew up in middle-class neighborhoods like Scranton and Wilmington
column2: that was the American dream and we knew it.

column1: But today that American dream feels as if it’s slowly slipping away. I don’t need to tell you that. You feel it every single day in your own lives.
I’ve never seen a time when Washington has watched so many people get knocked down without doing anything to help them get back up. Almost every night
column2: I take the train home to Wilmington
column3: sometimes very late. As I look out the window at the homes we pass
column4: I can almost hear what they’re talking about at the kitchen table after they put the kids to bed.

column1: Like millions of Americans
column2: they’re asking questions as profound as they are ordinary. Questions they never thought they would have to ask:

column1: * Should mom move in with us now that dad is gone?
* Fifty
column2: sixty
column3: seventy dollars to fill up the car?

column1: * Winter’s coming. How we gonna pay the heating bills?
* Another year and no raise?
* Did you hear the company may be cutting our health care?
* Now
column2: we owe more on the house than it’s worth. How are we going to send the kids to college?

column1: * How are we gonna be able to retire?
That’s the America that George Bush has left us
column2: and that’s the future John McCain will give us. These are not isolated discussions among families down on their luck. These are common stories among middle-class people who worked hard and played by the rules on the promise that their tomorrows would be better than their yesterdays.

column1: That promise is the bedrock of America. It defines who we are as a people. And now it’s in jeopardy. I know it. You know it. But John McCain doesn’t get it.
Barack Obama gets it. Like many of us
column2: Barack worked his way up. His is a great American story.

column1: You know
column2: I believe the measure of a man isn’t just the road he’s traveled; it’s the choices he’s made along the way. Barack Obama could have done anything after he graduated from college. With all his talent and promise
column3: he could have written his ticket to Wall Street. But that’s not what he chose to do. He chose to go to Chicago. The South Side. There he met men and women who had lost their jobs. Their neighborhood was devastated when the local steel plant closed. Their dreams deferred. Their dignity shattered. Their self-esteem gone.

column1: And he made their lives the work of his life. That’s what you do when you’ve been raised by a single mom
column2: who worked
column3: went to school and raised two kids on her own. That’s how you come to believe
column4: to the very core of your being
column5: that work is more than a paycheck. It’s dignity. It’s respect. It’s about whether you can look your children in the eye and say: we’re going to be ok.

column1: Because Barack made that choice
column3: 000 more children and parents have health care in Illinois. He fought to make that happen. And because Barack made that choice
column4: working families in Illinois pay less taxes and more people have moved from welfare to the dignity of work. He got it done.

column1: And when he came to Washington
column2: I watched him hit the ground running
column3: leading the fight to pass the most sweeping ethics reform in a generation. He reached across party lines to pass a law that helps keep nuclear weapons out of the hands of terrorists. And he moved Congress and the president to give our wounded veterans the care and dignity they deserve.

column1: You can learn an awful lot about a man campaigning with him
column2: debating him and seeing how he reacts under pressure. You learn about the strength of his mind
column3: but even more importantly
column4: you learn about the quality of his heart.

column1: I watched how he touched people
column2: how he inspired them
column3: and I realized he has tapped into the oldest American belief of all: We don’t have to accept a situation we cannot bear.

column1: We have the power to change it. That’s Barack Obama
column2: and that’s what he will do for this country. He’ll change it.

column1: John McCain is my friend. We’ve known each other for three decades. We’ve traveled the world together. It’s a friendship that goes beyond politics. And the personal courage and heroism John demonstrated still amaze me.
But I profoundly disagree with the direction that John wants to take the country. For example
John thinks that during the Bush years “we’ve made great progress economically.” I think it’s been abysmal.
And in the Senate
column2: John sided with President Bush 95 percent of the time. Give me a break. When John McCain proposes $200 billion in new tax breaks for corporate America
column3: $1 billion alone for just eight of the largest companies
column4: but no relief for 100 million American families
column5: that’s not change; that’s more of the same.

column1: Even today
column2: as oil companies post the biggest profits in history—a half trillion dollars in the last five years—he wants to give them another $4 billion in tax breaks. But he voted time and again against incentives for renewable energy: solar
column3: wind
column4: biofuels. That’s not change; that’s more of the same.

column1: Millions of jobs have left our shores
column2: yet John continues to support tax breaks for corporations that send them there. That’s not change; that’s more of the same.

column1: He voted 19 times against raising the minimum wage. For people who are struggling just to get to the next day
column2: that’s not change; that’s more of the same.

column1: And when he says he will continue to spend $10 billion a month in Iraq when Iraq is sitting on a surplus of nearly $80 billion
column2: that’s not change; that’s more of the same.

column1: The choice in this election is clear. These times require more than a good soldier; they require a wise leader
column2: a leader who can deliver change—the change everybody knows we need.

column1: Barack Obama will deliver that change. Barack Obama will reform our tax code. He’ll cut taxes for 95 percent of the American people who draw a paycheck. That’s the change we need.
Barack Obama will transform our economy by making alternative energy a genuine national priority
column2: creating 5 million new jobs and finally freeing us from the grip of foreign oil. That’s the change we need.

column1: Barack Obama knows that any country that out teaches us today will out-compete us tomorrow. He’ll invest in the next generation of teachers. He’ll make college more affordable. That’s the change we need.
Barack Obama will bring down health care costs by $2
column2: 500 for the typical family
column3: and
column4: at long last
column5: deliver affordable
column6: accessible health care for all Americans. That’s the change we need.

column1: Barack Obama will put more cops on the streets
column2: put the “security” back in Social Security and never give up until we achieve equal pay for women. That’s the change we need.

column1: As we gather here tonight
column2: our country is less secure and more isolated than at any time in recent history. The Bush-McCain foreign policy has dug us into a very deep hole with very few friends to help us climb out. For the last seven years
column3: this administration has failed to face the biggest forces shaping this century: the emergence of Russia
column4: China and India as great powers; the spread of lethal weapons; the shortage of secure supplies of energy
column5: food and water; the challenge of climate change; and the resurgence of fundamentalism in Afghanistan and Pakistan
column6: the real central front against terrorism.

column1: In recent days
column2: we’ve once again seen the consequences of this neglect with Russia’s challenge to the free and democratic country of Georgia. Barack Obama and I will end this neglect. We will hold Russia accountable for its actions
column3: and we’ll help the people of Georgia rebuild.

column1: I’ve been on the ground in Georgia
column2: Iraq
column3: Pakistan and Afghanistan
column4: and I can tell you in no uncertain terms: this Administration’s policy has been an abject failure. America cannot afford four more years of this.

column1: Now
column2: despite being complicit in this catastrophic foreign policy
column3: John McCain says Barack Obama isn’t ready to protect our national security. Now
column4: let me ask you: whose judgment should we trust? Should we trust John McCain’s judgment when he said only three years ago
column5: “Afghanistan—we don’t read about it anymore because it’s succeeded”? Or should we trust Barack Obama
column6: who more than a year ago called for sending two additional combat brigades to Afghanistan?

column1: The fact is
column2: al-Qaida and the Taliban—the people who actually attacked us on 9/11—have regrouped in those mountains between Afghanistan and Pakistan and are plotting new attacks. And the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff echoed Barack’s call for more troops.

column1: John McCain was wrong. Barack Obama was right.
Should we trust John McCain’s judgment when he rejected talking with Iran and then asked: What is there to talk about? Or Barack Obama
column2: who said we must talk and make it clear to Iran that its conduct must change.

column1: Now
column2: after seven years of denial
column3: even the Bush administration recognizes that we should talk to Iran
column4: because that’s the best way to advance our security.

column1: Again
column2: John McCain was wrong. Barack Obama was right.

column1: Should we trust John McCain’s judgment when he says there can be no timelines to draw down our troops from Iraq—that we must stay indefinitely? Or should we listen to Barack Obama
column2: who says shift responsibility to the Iraqis and set a time to bring our combat troops home?

column1: Now
column2: after six long years
column3: the Bush administration and the Iraqi government are on the verge of setting a date to bring our troops home.

column1: John McCain was wrong. Barack Obama was right.
Again and again
column2: on the most important national security issues of our time
column3: John McCain was wrong
column4: and Barack Obama was proven right.

column1: Folks
column2: remember when the world used to trust us? When they looked to us for leadership? With Barack Obama as our president
column3: they’ll look to us again
column4: they’ll trust us again
column5: and we’ll be able to lead again.

column1: Jill and I are truly honored to join Barack and Michelle on this journey. When I look at their young children—and when I look at my grandchildren—I realize why I’m here. I’m here for their future.
And I am here for everyone I grew up with in Scranton and Wilmington. I am here for the cops and firefighters
column2: the teachers and assembly line workers—the folks whose lives are the very measure of whether the American dream endures.

column1: Our greatest presidents—from Abraham Lincoln to Franklin Roosevelt to John Kennedy—they all challenged us to embrace change. Now
column2: it’s our responsibility to meet that challenge.

column1: Millions of Americans have been knocked down. And this is the time as Americans
column2: together
column3: we get back up. Our people are too good
column4: our debt to our parents and grandparents too great
column5: our obligation to our children is too sacred.

column1: These are extraordinary times. This is an extraordinary election. The American people are ready. I’m ready. Barack Obama is ready. This is his time. This is our time. This is America’s time.
May God bless America and protect our troops."	['https://web.archive.org/web/20080828144739im_/http://www.demconvention.com/themes/dnc/images/menu-arrow.gif'
column2: 'https://web.archive.org/web/20080828144739im_/http://www.demconvention.com/favicon.ico'

column1: 0	"Republican Senator Mitch McConnell and Democratic challenger Alison Lundergan Grimes sit on opposite sides of the debate about the role of money in U.S. elections.
A deluge of campaign cash is playing a significant role in Kentucky’s Senate race thus far.
The money raised by the campaigns and outside groups is expected to top the $100 million mark and go down as the most expensive in U.S. history.
More than any lawmaker
column2: McConnell is the face of loosening—if not
column3: eliminating—campaign finance regulations.

column1: For over a decade the GOP leader has espoused that money and free speech are synonymous. He has filed legal briefs urging the Supreme Court to reaffirm its Citizens United decision and supports a controversial case to further deregulate contribution limits placed on individuals.
In a March 17 e-mail to supporters
column2: Grimes took a strong stance against the influence wealthy donors are having and calls out McConnell as the chief architect and beneficiary of that system.

column1: “Special interest money has already flooded into Mitch McConnell’s campaign
column2: ” Grimes said. “He’s the number one recipient of contributions from lobbyists this cycle and his Karl Rove-affiliated Super PACs are clogging the Commonwealth’s airwaves with negative attack ads. Enough is enough—our democracy is too important to be auctioned off to the highest bidder.”

column1: Grimes has played it safe on the campaign trail when faced with thornier issues outside of core Democratic principles
column2: such as raising the minimum wage. But given the left’s apoplectic reaction to the Roberts Court’s dismantling limitations and the rise of super PACs
column3: her position is receiving applause from watchdog groups.

column1: “It’s very good that Alison Grimes has come out in support of a policy that puts regular people in charge of government again
column2: ” says David Donnelly
column3: who is executive director of Public Campaign Action Fund. “She understands that money in politics drowns out the voices of every day Kentuckians. This is a sharp difference between her and McConnell
column4: someone who is advocating the make the problem worse.”

column1: The Grimes campaign message also directs voters to sign a petition calling on Congress to “stop special interest billionaires
column2: ” that has the support of red state Democratic senators such as Joe Donnelly of Indiana and Joe Manchin of West Virginia.

column1: In the 2014 election cycle
column2: there are almost 1
column3: 000 registered super PACs that have generated over $141 million and spent more than $24.8 million on races.

column1: According to the non-partisan Center for Responsive Politics
column2: the pro-McConnell super PAC Kentuckians for Strong Leadership is among the ranks among the top ten groups in this year’s races.

column1: Democrats and liberal activists decrying the influence of money in politics have themselves pointed out its limitations in Kentucky’s Senate race.

McConnell has spent over half of the $20 million he’s raised this cycle and he has a number of outside groups spending millions in advertisements supporting his re-election. Yet McConnell’s approval ratings remain terribly low and Grimes either leads or ties the GOP leader in most polling.
Former FEC Chairman Michael Toner says despite arguments that the wealthy are purchasing American elections
column2: those independent expenditure committees haven’t always worked out for candidates.

column1: “One reason the federal courts over the years have not found a corruption threat at the independent spending is that sometimes it’s not that effective in directly advancing a candidate’s interest
column2: ” he says.

column1: “A lot of candidates who spend more money than their opponents whether out of their own pocket or let’s say supported by major outside groups
column2: their track record in winning elections is not that good to be honest. We’ve seen a lot of multi-millionaire candidates who are defeated in various races. Now to be sure some are also elected
column3: but by now means is the candidate with the most money spent on their behalf assured of being elected.”

column1: Grimes has raised $4.5 million since entering the race last year and been all over the country at fundraisers with big name Democratic donors. She outpaced McConnell’s money machine during the third quarter and Democratic-affiliated groups have also spent money attacking McConnell in television ads.
The McConnell campaign was quick to point out that while Grimes is criticizing Citizens United
column2: she is also benefiting from attack ads against the senator from outside liberal groups who praise her position.

column1: “Like Barack Obama
column2: Alison Lundergan Grimes is obviously much more concerned with political convenience than Constitutional protections
column3: ” McConnell campaign spokeswoman Allison Moore told WFPL. “The sad part is that she apparently sees no irony in the fact the special interest group who successfully persuaded her to embrace trampling on our First Amendment rights in the name of money in politics is the same one running hundreds of thousands of dollars of advertising on her behalf.”

column1: The top expenditures in 2014 have been super PACs with liberal viewpoints such as Senate Majority PAC
column2: which has slammed McConnell in TV ads.

column1: Asked about Grimes’ wealthy donors
column2: Donnelly says all elected officials and candidates are implicated but that what lawmakers do in Washington matters.

column1: “The real distinction is what are you going to do to clean it up and propose pro-actively to make the system better
column2: ” he says. “And on that score voters know in Alison Grimes they have someone who is going to champion the issue and that in Mitch McConnell who is going to make the problem worse.”"	['http://mediad.publicbroadcasting.net/p/wfpl/files/styles/card_280/public/201305/MitchGrimes.jpg'

column5: 'https://wfpl.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/MitchGrimes.jpg']	https://wfpl.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/MitchGrimes.jpg	Mitch McConnell

0	"The Kardashian family has a net worth in the hundreds of millions
column2: and they’re using their wealth to step up in a big way for those in need. The reality TV family banded together to raise $1 million to the families of victims of the Las Vegas mass shooting.

column1: Earlier today
column2: we announced that the Kardashian family will be donating $1 million to the victims of Las Vegas mass shooting
column3: considering both the bereaved and the surviving victims.

column1: Also
column2: to benefit those impacted by the shooting
column3: the Kardashian family will be hosting a “Day of Giving” on October 7. A “Day of Giving” will begin on Friday morning with other American celebrities and continue throughout the day on E!News. Across our social platforms

column1: “Las Vegas we are praying for you

column1: More than 50 people were killed and more than 500 more injured in a terrifying massacre Sunday night. It’s being reported by outlets as the deadliest mass shooting in the history of the United States.
A gunman
column2: now identified as 64-year-old Stephen Paddock
column3: opened fire on a country-music festival from a hotel window inside the nearby Mandalay Bay. Paddock shot and killed himself; Las Vegas Metro Police officers found him dead in the room.

column1: Our thoughts and prayers remain with the people of Las Vegas and again it’s our most fervent prayer we get enough security to make life fright-free again in the Nevada city." column1: 0	"President Donald Trump has sent a strong message to the Russia Federation over the country’s ban on the “peaceful activities” of Jehovah’s Witnesses.
Trump warns Russia to reverse its decision immediately else he would use the country’s own constitution against them.

“You know right that this is contrary to the constitution of the land of the Russia Federation. I request you to reverse the decision immediately before I use your own constitution against you” – Trump warned.
Trump went on to invite all Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia to seek asylum in the United States until their religious rights are reinstated in Russia.
“As this is an infringement of your fundamental human rights
column2: I therefore urge you to seek asylum in the United States until your rights are fully reinstated.” – Trump urged.

column1: Russia’s Supreme Court ruled on April 20
column2: 2017 that the Jehovah’s Witnesses organization should be closed down and no longer allowed to operate legally in Russia
column3: Human Rights Watch said today. The ruling
column4: which affects more than 100
column5: 000 Jehovah’s Witness worshippers across Russia
column6: is a serious breach of Russia’s obligations to respect and protect religious freedom.

column1: The case could be taken to the European Court of Human Rights
column2: which ruled a previous attempted ban on Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia unlawful in 2010.

column1: The Supreme Court was deciding on a claim lodged by the Russian ministry of justice to liquidate the group’s administrative centre near St Petersburg and 395 local organizations. Its decision will come into effect within 30 days unless an appeal is lodged
column2: when it will be delayed until the resolution of the case.

column1: “The Supreme Court has ruled to sustain the claim of Russia’s ministry of justice and deem the ‘Administrative Centre of Jehovah’s Witnesses in Russia’ organization extremist
column2: eliminate it and ban its activity in Russia
column3: ” said judge Yuri Ivanenko. “The property of the Jehovah’s Witnesses organization is to be confiscated to the state revenue.”

column1: A lawyer for the justice ministry
column2: Svetlana Borisova
column3: told the court adherents “pose a threat to the rights of the citizens
column4: public order and public security”.

column1: Jehovah’s Witnesses
column2: who are known for door-to-door preaching and handing out literature
column3: reject some of mainstream Christianity’s core beliefs and have more than 8.3 million members around the world"	['https://web.archive.org/web/20170506030914im_/http://states-tv.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/mosco-300x180.jpg'
