column1: 0	"Marriott Wardman Park
Washington
column2: D.C.

column1: 12:35 P.M. EDT
THE PRESIDENT: Thank you very much. (Applause.) Please have a seat. Well
column2: good afternoon
column3: and thank you to Dean Singleton and the board of the Associated Press for inviting me here today. It is a pleasure to speak to all of you -- and to have a microphone that I can see. (Laughter.) Feel free to transmit any of this to Vladimir if you see him. (Laughter.)

column1: Clearly
column2: we’re already in the beginning months of another long
column3: lively election year. There will be gaffes and minor controversies
column4: be hot mics and Etch-a-Sketch moments. You will cover every word that we say
column5: and we will complain vociferously about the unflattering words that you write -- unless
column6: of course
column7: you're writing about the other guy -- in which case
column8: good job. (Laughter.)

column1: But there are also big
column2: fundamental issues at stake right now -- issues that deserve serious debate among every candidate
column3: and serious coverage among every reporter. Whoever he may be
column4: the next President will inherit an economy that is recovering
column5: but not yet recovered
column6: from the worst economic calamity since the Great Depression. Too many Americans will still be looking for a job that pays enough to cover their bills or their mortgage. Too many citizens will still lack the sort of financial security that started slipping away years before this recession hit. A debt that has grown over the last decade
column7: primarily as a result of two wars
column8: two massive tax cuts
column10: will have to be paid down.

column1: In the face of all these challenges
column2: we're going to have to answer a central question as a nation: What
column3: if anything
column4: can we do to restore a sense of security for people who are willing to work hard and act responsibly in this country? Can we succeed as a country where a shrinking number of people do exceedingly well
column5: while a growing number struggle to get by? Or are we better off when everyone gets a fair shot
column6: and everyone does their fair share
column7: and everyone plays by the same rules?

column1: This is not just another run-of-the-mill political debate. I’ve said it’s the defining issue of our time
column2: and I believe it. It’s why I ran in 2008. It’s what my presidency has been about. It’s why I’m running again. I believe this is a make-or-break moment for the middle class
column3: and I can’t remember a time when the choice between competing visions of our future has been so unambiguously clear.

column1: Keep in mind
column2: I have never been somebody who believes that government can or should try to solve every problem. Some of you know my first job in Chicago was working with a group of Catholic churches that often did more good for the people in their communities than any government program could. In those same communities I saw that no education policy
column3: however well crafted
column4: can take the place of a parent’s love and attention.

column1: As President
column2: I’ve eliminated dozens of programs that weren’t working
column3: and announced over 500 regulatory reforms that will save businesses and taxpayers billions
column4: and put annual domestic spending on a path to become the smallest share of the economy since Dwight Eisenhower held this office -- since before I was born. I know that the true engine of job creation in this country is the private sector
column5: not Washington
column6: which is why I’ve cut taxes for small business owners 17 times over the last three years.

column1: So I believe deeply that the free market is the greatest force for economic progress in human history. My mother and the grandparents who raised me instilled the values of self-reliance and personal responsibility that remain the cornerstone of the American idea. But I also share the belief of our first Republican President
column2: Abraham Lincoln -- a belief that
column3: through government
column4: we should do together what we cannot do as well for ourselves.

column1: That belief is the reason this country has been able to build a strong military to keep us safe
column2: and public schools to educate our children. That belief is why we’ve been able to lay down railroads and highways to facilitate travel and commerce. That belief is why we’ve been able to support the work of scientists and researchers whose discoveries have saved lives
column3: and unleashed repeated technological revolutions
column4: and led to countless new jobs and entire industries.

column1: That belief is also why we’ve sought to ensure that every citizen can count on some basic measure of security. We do this because we recognize that no matter how responsibly we live our lives
column2: any one of us
column3: at any moment
column4: might face hard times
column5: might face bad luck
column6: might face a crippling illness or a layoff. And so we contribute to programs like Medicare and Social Security
column7: which guarantee health care and a source of income after a lifetime of hard work. We provide unemployment insurance
column8: which protects us against unexpected job loss and facilitates the labor mobility that makes our economy so dynamic. We provide for Medicaid
column9: which makes sure that millions of seniors in nursing homes and children with disabilities are getting the care that they need.

column1: For generations
column2: nearly all of these investments -- from transportation to education to retirement programs -- have been supported by people in both parties. As much as we might associate the G.I. Bill with Franklin Roosevelt
column3: or Medicare with Lyndon Johnson
column4: it was a Republican
column5: Lincoln
column6: who launched the Transcontinental Railroad
column8: land grant colleges. It was Eisenhower who launched the Interstate Highway System and new investment in scientific research. It was Richard Nixon who created the Environmental Protection Agency
column9: Ronald Reagan who worked with Democrats to save Social Security. It was George W. Bush who added prescription drug coverage to Medicare.

column1: What leaders in both parties have traditionally understood is that these investments aren’t part of some scheme to redistribute wealth from one group to another. They are expressions of the fact that we are one nation. These investments benefit us all. They contribute to genuine
column2: durable economic growth.

column1: Show me a business leader who wouldn’t profit if more Americans could afford to get the skills and education that today’s jobs require. Ask any company where they’d rather locate and hire workers –- a country with crumbling roads and bridges
column2: or one that’s committed to high-speed Internet and high-speed railroads and high-tech research and development?

column1: It doesn’t make us weaker when we guarantee basic security for the elderly or the sick or those who are actively looking for work. What makes us weaker is when fewer and fewer people can afford to buy the goods and services our businesses sell
column2: or when entrepreneurs don’t have the financial security to take a chance and start a new business. What drags down our entire economy is when there’s an ever-widening chasm between the ultra-rich and everybody else.

column1: In this country
column2: broad-based prosperity has never trickled down from the success of a wealthy few. It has always come from the success of a strong and growing middle class. That’s how a generation who went to college on the G.I. Bill
column3: including my grandfather
column4: helped build the most prosperous economy the world has ever known. That’s why a CEO like Henry Ford made it his mission to pay his workers enough so they could buy the cars that they made. That’s why research has shown that countries with less inequality tend to have stronger and steadier economic growth over the long run.

column1: And yet
column2: for much of the last century
column3: we have been having the same argument with folks who keep peddling some version of trickle-down economics. They keep telling us that if we’d convert more of our investments in education and research and health care into tax cuts -- especially for the wealthy -- our economy will grow stronger. They keep telling us that if we’d just strip away more regulations
column4: and let businesses pollute more and treat workers and consumers with impunity
column5: that somehow we’d all be better off. We’re told that when the wealthy become even wealthier
column6: and corporations are allowed to maximize their profits by whatever means necessary
column8: and that their success will automatically translate into more jobs and prosperity for everybody else. That’s the theory.

column1: Now
column2: the problem for advocates of this theory is that we’ve tried their approach -- on a massive scale. The results of their experiment are there for all to see. At the beginning of the last decade
column3: the wealthiest Americans received a huge tax cut in 2001 and another huge tax cut in 2003. We were promised that these tax cuts would lead to faster job growth. They did not. The wealthy got wealthier -- we would expect that. The income of the top 1 percent has grown by more than 275 percent over the last few decades
column4: to an average of $1.3 million a year. But prosperity sure didn't trickle down.

column1: Instead
column2: during the last decade
column3: we had the slowest job growth in half a century. And the typical American family actually saw their incomes fall by about 6 percent
column4: even as the economy was growing.

column1: It was a period when insurance companies and mortgage lenders and financial institutions didn’t have to abide by strong enough regulations
column2: or they found their ways around them. And what was the result? Profits for many of these companies soared. But so did people’s health insurance premiums. Patients were routinely denied care
column3: often when they needed it most. Families were enticed
column4: and sometimes just plain tricked
column5: into buying homes they couldn’t afford. Huge
column6: reckless bets were made with other people’s money on the line. And our entire financial system was nearly destroyed.

column1: So we tried this theory out. And you would think that after the results of this experiment in trickle-down economics
column2: after the results were made painfully clear
column3: that the proponents of this theory might show some humility
column4: might moderate their views a bit. You'd think they’d say
column5: you know what
column6: maybe some rules and regulations are necessary to protect the economy and prevent people from being taken advantage of by insurance companies or credit card companies or mortgage lenders. Maybe
column8: at a time of growing debt and widening inequality
column9: we should hold off on giving the wealthiest Americans another round of big tax cuts. Maybe when we know that most of today’s middle-class jobs require more than a high school degree
column11: or lay off thousands of teachers
column12: or raise interest rates on college loans
column13: or take away people’s financial aid.

column1: But that’s exactly the opposite of what they’ve done. Instead of moderating their views even slightly
column2: the Republicans running Congress right now have doubled down
column3: and proposed a budget so far to the right it makes the Contract with America look like the New Deal. (Laughter.) In fact
column4: that renowned liberal
column5: Newt Gingrich
column6: first called the original version of the budget ""radical"" and said it would contribute to ""right-wing social engineering."" This is coming from Newt Gingrich.

column1: And yet
column2: this isn’t a budget supported by some small rump group in the Republican Party. This is now the party’s governing platform. This is what they’re running on. One of my potential opponents
column3: Governor Romney
column4: has said that he hoped a similar version of this plan from last year would be introduced as a bill on day one of his presidency. He said that he’s “very supportive” of this new budget
column5: and he even called it ""marvelous"" -- which is a word you don’t often hear when it comes to describing a budget. (Laughter.) It’s a word you don’t often hear generally. (Laughter.)

column1: So here’s what this ""marvelous"" budget does. Back in the summer
column2: I came to an agreement with Republicans in Congress to cut roughly $1 trillion in annual spending. Some of these cuts were about getting rid of waste; others were about programs that we support but just can’t afford given our deficits and our debt. And part of the agreement was a guarantee of another trillion in savings
column3: for a total of about $2 trillion in deficit reduction.

column1: This new House Republican budget
column2: however
column3: breaks our bipartisan agreement and proposes massive new cuts in annual domestic spending –- exactly the area where we’ve already cut the most. And I want to actually go through what it would mean for our country if these cuts were to be spread out evenly. So bear with me. I want to go through this -- because I don’t think people fully appreciate the nature of this budget.

column1: The year after next
column2: nearly 10 million college students would see their financial aid cut by an average of more than $1
column3: 000 each. There would be 1
column4: 600 fewer medical grants
column5: research grants for things like Alzheimer’s and cancer and AIDS. There would be 4
column6: 000 fewer scientific research grants
column8: 000 researchers
column10: and teachers. Investments in clean energy technologies that are helping us reduce our dependence on foreign oil would be cut by nearly a fifth.

column1: If this budget becomes law and the cuts were applied evenly
column2: starting in 2014
column3: over 200
column4: 000 children would lose their chance to get an early education in the Head Start program. Two million mothers and young children would be cut from a program that gives them access to healthy food. There would be 4
column5: 500 fewer federal grants at the Department of Justice and the FBI to combat violent crime
column6: financial crime
column7: and help secure our borders. Hundreds of national parks would be forced to close for part or all of the year. We wouldn’t have the capacity to enforce the laws that protect the air we breathe
column8: the water we drink
column9: or the food that we eat.

column1: Cuts to the FAA would likely result in more flight cancellations
column2: delays
column3: and the complete elimination of air traffic control services in parts of the country. Over time
column4: our weather forecasts would become less accurate because we wouldn’t be able to afford to launch new satellites. And that means governors and mayors would have to wait longer to order evacuations in the event of a hurricane.

column1: That’s just a partial sampling of the consequences of this budget. Now
column2: you can anticipate Republicans may say
column3: well
column4: we’ll avoid some of these cuts -- since they don’t specify exactly the cuts that they would make. But they can only avoid some of these cuts if they cut even deeper in other areas. This is math. If they want to make smaller cuts to medical research that means they’ve got to cut even deeper in funding for things like teaching and law enforcement. The converse is true as well. If they want to protect early childhood education
column5: it will mean further reducing things like financial aid for young people trying to afford college.

column1: Perhaps they will never tell us where the knife will fall -- but you can be sure that with cuts this deep
column2: there is no secret plan or formula that will be able to protect the investments we need to help our economy grow.

column1: This is not conjecture. I am not exaggerating. These are facts. And these are just the cuts that would happen the year after next.
If this budget became law
column2: by the middle of the century
column3: funding for the kinds of things I just mentioned would have to be cut by about 95 percent. Let me repeat that. Those categories I just mentioned we would have to cut by 95 percent. As a practical matter
column4: the federal budget would basically amount to whatever is left in entitlements
column5: defense spending
column6: and interest on the national debt -- period. Money for these investments that have traditionally been supported on a bipartisan basis would be practically eliminated.

column1: And the same is true for other priorities like transportation
column2: and homeland security
column3: and veterans programs for the men and women who have risked their lives for this country. This is not an exaggeration. Check it out yourself.

column1: And this is to say nothing about what the budget does to health care. We’re told that Medicaid would simply be handed over to the states -- that's the pitch: Let's get it out of the central bureaucracy. The states can experiment. They'll be able to run the programs a lot better. But here's the deal the states would be getting. They would have to be running these programs in the face of the largest cut to Medicaid that has ever been proposed -- a cut that
column2: according to one nonpartisan group
column3: would take away health care for about 19 million Americans -- 19 million.

column1: Who are these Americans? Many are someone’s grandparents who
column2: without Medicaid
column3: won't be able to afford nursing home care without Medicaid. Many are poor children. Some are middle-class families who have children with autism or Down’s Syndrome. Some are kids with disabilities so severe that they require 24-hour care. These are the people who count on Medicaid.

column1: Then there’s Medicare. Because health care costs keep rising and the Baby Boom generation is retiring
column2: Medicare
column3: we all know
column4: is one of the biggest drivers of our long-term deficit. That’s a challenge we have to meet by bringing down the cost of health care overall so that seniors and taxpayers can share in the savings.

column1: But here’s the solution proposed by the Republicans in Washington
column2: and embraced by most of their candidates for president: Instead of being enrolled in Medicare when they turn 65
column3: seniors who retire a decade from now would get a voucher that equals the cost of the second cheapest health care plan in their area. If Medicare is more expensive than that private plan
column4: they’ll have to pay more if they want to enroll in traditional Medicare. If health care costs rise faster than the amount of the voucher -- as
column5: by the way
column6: they’ve been doing for decades -- that’s too bad. Seniors bear the risk. If the voucher isn’t enough to buy a private plan with the specific doctors and care that you need

column1: So most experts will tell you the way this voucher plan encourages savings is not through better care at cheaper cost. The way these private insurance companies save money is by designing and marketing plans to attract the youngest and healthiest seniors -- cherry-picking -- leaving the older and sicker seniors in traditional Medicare
column2: where they have access to a wide range of doctors and guaranteed care. But that
column3: of course
column4: makes the traditional Medicare program even more expensive
column5: and raise premiums even further.

column1: The net result is that our country will end up spending more on health care
column2: and the only reason the government will save any money -- it won’t be on our books -- is because we’ve shifted it to seniors. They’ll bear more of the costs themselves. It’s a bad idea
column3: and it will ultimately end Medicare as we know it.

column1: Now
column2: the proponents of this budget will tell us we have to make all these draconian cuts because our deficit is so large; this is an existential crisis
column3: we have to think about future generations
column4: so on and so on. And that argument might have a shred of credibility were it not for their proposal to also spend $4.6 trillion over the next decade on lower tax rates.

column1: We’re told that these tax cuts will supposedly be paid for by closing loopholes and eliminating wasteful deductions. But the Republicans in Congress refuse to list a single tax loophole they are willing to close. Not one. And by the way
column2: there is no way to get even close to $4.6 trillion in savings without dramatically reducing all kinds of tax breaks that go to middle-class families -- tax breaks for health care
column3: tax breaks for retirement
column4: tax breaks for homeownership.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: these proposed tax breaks would come on top of more than a trillion dollars in tax giveaways for people making more than $250
column3: 000 a year. That’s an average of at least $150
column4: 000 for every millionaire in this country -- $150

column1: Let’s just step back for a second and look at what $150
column2: 000 pays for: A year’s worth of prescription drug coverage for a senior citizen. Plus a new school computer lab. Plus a year of medical care for a returning veteran. Plus a medical research grant for a chronic disease. Plus a year’s salary for a firefighter or police officer. Plus a tax credit to make a year of college more affordable. Plus a year’s worth of financial aid. One hundred fifty thousand dollars could pay for all of these things combined -- investments in education and research that are essential to economic growth that benefits all of us. For $150
column4: that would be going to each millionaire and billionaire in this country. This budget says we’d be better off as a country if that’s how we spend it.

column1: This is supposed to be about paying down our deficit? It’s laughable.

The bipartisan Simpson-Bowles commission that I created -- which the Republicans originally were for until I was for it -- that was about paying down the deficit. And I didn’t agree with all the details. I proposed about $600 billion more in revenue and $600 billion -- I'm sorry -- it proposed about $600 billion more in revenue and about $600 billion more in defense cuts than I proposed in my own budget. But Bowles-Simpson was a serious
column2: honest
column3: balanced effort between Democrats and Republicans to bring down the deficit. That’s why
column4: although it differs in some ways
column5: my budget takes a similarly balanced approach: Cuts in discretionary spending
column6: cuts in mandatory spending

column1: This congressional Republican budget is something different altogether. It is a Trojan Horse. Disguised as deficit reduction plans
column2: it is really an attempt to impose a radical vision on our country. It is thinly veiled social Darwinism. It is antithetical to our entire history as a land of opportunity and upward mobility for everybody who’s willing to work for it; a place where prosperity doesn’t trickle down from the top
column3: but grows outward from the heart of the middle class. And by gutting the very things we need to grow an economy that’s built to last -- education and training
column4: research and development
column5: our infrastructure -- it is a prescription for decline.

column1: And everybody here should understand that because there's very few people here who haven't benefitted at some point from those investments that were made in the '50s and the '60s and the '70s and the '80s. That’s part of how we got ahead. And now
column2: we're going to be pulling up those ladders up for the next generation?

column1: So in the months ahead
column2: I will be fighting as hard as I know how for this truer vision of what the United States of America is all about. Absolutely
column3: we have to get serious about the deficit. And that will require tough choices and sacrifice. And I’ve already shown myself willing to make these tough choices when I signed into law the biggest spending cut of any President in recent memory. In fact
column4: if you adjust for the economy
column5: the Congressional Budget Office says the overall spending next year will be lower than any year under Ronald Reagan.

column1: And I’m willing to make more of those difficult spending decisions in the months ahead. But I’ve said it before and I’ll say it again -- there has to be some balance. All of us have to do our fair share.
I’ve also put forward a detailed plan that would reform and strengthen Medicare and Medicaid. By the beginning of the next decade
column2: it achieves the same amount of annual health savings as the plan proposed by Simpson-Bowles -- the Simpson-Bowles commission
column3: and it does so by making changes that people in my party haven’t always been comfortable with. But instead of saving money by shifting costs to seniors
column4: like the congressional Republican plan proposes
column5: our approach would lower the cost of health care throughout the entire system. It goes after excessive subsidies to prescription drug companies. It gets more efficiency out of Medicaid without gutting the program. It asks the very wealthiest seniors to pay a little bit more. It changes the way we pay for health care -- not by procedure or the number of days spent in a hospital
column6: but with new incentives for doctors and hospitals to improve their results.

column1: And it slows the growth of Medicare costs by strengthening an independent commission -- a commission not made up of bureaucrats from government or insurance companies
column2: but doctors and nurses and medical experts and consumers
column3: who will look at all the evidence and recommend the best way to reduce unnecessary health care spending while protecting access to the care that the seniors need.

column1: We also have a much different approach when it comes to taxes -- an approach that says if we’re serious about paying down our debt
column2: we can’t afford to spend trillions more on tax cuts for folks like me
column3: for wealthy Americans who don’t need them and weren’t even asking for them
column4: and that the country cannot afford. At a time when the share of national income flowing to the top 1 percent of people in this country has climbed to levels last seen in the 1920s
column5: those same folks are paying taxes at one of the lowest rates in 50 years. As both I and Warren Buffett have pointed out many times now
column6: he’s paying a lower tax rate than his secretary. That is not fair. It is not right.

column1: And the choice is really very simple. If you want to keep these tax rates and deductions in place -- or give even more tax breaks to the wealthy
column2: as the Republicans in Congress propose -- then one of two things happen: Either it means higher deficits
column3: or it means more sacrifice from the middle class. Seniors will have to pay more for Medicare. College students will lose some of their financial aid. Working families who are scraping by will have to do more because the richest Americans are doing less. I repeat what I’ve said before: That is not class warfare
column4: that is not class envy
column5: that is math.

column1: If that’s the choice that members of Congress want to make
column2: then we’re going to make sure every American knows about it. In a few weeks
column3: there will be a vote on what we’ve called the Buffett Rule. Simple concept: If you make more than a million dollars a year -- not that you have a million dollars -- if you make more than a million dollars annually
column4: then you should pay at least the same percentage of your income in taxes as middle-class families do. On the other hand
column5: if you make under $250
column6: 000 a year -- like 98 percent of American families do -- then your taxes shouldn’t go up. That’s the proposal.

column1: Now
column2: you’ll hear some people point out that the Buffett Rule alone won’t raise enough revenue to solve our deficit problems. Maybe not
column3: but it’s definitely a step in the right direction. And I intend to keep fighting for this kind of balance and fairness until the other side starts listening
column4: because I believe this is what the American people want. I believe this is the best way to pay for the investments we need to grow our economy and strengthen the middle class. And by the way
column5: I believe it’s the right thing to do.

column1: This larger debate that we will be having and that you will be covering in the coming year about the size and role of government
column2: this debate has been with us since our founding days. And during moments of great challenge and change
column3: like the ones that we’re living through now
column4: the debate gets sharper; it gets more vigorous. That’s a good thing. As a country that prizes both our individual freedom and our obligations to one another
column5: this is one of the most important debates that we can have.

column1: But no matter what we argue or where we stand
column2: we have always held certain beliefs as Americans. We believe that in order to preserve our own freedoms and pursue our own happiness
column3: we can’t just think about ourselves. We have to think about the country that made those liberties possible. We have to think about our fellow citizens with whom we share a community. We have to think about what’s required to preserve the American Dream for future generations.

column1: And this sense of responsibility -- to each other and our country -- this isn’t a partisan feeling. This isn’t a Democratic or Republican idea. It’s patriotism. And if we keep that in mind
column2: and uphold our obligations to one another and to this larger enterprise that is America
column3: then I have no doubt that we will continue our long and prosperous journey as the greatest nation on Earth.

column1: Thank you. God bless you. God bless the United States of America. (Applause.) Thank you.
MR. SINGLETON: Thank you
column2: Mr. President. We appreciate so much you being with us today. I have some questions from the audience
column3: which I will ask -- and I'll be more careful than I was last time I did this.

column1: Republicans have been sharply critical of your budget ideas as well. What can you say to the Americans who just want both sides to stop fighting and get some work done on their behalf?
THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: I completely understand the American people’s frustrations
column3: because the truth is that these are eminently solvable problems. I know that Christine Lagarde is here from the IMF
column4: and she’s looking at the books of a lot of other countries around the world. The kinds of challenges they face fiscally are so much more severe than anything that we confront -- if we make some sensible decisions.

column1: So the American people’s impulses are absolutely right. These are solvable problems if people of good faith came together and were willing to compromise. The challenge we have right now is that we have on one side
column2: a party that will brook no compromise. And this is not just my assertion. We had presidential candidates who stood on a stage and were asked
column3: “Would you accept a budget package
column4: a deficit reduction plan
column5: that involved $10 of cuts for every dollar in revenue increases?” Ten-to-one ratio of spending cuts to revenue. Not one of them raised their hand.

column1: Think about that. Ronald Reagan
column2: who
column3: as I recall
column4: is not accused of being a tax-and-spend socialist
column5: understood repeatedly that when the deficit started to get out of control
column6: that for him to make a deal he would have to propose both spending cuts and tax increases. Did it multiple times. He could not get through a Republican primary today.

column1: So let's look at Bowles-Simpson. Essentially
column2: my differences with Bowles-Simpson were I actually proposed less revenue and slightly lower defense spending cuts. The Republicans want to increase defense spending and take in no revenue
column3: which makes it impossible to balance the deficit under the terms that Bowles-Simpson laid out -- unless you essentially eliminate discretionary spending. You don't just cut discretionary spending. Everything we think of as being pretty important -- from education to basic science and research to transportation spending to national parks to environmental protection -- we'd essentially have to eliminate.

column1: I guess another way of thinking about this is -- and this bears on your reporting. I think that there is oftentimes the impulse to suggest that if the two parties are disagreeing
column2: then they're equally at fault and the truth lies somewhere in the middle
column3: and an equivalence is presented -- which reinforces I think people's cynicism about Washington generally. This is not one of those situations where there's an equivalence. I've got some of the most liberal Democrats in Congress who were prepared to make significant changes to entitlements that go against their political interests
column4: and who said they were willing to do it. And we couldn't get a Republican to stand up and say
column5: we'll raise some revenue
column6: or even to suggest that we won't give more tax cuts to people who don't need them.

column1: And so I think it's important to put the current debate in some historical context. It's not just true
column2: by the way
column3: of the budget. It's true of a lot of the debates that we're having out here.

column1: Cap and trade was originally proposed by conservatives and Republicans as a market-based solution to solving environmental problems. The first President to talk about cap and trade was George H.W. Bush. Now you've got the other party essentially saying we shouldn’t even be thinking about environmental protection; let's gut the EPA.
Health care
column2: which is in the news right now -- there's a reason why there's a little bit of confusion in the Republican primary about health care and the individual mandate since it originated as a conservative idea to preserve the private marketplace in health care while still assuring that everybody got covered
column3: in contrast to a single-payer plan. Now
column4: suddenly
column5: this is some socialist overreach.

column1: So as all of you are doing your reporting
column2: I think it's important to remember that the positions I'm taking now on the budget and a host of other issues
column3: if we had been having this discussion 20 years ago
column4: or even 15 years ago
column5: would have been considered squarely centrist positions. What's changed is the center of the Republican Party. And that’s certainly true with the budget.

column1: MR. SINGLETON: Mr. President
column2: the managing director of the (inaudible) for continuation of United States leadership (inaudible) economic issues
column3: and underscored the need for a lower deficit and lower debt. How can you respond to that claim?

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: look
column3: she's absolutely right. It's interesting
column4: when I travel around the world at these international fora -- and I've said this before -- the degree to which America is still the one indispensable nation
column5: the degree to which
column6: even as other countries are rising and their economies are expanding
column7: we are still looked to for leadership
column8: for agenda setting -- not just because of our size
column9: not just because of our military power
column10: but because there is a sense that unlike most superpowers in the past
column11: we try to set out a set of universal rules
column12: a set of principles by which everybody can benefit.

column1: And that’s true on the economic front as well. We continue to be the world’s largest market
column2: an important engine for economic growth. We can’t return to a time when by simply borrowing and consuming
column3: we end up driving global economic growth.

column1: I said this a few months after I was elected at the first G20 summit. I said the days when Americans using their credit cards and home equity loans finance the rest of the world’s growth by taking in imports from every place else -- those days are over. On the other hand
column2: we continue to be a extraordinarily important market and foundation for global economic growth.

column1: We do have to take care of our deficits. I think Christine has spoken before
column2: and I think most economists would argue as well
column3: that the challenge when it comes to our deficits is not short-term discretionary spending
column4: which is manageable. As I said before and I want to repeat
column5: as a percentage of our GDP
column6: our discretionary spending -- all the things that the Republicans are proposing cutting -- is actually lower than it's been since Dwight Eisenhower. There has not been some massive expansion of social programs
column8: environmental programs
column9: education programs. That’s not our problem.

column1: Our problem is that our revenue has dropped down to between 15 and 16 percent -- far lower than it has been historically
column2: certainly far lower than it was under Ronald Reagan -- at the same time as our health care costs have surged
column3: and our demographics mean that there is more and more pressure being placed on financing our Medicare
column4: Medicaid and Social Security programs.

column1: So at a time when the recovery is still gaining steam
column2: and unemployment is still very high
column3: the solution should be pretty apparent. And that is even as we continue to make investments in growth today -- for example
column4: putting some of our construction workers back to work rebuilding schools and roads and bridges
column5: or helping states to rehire teachers at a time when schools are having a huge difficulty retaining quality teachers in the classroom -- all of which would benefit our economy
column6: we focus on a long-term plan to stabilize our revenues at a responsible level and to deal with our health care programs in a responsible way. And that's exactly what I'm proposing.

column1: And what we've proposed is let's go back
column2: for folks who are making more than $250
column3: 000 a year
column4: to levels that were in place during the Clinton era
column5: when wealthy people were doing just fine
column6: and the economy was growing a lot stronger than it did after they were cut. And let's take on Medicare and Medicaid in a serious way -- which is not just a matter of taking those costs off the books
column8: and pushing them onto individual seniors
column9: but let's actually reduce health care costs. Because we spend more on health care with not as good outcomes as any other advanced

column1: And that would seem to be a sensible proposal. The problem right now is not the technical means to solve it. The problem is our politics. And that's part of what this election and what this debate will need to be about
column2: is
column3: are we
column4: as a country
column5: willing to get back to common-sense
column6: balanced
column7: fair solutions that encourage our long-term economic growth and stabilize our budget. And it can be done.

column1: One last point I want to make
column2: Dean
column3: that I think is important
column4: because it goes to the growth issue. If state and local government hiring were basically on par to what our current recovery -- on par to past recoveries
column5: the unemployment rate would probably be about a point lower than it is right now. If the construction industry were going through what we normally go through
column6: that would be another point lower. The challenge we have right now -- part of the challenge we have in terms of growth has to do with the very specific issues of huge cuts in state and local government
column7: and the housing market still recovering from this massive bubble. And that -- those two things are huge headwinds in terms of growth.

column1: I say this because if we
column2: for example
column3: put some of those construction workers back to work
column4: or we put some of those teachers back in the classroom
column5: that could actually help create the kind of virtuous cycle that would bring in more revenues just because of economic growth
column6: would benefit the private sector in significant ways. And that could help contribute to deficit reduction in the short term
column7: even as we still have to do these important changes to our health care programs over the long term.

column1: MR. SINGLETON: Mr. President
column2: you said yesterday that it would be unprecedented for a Supreme Court to overturn laws passed by an elected Congress. But that is exactly what the Court has done during its entire existence. If the Court were to overturn individual mandate
column3: what would you do
column4: or propose to do
column5: for the 30 million people who wouldn’t have health care after that ruling?

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: first of all
column3: let me be very specific. We have not seen a Court overturn a law that was passed by Congress on a economic issue
column4: like health care
column5: that I think most people would clearly consider commerce -- a law like that has not been overturned at least since Lochner. Right? So we’re going back to the ’30s
column6: pre New Deal.

column1: And the point I was making is that the Supreme Court is the final say on our Constitution and our laws
column2: and all of us have to respect it
column3: but it’s precisely because of that extraordinary power that the Court has traditionally exercised significant restraint and deference to our duly elected legislature
column4: our Congress. And so the burden is on those who would overturn a law like this.

column1: Now
column2: as I said
column3: I expect the Supreme Court actually to recognize that and to abide by well-established precedence out there. I have enormous confidence that in looking at this law
column4: not only is it constitutional
column5: but that the Court is going to exercise its jurisprudence carefully because of the profound power that our Supreme Court has. As a consequence
column6: we’re not spending a whole bunch of time planning for contingencies.

column1: What I did emphasize yesterday is there is a human element to this that everybody has to remember. This is not an abstract exercise. I get letters every day from people who are affected by the health care law right now
column2: even though it’s not fully implemented. Young people who are 24
column4: who say
column5: you know what
column6: I just got diagnosed with a tumor. First of all
column7: I would not have gone to get a check-up if I hadn’t had health insurance. Second of all
column8: I wouldn’t have been able to afford to get it treated had I not been on my parent’s plan. Thank you and thank Congress for getting this done.

column1: I get letters from folks who have just lost their job
column2: their COBRA is running out. They’re in the middle of treatment for colon cancer or breast cancer
column3: and they’re worried when their COBRA runs out
column4: if they’re still sick
column5: what are they going to be able to do because they’re not going to be able to get health insurance.

column1: And the point I think that was made very ably before the Supreme Court
column2: but I think most health care economists who have looked at this have acknowledged
column3: is there are basically two ways to cover people with preexisting conditions or assure that people can always get coverage even when they had bad illnesses. One way is the single-payer plan -- everybody is under a single system
column4: like Medicare. The other way is to set up a system in which you don’t have people who are healthy but don’t bother to get health insurance
column5: and then we all have to pay for them in the emergency room.

column1: That doesn’t work
column2: and so
column3: as a consequence
column4: we've got to make sure that those folks are taking their responsibility seriously
column5: which is what the individual mandate does.

column1: So I don’t anticipate the Court striking this down. I think they take their responsibilities very seriously. But I think what's more important is for all of us
column2: Democrats and Republicans
column3: to recognize that in a country like ours -- the wealthiest
column4: most powerful country on Earth -- we shouldn’t have a system in which millions of people are at risk of bankruptcy because they get sick
column5: or end up waiting until they do get sick and then go to the emergency room
column6: which involves all of us paying for it.

column1: MR. SINGLETON: Mr. President
column2: you've been very
column3: very generous with your time
column4: and we appreciate very much you being here.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Thank you so much
column2: everybody. (Applause.) Thank you.

column1: END
1:35 P.M. EDT"	['https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/profiles/forall/modules/custom/gov_whitehouse_www/images/icons/wh_logo_seal.png'
column2: 'https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/sites/whitehouse.gov/files/images/twitter_cards_default.jpg']	https://obamawhitehouse.archives.gov/sites/whitehouse.gov/files/images/twitter_cards_default.jpg	Remarks by the President at the Associated Press Luncheon	http://www.whitehouse.gov

column1: 0	"Transcript: NPR's Full Interview With Sen. Marco Rubio
Sen. Marco Rubio
column2: R-Fla.
column3: is running for president and spoke with NPR's Steve Inskeep on Monday ahead of his big announcement.

column1: Rubio talked about how he hopes to stand out in the 2016 presidential field
column2: Indiana's religious freedom law
column3: the president's deal with Iran
column4: immigration policy
column5: and America's warming relationship with Cuba.

column1: STEVE INSKEEP: In all the years I've been interviewing people
column2: I don't think I've spoken with somebody on the day of an announcement like this. And I was thinking that if it were me
column3: there might be a moment the night before where I was lying awake wondering if I was really ready for this. Did you have a moment of wondering if you were really ready for this?

column1: SEN. MARCO RUBIO: Not last night
column2: but
column3: I mean
column4: if you reach the point where you're wondering it the night before you announce
column5: then you probably shouldn't run. I think anyone who's thinking about the highest office in the most powerful nation on earth has to spend some time analyzing whether they're prepared for the job. And look
column6: I think the job is perhaps the most difficult job in politics anywhere in the world. You're the leader of the most powerful military on the planet. You make decisions that have global implications. And it's happening at a time when the country's going through an extraordinary economic transformation that is leaving many people insecure. But from all that and given both my experience at the local
column8: and especially the lessons learned over the last five years as I've been engaged in federal policy making
column9: I'm very confident that I have the judgment and the knowledge that I need to do a very good job as president of the United States. And clearly
column10: as you see the history of the presidency
column11: people who go into that office grow
column12: the office helps you grow as well as you go through it and that's
column13: having the ability to learn is a big part of the office as well. But I'm certainly capable from day 1. I'm very confident that I have the capability from day no. 1 to lead this country.

column1: Are you also affirming that you are not giving up your — are you also affirming that you are not running for Senate?
I am not. And the reason I think strongly about that is
column2: if you've decided that you want to serve this country as its president
column3: that's what you should be running for. And I find myself in a situation where my Senate seat comes up for re-election at the exact same time as the presidency. And by Florida law
column4: you can't run for both
column5: anyway. But to even be thinking about a Plan B in case this doesn't work
column6: I think diminishes your ability to succeed on the campaign because your mind will always be on
column8: then I can do something else. And the truth is that
column10: I don't want to be in politics my entire life. And I'm prepared to serve this country now in its highest office and I'm excited about this opportunity.

column1: You'll be in a crowded Republican field. How do you expect to distinguish yourself from your opponents on the Republican side?
Well
column2: I expect that I'm going to go out and tell people my vision for the future of this country. I'm going to be very specific and detailed about our plans and how we're going to get there. In fact
column3: I've done that already. We have a very detailed policy position that we've outlined on numerous issues over the last two years
column4: culminating in my book that just came out earlier this year
column5: American Dreams. And I think from that
column6: voters are going to analyze the different position of the candidates
column8: their history
column9: but more importantly their view of the future and their plans to get us there and I'm very confident that that will lead to success.

column1: Is there a sentence that people can have in their heads? Marco Rubio is different from the others because...
He has the clear view of how the 21st century can also be an American century.
We're in a moment where you have put out plans proposing to reshape the way the federal government deals with federal assistance to the poor.
Yes.
We're in a moment where Jeb Bush
column2: who may also run
column3: has a superPAC called Right to Rise. And this week
column4: of course
column5: Hillary Clinton declared her campaign for the presidency talking about helping everyday people. What's going on there?

column1: Well
column2: that's a good thing for our country because equality of opportunity has always defined us as a people and as a nation. And the fact that there are millions of people now in America that are starting to have significant doubts about whether we're still that kind of country should be deeply concerning to us. Our identity is at stake. Every country in the world has rich people. What makes America different is
column3: we've had millions and millions of people who through hard work and perseverance are able to achieve happiness and upward mobility. And the fact that that's in danger and in question is deeply concerning
column4: and should be. It threatens our identity. So I'm glad that people are talking about it. Ultimately
column5: talking about it won't be enough. You have to have plans that work to help us address it. And for me it begins by embracing and acknowledging the reality that we are living through a massive transformation into this post-industrial 21st century economy that is both disruptive but also exciting. It comes not just with challenges
column6: but also with opportunities. But we can only embrace those opportunities if we move forward on thinking about the changes we're going to have to make in order to fully enter the 21st century.

column1: What's one way that your approach would be different from Jeb Bush's or Hillary Clinton's?
Well
column2: as far as the Republican field is concerned
column3: there will be plenty of time for comparison shopping. The truth is
column4: for voters
column5: the truth is that at this moment most of my opponents in the field beyond talking about upward mobility have not clearly outlined what they would do. We have a clear policy outline on each of these issues that people can read about. And if
column6: you know
column7: all of my opponents and other candidates in the Republican field choose to adopt some of those ideas
column8: I'll consider that a victory as well as flattery. But on the Democratic side
column11: Hillary Clinton is someone who's deeply wedded to the institutions of the 20th century. Her plans are to spend more money on the existing higher education system. That system doesn't work any more. It doesn't work any more because we don't graduate enough young people from high school ready to work. We need to do more of that — ready to work in trades as mechanics
column12: airplane technicians and plumbers and engineers. These are good — welders. These are good 21st century jobs and we are capable of teaching people how to do that so at 18
column14: they can be employed. We also need to have more flexible
column15: more flexibility in higher education for working Americans who can't afford to drop everything and go to school full-time for four years. We need to have programs that allow someone who works full time to learn at their own pace
column17: so that a receptionist can become a paralegal
column18: so that the home-health aide making $10 an hour can become a dental hygienist making $55
column19: 000 a year. And then we have to have more quality measures in higher education. For example
column20: before you take out a student loan--

column1: Mhmm
I have a bill that says every student
column2: before you take out a student loan
column3: needs to be told how much you can expect to make when you graduate from that school with the degree you're pursuing so you can make an informed decision about whether or not it's worth it to borrow a bunch of money for that degree.

column1: A Florida political reporter noticed that you spent a plane ride sitting beside Jeb Bush
column2: more than two hours
column3: coming back from an NRA convention. Did you guys talk about the presidential campaign at all?

column1: Not in great detail. Jeb and I are friends
column2: we'll always be friends. And I have tremendous admiration for him as a person
column3: what he did as governor
column4: and personal affection. And that's not going to change. I don't view
column5: I'm not running against Jeb Bush and I'm not running against anybody in this field. I'm running because I strongly believe that I have something to offer this country that no one else in the field does at this moment in our history. And I'm going to go out there and do the best job that I can and — but
column6: I mean
column7: that's not going to impact our relationship in any way that's going to change how we feel about one another and it was great to see him and spend quality time just talking about good times and everything going on ...

column1: You didn't talk politics very much at all?
... and everything in between. Sure
column2: I mean we had observations about — we joked with a lot of the passengers who saw us sitting next to each other and we took some pictures with people and we told them
column3: we warned them how historic a picture like that may be one day. And
column4: um
column5: but you know
column6: we talked about the Masters
column7: we talked about the Paleo diet
column8: we talked about the Miami Dolphins. I mean it
column10: reminisced about old war stories from our time in the legislature
column11: when I was in the legislature and he was governor. It was just a host of things.

column1: Sooner or later if you go forward and he goes forward
column2: there's going to be a moment where you're going to have to say
column3: ""Here's why it should be me and not him.""

column1: I don't know. I mean
column2: I think this year's going to be quite different in that regard. We have a quality field of candidates who are going to be well financed and experienced
column3: who are going to be running. And I think that'll change the nature of the race. There'll certainly be moments when others will try to draw distinctions. But in my mind
column4: I'm going to talk about who I am and what I want to do. And I'll let voters make the decision about who they think is best capable at this moment of leading our country.

column1: You scheduled an announcement at Miami's Freedom Tower
column2: which has historic significance because Cubans who fled Fidel Castro's regime in the 60s and 70s received federal aid there. This brings to mind that you have strongly criticized President Obama's restoration of relations with Cuba. If you're elected
column3: would you reverse that policy?

column1: Absolutely
column2: and I think the reason why is because I'm interested in
column3: my interest in Cuba is freedom and democracy. I think the Cuban people
column4: they are free
column5: have the right to choose any economic model they want to follow. I don't believe these changes will actually further democracy. In fact
column6: I think they will make it harder to achieve. The goal of the Castro regime is to create the impression and the reality that their form of government is a legitimate form of government and set it in concrete. They know they have a generational challenge. Most of their top leaders are in their 80s. The actuarial tables tell you they don't have much longer. And they want to leave in place global recognition for this form of government so that it can continue in perpetuity. And that means the Cuban people will never have the chance to experience what the people in the Dominican Republic and Haiti have
column7: what the people in Mexico have
column8: what the people in Peru have
column9: what the people in Colombia have
column10: which is free and fair elections. And that's all I want for the people in Cuba. And I think U.S. policy towards Cuba is a major leverage point that we can use to help the Cuban people achieve freedom for themselves.

column1: But help me think through this. The president made this announcement
column2: they're working on getting an embassy going at some point in the future. He went to Summit of the Americas where other countries in Latin America very much welcomed the restoration of relations. You're saying that if you're elected
column3: you would close that embassy
column4: you would break diplomatic ties
column5: you would go back to the way things were?

column1: We have an interest section in Cuba and it will continue to operate
column2: but an embassy
column3: I'm not
column4: I don't believe this country should be diplomatically recognizing a nation of the nature of Cuba. Obviously there are other dictatorships in the world that we have relations with by geopolitical reality. You know
column5: China's the largest country in the world
column6: the second largest economy
column7: the second largest military force. There are geopolitical realities there. Cuba is a brutal
column8: tyrannical dictatorship 90 miles from the shore of our country. It is a nation that helps North Korea evade U.N. weapon sanctions. It is a country that harbors fugitives from American justice
column9: including Medicare fraudsters and someone who killed a police officer in the United States. And I just think that we should have continued with the policy and perhaps looked for new ways of — continue with the policy of not recognizing that regime and not allowing them access to economic growth that would allow them to perpetuate themselves in power
column10: and continue to search for ways to provide the Cuban people with more information about the reality of the world so they would be empowered to eventually create for themselves a democratic society.

column1: You've also said that you would reverse the president's deal with Iran
column2: assuming that that is finalized. You said you would absolutely do that. What would that look like on day one?

column1: Well
column2: I would not adhere — well
column3: we have to understand the deal
column4: basically
column5: can be what it is on paper. What the president is banking on is that he's going to use a national security waiver to lift the sanctions on Iran
column6: the economic sanctions that now exist. And we would simply re-impose the sanctions. And I still have tremendous questions about whether this deal's even viable. The Iranians are now saying that what we're saying the deal is and what they understand it to be are two different things. This issue of them asking for immediate relief of sanctions the minute the deal is signed is going to be a deal breaker. I hope it would be a deal break for this administration. And at the end of the day
column7: we need to recognize that what Iran is trying to do here
column8: and this is clear to anyone who has inside knowledge into this or has followed it closely
column9: Iran is trying to maintain all the infrastructure they need to be nuclear capable without agreeing to any irreversible concessions. And that seems to be what they have achieved
column10: if in fact this moves forward. So in my mind
column11: we would just reinstitute the sanctions.

column1: But I'm just thinking this through. The deal is made. It's made not just with the United States
column2: but with the European allies. Would you move forward with re-imposing sanctions even if the Europeans don't go along with it?

column1: Yes
column2: it wouldn't be as effective
column3: obviously. We would
column4: ultimately
column5: I think
column6: the Europeans are going to have a test anyway because the Iranians are going to violate the sanctions at some point. They're going to evade it either by trying to take advantage of loopholes in the deal
column7: or they'll just flat out evade it because they've always had a secret component to their
column8: to their program. And at that point
column9: they're going to have a huge test on their hands
column11: are they willing to live by the agreement that they even signed on to? But from the United States' perspective
column12: while we want our allies to join us in this endeavor
column13: and certainly sanctions against Iran would be more effective were they in conjunction with our allies around the world
column14: we have to look out for our own national security concerns. And in my mind
column15: if the president wanted this to be a permanent deal that survived his presidency
column16: he would have brought it to Congress.

column1: I'm just thinking through further
column2: though
column3: as part of this deal
column4: assuming it's finalized
column5: the Iranians get rid of a vast amount of enriched uranium
column6: almost all they have. They limit the amount of enrichment that they will have. They limit the number of centrifuges they will operate and they will allow inspections for decades
column8: all that

column1: They would retain all the infrastructure
column2: first of all
column3: they ...

column1: They retain infrastructure
column2: sure.

column1: They retain not only just infrastructure
column2: they retain centrifuges
column3: too. They may not be spinning them
column4: but they will retain them in their possession. They continue to develop their long range missile capabilities
column5: which are unstopped. There's no prohibition on them acquiring a weapon design as they probably
column6: may even already have. They continue to sponsor terrorism all over the world. In fact
column7: now they'll have more funding to pay for it
column8: in places they already control
column9: places like Beirut. They're increasingly active in Yemen. Their hand and their role's clear in Bahrain and in a growing number of places around the world. And they continue to be run by a radical Shia cleric who has apocalyptic views of the future and of their role in it. So none of these things change. Their infrastructure will remain in place and at some point
column10: they could follow the North Korean model very easily
column11: which is they can cook up an excuse for why they need to have a weapon program and move forward on it.

column1: Is war inevitable then?

I hope not. My hope is that we can delay a program long enough and you would hope that there would be some sort of change in leadership in Iran that would at least allow them to decide that they would rather have an economy than have a weapon. You can't guarantee it. But at the end of the day no one wants war
column2: but I actually think that this deal could advance the prospects of war. I think this deal and the fact that Iran will retain nuclear infrastructure increases the likelihood that one of their neighbors may take action against them
column3: whether it's Israel or the Saudis or someone else. It also increases the likelihood now
column4: that Iran becomes even more aggressive in its proxy wars that it's conducting all over the world. It also increases the likelihood that they'll increase their conventional capabilities threatening our U.S. presence in the region. And ultimately I think it almost guarantees an arms race in the region
column5: because the Saudis have made very clear
column6: and others
column8: that whatever Iran has
column9: they'll get as well. So if Iran is allowed to enrich to a certain level
column10: they will begin doing the same
column11: requiring a capability to do the same.

column1: Let me ask about a domestic issue. In recent weeks
column2: the state of Indiana passed a Religious Freedom law
column3: which was interpreted by many as discrimination
column4: by others
column5: as protection for people who don't want to take part in gay marriage. You defended the law and spoke about the hypothetical example of a florist who was asked to participate in a gay marriage and wanted to refuse. You said that person should have the right to follow their religious beliefs. Indiana
column6: though
column7: has since changed the law. Do you still support that concept?

column1: Well
column2: to be fair
column3: I haven't read the change in detail to give you an opinion on it specifically
column4: but I'll tell you where I stand. I don't believe you can discriminate against people. So I don't believe it's right for a florist to say
column5: I'm not going to provide you flowers because you're gay. I think there's a difference between not providing services to a person because of their identity
column6: who they are or who they love
column8: I'm not going to participate in an event
column10: because that violates my religious beliefs. There's a distinction between those two things. So
column12: you can't not — it's immoral and wrong to say
column13: I'm not going to allow someone who's gay or lesbian to use my restaurant
column15: or provide photography service to them because they're gay. The difference here is
column16: we're not talking about discriminating against a person because of who they are
column17: we're talking about someone who's saying — what I'm talking about
column20: I just don't want to participate as a vendor for an event
column21: a specific event that violates the tenets of my faith.

column1: What if two gay people get married and then they go that night to a hotel. Can the hotelkeeper refuse service to them?
That's not part of an event. Again
column2: I mean
column3: that's
column4: there's a difference between saying
column5: we're not going to allow you to stay in our hotel
column6: common lodging establishment where people have a right to shelter
column8: medical care
column9: and saying we're not going to
column10: what we're not going to do is provide services to an event
column12: which is the wedding itself. And I think that's the distinction point that people have been pointing to
column14: because mainstream Christianity teaches that marriage is between one man and one woman. People feel very strongly about that. And to ask someone to individually provide services to something of that nature
column15: I think violates their religious liberty.

column1: There's a big question lurking here
column2: which is that most Americans
column3: according to surveys
column4: now support gay marriage. A large minority of Americans still oppose gay marriage. The question is
column5: that people seem to be wrestling with
column6: is
column7: what ground do opponents of gay marriage have left to stand on? What ground should they have to stand on?

column1: First of all
column2: if the majority of Americans support gay marriage
column3: then you'll see it reflected in changes in state law
column4: which has always regulated marriage. And so at the end of the day
column5: if a majority of people in any given state in this country petition their legislature to change the definition of marriage to include the marriage of two people of the same sex
column6: that'll be the law of the land. And that is what it is. Separate from that
column7: there's a constitutional protection of religious liberty that allows people to live by the tenets of their faith both in their public and in private life. That doesn't mean that you're allowed to go in and disrupt a gay wedding. But by the same token
column8: it doesn't mean that someone's allowed to come to you and force you to be a participant in a ceremony that violates the tenets of your faith. And to be honest
column11: a same-sex couple doesn't want a florist or a photographer at their wedding that doesn't agree with the choice that they've made. So we're really talking about an issue that in large part is really not going to manifest itself in daily life
column12: but in the instances that it does
column13: there are individuals that don't want to be compelled by force of law to participate in an event that puts them in the position of violating their religious faith. There's a difference between that and discriminating against an individual because of who they are.

column1: Are there are other specific situations on your mind where you feel that people who are opposed to gay marriage would need some kind of protection from
column2: from it?

column1: Well
column2: I mean
column3: that's the one that's in the news today. Again
column4: I don't
column5: we can always sit here and engage in hypotheticals
column6: this
column8: and the other
column9: but at the end of the day
column11: that's the one that's emerged because there's real cases behind people being fined for not providing services to a
column12: to a ceremony as opposed to individuals.

column1: When we spoke last year
column2: we talked about immigration
column3: an issue on which you worked for a time on an immigration reform bill. You said
column4: first
column5: the reason to do that is not political
column6: it's substantive. But
column8: that there would be a political effect. That if the Republican Party deals with immigration
column9: it would then have an opportunity to talk with Latino voters about other issues. And
column11: this is a voter group where Republicans have done very poorly in recent elections. Immigration hasn't been dealt with. What are the likely consequences for the Republican party in 2016?

column1: Well
column2: again
column3: every candidate has a different position on where they stand on the issue. From my perspective
column4: I continue to believe it's an issue we need to address. The only point I've made is that I think the lessons of the last couple of years
column5: for me
column6: is that we're not going to be able to deal with it in one big piece of legislation. I still think we need to do immigration reform. I just don't think you can do it in a comprehensive
column8: given the lack of trust that there is today in the federal government. I honestly believe that the key to moving forward on immigration is to first and foremost prove to the American people that we are going to bring future illegal immigration under control — that if we legalize 12 million people
column9: they won't be replaced by 12 million more who are here illegally. And I honestly believe
column10: given my experiences on this issue now
column12: the American people and the majority of Republicans and conservatives will be very reasonable and
column13: and responsible about how we address the reality that we have 12 million human beings living in this country illegally.

column1: But we're in a circumstance
column2: granted there's still time
column3: but we're in a circumstance where it doesn't look like immigration legislation is going to get through Congress before 2016. What does that mean for your party?

column1: And I think
column2: I think it's nearly – well
column3: I just outlined to you what I think the key is to moving forward. And I think that's impossible as long as Barack Obama's president now
column4: because on two instances
column5: particularly very recently
column6: last year
column7: he issued an executive order ordering federal agencies not to enforce immigration law. So if I'm telling you that the key to moving forward is the enforcement of immigration law
column8: then that says the notion that future illegal immigration will be brought under control
column9: and you have a president that's ordering agencies not to enforce immigration law
column12: that future illegal immigration will be brought under control
column13: as long as Barack Obama's president

column1: How do you keep from getting hammered on that in a general election where the Hispanic vote may be very important?
Well
column2: I don't know about the others
column3: but I've done more immigration than Hillary Clinton ever did. I mean
column4: I helped pass an immigration bill in a Senate dominated by Democrats. And that's more than she's ever done. She's given speeches on it
column5: but she's never done anything on it. So I have a record of trying to do something on it. It didn't work because at the end of the day
column6: we did not sufficiently address the issue of
column7: of illegal immigration and I warned about that throughout that process
column8: as well
column9: that I didn't think we were doing enough to give that bill a chance of moving forward in the House.

column1: Does your biography help?
I think biography's part of all of our lives
column2: all of our candidacies
column3: because it certainly influences how you view the country and how you view issues. I have a personal attachment to the working class because it's where I come from
column4: it's still the neighborhood I live in
column5: it's the people my children go to school with
column6: it's the community that I'm involved in. And
column7: but I also happen to think it's the identity of our country. And every candidate
column8: you know
column9: will bring to bear their experiences in life and how it's guided them and influenced their thinking
column11: I think it matters simply because it informs me on my policy decisions.

column1: There's a big question here
column2: also
column3: because the Republican party
column4: as many people have noted
column5: faces a demographic challenge that gets a little worse with every election cycle. Growing groups in society
column6: such as Latinos and others
column8: and Republican voter groups
column10: are getting smaller. What's the Republican Party need to do about that?

column1: Well
column2: at the end
column3: I don't think people go to the ballot box and say
column4: I'm a Latino
column5: therefore I'm voting Democrat. I think they bring with them their hopes and fears about the future
column6: and they vote for whoever they think best understands them. And the challenge the Republican Party has had is unfairly
column8: they've been portrayed as a party that doesn't care about people who are trying to make it. A disproportionate number of people who are trying to make it
column10: who are out there working for a living at $18 an hour
column12: happen to also be people from minority communities. And if you think someone doesn't care or understand people like you
column13: no matter what your policies are
column14: it's going to be difficult to get them to listen to you
column15: much less vote for you. And so I hope the Republican Party can become the champion of the working class because I think our policy proposals of limited government and free enterprise are better for the people who are trying to make it than big government is. The fact is that big government helps the people who have made it. If you can afford to hire an army of lawyers
column16: lobbyists and others to help you navigate and sometimes influence the law
column17: you'll benefit. And so that's why you see big banks
column19: keep winning. And everybody else is stuck and being left behind.

column1: So you're beginning this gigantic game of Survivor with who knows how many other candidates. You're smiling as I say that. With who knows how many other candidates
column2: what will determine who survives ultimately and how will you make sure it's you?

column1: Well
column2: there are basics about any campaign. Obviously you'll have to put time into it
column3: you'll have to be able to raise sufficient funds to communicate your message. And on a daily basis
column4: you have to make sure you do the best you can to help convince people in a crowded field that you're the best person at this time for the job that you seek. But beyond it
column5: I really think the key is
column6: who can inspire our country into believing that the future doesn't have to be worse than our past
column7: that the 21st century can be better than the 20th. And then once you've inspired them to believe that
column8: showing them how we can accomplish it. And I feel very confident in our ability to do it and I think that's why we're going to win.

column1: Should I think of this as an insurgent campaign
column2: because you don't have the resources of Jeb Bush
column3: particularly?

column1: Well
column2: I think our resources will be sufficient to do the job we're trying to do. At the end of the day
column3: this is not a fundraising competition in and of itself. You also have to have a message and a messenger and a policy outline that proves to people that
column4: that your campaign is better for them than what someone else is offering. But I'm certainly not the frontrunner and — but that's O.K. The election isn't tomorrow.

column1: What are you doing to make sure you don't run out of money?
(Laughs) We're going to
column2: we
column3: we're trying to raise as much money as we can and that's important. As long as the media outlets keep charging us for advertising
column4: we'll have to keep raising money.

column1: Senator Rubio
column2: thanks very much.
