column1: 0	"Money woes in the most populous US state have given birth to an impromptu trading market for the newest of American financial instruments – the California IOU.
Encumbered by a $26bn (£16bn) budget shortfall and a seemingly intractable political stalemate
column2: California's state government is issuing IOUs to businesses
column3: health clinics
column4: college students and taxpayers who are owed money by the state.

column1: The green documents look like any ordinary cheque except for the words ""registered warrant"" stamped in the corner. They carry a 3.75% interest rate and can be cashed in October
column2: by which time California's governor
column3: Arnold Schwarzenegger
column4: is hoping that he will have some money.

column1: Entrepreneurs have been quick to leap on the phenomenon
column2: with Craigslist and eBay cluttered with offers. A website
column3: BuyMyIOU.com
column4: aims to match sellers of the warrants with buyers eager to snap up the above-market interest rate.

column1: The market's at an early stage – we're really in the infancy of it right now
column2: said Mark Granger
column3: president of Pacific West Managers
column4: a finance company offering to buy IOUs. ""It's a little unusual to see the state of California resorting to paying its bills like this.""

column1: California is the world's eighth largest economy but its financial situation is grave. The once booming property market has been hit catastrophically by foreclosures and its wealthy elite have seen their income wiped out by stockmarket woes. Usually 1% of the population contribute 50% of income tax revenue
column2: but the capital gains of these rich individuals have evaporated.

column1: Dismal relations between Democrats and Republicans have all but frozen business in the state capital
column2: Sacramento. A two-thirds majority is required to pass any budget
column3: but Republicans
column4: with just over a third of the legislature
column5: are refusing to countenance tax rises while the Democrats are balking at spending cuts.

column1: Schwarzenegger has proposed deep cuts to social programmes
column2: including aid for the elderly
column3: disabled and impoverished
column4: plus cuts to schools
column5: healthcare and universities. Larry Gerston
column6: a professor of political science at San José State University
column7: says this will accentuate an already yawning gap between the rich and poor: ""The state is quickly becoming an hourglass economy. The middle class is all but evaporating – people are either moving further to the top or sinking to the bottom.""

column1: The initial victims of the standoff are California's creditors
column2: who had received 91
column3: 000 IOUs worth $354m as of the end of Thursday. High-street banks
column4: including Bank of America
column5: Wells Fargo and JP Morgan Chase
column6: agreed to cash them for a few days but announced that they would not accept them beyond the end of the week.

column1: There's a sentiment inside the banks that the longer they accept the warrants
column2: the longer the budget impasse will go on
column3: said Beth Mills
column4: a spokeswoman for the Californian Bankers Association.

column1: That leaves IOU holders with limited options. Certain local credit unions are still taking the notes at face value. Beyond that
column2: holders face a choice of either waiting until October to receive their money or selling them at a discount on a rapidly developing informal market.

column1: Many online offers for the IOUs propose dubious rates. On eBay
column2: one buyer was willing to pay $140 in return for $170 worth of IOUs. Granger
column3: whose firm sees the debt crisis as a potentially lucrative opportunity
column4: said a market rate was emerging of between 80 and 95 cents on the dollar. ""Because they're cumbersome and troublesome to deal with
column5: a lot of the big investment houses are not going to deal with them
column6: he said. ""And some people will just put them in their piggy banks.""

column1: Last week
column2: the credit agency Fitch cut its rating on California's debt by two notches from ""A minus"" to BBB - just two levels above ""junk"" status. Analysts fear that there could be weeks of IOUs to come.

column1: Gerston says a confrontational culture of extreme left-wing and right-wing politics has contributed to the morass
column2: as has a reluctance to wake up to problems: ""Californians are known as laidback for a reason they've earned that reputation. Most people just don't believe what's in front of them. They just don't buy it."""	['https://i.guim.co.uk/img/static/sys-images/Guardian/Pix/pictures/2008/09/24/0924_cali_460x276.jpg?width=300&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=3fb839c8149f20f68340a4b24832fdea'

column1: 0	"Published on Sep 20

column2: the Reagan reelection campaign set the standard for modern political advertising with its fabled ""Morning in America"" series
column3: which included one of the greatest political ads of all time -- ""Better
column4: Prouder
column5: Stronger."" The ad captured the zeitgeist -- America under President Reagan was coming back
column6: full of optimism and confidence in the future.

column1: Today
column2: the zeitgeist is exactly the opposite. Americans are worried about their future
column3: and about a government determined to implement policies that just don't work. But like its predecessor
column4: ""Mourning in America"" offers a new hope -- if we can just get our government to return to time-tested policies that can spark a rebirth of liberty."	['http://www.youtube.com/yts/img/pixel-vfl3z5WfW.gif'
column5: 'https://i.ytimg.com/vi/_YXqf_6ug54/hqdefault.jpg']	https://i.ytimg.com/vi/_YXqf_6ug54/hqdefault.jpg	Mourning in America	http://www.youtube.com

column1: 0	"""Yesterday
column2: Republican primary voters nominated me for another term in the U.S. Senate. I’m honored by their support. Now
column3: I have the privilege of standing before all the voters of Arizona and appealing for your support in the general election. As always
column4: I consider myself fortunate to be subject to your judgment.""I never had a hometown growing up. My dad was in the Navy and we moved every couple years. Arizona is the best home I’ve ever had
column5: and serving Arizonans in the Senate is the best job and greatest privilege anyone could ask for. Thank you from the bottom of my heart.""No matter which side of the presidential election you’re on
column6: whether you’re satisfied or dissatisfied with your choices for president
column7: this election is an important one. Hugely consequential issues are at stake.""How can we help build a stronger economy? The great promise of America is we can all go as far as our industry
column8: talent and dreams take us. But for some Americans
column9: that promise doesn’t seem as certain as it did for previous generations. We need to make different choices – right away -- to get the kind of economic growth that offers the dignity of honest work and a fair chance to prosper to all Americans
column10: no matter where they started in life""How can we make safer a world that’s become much more dangerous in recent years? Will we have the strength and wisdom to face down challenges from old adversaries
column11: and the courage and confidence to defeat the scourge of terrorism on our watch?""How can we be secure in our own country? We need more control over our borders
column12: but also smarter immigration policies that enforce the law and reflect our values.""We need a healthcare system that provides what Obamacare promised but failed to deliver
column14: affordable and reliable.""We need to keep our promises to veterans
column15: to care generously for the health and welfare of those who risked everything to keep their promises to us.""My opponent
column17: is a good person. But if Hillary Clinton is elected president
column18: Arizona will need a Senator who will act as a check - not a rubber stamp.""Ann Kirkpatrick won’t oppose higher taxes. She won’t oppose more federal spending. And she won’t oppose increased debts that slow economic growth. She won’t offer alternatives that trust in the innovation and industry of the American people and create jobs with a future. I will.""She won’t insist that our military has the resources it needs to defend us from the many dangerous
column19: complex threats we face. I will.""She won’t exercise her right to advise and consent on presidential appointments to make sure we don’t have the wrong people in important jobs or Supreme Court Justices who will take the courts to liberal extremes. I will.""She won’t support replacing the failed healthcare policies of the incumbent administration. I will. She said her vote for Obamacare was her proudest. She still maintains that even as 10
column20: 000 people in Pinal County face the prospect of losing their insurance because the system won’t work as promised.""I voted against Obamacare and will continue to support efforts to replace it with a health care plan that work for everyone.""These are some of the most important issues facing Arizona - but not the only important issues to be decided in the coming months. On each of these critical issues
column21: I promise to do my best for the people who have done so much for me
column22: and to give voice to the voiceless.""I won’t get everything right. No one does. But I’ll use all the knowledge I’ve acquired from experience
column23: and all the strength I have to help make Arizona and America a stronger
column25: more prosperous home for all of us.""Thank you."" Show less"	['https://www.youtube.com/pagead/viewthroughconversion/962985656/?backend=innertube&cname=1&cver=1_20200404&data=backend%3Dinnertube%3Bcname%3D1%3Bcver%3D1_20200404%3Bptype%3Dcview%3Btype%3Dcview%3Butuid%3DEyLs_rjU7gwtUNJR4wtjEQ&foc_id=EyLs_rjU7gwtUNJR4wtjEQ&label=followon_cvisit&ptype=cview'

column1: 0	"Snoop Dogg
column2: major pothead and advocate of violence as a form of protest
column3: has landed in hot water over his video “Lavender
column4: ” in which he shoots Donald Trump. In the video
column5: the rapper shoots a clown version of President Trump with a toy gun
column6: but that’s not what got him in trouble.

column1: After the story went viral
column2: a reporter from Breitbart caught up with Snoop Dogg and asked him if he believed violence was the answer. His response was chilling. He said:

column1: “No
column2: man. I don’t like violence any more than the next guy
column3: but I would hope that if this clown in the White House was about to start a war or somethin’ that someone would do what I did but with a real gun. I know I would and I would encourage anyone who could get close enough to do the same. That’s not violence…it’s survival of the species.”

column1: The reporter
column2: Glen Dingusman
column3: immediately contacted the Secret Service with his evidence of violent threats made against the president and Snoop Dogg
column4: who was on his way into a restaurant for lunch when the exchange happened
column5: never made it past his hot wing appetizer.

column1: According to the agency
column2: he will be held as a military combatant without being charged until they can ascertain whether or not he’s a threat to the president. At the very least
column3: this should teach him and some other dumb liberals a good lesson about what happens in Trump’s America if you say and do stupid crap.

column1: 0	"This is the transcript of the debate between Democratic presidential candidates Sens. Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama on February 21
column2: 2008 at the University of Texas in Austin.

column1: Sens. Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton face off in a high-stakes debate
column2: Thursday night. more photos »

column1: CNN's CAMPBELL BROWN: And the candidates have taken their seats. We are ready to get started. On behalf of CNN
column2: Univision and the candidates
column3: we want to thank our hosts
column4: the University of Texas and the LBJ School and Library.

column1: And now I want to give you an idea of what to expect over the next 90 minutes or so. We want to have a real conversation between these two candidates on the issues important to Texas and the entire nation
column2: so we won't have any hard and fast rules for them to follow. We simply ask the candidates to keep their answers to a reasonable length and to stay on point.

column1: And we have given the candidates the opportunity to make opening statements. The order was determined by a draw. Senator Obama won the draw and elected to go second.
So please go ahead
column2: Senator Clinton.

column1: SEN. HILLARY CLINTON: Well
column2: thank you.

column1: And I am just delighted to be back here in Austin. You know
column2: nearly 36 years ago I came to Austin for my very first political job
column3: and that was registering voters in south Texas. And I had the great privilege of living for a while in Austin and in San Antonio
column4: and meeting people and making friends that have stayed with me for a lifetime.

column1: And I found that we had a lot in common
column2: a lot of shared values
column3: a belief that hard work is important
column4: that self-reliance and individual responsibility count for a lot.

column1: CLINTON: And among the people whom I got to know
column2: who became not only friends
column3: but heroes
column4: were Barbara Jordan
column5: who taught me a lot about courage
column6: and today...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
...would actually be her birthday. I remember all the time about how she got up every single morning
column2: facing almost insurmountable odds
column3: to do what she did.

column1: And another was my great friend Ann Richards
column2: who taught me so much...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... about determination. Ann was a great champion for the people of Texas. She also reminded us that every so often it is good to have a laugh about what it is we're engaged in.
And as I think back on those years and the work that I've done ever since
column2: you know
column3: for me politics is about making real differences in people's lives. I am very
column4: very proud that over these years I have been able to make a difference in the lives of people in Texas
column5: Ohio and elsewhere.

column1: CLINTON: You know
column3: 000 children in Texas get health care every month because I helped to start the Children's Health Insurance Program.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And 21
column2: 000 National Guard and Reserve members get access to health care because I went across the party line and joined up with a Republican senator to make that happen.

column1: So there's a lot that we've already done. But there's so much more to do.
I want to take on the tough issues that face us now. I want to stop the health insurance companies from discriminating against people because they're sick. You know
column2: it's unconstitutional to discriminate on the basis of race or gender or ethnic origin or religion
column3: but it's OK to discriminate against sick people.

column1: And we're going to end that
column2: because it's time we said no more.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And I want to continue the work that I've done in the Senate to take care of our veterans.
CLINTON: It was shocking and shameful
column2: what happened
column3: that we discovered about a year ago at Walter Reed. We can do so much better
column4: to take care of the people who've taken care of us.

column1: And there is a lot of work ahead. I offer a lifetime of experience and proven results. And I know that
column2: if we work together
column3: we can take on the special interests
column4: transfer $55 billion of all those giveaways and subsidies that President Bush has given them
column5: back to the middle class
column6: to create jobs and provide health care and make college affordable.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And I ask you -- I ask you to join in my campaign. It's now up to the people of Texas
column2: Ohio
column3: and the other states ahead.

column1: So
column2: if you'll be part of this campaign
column3: which is your really your campaign
column4: about your futures
column5: your families
column6: your jobs and your health care
column7: we'll continue to make a difference for America.

column1: Thank you all very much.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Clinton
column2: thank you.

column1: BROWN: Senator Obama?
(APPLAUSE)
SEN. BARACK OBAMA: First of all
column2: thank you so much to the University of Texas for hosting us
column3: and it's a great honor to share the stage once again with Senator Clinton. I've said before that we've been friends before this campaign started; we'll be friends afterwards
column4: unified to bring about changes in this country.

column1: You know
column2: we are at a defining moment in our history. Our nation is at war
column3: and our economy is increasingly in shambles. And the families of Texas and all across America are feeling the brunt of that failing economy.

column1: This week
column2: I met a couple in San Antonio
column3: who -- as a consequence of entering into a predatory loan -- are on the brink of foreclosure and are actually seeing them having to cut back on their medical expenses
column4: because their mortgage doubled in two weeks.

column1: OBAMA: I've met a young woman who gets three hours of sleep a night because she has to work the night shift even as she's going to school full time
column2: and still can't afford to provide the health care for her sister who's ill.

column1: In Youngstown
column2: Ohio
column3: talked to workers who have seen their plants shipped overseas as a consequence of bad trade deals like NAFTA
column4: literally seeing equipment unbolted from the floors of factories and shipped to China
column5: resulting in devastating job losses and communities completely falling apart.

column1: And all across America I'm meeting not just veterans
column2: but also the parents of those who have fallen.

column1: One mother in Green Bay gave me this bracelet in memory of a 20- year-old son who had been killed in a roadside bomb
column2: as a consequence of a war that I believe should have never been authorized and should have never been waged and has cost us billions of dollars that could have been invested here in the United States in roads and bridges and infrastructure and making sure that young people can go to college and that those who need health care actually get it.

column1: OBAMA: Now
column2: Senator Clinton...

column1: (APPLAUSE)

... Senator Clinton and I have been talking about these issues for the last 13 months. We both offer detailed proposals to try to deal with them. Some of them are the same. Some we have differences of opinion.

But I think we both recognize that these problems have to be dealt with and that we have seen an administration over the last seven years that has failed to address them and -- in many ways -- has made them worse.
But understand that what is lacking right now is not good ideas.
OBAMA: The problem we have is that Washington has become a place where good ideas go to die. They go to die because the lobbyists...
(APPLAUSE)

They go to die because lobbyists and special interests have a strangle-hold on the agenda in Washington. They go to die in Washington because too many politicians are interested in scoring political points rather than bridging differences in order to get things done.
And so the central premise of this campaign is that we can bring this country together
column2: that we can push against the special interests that have come to dominate the agenda in Washington
column3: that we can be straight with the American people about how we're going to solve these problems and enlist them in taking back their government.

column1: You know
column2: Senator Clinton mentioned Barbara Jordan
column3: somebody who was an inspiration to me and so many people throughout the country. And she said that what the American people want is very simple: They want an America that is as good as its promise.

column1: OBAMA: I'm running for president because I want to help America be as good as its promise.
Thank you very much.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right
column2: Senator Obama
column3: thank you
column4: and let's begin with questions.

column1: Jorge Ramos?
UNIVISION's JORGE RAMOS: Thank you very much (SPEAKING IN SPANISH).
Thank you so much for being with us
column2: and let me start with a little news. After nearly half a century in office
column3: Fidel Castro resigned as the head of the Cuban government. Ninety miles off the coast of the United States
column4: we might have a new opportunity.

column1: The question for you
column2: Senator Clinton: Would you be willing to sit down with Raul Castro
column3: or whoever leads the Cuban dictatorship when you take office at least just once
column4: to get a measure of the man?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: Jorge
column3: I hope we have an opportunity. The people of Cuba deserve to have a democracy. And this gives the Cuban government
column4: under Raul Castro
column5: a chance to change direction from the one that was set for 50 years by his brother.

column1: I'm going to be looking for some of those changes: releasing political prisoner
column2: ending some of the oppressive practices on the press
column3: opening up the economy.

column1: Of course the United States stands ready. And
column2: as president
column3: I would be ready to reach out and work with a new Cuban government
column4: once it demonstrated that it truly was going to change that direction.

column1: I want to bring the region together
column2: our European allies who have influence with Cuba
column3: to try to push for some of those changes
column4: and to make it very clear that
column5: if Cuba moves toward democracy and freedom for its people
column6: the United States will welcome that.

column1: CLINTON: And as president
column2: I would look for opportunities to try to make that happen and to create the momentum that might eventually lead to a presidential visit.

column1: But there has to be evidence that indeed the changes are real; that they are taking place; and that the Cuban people will finally be given an opportunity to have their future determined by themselves.
RAMOS: Very simply
column2: would you meet with him or not
column3: with Raul Castro?

column1: CLINTON: I would not meet with him until there was evidence that change was happening
column2: because I think it's important that they demonstrate clearly that they are committed to change the direction. Then I think
column3: you know
column4: something like diplomatic encounters and negotiations over specifics could take place.

column1: But we've had this conversation before
column2: Senator Obama and myself
column3: and I believe that we should have full diplomatic engagement where appropriate. But a presidential visit should not be offered and given without some evidence that it will demonstrate the kind of progress that is in our interest
column4: and in this case
column5: in the interests of the Cuban people.

column1: BROWN: Senator Obama
column2: just to follow up
column3: you had said in a previous CNN debate that you would meet with the leaders of Cuban
column4: Iran
column5: North Korea
column6: among others
column7: so presumably you would be willing to meet with the new leader of Cuba.

column1: OBAMA: That's correct. Now
column2: keep in mind that the starting point for our policy in Cuba should be the liberty of the Cuban people. And I think we recognize that that liberty has not existed throughout the Castro regime. And we now have an opportunity to potentially change the relationship between the United States and Cuba after over half a century.

column1: I would meet without preconditions
column2: although Senator Clinton is right that there has to be preparation. It is very important for us to make sure that there was an agenda
column3: and on that agenda was human rights
column4: releasing of political prisoners
column5: opening up the press. And that preparation might take some time.

column1: But I do think that it's important for the United States not just to talk to its friends
column2: but also to talk to its enemies. In fact
column3: that's where diplomacy makes the biggest difference.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: One other thing that I've said
column2: as a show of good faith that we're interested in pursuing potentially a new relationship
column3: what I've called for is a loosening of the restrictions on remittances from family members to the people of Cuba
column4: as well as travel restrictions for family members who want to visit their family members in Cuba.

column1: And I think that initiating that change in policy as a start and then suggesting that an agenda get set up is something that could be useful
column2: but I would not normalize relations until we started seeing some of the progress that Senator Clinton was talking about.

column1: BROWN: But that's different from your position back in 2003. You called U.S. policy toward Cuba a miserable failure
column2: and you supported normalizing relations.

column1: BROWN: So you've backtracked now...
OBAMA: I support the eventual normalization. And it's absolutely true that I think our policy has been a failure. I mean
column2: the fact is
column3: is that during my entire lifetime
column4: and Senator Clinton's entire lifetime
column5: you essentially have seen a Cuba that has been isolated
column6: but has not made progress when it comes to the issues of political rights and personal freedoms that are so important to the people of Cuba.

column1: So I think that we have to shift policy. I think our goal has to be ultimately normalization. But that's going to happen in steps. And the first step
column2: as I said
column3: is changing our rules with respect to remittances and with respect to travel.

column1: And then I think it is important for us to have the direct contact
column2: not just in Cuba
column3: but I think this principle applies generally. I recall what John F. Kennedy once said
column4: that we should never negotiate out of fear
column5: but we should never fear to negotiate. And this moment
column6: this opportunity when Fidel Castro has finally stepped down
column8: is one that we should try to take advantage of.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Clinton
column2: do you want a quick response?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I agree
column3: absolutely
column4: that we should be willing to have diplomatic negotiations and processes with anyone. I've been a strong advocate of opening up such a diplomatic process with Iran
column5: for a number of years.

column1: Because I think we should look for ways that we can possibly move countries that are adversarial to us
column2: you know
column3: toward the world community. It's in our interests. It's in the interests of the people in countries that
column4: frankly
column5: are oppressed
column6: like Cuba

column1: But there has been this difference between us over when and whether the president should offer a meeting
column2: without preconditions
column3: with those with whom we do not have diplomatic relations. And it should be part of a process
column4: but I don't think it should be offered in the beginning. Because I think that undermines the capacity for us to actually take the measure of somebody like Raul Castro or Ahmadinejad and others.

column1: CLINTON: And
column2: as President Kennedy said
column3: he wouldn't be afraid to negotiate
column4: but he would expect there to be a lot of preparatory work done
column5: to find out exactly what we would get out of it.

column1: And therefore
column2: I do think we should be eliminating the policy of the Bush administration
column3: which has been very narrowly defined
column4: and frankly against our interests
column5: because we have failed to reach out to countries
column6: we have alienated our friends
column7: and we have emboldened our enemies.

column1: So I would get back to very vigorous diplomacy
column2: and I would use bipartisan diplomacy. I would ask emissaries from both political parties to represent me and our country
column3: because I want to send a very clear message to the rest of the world that the era of unilateralism
column4: preemption and arrogance of the Bush administration is over and we're going to...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Very briefly and then we're going to move on.
(APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: I think
column2: as I said before
column3: preparation is actually absolutely critical in any meeting. And I think it is absolutely true that either of us would step back from some of the Bush unilateralism that's caused so much damage.

column1: But I do think it is important precisely because the Bush administration has done so much damage to American foreign relations that the president take a more active role in diplomacy than might have been true 20 or 30 years ago.
Because the problem is
column2: if we think that meeting with the president is a privilege that has to be earned
column3: I think that reinforces the sense that we stand above the rest of the world at this point in time. And I think that it's important for us in undoing the damage that has been done over the last seven years
column4: for the president to be willing to take that extra step.

column1: OBAMA: That is the kind of step that I would like to take as president of the United States.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: A question now on the economy.
John King?
CNN's JOHN KING: Campbell
column2: Senators
column3: good evening
column4: first.

column1: I want to bring the conversation back home. You know from your travels -- you don't need to look at the polls or anything else -- that the economy is by far now the dominant issue that voters want to hear about from the candidates.
For some
column2: that is a question about: What should we do about an economy that is at the edge or perhaps in the early stages of a recession? For some
column3: it is more focused. Maybe it is: Will you raise the minimum wage? Maybe it's about trade deals that they think leave them on the raw end
column4: as you mentioned in your opening statement
column5: Senator Obama.

column1: But when we ask Democrats
column2: ""How are these two candidates different?
column3: they even think they don't know.

column1: Senator Obama
column2: beginning with you
column3: tell us as specifically as you can
column4: how would a President Obama be different than a President Clinton in managing the nation's economy?

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: first of all
column3: let me emphasize the point that you just made
column4: which is: You don't need an economist or the Federal Reserve to tell the American people that the economy's in trouble
column5: because they've been experiencing it for years now.

column1: Everywhere you go
column2: you meet people who are working harder for less
column3: wages and incomes have flatlined
column4: people are seeing escalating costs of everything from health care to gas at the pump.

column1: And so people have been struggling for a long time. In some communities
column2: they have been struggling for decades now. So this has to be a priority of the next president.

column1: Now
column2: what I've said is that we have to restore a sense of fairness and balance to our economy
column3: and that means a couple of things.

column1: Number one
column2: with our tax code: We've got to stop giving tax breaks to companies that are shipping jobs overseas and invest those tax breaks in companies that are investing here in the United States of America.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
We have to end the Bush tax cuts to the wealthy...
(APPLAUSE)
... and to provide tax breaks to middle-class Americans and working Americans who need them.
OBAMA: So I've said that if you are making $75
column2: 000 a year or less
column3: I want to give an offset to your payroll tax that will mean $1
column4: 000 extra in the pockets of ordinary Americans. Senior citizens making less than $50
column6: you shouldn't have to pay income tax on your Social Security.

column1: We pay for these by closing tax loopholes and tax havens that are being manipulated.
(APPLAUSE)
On our trade deals
column2: I think it is absolutely critical that we engaged in trade
column3: but it has to be viewed not just through the lens of Wall Street
column4: but also Main Street
column5: which means we've got strong labor standards and strong environmental standards and safety standards
column6: so we don't have toys being shipped in the United States with lead paint on them.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
So these are all issues that I've talked about repeatedly
column2: and I think there are also opportunities in our economy around creating a green economy. We send $1 billion to foreign countries every day because of our addiction to foreign oil.

column1: OBAMA: And for us to move rapidly to cap greenhouse gases
column2: generate billions of dollars that we can reinvest in solar and wind and biodiesel -- that can put people back to work. So...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Now
column2: I don't want to take too much time. And I'm sure we'll be spend more time discussing this.

column1: Senator Clinton and I
column2: I think
column3: both agree on many of these issues. And I think it's a credit to the Democratic Party as a whole that the other candidates who were involved earlier on agreed with us on many of these issues.

column1: I think that there is a real
column2: solid agenda for moving change forward in the next presidency.

column1: The question people are going to have to ask is: How do we get it done?

And it is my strong belief that the changes are only going to come about if we're able to form a working coalition for change. Because people who were benefiting from the current tax code are going to resist. The special interests and lobbyists are going to resist.
And I think it has to be a priority for whoever the next president is to be able to overcome the dominance of the special interests in Washington
column2: to bring about the kinds of economic changes that I'm talking about.

column1: OBAMA: And that's an area where Senator Clinton and I may have a slight difference. But I'm happy to let her speak first and then can pick up on anything that's been left out.
KING: Let's give Senator Clinton that opportunity then.
(APPLAUSE)
As you have campaigned
column2: Senator
column3: on this issue and others
column4: but specifically on this issue
column5: you have said
column6: ""I am ready on day one to take charge of the economy.""

column1: The clear implication
column2: since you have one opponent at the moment
column3: is that you're ready; he's not.

column1: What would you do differently on day one than a President Obama would when it comes to managing the nation's economy?
CLINTON: Well
column2: I would agree with a lot that Senator Obama just said
column3: because it is the Democratic agenda.

column1: CLINTON: We are going to rid the tax code of these loopholes and giveaways.
We're going to stop giving a penny of your money to anybody who ships a job out of Texas
column2: Ohio or anywhere else to another country.

column1: We're certainly going to begin to get the tax code to reflect what the needs of middle class families are so we can rebuild a strong and prosperous middle class.
You know
column2: the wealthy and the well-connected have had a president the last seven years
column3: and I think it's time that the rest of America had a president to work for you every single day.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
We will also have a different approach toward trade.
We're going to start having trade agreements that not only have strong environmental and labor standards
column2: but I want to have a trade time-out. We're going to look and see what's working and what's not working
column3: and I'd like to have a trade prosecutor to actually enforce the trade agreements that we have before we enter into any others.

column1: We're also going to put much tougher standards in place so that people cannot import toys with lead paint
column2: contaminated pet food
column3: contaminated drugs into our market. We're going to have much more vigorous enforcement of safety standards.

column1: CLINTON: Now
column2: in addition
column3: there are steps I would take immediately. One is on this foreclosure crisis. I have been saying for nearly a year we had to crack down on the abusive practices of the lenders. But we also need a moratorium on home foreclosures.

column1: Everywhere I go
column2: I meet people who either have been or about to lose their home. 85
column3: 000 homes in foreclosure in Texas; 90
column4: 000 in Ohio. I've met the families: the hairdresser
column5: the single mom who's going to lose her home
column6: the postal worker who got really hoodwinked into an agreement that wasn't fair to him.

column1: So I would put a moratorium for 90 days
column2: to give us time to work out a way for people to stay in their homes
column3: and I would freeze interest rates for five years. Because these adjustable-rate mortgages
column4: if they keep going up
column5: millions of Americans are going to be homeless. And vacant homes will be across the neighborhoods of Texas and America.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: Now
column2: in addition
column3: there are three ways we need to jump start the economy.

column1: Clean green jobs; I've been promoting this. I wanted it to be part of the stimulus package. I thought a $5 billion investment in clean green jobs would put hundreds of thousands of Americans to work helping to create our future.
We also need to invest in our infrastructure. We don't have enough roads to take care of the congestion
column2: we have crumbling bridges and tunnels. We need to rebuild America
column3: and that will also put people to work.

column1: And
column2: finally
column3: we need to end George Bush's war on science
column4: which has been waged against scientists and researchers...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Thank you
column2: Senator. And we've got a lot of ground to cover...

column1: CLINTON: This is about how we fund the future. We've got to get back to being the innovation nation. Think of everything that goes on at this great university to create the new economy...
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right. Senator Clinton
column2: thank you very much.

column1: BROWN: And
column2: as I was saying
column3: we've got a lot to get through. So I do want to shift gears and go on to another topic especially important here in Texas
column4: which is immigration.

column1: And
column2: Jorge
column3: you have a question.

column1: RAMOS: (SPEAKING IN SPANISH) Federal raids by immigration enforcement officials on homes and businesses have generated a great deal of fear and anxiety in the Hispanic community and have divided the family of some of the 3 million U.S.-born children who have at least one undocumented parent.
Would you consider stopping these raids once you take office until comprehensive immigration reform can be passed?
CLINTON: I would consider that
column2: except in egregious situations where it would be appropriate to take the actions you're referring to.

column1: But when we see what's been happening
column2: with literally babies being left with no one to take care of them
column3: children coming home from school
column4: no responsible adult left
column5: that is not the America that I know.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: That is against American values. And it is...
(APPLAUSE)

And it is a stark admission of failure by the federal government. We need comprehensive immigration reform. I have been for this. I signed onto the first comprehensive bill back in 2004. I've been advocating for it: tougher
column2: more secure borders
column3: of course
column4: but let's do it the right way
column5: cracking down on employers
column6: especially once we get to comprehensive immigration reform
column7: who exploit undocumented workers and drive down wages for everyone else.

column1: I'd like to see more federal help for communities like Austin and others like Laredo
column2: where I was this morning
column3: that absorb the health care
column4: education
column5: and law enforcement costs.

column1: And I personally
column2: as president
column3: would work with our neighbors to the south
column4: to help them create more jobs for their own people.

column1: Finally
column2: we need a path to legalization
column3: to bring the immigrants out of the shadows
column4: give them the conditions that we expect them to meet
column5: paying a fine for coming here illegally
column6: trying to pay back taxes
column8: and learning English.

column1: If they had a committed a crime in our country or the country they came from
column2: then they should be deported. But for everyone else
column3: there must be a path to legalization. I would introduce that in the first 100 days of my presidency.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Obama
column2: is your position the same as Hillary Clinton's?

column1: OBAMA: There are a couple of things I would add. Comprehensive immigration reform is something that I have worked on extensively.
Two years ago
column2: we were able to get a bill out of the Senate. I was one of the group of senators that helped to move it through
column3: but it died in the House this year. Because it was used as a political football instead of a way of solving a problem
column4: nothing happened.

column1: And so there are a couple of things that I would just add to what Senator Clinton said.
Number one
column2: it is absolutely critical that we tone down the rhetoric when it comes to the immigration debate
column3: because there has been an undertone that has been ugly.

column1: Oftentimes
column2: it has been directed at the Hispanic community. We have seen hate crimes skyrocket in the wake of the immigration debate as it has been conducted in Washington
column3: and that is unacceptable.

column1: We are a nation of laws and we are a nation of immigrants
column2: and we can reconcile those two things. So we need comprehensive reform...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... we need comprehensive reform
column2: and that means stronger border security. It means that we are cracking down on employers that are taking advantage of undocumented workers because they can't complain if they're not paid a minimum wage.

column1: OBAMA: They can't complain if they're not getting overtime. Worker safety laws are not being observed.
We have to crack down on those employers
column2: although we also have to make sure that we do it in a way that doesn't lead to people with Spanish surnames being discriminated against
column3: so there's got to be a safeguard there.

column1: We have to require that undocumented workers
column2: who are provided a pathway to citizenship
column3: not only learn English
column4: pay back taxes and pay a significant fine
column5: but also that they're going to the back of the line
column6: so that they are not getting citizenship before those who have applied legally

column1: Number one
column2: it is important that we fix the legal immigration system
column3: because right now we've got a backlog that means years for people to apply legally.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And what's worse is
column2: we keep on increasing the fees
column3: so that if you've got a hard working immigrant family
column4: they've got to hire a lawyer; they've got to pay thousands of dollars in fees. They just can't afford it. And it's discriminatory against people who have good character
column5: we should want in this country
column6: but don't have the money. So we've got to fix that.

column1: OBAMA: So we've got to fix that.
The second thing is
column2: we have to improve our relationship with Mexico and work with the Mexican government so that their economy is producing jobs on that side of the border.

column1: And the problem that we have...
(APPLAUSE)
The problem that we have is that we have had an administration that came in promising all sorts of leadership on creating a U.S.- Mexican relationship. And
column2: frankly
column3: President Bush dropped the ball. He has been so obsessed with Iraq that we have not seen the kinds of outreach and cooperative work that would ensure that the Mexican economy is working not just for the very wealthy in Mexico
column4: but for all people. And that's as policy that I'm going to change when I'm president of the United States.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right
column2: Senator Obama.

column1: We're going to stay with this topic. I want to have John King ask another question.
Go ahead
column2: John.

column1: KING: I want to stay on the issue
column2: but move to a controversial item that was not held up when the immigration debate collapsed in Washington
column3: and that is the border fence.

column1: KING: To many Americans
column2: it is a simple question of sovereignty and security. America should be able to keep people out that it doesn't want in.

column1: But
column2: as you know in this state
column3: especially if you go to the south of here
column4: along the border
column5: and in other border states
column6: to many people it's a much more personal question. It could be a question of their livelihood. It could be a question of cross-border trade. It might be an issue to a rancher of property rights. It might be a simple question of whether someone can take a walk or a short drive to see their family members.

column1: Senator
column2: back in 2006
column3: you voted for the construction of that fence. As you know
column4: progress has been slow.

column1: As president of the United States
column2: would you commit tonight that you would finish the fence and speed up the construction
column3: or do you think it's time for a president of the United States to raise his or her hand and say
column4: ""You know what? Wait a minute. Let's think about this again. Do we really want to do this?""

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I think both Senator Obama and I voted for that as part of the immigration debate.

column1: CLINTON: And having been along the border for the last week or so -- in fact
column2: last night I was at the University of Texas at Brownsville -- and this is how absurd this has become under the Bush administration. Because
column3: you know
column4: there is a smart way to protect our borders
column5: and there is a dumb way to protect our borders.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And what I learned last night when I was there with Congressman Ortiz is that the University of Texas at Brownsville would have part of its campus cut off.

This is the kind of absurdity that we're getting from this administration. I know it because I've been fighting with them about the northern border. Their imposition of passports and other kinds of burdens are separating people from families
column2: interfering with business and commerce
column3: the movement of goods and people.

column1: So what I've said is that I would say
column2: wait a minute
column3: we need to review this. There may be places where a physical barrier is appropriate.

column1: I think when both of us voted for this
column2: we were voting for the possibility that where it was appropriate and made sense
column3: it would be considered. But as with so much
column4: the Bush administration has gone off the deep end
column5: and they are unfortunately coming up with a plan that I think is counterproductive.

column1: CLINTON: So I would have a review. I would listen to the people who live along the border
column2: who understand...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... what it is we need to be doing to protect our country.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Let me go on
column2: again -- John?

column1: KING: Does that mean that you think your vote was wrong
column2: or the implementation of it was wrong?

column1: Because
column2: as you know
column3: when they first built the fence in the San Diego area
column4: it only went so far. And what it did was it sopped the people coming straight up the path of where that was built
column5: and they simply moved. And California's problem became Arizona's problem.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
CLINTON: But
column2: you know
column3: John
column4: there is -- there's a lot we've learned about technology and smart fencing. You know
column5: there is technology that can be used instead of a physical barrier.

column1: CLINTON: It requires us having enough personnel along the border so that people can be supervising a certain limited amount of space and will be able to be responsive in the event of people attempting to cross illegally.
I think that the way that the Bush administration is going about this
column2: filing eminent domain actions against landowners and municipalities
column3: makes no sense.

column1: So what I have said is
column2: yes
column3: there are places when after a careful review
column4: again listening to the people who live along the border
column5: there may be limited places where it would work. But let's deploy more technology and personnel
column6: instead of the physical barrier.

column1: I frankly think that will work better and it will give us an opportunity to secure our borders without interfering with family relations
column2: business relations
column3: recreation and so much else that makes living along the border
column4: you know
column5: wonderful.

column1: BROWN: All right.
CLINTON: And the people who live there need to have a president who understands it
column2: will listen to them and be responsive.

column1: BROWN: All right
column2: Senator Clinton.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Senator Obama
column2: go ahead please.

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: this is an area where Senator Clinton and I almost entirely agree. I think that the key is to consult with local communities
column3: whether it's on the commercial interests or the environmental stakes of creating any kind of barrier.

column1: And the Bush administration is not real good at listening. That's not what they do well.
(LAUGHTER)
And so I will reverse that policy. As Senator Clinton indicated
column2: there may be areas where it makes sense to have some fencing. But for the most part
column3: having border patrolled
column4: surveillance
column5: deploying effective technology
column6: that's going to be the better approach.

column1: The one thing I do have to say
column2: though
column3: about this issue is
column4: it is very important for us
column5: I think
column6: to deal with this problem in terms of thousands of -- hundreds of thousands of people coming over the borders on a regular basis if we want to also provide opportunity for the 12 million undocumented workers who are here.

column1: OBAMA: Senator Clinton and I have both campaigned in places like Iowa and Ohio and my home state of Illinois
column2: and I think that the American people want fairness
column3: want justice. I think they recognize that the idea that you're going to deport 12 million people is ridiculous
column4: that we're not going to be devoting all our law enforcement resources...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... to sending people back.
But what they do also want is some order to the process. And so
column2: we're not going to be able to do these things in isolation. We're not going to be able to deal with the 12 million people who are living in the shadows and give them a way of getting out of the shadows if we don't also deal with the problem of this constant influx of undocumented workers.

column1: And that's why I think comprehensive reform is so important. That's the kind of leadership that I've shown in the past; that's the kind of leadership that I'll show in the future.
One last point I want to make on the immigration issue because we may be moving to different topics: Something that we can do immediately that I think is very important is to pass the Dream Act
column2: which allows children who through no fault of their own are here but have essentially grown up as Americans
column3: allow them the opportunity for higher education.

column1: OBAMA: I do not want two classes of citizens in this country.
(APPLAUSE)
I want everybody to prosper. That's going to be a top priority.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: OK
column2: we've got one last question on immigration.

column1: Jorge
column2: go ahead.

column1: RAMOS: (SPEAKING SPANISH) Right now
column2: there are more than 30 million people in this country who speak Spanish.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Many of them are right here. By the year 2050
column2: there will be 120 million Hispanics in the United States. Now
column3: is there any downside
column4: Senator Clinton
column5: to the United States becoming (SPEAKING SPANISH) becoming a bilingual nation? Is there a limit?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I think it's important for as many Americans as possible to do what I have never been able to do
column3: and that is learn another language and try to be bilingual because that connects us to the rest of the world.

column1: I think it is important
column2: though
column3: that English remain our common unifying language because that brings our country together in a way that we have seen generations of immigrants coming to our shores be able to be part of the American experience and pursue the American dream.

column1: You know
column2: I have been adamantly against the efforts by some to make English the official language. That I do not believe is appropriate
column3: and I have voted against it and spoken against it.

column1: CLINTON: I represent New York. We have 170 languages in New York City alone. And I do not think that we should be
column2: in any way
column3: discriminating against people who do not speak English
column4: who use facilities like hospitals or have to go to court to enforce their rights.

column1: But I do think that English does remain an important part of the American experience. So I encourage people to become bilingual. But I also want to see English remain the common
column2: unifying language of our country.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
RAMOS: Senator Obama
column2: is there any down side to the United States becoming a bilingual nation?

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: I think it is important that everyone learns English and that we have that process of binding ourselves together as a country. I think that's very important.

column1: I also think that every student should be learning a second language
column2: because...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... you know
column2: so
column3: when you start getting into a debate about bilingual education
column4: for example
column5: now
column6: I want to make sure that children who are coming out of Spanish-speaking households had the opportunity to learn and are not falling behind.

column1: OBAMA: If bilingual education helps them do that
column2: I want to give them the opportunity.

column1: But I also want to make sure that English-speaking children are getting foreign languages because this world is becoming more interdependent and part of the process of America's continued leadership in the world is going to be our capacity to communicate across boundaries
column2: across borders
column3: and that's something frankly where we've fallen behind.

column1: One of the failures of No Child Left Behind
column2: a law that I think a lot of local and state officials have been troubled by
column3: is that it is so narrowly focused on standardized tests that it has pushed out a lot of important learning that needs to take place.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And foreign languages is one of those areas that I think has been neglected. I want to put more resources into it.
BROWN: All right.
We're going to take a quick break. We've got to go to a commercial. We'll be back with a lot more. There is also a debate we should mention raging online right now. Go to our Web site
column2: CNNpolitics.com
column3: and join in. The debate here at the University of Texas in Austin continues right after this.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
BROWN: And we are back. We're here in Austin
column2: Texas
column3: the capital city. Welcome back to the Texas Democratic debate at the University of Texas
column4: Austin.

column1: The first question now goes to John King.
KING: Senator
column2: as I'm sitting here
column3: we're about 45 minutes into the discussion tonight
column4: and I'm having what I like to call one of those parallel universe moments.

column1: I've been watching each of you give speeches in arenas not unlike this one individually. And the tone is often quite different than the very polite
column2: substantive discourse we've had tonight.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
(APPLAUSE)
And so
column2: I want to ask you about that. There are times when each of you seems to call into question the other one's credibility or truthfulness.

column1: And
column2: Senator Clinton
column3: I want to talk specifically about some words you've spoken here in the state of Texas over the past couple of days.

column1: You've said
column2: quote
column3: ""My opponent gives speeches; I offer solutions.""

column1: You said the choice for Democrats in this campaign is
column2: quote
column3: ""talk versus action.""

column1: Now
column2: in a campaign that some of us are old enough to remember
column3: maybe not many of the students here
column4: this would be called the ""Where's the beef?"" question.

column1: But
column2: since we're in Texas
column3: I'd like to borrow a phrase that they often use here and you've used yourself in the context of President Bush. Are you saying that your opponent is all hat and no cattle
column4: and can you say that after the last 45 minutes?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I have said that about President Bush
column3: and I think our next president needs to be a lot less hat and a lot more cattle.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
You know
column2: I think you can tell from the first 45 minutes
column3: you know
column4: Senator Obama and I have a lot in common. We both care passionately about our country. We are devoted to public service. We care deeply about the future
column5: and we have run a very vigorous and contested primary campaign
column6: which has been by most standards
column8: very positive and extremely civil.

column1: CLINTON: But there are differences between us. And I think
column2: in our efforts to draw those contrasts and comparisons
column3: we obviously try to let voters know how we see the world differently.

column1: And I do offer solutions. That's what I believe in and what I have done. And it's what I offer to voters because it's part of my life
column2: over the last 35 years
column3: working to get kids health care
column4: working to expand legal services for the poor
column5: working to register voters
column6: working to make a difference. Because I think that this country has given me so much.

column1: And there are differences between our records and our accomplishments. I have to confess
column2: I was somewhat amused
column3: the other night
column4: when
column5: on one of the TV shows
column6: one of Senator Obama's supporters couldn't.

column1: So I know that there are comparisons and contrasts to be drawn between us. And it's important that voters get that information. So
column2: yes
column3: I do think that words are important and words matter
column4: but actions speak louder than words. And I offer...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Obama
column2: go ahead.

column1: BROWN: Senator Obama
column2: do you want to respond?

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: I think actions do speak louder than words
column3: which is why over the 20 years of my public service I have acted a lot to provide health care to people who didn't have it
column4: to provide tax breaks to families that needed it
column5: to reform a criminal justice system that had resulted in wrongful convictions
column6: to open up our government and to pass the toughest ethics reform legislation since Watergate
column7: to make sure that we create transparency...

column1: (APPLAUSE)

... to make sure that we create transparency in our government so that we know where federal spending is going and it's not going to a bunch of boondoggles and earmarks that are wasting taxpayer money that could be spent on things like early childhood education.
You know
column2: I think if you talk to those wounded warriors at Walter Reed who
column3: prior to me getting to the Senate
column4: were having to pay for their meals and have to pay for their phone calls to their family while they're recovering from amputations
column5: I think they've said that I've engaged not just in talk
column6: but in action.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: Now
column2: I think that Senator Clinton has a fine record and I don't want to denigrate that record. I do think there is a fundamental difference between us in terms of how change comes about. Senator Clinton of late has said: Let's get real. The implication is that the people who've been voting for me or involved in my campaign are somehow delusional.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
And that
column2: you know
column3: the 20 million people who've been paying attention to 19 debates and the editorial boards all across the country at newspapers who have given me endorsements
column4: including every major newspaper here in the state of Texas.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: You know
column2: the thinking is that somehow
column3: they're being duped
column4: and eventually they're going to see the reality of things.

column1: Well
column2: I think they perceive reality of what's going on in Washington very clearly. What they see is that if we don't bring the country together
column3: stop the endless bickering
column4: actually focus on solutions and reduce the special interests that have dominated Washington
column5: then we will not get anything done. And the reason that this campaign has done so well...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
The reason that this campaign has done so well is because people understand that it is not just a matter of putting forward policy positions.

OBAMA: Senator Clinton and I share a lot of policy positions. But if we can't inspire the American people to get involved in their government and if we can't inspire them to go beyond the racial divisions and the religious divisions and the regional divisions that have plagued our politics for so long
column2: then we will continue to see the kind of gridlock and nonperformance in Washington that is resulting in families suffering in very real ways.

column1: I'm running for president to start doing something about that suffering
column2: and so are the people who are behind my campaign.

column1: (APPLAUSE)

BROWN: I think one of the points -- I think one of the points that John King was alluding to in talking about some of Senator Clinton's comments is there has been a lot of attention lately on some of your speeches
column2: that they are very similar to some of the speeches by your friend and supporter Deval Patrick
column3: the governor of Massachusetts
column4: and Senator Clinton's campaign has made a big issue of this. To be blunt
column5: they've accused you of plagiarism.

column1: OBAMA: Right.
BROWN: How do you respond?
OBAMA: Well
column2: look
column3: the -- first of all
column4: it's not a lot of speeches. There are two lines in speeches that I've been giving over the last couple of weeks.

column1: I've been campaigning now for the last two years. Deval is a national co-chairman of my campaign
column2: and suggested an argument that I share
column3: that words are important. Words matter. And the implication that they don't I think diminishes how important it is to speak to the American people directly about making America as good as its promise. Barbara Jordan understood this as well as anybody.

column1: OBAMA: And the notion that I had plagiarized from somebody who was one of my national co-chairs...
(APPLAUSE)
... who gave me the line and suggested that I use it
column2: I think
column3: is silly
column4: and...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... you know
column2: this is where we start getting into silly season
column3: in politics
column4: and I think people start getting discouraged about it...

column1: (LAUGHTER)
... and they don't want...
(APPLAUSE)
What they want is
column2: how are we going to create good jobs and good wages?

column1: How are we going to provide health care to the American people?
How are we going to make sure that college is affordable?
So what I've been talking about
column2: in this speeches -- and I've got to admit
column3: some of them are pretty good.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
What I've been talking about is not just hope and not just inspiration. It's a $4
column2: 000 tuition credit for every student
column3: every year
column4: in exchange for national service...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... so that college becomes more affordable.

OBAMA: I've been talking about making sure that we change our tax code so that working families actually get relief. I have been talking about making sure that we bring an end to this war in Iraq so that we can start bringing our troops home and invest money here in the United States.
(APPLAUSE)
So just to finish up
column2: these are very specific
column3: concrete
column4: detailed proposals
column5: many of them which I have been working on for years now. Senator Clinton has a fine record. So do I. I'm happy to have a debate on the issues
column6: but what we shouldn't be spending time doing is tearing each other down. We should be spending time lifting the country up.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Clinton
column2: is it the silly season?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: I think that if your candidacy is going to be about words
column3: then they should be your own words. That's
column4: I think
column5: a very simple proposition.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And
column2: you know
column3: lifting whole passages from someone else's speeches is not change you can believe in
column4: it's change you can Xerox. And I just don't think...

column1: OBAMA: Come on.
(CROSSTALK)
CLINTON: No
column2: but
column3: you know
column4: but
column5: Barack
column6: it is.

column1: Because
column2: you know
column3: if you look -- if you look -- if you look at the YouTube of these videos
column4: it does raise questions.

column1: Now
column2: there is no doubt that you are a passionate
column3: eloquent speaker
column4: and I applaud you for that. But when you look at what we face in this country
column5: we do need to unite the country
column6: but we have to unite it for a purpose around very specific goals.

column1: CLINTON: It is not enough to say
column2: ""Let's come together."" We know we're going to have to work hard to overcome the opposition of those who do not want the changes to get to universal health care.

column1: You know
column2: when I proposed a universal health care plan
column3: as did Senator Edwards
column4: we took a big risk
column5: because we know it's politically controversial to say we're going to cover everyone.

column1: And you chose not to do that. You chose to put forth a health care plan that will leave out at least 15 million people. That's a big difference.
When I said we should put a moratorium on home foreclosures
column2: basically your response was
column3: well
column4: that wouldn't work.

column1: And
column2: you know
column3: in the last week
column4: even President Bush has said we have to do something like that.

column1: I just believe that we've got to look hard at the difficult challenges we face
column2: especially after George Bush leaves the White House.

column1: CLINTON: The world will breathe a sigh of relief once he is gone. We all know that.
(APPLAUSE)
But then we've got to do the hard work of not just bringing the country together
column2: but overcoming a lot of the entrenched opposition to the very ideas that both of us believe in
column3: and for some of us have been fighting for
column4: for a very long time. You know
column5: when I took on...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
When I took on universal health care back in '93 and '94
column2: it was against a firestorm of special interest opposition. I was more than happy to do that
column3: because I believe passionately in getting quality affordable health care to every American.

column1: I don't want to leave anybody out. I see the results of leaving people out. I am tired of health insurance companies deciding who will live or die in America.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right
column2: Senator Clinton
column3: thank you.

column1: Senator Obama
column2: please respond.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: Well
column2: I think that Senator Clinton mentioned two specific issue areas where we've got some differences. I'm happy to debate those
column3: which is what I think should be the focus of this campaign. We both want universal health care.

column1: When I released my plan a few months later
column2: we were in a debate and Senator Clinton said we all want universal health care. Of course
column3: I was down 20 points in the polls at the time
column4: and so my plan was pretty good. It's not as good now
column5: but my plan hasn't changed. The politics have changed a little bit.

column1: We both -- 95 percent of our plans are similar. We both want to set up a system in which any person is going to be able to get coverage that is as good as we have as members of Congress. And we are going to subsidize those who can't afford it.
OBAMA: We're going to make sure that we reduce costs by emphasizing prevention. And I want to make sure that we're applying technology to improve quality
column2: cut bureaucracy.

column1: Now
column2: I also want to make sure that we're reducing costs for those who already have health insurance. So we put in place a catastrophic reinsurance plan that would reduce costs by $2
column3: 500 per family per year.

column1: So we've got a lot of similarities in our plan. We've got a philosophical difference
column2: which we've debated repeatedly
column3: and that is that Senator Clinton believes the only way to achieve universal health care is to force everybody to purchase it.

column1: And my belief is
column2: the reason that people don't have it is not because they don't want it but because they can't afford it.

column1: And so I emphasize reducing costs.
(APPLAUSE)
And as has been noted by many observers
column2: including Bill Clinton's former secretary of labor
column3: my plan does more than anybody to reduce costs
column4: and there is nobody out there who wants health insurance who can't have it.

column1: OBAMA: Now
column2: there are legitimate arguments for why Senator Clinton and others have called for a mandate
column3: and I'm happy to have that debate.

column1: But the notion that I am leaving 15 million people out somehow implies that we are different in our goals of providing coverage to all Americans
column2: and that is simply not true. We think that there's going to be a different way of getting there.

column1: One last point I want to make on the health care front. I admire the fact that Senator Clinton tried to bring about health care reform back in 1993. She deserves credit for that.
(APPLAUSE)
But I said before
column2: I think she did it in the wrong way
column3: because it wasn't just the fact that the insurance companies
column4: the drug companies were battling here
column5: and no doubt they were. It was also that Senator Clinton and the administration went behind closed doors
column6: excluded the participation even of Democratic members of Congress who had slightly different ideas than the ones that Senator Clinton had put forward.

column1: And
column2: as a consequence
column3: it was much more difficult to get Congress to cooperate.

column1: OBAMA: And I've said that I'm going to do things differently. I think we have to open up the process. Everybody has to have a seat at the table. And most importantly
column2: the American people have to be involved and educated about how this change is going to be brought about.

column1: The point is this
column2: you know
column3: we can have great plans
column4: but if we don't change how the politics is working in Washington
column5: then neither of our plans are going to happen
column6: and we're going to be four years from now debating once again how we're going to bring universal health care to this country.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right
column2: we've got some time constraints here
column3: so we've got to take another real quick break. Stay with us. We've got a lot more ahead.

column1: You can compare the candidates on the issues any time; just go to our Web site
column2: Cnnpolitics.com. A lot more ahead here at the University of Texas. We'll be right back.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: An enthusiastic crowd here at the University of Texas.
Welcome back to the Texas Democratic debate. Let's get right to it. Jorge Ramos with the next question.
RAMOS: Senator Clinton
column2: yesterday you said
column3: and I'm quoting
column4: ""One of us is ready to be commander in chief.""

column1: Are you saying that Senator Obama is not ready and not qualified to be commander in chief?
CLINTON: Well
column2: I believe that I am ready and I am prepared. And I will leave that to the voters to decide.

column1: But I want to get back to health care
column2: because I didn't get a chance to respond after Senator Obama finished. No
column3: let me finish
column4: Jorge...

column1: RAMOS: But I would like to come back...
CLINTON: This is a significant difference. You know
column2: Senator Obama has said it's a philosophical difference. I think it's a substantive difference.

column1: He has a mandate for parents to be sure to ensure their children. I agree with that. I just know that if we don't go and require everyone to have health insurance
column2: the health insurance industry will still game the system. Everyone of us with insurance will pay the hidden tax of approximately $900 a year to make up for the lack of insurance.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And you know
column2: in one of our earlier debates
column3: John Edwards made a great point. It would be as though Social Security were voluntary. Medicare
column4: one of the great accomplishments of President Johnson
column5: was voluntary.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I do not believe that is going to work. So it's not just a philosophical difference.
CLINTON: You look at what will work and what will not work. If you do not have a plan that starts out attempting to achieve universal health care
column2: you will be nibbled to death
column3: and we will be back here with more and more people uninsured and rising costs.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right. We appreciate that you want to make a point
column2: Senator Obama. We have limited time
column3: so I would like Jorge to move on to another subject or we're going to be out of time.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
OBAMA: Well
column2: I understand. But I think that Senator Clinton made a...

column1: (LAUGHTER)
You know
column2: she's making a point
column3: and I think I should have the opportunity to respond very briefly. And I'll try to make...

column1: BROWN: Very briefly
column2: absolutely.

column1: OBAMA: Number one
column2: understand that when Senator Clinton says a mandate
column3: it's not a mandate on government to provide health insurance
column4: it's a mandate on individuals to purchase it. And Senator Clinton is right; we have to find out what works.

column1: OBAMA: Now
column2: Massachusetts has a mandate right now. They have exempted 20 percent of the uninsured because they have concluded that that 20 percent can't afford it.

column1: In some cases
column2: there are people who are paying fines and still can't afford it
column3: so now they're worse off than they were. They don't have health insurance and they're paying a fine.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
In order for you to force people to get health insurance
column2: you've got to have a very harsh penalty
column3: and Senator Clinton has said that we won't go after their wages. Now
column4: this is a substantive difference. But understand that both of us seek to get universal health care. I have a substantive difference with Senator Clinton on how to get there.

column1: BROWN: All right
column2: Senator Clinton?

column1: CLINTON: Wait a minute
column2: no
column3: this is too important. This is the number one issue that people talk to me about. You know
column4: when a mother grabs my arm and says
column5: ""I can't get the operation my son needs because I don't have health insurance
column6: it is personal for me.

column1: CLINTON: And I just fundamentally disagree.
You know
column2: Senator Obama's plan has a mandate on parents and a fine if parents do not...

column1: OBAMA: That's right.
CLINTON: ... insure their children.
OBAMA: That's right.
CLINTON: Because he recognizes that unless we have some kind of restriction
column2: we will not get there.

column1: OBAMA: There's a reason.
CLINTON: He's also said that if people show up at a hospital sick
column2: without health insurance
column3: well
column4: maybe at that point you can fine them.

column1: We would not have a social compact with Social Security and Medicare if everyone did not have to participate. I want a universal health care plan.
(APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: Now
column2: that's -- that mother -- that mother who is desperate to get health care for her child
column3: will be able to get that health care under my plan. Point number one.

column1: Point number two
column2: the reason a mandate for children can be effective is we've got an ability to make affordable health care available to that child
column3: right now.

column1: OBAMA: There are no excuses. If a parent is not providing health care for that child
column2: it's because the parent's not being responsible
column3: under my plan. And those children don't have a choice. But I think that adults are going to be able to see that they can afford it
column4: under my plan; they will get it
column5: under my plan.

column1: And it is true that
column2: if it turns out that some are gaming the system
column3: then we can impose
column4: potentially
column5: some penalties on them for gaming the system.

column1: But the notion that
column2: somehow
column3: I am interested in leaving out 15 million people
column4: without health insurance
column5: is simply not true.

column1: BROWN: All right. Jorge...
CLINTON: We disagree on that.
BROWN: OK. Jorge -- let's let Jorge re-ask his question
column2: because I don't think anyone remembers that one.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
RAMOS: Let me try again
column2: and not in Spanish
column3: OK?

column1: (LAUGHTER)
Here we go again. Because we also believe the war in Iraq is very important.
And here's the question. Are you suggesting that Senator Obama is not ready; he doesn't have the experience to be commander in chief? That's a question of: What did you mean by that phrase?
CLINTON: What I mean is that
column2: you know
column3: for more than 15 years
column4: I've been honored to represent our country in more than 80 countries to negotiate on matters such as opening borders for refugees during the war in Kosovo
column5: to stand up for women's rights as human rights around the world. I've served on the Senate...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I've served on the Senate Armed Services Committee
column2: and I have worked as one of the leaders in the Congress on behalf of Homeland Security in the very difficult challenges we face.

column1: You know
column2: just this week
column3: it's a good example. We had elections in Pakistan
column4: we had change in government in Cuba -- or at least the leadership. We've had the elections that
column5: you know
