column6: should have happened that haven't happened and just changed the leader the way they do in Cuba. We've had Kosovo declaring independence
column7: and we have had our embassy set on fire in Serbia.

column1: So we have serious problems that pose a real question about presidential leadership
column2: and also some great opportunities. You know
column3: we now have opportunities perhaps with Cuba
column4: I hope with President Musharraf
column5: for him to do the right thing.

column1: CLINTON: I supported the independence of Kosovo because I think it is imperative that in the heart of Europe we continue to promote independence and democracy. And I would be moving very aggressively to hold the Serbian government responsible with their security forces to protect our embassy. Under international law
column2: they should be doing that.

column1: So when you think about everything that is going to happen
column2: what we can predict and what we cannot predict
column3: I believe that I am prepared and ready on day one to be commander in chief
column4: to be the president
column5: to turn our economy around
column6: and to begin making a lot of these very difficult decisions that we will inherit from George Bush. And that is what I am putting forth to the voters.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Obama?
OBAMA: I wouldn't be running if I didn't think I was prepared to be commander-in-chief.
(APPLAUSE)
My number one job as president will be to keep the American people safe. I will do whatever is required to accomplish that. I will not hesitate to act against those that would do America harm.
Now
column2: that involves maintaining the strongest military on earth
column3: which means that we are training our troops properly and equipping them properly
column4: and putting them on proper rotations. And there are an awful lot of families here in Texas who have been burdened under two and three and four tours because of the poor planning of the current commander-in-chief
column5: and that will end when I am president.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: But it also means using our military wisely. And on what I believe was the single most important foreign policy decision of this generation
column2: whether or not to go to war in Iraq
column3: I believe I showed the judgment of a commander in chief. And I think that Senator Clinton was wrong in her judgments on that.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Now
column2: that has consequences -- that has significant consequences
column3: because it has diverted attention from Afghanistan where al Qaeda
column4: that killed 3
column5: 000 Americans
column6: are stronger now than at any time since 2001.

column1: You know
column2: I've heard from an Army captain who was the head of a rifle platoon -- supposed to have 39 men in a rifle platoon. Ended up being sent to Afghanistan with 24 because 15 of those soldiers had been sent to Iraq.

column1: OBAMA: And as a consequence
column2: they didn't have enough ammunition
column3: they didn't have enough humvees. They were actually capturing Taliban weapons
column4: because it was easier to get Taliban weapons than it was for them to get properly equipped by our current commander in chief.

column1: Now
column2: that's a consequence of bad judgment. And you know
column3: the question is
column4: on the critical issues that we face right now
column5: who's going to show the judgment to lead? And I think that on every critical issue that we've seen in foreign policy over the last several years -- going into Iraq originally
column6: I didn't just oppose it for the sake of opposing it.

column1: I said this is going to distract us from Afghanistan; this is going to fan the flames of anti-American sentiment; it's going to cost us billions of dollars and thousands of lives and overstretch our military. And I was right.
On the question of Pakistan
column2: which Senator Clinton just raised -- we just had an election there. But I've said very clearly that we have put all our eggs in the Musharraf basket. That was a mistake. We should be going after al Qaeda and making sure that Pakistan is serious about hunting down terrorists
column3: as well as expanding democracy. And I was right about that.

column1: On the issues that have come up that a commander in chief is going to have to make decisions on
column2: I have shown the judgment to lead. That is the leadership that I want to show when I'm president of the United States.

column1: OBAMA: On the issues that have come up
column2: that a commander in chief is going to have to make decisions on
column3: I have shown the judgment to lead. That is the leadership that I want to show when I'm president of the United States.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right. We're going to stay with this and stay on Iraq.
John King?
KING: I want to continue in this vein
column2: and hone in on the very point you just made. Because one of you
column3: unless this remarkable campaign here takes another wacky
column4: unpredictable turn
column5: is going to be running against a decorated war hero
column6: who is going to say that you don't have the experience to be commander in chief.

column1: And you have both said
column2: it's not about that type of experience; it's about judgment.

column1: You both had to make a judgment
column2: a short time ago
column3: in your job in the United States Senate
column4: about whether to support the surge. And as that was going on
column5: Senator Clinton
column6: you had the commanding general in Iraq before you. And you said
column7: ""I think that the reports provide to us really require the willing suspension of disbelief"" -- your words to General Petraeus.

column1: KING: I want you to look at Iraq now and listen to those who say the security situation is better. Ideal
column2: no
column3: but better -- some say significantly
column4: in recent days
column5: even some steps toward a political reconciliation.

column1: Is Iraq today better off than it was six months or a year ago because of the surge?
CLINTON: Well
column2: John
column3: I think you forget a very important premise of the surge. The rationale of the surge was to create the space and time for the Iraqi government to make the decisions that only it can make.

column1: Now
column2: there is no doubt
column3: given the skill and the commitment of our young men and women in uniform that putting more of them in will give us a tactical advantage and will provide security in some places
column4: and that has occurred.

column1: CLINTON: But the fact is that the purpose of it has not been fulfilled. The Iraqi government has slowly inched toward making a few of the decisions in a less than complete way
column2: but it hasn't taken advantage of the sacrifice and the losses of life and billions of dollars that have occurred since the surge began.

column1: That is why I have said
column2: upon taking office I would ask the secretary of defense and the Joint Chiefs of Staff and my security advisers to give me a plan so that I could begin withdrawing our troops within 60 days.

column1: And I would begin that with...
(APPLAUSE)
... with a very clear message to the Iraqis that they no longer had a blank check
column2: as they had been given by President Bush
column3: that as we withdraw our troops
column4: probably one to two brigades a month
column5: they would have to step up and make these decisions.

column1: CLINTON: I believe that is in the best interest of our military
column2: which has been stretched thin.

column1: Last night in Brownsville
column2: you know
column3: a woman grabbed my hand and said
column4: ""Please
column5: my husband's there for the third time. Bring him home.""

column1: And I told her privately what I have said publicly many times -- I will bring him home because I do not think it is in the interest of America or of the Iraqis that we continue to be there. It is up to the Iraqis to decide the kind of future they will have.
(APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Obama
column2: in the same vein
column3: you were also opposed to the surge from the beginning. Were you wrong?

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: I think it is indisputable that we've seen violence reduced in Iraq. And that's a credit to our brave men and women in uniform.

column1: In fact
column2: you know
column3: the 1st Cavalry
column4: out of Fort Hood
column5: played an enormous role in pushing back al Qaeda out of Baghdad.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
OBAMA: And
column2: you know
column3: we honor their service.

column1: But this is a tactical victory imposed upon a huge strategic blunder.
(LAUGHTER)
And I think that
column2: when we're having a debate with John McCain
column3: it is going to be much easier for the candidate who was opposed to the concept of invading Iraq in the first place to have a debate about the wisdom of that decision...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... than having to argue about the tactics subsequent to the decision.
(LAUGHTER)
Because
column2: ultimately
column3: that's what's at stake. Understand
column4: not only have we been diverted from Afghanistan. We've been diverted from focusing on Latin America.

column1: We contribute -- our entire foreign aid to Latin America is $2.7 billion
column2: approximately what we spend in Iraq in a week.

column1: OBAMA: And it is any surprise
column2: then
column3: that you've seen people like Hugo Chavez and countries like China move into the void
column4: because we've been neglectful of that.

column1: Iran is the single biggest strategic beneficiary of us having invaded Iraq
column2: and that is something that I think John McCain has to come to terms with.

column1: So that is a debate that I'm happy to have.
One last point I want to make on this
column2: and that is
column3: the incredible burden that has been placed on the American people
column4: starting with military families
column5: and the fact that we still are not doing right by our veterans
column6: that we still don't honor their service
column7: that there are still homeless veterans
column8: that we still don't screen properly for post-traumatic stress disorder and make sure that they're getting mental services that they need

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... having veterans in south Texas have to drive 250 miles to access a veterans hospital.
OBAMA: That's unacceptable. But we talked about the economy earlier
column2: the fact that we're spending $12 billion every month in Iraq means that we can't engage in the kind of infrastructure improvements that are going to make us more competitive. It means that we can't deliver on the kinds of health care reforms that both Senator Clinton and I are looking for.

column1: And that is also an argument that we have to have with John McCain because he has said that he is willing to have these troops over there for 100 years. The notion that we would sustain that kind of effort and neglect not only making us more secure here at home
column2: more competitive here at home
column3: allow our economy to sink. As John McCain says
column4: he doesn't really understand the economy that well. It is clear from his embrace of George Bush's policies that he doesn't
column5: and that's what I intend to change when I am president of the United States of America.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right. We've got to take another quick break. We've got a lot more ahead. Stay with us. We'll be right back.
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
BROWN: Welcome back to the Texas Democratic debate.
Stay with us after the debate. Anderson Cooper and the best political team on television will have lots of analysis.
But back to the debate.
John King?
KING: Thank you.
Both of you have been harshly critical of the Bush administration for its secrecy
column2: what you consider overuse of secrecy and executive power.

column1: Tonight
column2: Senator Obama
column3: you've talked about more transparency. You also at one point criticized earmarks.

column1: And yet
column2: a recent report came out that identified you -- lower on the list in terms how much money senators seek and sneak into the budget for these pork barrel spending projects
column3: but it still said you were responsible for $91 million in earmarks.

column1: And you have refused to say where the money went
column2: what it's for. Why?

column1: OBAMA: No
column2: that's not true. We've actually disclosed
column3: John
column4: all our earmarks. And so
column5: you know
column6: we'll be happy to provide you with that information
column7: because I believe very strongly in transparency.

column1: OBAMA: As I indicated earlier
column2: one of the things that I did last year was to pass a bill with Tom Coburn
column3: very conservative Republican but a sincere fiscal conservative. And we got together and created what we call Google for Government. It's a searchable database
column4: where every single dollar of federal spending is posted on the Internet
column5: so that ordinary voters can take a look. And if they see a bridge to nowhere being built
column6: they know where it's going and who sponsored it. And if they see a no-bid contract going to Halliburton
column8: too.

column1: And you know
column2: the idea is that we open up the process so that the American people can make judgments about whether or not government is doing what it's supposed to be doing with its taxpayer money. And I've been consistently in favor of more disclosure around earmarks.

column1: OBAMA: Now
column2: keep in mind
column3: a lot of these are worthy projects in our states. I have actively pursued projects that I think are important. But I want to make sure that they're not done in the dark of night
column4: that they're not done in committee
column5: that everybody stands up and says
column6: ""this is the kind of spending that I think is important.""

column1: I have consistently supported those efforts. I will push for those as president of the United States of America.
KING: Senator Clinton
column2: as you know
column3: I think your number was about $342 million. You say they're worthy projects
column4: as Senator Obama did
column5: for your state and that's part of your job
column6: to get money for worthy projects back in your state.

column1: Senator McCain
column2: as you know
column3: is proud of going around the country earmark.

column1: On the specific issue of pork barrel spending
column2: fiscal accountability by the government at a time when many Americans frankly think
column3: whether it is the House or the Senate
column4: that you all waste money on things that aren't important to them
column5: don't affect their daily lives
column6: does he have a better case to make to the American people that
column7: ""I have done this my entire career; I will do it as president
column8: on the issue of on the issue of wasteful pork barrel spending?

column1: CLINTON: Well
column2: no
column3: not at all. Because he supported the wasteful tax cuts of the Bush administration and the Iraq war
column4: with the billions of dollars...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... that have been spent
column2: and wants it to continue.

column1: You know
column2: when President Bush came into office
column3: he inherited a balanced budget and a surplus. And it is gone. And we now are looking at a projected deficit of $400 billion
column4: under the new Bush budget
column5: and a $9 trillion debt.

column1: We borrow money from the Chinese to buy oil from the Saudis. That is not a winning strategy for America.
(APPLAUSE)
I will get us back to fiscal responsibility. And I will make it clear that the Bush tax cuts on the upper income
column2: those making more than $250
column3: 000 a year
column4: will be allowed to expire.

column1: CLINTON: Middle-class tax cuts and support for the middle class
column2: to make college affordable
column3: retirement security possible
column4: health insurance affordable: Those will be my priorities.

column1: And I think it's important that we look at where the money has gone under President Bush -- no-bid contracts
column2: cronyism
column3: outsourcing the government in ways that haven't saved us money and have reduced accountability.

column1: So the larger question is
column2: who really is going to move us toward fiscal responsibility
column3: and I believe that we can get back on the path we were on. It was working well. It was one of the reasons why the economy was booming.

column1: I've got that
column2: you know
column3: clearly in my economic blueprint
column4: which is something that I've published the last few days
column5: because it's part of what we have to do again. And I think that I will be very comfortable and effective in taking on Senator McCain over the fiscal irresponsibility of the Republican Party that he's been a part of.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right.
An issue relating to the current election.
Jorge?
RAMOS: As we can see
column2: this has been an extremely close nomination battle that will come down to superdelegates. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi
column3: the highest ranking Democrat in government
column4: said recently
column5: and I'm quoting
column6: ""It would be a problem"" -- and this is a question for you
column7: Senator Clinton -- ""it would be a problem for the party if the verdict would be something different than the public has decided.""

column1: Do you agree?
CLINTON: Well
column2: you know
column3: these are the rules that are followed
column4: and you know
column5: I think that it will sort itself out. I'm not worried about that. We will have a nominee
column6: and we will have a unified Democratic Party
column7: and we will go on to victory in November.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Obama
column2: go ahead. Do you have a response to Senator Clinton?

column1: OBAMA: Well
column2: I think it is important
column3: given how hard Senator Clinton and I have been working
column4: that these primaries and caucuses count for something. And so my belief is that...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... the will of the voters
column2: expressed in this long election process
column3: is what ultimately will determine who our next nominee is going to be.

column1: OBAMA: But understand what I think is most important to the voters
column2: and that is that we have a government that is listening to them again. They feel as if they've been shut out.

column1: You know
column2: when I meet mothers who are trying to figure out how to get health care for their kids
column3: it's not just the desperation of that single mom. It's also that when they try to find some help
column4: oftentimes they're hitting a brick wall.

column1: And they don't get a sense that the debates that are happening in Washington right now relate to them at all. And what they believe is that people are trying to get on TV and they're trying to score points and they're trying to win elections
column2: and that they're not interested in knocking down the barriers that stand between the American people and their dreams.

column1: And I have no doubt that the Democratic Party at its best can summon a sense of common purpose again and higher purpose for the American people.
OBAMA: And I think that the next nominee going into the November election is going to have a lot to talk about because the American people are tired of politics that is dominated by the powerful
column2: by the connected. They want their government back
column3: and that's what I intend to provide them when I'm nominated for president of the United States.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: We have time for just one final question
column2: and we thought we would sort of end on a more philosophical question. You've both spent a lot of time talking about leadership
column3: about who's ready and who has the right judgment to lead if elected president.

column1: A leader's judgment is most tested at times of crisis. I'm wondering if both of you will describe what was the moment that tested you the most
column2: that moment of crisis.

column1: BROWN: Senator Obama?
OBAMA: Well
column2: you know
column3: I wouldn't point to a single moment. But what I look at is the trajectory of my life because
column4: you know
column5: I was raised by a single mom. My father left when I was two
column6: and I was raised by my mother and my grandparents.

column1: And
column2: you know
column3: there were rocky periods during my youth
column4: when I made mistakes and was off course. And what was most important
column5: in my life
column6: was learning to take responsibility for my own actions
column7: learning to take responsibility for not only my own actions but how I can bring people together to actually have an impact on the world.

column1: And so
column2: working as a community organizer on the streets of Chicago
column3: with ordinary people
column4: bringing them together and organizing them to provide jobs and health care
column5: economic security to people who didn't have it
column6: then working as a civil rights attorney and rejecting the jobs on Wall Street to fight for those who were being discriminated against on the job -- that cumulative experience
column8: is the judgment that I now bring.

column1: OBAMA: It's the reason that I have the capacity to bring people together
column2: and it's the reason why I am determined to make sure that the American people get a government that is worthy of their decency and their generosity.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: Senator Clinton?
CLINTON: Well
column2: I think everybody here knows I've lived through some crises and some challenging moments in my life. And...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And I am grateful for the support and the prayers of countless Americans.
But people often ask me
column2: ""How do you do it?"" You know
column3: ""How do you keep going?"" And I just have to shake my head in wonderment
column4: because with all of the challenges that I've had
column5: they are nothing compared to what I see happening in the lives of Americans every single day. along with Senator McCain
column6: as the only two elected officials
column7: to speak at the opening at the Intrepid Center at Brooke Medical Center in San Antonio
column8: a center designed to take care of and provide rehabilitation for our brave young men and women who have been injured in war.

column1: And I remember sitting up there and watching them come in. Those who could walk were walking. Those who had lost limbs were trying with great courage to get themselves in without the help of others. Some were in wheelchairs and some were on gurneys. And the speaker representing these wounded warriors had had most of his face disfigured by the results of fire from a roadside bomb.
CLINTON: You know
column2: the hits I've taken in life are nothing compared to what goes on every single day in the lives of people across our country.

column1: And I resolved at a very young age that I'd been blessed and that I was called by my faith and by my upbringing to do what I could to give others the same opportunities and blessings that I took for granted.
That's what gets me up in the morning. That's what motivates me in this campaign.
(APPLAUSE)
And
column2: you know
column3: no matter what happens in this contest -- and I am honored
column4: I am honored to be here with Barack Obama. I am absolutely honored.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
CLINTON: Whatever happens
column2: we're going to be fine. You know
column3: we have strong support from our families and our friends. I just hope that we'll be able to say the same thing about the American people
column4: and that's what this election should be about.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BROWN: All right
column2: a standing ovation here in Austin
column3: Texas. Our thanks to Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Clinton. We appreciate your time tonight.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
And to John and Jorge as well.
We also want to thank our debate partners
column2: the University of Texas at Austin and the Texas Democratic Party
column3: the LBJ Library as well
column4: and the city of Austin.

column1: 0	"For Immediate Release
July 9
column2: 2008 Contact: Press Office

column1: 703-650-5550 Barack Obama's FISA Flip Front and Center
Today Obama Abandons Pledge To Filibuster FISA Bill ARLINGTON
column2: VA -- Today
column3: McCain spokesman Tucker Bounds issued the following statement concerning Barack Obama's role in the Senate's terrorist surveillance debate: ""A few short months ago
column4: Barack Obama outwardly opposed terrorist surveillance legislation
column5: saying that he would filibuster any bill that includes immunity for American telecommunications companies that had been asked by the government to participate in the program. Today
column6: the U.S. Senate will approve legislation providing the immunity Barack Obama supposedly opposed
column8: he will not support a filibuster. What Barack Obama will do is show that he's willing to change positions
column9: break campaign commitments and undermine his own words in his quest for higher office."" During The Primaries
column10: Barack Obama Pledged To Filibuster Any Bill Which Contained Immunity For Telecommunications Companies Involved In Electronic Surveillance
column11: But Now Backs A Bill That Would Do Just That In October 2007
column12: The Obama Campaign Pledged He Would Filibuster ""Any Bill That Includes Retroactive Immunity For Telecommunications Companies."" Obama Spokesman Bill Burton: ""To be clear: Barack will support a filibuster of any bill that includes retroactive immunity for telecommunications companies."" (Greg Sargent
column13: ""Obama Camp Says It: He'll Support Filibuster Of Any Bill Containing Telecom Immunity
column16: 10/24/07) Barack Obama Now Supports A Bill Reauthorizing Electronic Surveillance That Grants Immunity To Telecommunications Companies. Obama: ""Under this compromise legislation
column17: an important tool in the fight against terrorism will continue. It does
column20: and I will work in the Senate to remove this provision so that we can seek full accountability for past offenses. So I support the compromise
column21: but do so with a firm pledge that as President
column22: I will carefully monitor the program
column23: review the report by the Inspectors General
column24: and work with the Congress to take any additional steps I deem necessary to protect the lives and the liberty of the American people."" (Ben Smith

0	An offer to participate in an online survey to get free Delta Airline tickets is a scam.
Congratulations! You have been selected to take part in our short survey to get 2 Free Delta Airline Tickets! We only have 332 Tickets remaining so hurry up!"" states the website Delta-Flying.info.
After we started our fact-check
column2: the link was no longer in use and had been flagged as suspected phishing. It is not an official Delta website.

column1: Such hoaxes that Delta or other airlines
column2: including Southwest Airlines
column3: have been giving away free tickets have circulated for years.

column1: Don’t take the surveys — these are all scams.
Graham Cluley
column2: a security analyst
column3: has previously written about the repercussions of the Southwest scam in 2016:

column1: The end result of all these shenanigans
column2: of course
column3: is to trick Facebook users into poor decisions – whether it be taking online surveys which earn affiliate cash for the scammers
column4: signing up for expensive premium rate mobile services
column5: or spamming the unwary with unwanted (and sometimes malicious) messages. .... If you are ever in any doubt as to whether a special offer on Facebook is genuine or not
column6: visit the company’s real website to see if they mention the competition there – or whether they are warning of a scam.""

column1: Delta spokeswoman Kate Modolo pointed to this page on Delta.com where legitimate offers from the airline are located.

The story that said Delta Airlines offers free airline tickets for people who take a short survey is a scam. We rate this story Pants on Fire."	['https://static.politifact.com/CACHE/images/politifact/staffers/zwPolitifactHeadshots20/6fdc6a24cf411eb1679d1fb84ded25f2.JPG'

column1: 0	"Senate Democrats Demand Supreme Court Nominee Not Be Unduly Influenced By U.S. Constitution
WASHINGTON
column2: D.C.—Still reeling from Trump’s previous Supreme Court nominee
column3: Neil Gorsuch
column4: Democrats plan to scrutinize any new nominee to ensure that he or she isn’t yet another crony of something called “The Constitution
column5: ” Senate Democrats announced Friday.

column1: “Time and time again
column2: we find progressive laws getting struck down
column3: ” Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said in a Senate address. “And it’s always — always — the ones the Constitution is against. These right-wing judges don’t think for themselves
column4: they just do whatever the Constitution says. And it’s time for that to end.”

column1: Senate Democrats have vowed to make sure that any new nominee isn’t going to be beholden to outside influences like the Constitution
column2: the founding fathers
column3: or the rule of law. “We need judges to be advocates of progressive laws
column4: ” Senator Elizabeth Warren added. “Not people who will bow to the whims of the Constitution
column5: pitting its extremist values of freedom of speech and freedom of religion against our agenda.”

column1: “We’re sick and tired of the Constitution sitting in the National Archives
column2: manipulating everything we do
column3: ” stated Senator Cory Booker
column4: trying to emote for the cameras but failing. Booker then called a ten-minute recess for him to refresh his supply of fake tears before he could continue.

column1: Asked about their concerns
column2: Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said he “doesn’t care” and plans to “completely ignore” the Democrats in the nomination process since “there’s nothing they can do” and he is “literally unstoppable.”

column1: 0	"SAGINAW
column2: Mich. — A man recently pardoned by former President Barack Obama was shot and killed by two men with assault-style rifles.

column1: It happened at 9:40 p.m. on Jan. 23
column2: at Bannum Place Federal Corrections Halfway House in Saginaw.

column1: Michigan State Police spokesperson Lt. David Kaiser told WNEM the two masked men barged into the building and shot 31-year-old Demarlon Thomas of Saginaw.
He was shot multiple times by one of the gunmen
column2: while the other held roughly two dozen others at the home at gunpoint. Thomas died at the scene.

column1: “One person watched over a group of them while another subject located the victim and executed him
column2: ” Kaiser told MLive.com. “They were looking for this person.”

column1: The two suspects then fled the area. No one else was injured.
It wasn’t immediately known how long Thomas had been out of prison and living in the halfway house.
Thomas was a former Sunny Side Gang member
column2: according to Kaiser. He was busted in one of the biggest drug busts in Saginaw
column3: known as “Operation Sunset.”

column2: he was sentenced to 19 years in prison for the distribution of five grams or more of cocaine. The operation effectively ended the Sunny Side Gang.

column1: Thomas was among the 79 people pardoned on Nov. 22 by former President Obama.
His jail sentence was set to expire in March.
If you have any information
column2: call D/SGT. Jim Bush at (231) 250-9471 or Crime Stoppers at 1-800-422-JAIL."	['https://tribwpix.files.wordpress.com/2017/01/s074312323-300.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=770&h=433'
