column1: Return to Transcripts main page
STATE OF THE UNION WITH CANDY CROWLEY
Interview With Congressmen Larson
column2: Pence; Interview With Senators Hatch
column3: Feinstein

column1: Aired March 21
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
CROWLEY: Normally
column2: on Sundays
column3: we take a reflective look at the past week and set the agenda for the coming days
column4: but today is no normal Sunday. We are four hours away from a showdown in the House of Representatives
column5: a series of votes that will determine the future of health care reform
column6: impact the economy
column7: influence this November's election and set the stage for the rest of President Obama's agenda. Today is no normal Sunday. Today is game day. I am Candy Crowley and this is State of the Union.

column1: This morning
column2: health reform from all angles. Two House leaders
column3: John Larson and Mike Pence
column4: on today's vote. Two senior senators
column5: Dianne Feinstein
column6: and Orrin Hatch
column7: on the week ahead. And analysis from Donna Brazile and Bill Bennett.

column1: We have heard the words ""end game"" so many times in this health care debate
column2: I wouldn't try it now. That said
column3: it would in fact be the end if Republicans prevailed in today's vote. For Democrats
column4: the magic number is 216. That's how many yeas needed to pass the health care bill in the House
column5: 216 votes among the 253 Democratic members. It has been a struggle all week to get there. We begin with seven days in two minutes.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
DAVID AXELROD
column2: SR. ADVISER TO THE PRESIDENT: I think we will have the votes.

column1: REP. JOHN A. BOEHNER
column2: R-OHIO: If she had 216 votes
column3: this bill would be long gone.

column1: PRESIDENT BARACK OBAMA: Hello
column2: Ohio!

column1: REP. NANCY PELOSI
column2: D-CALIF.
column3: SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: When we bring the bill to the floor
column4: we will have the votes.

column1: REP. JAMES E. CLYBURN
column2: D-S.C.
column3: MAJORITY WHIP: We need to get to 216. And we are still tweaking stuff.

column1: OBAMA: Your own congressman
column2: who is tireless on behalf of the working people
column3: Dennis Kucinich.

column1: ROBERT GIBBS
column2: WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: It is an important trip that the president will take. And I think he looks forward to it. REP. ERIC CANTOR
column3: R-VA.: I mean
column4: it is clear. They don't have the votes
column5: because the American people can't stand this bill.

column1: REP. DENNIS J. KUCINICH
column2: D-OHIO: I've decided to cast a vote in favor of the legislation.

column1: GIBBS: That he must postpone his planned visits for a later date.
REP. BART STUPAK
column2: D-MICH.: As of today
column3: I am still voting no. Yes
column4: I am still standing with this principle
column5: protecting the sanctity of life. Yes.

column1: OBAMA: Hello
column2: George Mason!

column1: (UNKNOWN): Yes. I will be voting yes for the bill.
PELOSI: Right now
column2: we are just getting votes to pass a bill.

column1: OBAMA: And in just a few days
column2: a century-long struggle will culminate in a historic vote.

column1: BOEHNER: We are about 24 hours from Armageddon.
CROWD: Kill the bill
column2: kill the bill
column3: kill the bill!

column1: REP. ANH ""JOSEPH"" CAO
column2: R-LA.: Tomorrow will be a sad day for me as I cast a no vote against something I believe we need.

column1: (UNKNOWN): I will be a proud supporter of health care reform.
REP. STENY H. HOYER
column2: D-MD.
column3: MAJORITY LEADER: Clearly
column4: we believe we have the vote.

column1: (UNKNOWN): We feel like we have been pregnant for 17 months. Let's get on with it already.
OBAMA: We have been debating health care for decades. It has now been debated for a year. It is in your hands.
(END VIDEOTAPE)
CROWLEY: Here to look ahead to today's vote and the high stakes politics surrounding it
column2: House Democratic Caucus Chairman
column3: John Larson of Connecticut
column4: and the House Republican Conference Chairman Mike Pence of Indiana. Gentlemen
column5: thank you both for joining me.

column1: PENCE: Thank you
column2: Candy.

column1: LARSON: Great to be with you
column2: Candy.

column1: CROWLEY: State of play
column2: where are you? 216
column3: do you have it locked in?

column1: LARSON: This is a historic day. And we are happy warriors. We are so proud of the Democratic caucus
column2: that we will be a part of history
column3: joining Franklin Delano Roosevelt's passage of Social Security
column4: Lyndon Johnson's passage of Medicare
column5: and now Barack Obama's passage of health care reform.

column1: CROWLEY: So you have got the 216?
LARSON: We've got the votes. And the reason for that
column2: Candy
column3: I think it started earlier this week with Natoma Canfield becoming the poster child for -- or lady for health care reform. And that struck such a cord within our caucus. And Dennis Moore standing up to give a speech in the caucus was Blackberried by a woman who works with him in Kansas. She said thank you for voting for this. I know I am losing my job at the end of this year
column4: and unfortunately
column5: I have just been diagnosed with cancer. Without this bill
column6: I'm lost. Dennis ended by saying
column7: and she is 24. You could have heard a pin drop.

column1: This is about whose side you are on. And clearly
column2: this historic moment in the people's chamber
column3: we are on the side of the American people and those that have been denied access to health care
column4: and those who have pre-existing conditions who have been denied
column5: and those who have had their policies rescinded.

column1: CROWLEY: Congressman Pence
column2: I think that puts you on the side not of the people
column3: if we take his calculation. What is left for Republicans to do? Congressman Larson says they have the 216. So it is all over but the shouting? You guys vote no and move on?

column1: PENCE: Well
column2: I don't know if they have the votes. House Republicans are going to use every means at our disposal.

column1: CROWLEY: What is that?
PENCE: Well
column2: stay tuned
column3: Candy. It's going to be an interesting day.

column1: CROWLEY: Can you disrupt the vote? I mean
column2: what's available?

column1: PENCE: We are going to use every means at our disposal to oppose this government takeover of health care. Because quite frankly
column2: as thousands gather at rallies all across this country and here in the nation's capital
column3: yesterday
column4: you know
column5: the American people are sick and tired of runaway federal spending by both parties
column6: of borrowing and bailouts and takeovers. And I believe this is going to be a historic weekend.

column1: LARSON: It is.

PENCE: But I think it is going to be different from the way John thinks it is going to be. I think this is going to be a historic weekend because I think this weekend is going to be the beginning of the end of business as usual in Washington
column2: D.C. I think the American people see an administration and see a Congress that are in a headlong rush to confront the very real challenges that we have in health care with more government instead of more freedom.

column1: They know -- the Republicans have been offering solutions from the beginning. Let people purchase health insurance across state lines
column2: pass malpractice reform
column3: cover preexisting conditions. All of that can be done without a massive
column4: trillion-dollar expansion of the federal government and burdening future generations with more deficits and more debt.

column1: CROWLEY: But the reality of this day is that you don't have the votes to stop it. You may have the means to delay it. PENCE: Right. You know
column2: the Republicans
column3: it shouldn't be a news flash to anybody
column4: Republicans don't have the votes to stop anything in the House of Representatives. We are in a decisive minority.

column1: CROWLEY: (inaudible) politically.
PENCE: But what's remarkable about this one-year debate has proven my point
column2: that a minority in Congress plus the American people equals a majority. Republicans -- the reason they weren't able to do this last year -- remember all the deadlines? We had deadlines in the summer
column3: we had deadlines in the fall
column4: we had deadlines at the end of the year. The American people don't want this government takeover of health care. And I don't know if they have the votes today
column5: but I guarantee you
column6: the American people know they have the votes in America.

column1: LARSON: The American people who are already on Medicare
column2: all of our veterans who already receive Tricare
column3: understand the importance and the value of having insurance coverage. For 47 million Americans who have none
column4: 31 million will now be able to have access to insurance
column5: lowering costs
column6: lowering costs for small businesses
column8: $138 billion
column9: and then $1.2 trillion. We can't afford not to do this. And taking care of those people--

column1: (CROSSTALK)
CROWLEY: I want to talk about the debt. Hang on one second. I have got to take a small break--
(CROSSTALK)
CROWLEY: We will come back. I do want to talk about the costs. There are some figures out there floating. I'll do that
column2: we'll be back with Congressmen Larson and Pence right after this.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CROWLEY: We are back with Democratic Congressman John Larson of Connecticut and Republican Congressman Mike Pence of Indiana. We were talking about the cost of this. The CBO has said over 10 years this health care bill will reduce the deficit by $143 billion.
However
column2: that doesn't include what might come and what has been promised
column3: with more than a wink and a nod to doctors
column4: which is to up their Medicare payments
column5: their reimbursements
column6: which would cost $208 million
column7: which then means it actually would be -- would add to the deficit.

column1: Is that -- is my math correct there? LARSON: Well
column2: if that were to be true. But here is the thing
column3: there is no question about the fact that we need to take care of the docs and we need to emphasize primary care. But also what never gets discussed
column4: Candy
column5: is something that Reuters came out with earlier this year
column6: $700 billion annually in inefficiencies in this system
column8: lack of a continuum of care

column1: I think that we're going to -- that's $7 trillion over a 10-year period. I think that we're more than going to be able to wring out the cost in there. I think that's why the president brought people down to Washington
column2: to the White House
column3: that's why he brought the six (ph) in to try to wring out those costs as we go forward.

column1: You know
column2: we spend 20 percent of gross domestic product. The closest country to us is Switzerland. I can't believe that we can't get that money out of there.

column1: CROWLEY: Can't we get that money out of there?
PENCE: Yes
column2: yes
column3: we do such a great job here in Washington wringing out the cost.

column1: LARSON: Now that's in the private sector.
PENCE: One-point-six trillion dollar deficit this year
column2: you know
column3: only in Washington D.C. could you say with a straight face that you are going to spend $1 trillion and save tax-payers money. Look
column4: you point out the doc fix. This is a total fraud. The Democrats are leaving out $200 billion in spending that the speaker of the house committed again this week to spend
column5: which makes this -- even using this CBO's numbers
column6: it makes it a bill that adds to the deficit in the short term and in the long term.

column1: But look
column2: even beyond that
column3: Candy
column4: the American people know that you expand the federal government's role in health care without giving the American people more health care choices by purchasing across state lines
column5: without passing any medical malpractice reform at all -- roughly a third of health care costs in this country I hear are actually defensive medicine driven by junk lawsuits.

column1: The American people know this is going to cost more and add more to the deficit
column2: add more to the debt
column3: cost higher taxes even than the rosiest scenarios that are presented...

column1: LARSON: The CBO is the bible. The CBO says...
CROWLEY: It is
column2: but it's not always accurate
column3: as you know.

column1: LARSON: We have arguments with them all of the time
column2: but...

column1: CROWLEY: Somebody once told me that predicting...
LARSON: ... that's all that we can -- that's all that we can vote on.
CROWLEY: Sure
column2: absolutely. But it still is one of those things that we might not find out...

column1: PENCE: And the president...
CROWLEY: ... except for 10 years from now.
LARSON: And the president has put in numerous reforms that are going to take effect
column2: including the inability to rescind your insurance policy
column3: pre-existing conditions. For women across this country
column4: Candy
column5: I mean
column6: there birth is a pre-existing condition
column7: domestic violence is a pre-existing condition
column8: a C-section is a pre- existing condition

column1: (CROSSTALK)
PENCE: My wife had to -- John
column2: my wife had a pre-existing condition. I lost my job about 15 years ago. My wife had a pre- existing condition. She was pregnant with our daughter Audrey. We went to the state guarantee fund
column3: a fund that would be replenished if we passed medical malpractice reform
column4: we could use the savings to strengthen those funds to cover people like my wife was covered.

column1: You don't need a government takeover of health care. You don't need to mandate that every American purchase health insurance whether they want it or need it or not
column2: and you don't need to put us on a pathway towards socialized medicine.

column1: LARSON: Where is the takeover by the government?
PENCE: And that's what this crowd is doing today.
LARSON: Where is the takeover by the government? CROWLEY: Let me ask you something
column2: just turn...

column1: LARSON: Humana runs Medicare currently. Tricare is run by them. Where is the takeover of government?
PENCE: Well
column2: I'll break it down. John
column3: if you mandate that every American purchase health insurance
column4: you mandate that every business provide it...

column1: LARSON: Do we mandate that people get car insurance?
PENCE: ... you create a...
(CROSSTALK)
PENCE: ... so that people end up in government-run insurance
column2: and you provide public funding for abortion
column3: you mandate insurance plans
column4: cover it within the exchange...

column1: LARSON: There is no funding for abortion in this bill.
PENCE: It is a government takeover of health care.
LARSON: There is no funding for abortion in this bill. It follows Hyde. That's not -- that's the case. PENCE: John
column2: you know that is not true. The Catholic Church...

column1: LARSON: I know it's absolutely true.
PENCE: ... the Catholic bishops
column2: the right to life says...

column1: LARSON: Sixty thousand nuns can't be wrong.
PENCE: ... public funding for abortions is in this bill.
LARSON: Thank God for the sisters of Notre Dame
column2: that's what I think.

column1: CROWLEY: Let me call a time here
column2: because we are out of time. But for more of this
column3: our audience can tune into the House debate starting this afternoon. And I suspect that pass or not pass
column4: this debate continues as we watch how it goes.

column1: LARSON: That's right. Very strong disagreements. But Mike Pence is an honorable man. And I look forward to this debate
column2: and as are our colleagues. I hope that we do ratchet down the conversation though
column3: because when two of our colleagues are spat on and hurled racial slurs
column4: it is time...

column1: CROWLEY: It did indeed happen.
LARSON: ... it's time to ratchet down things a little bit.
PENCE: Well
column2: I'll tell you
column3: I was in Selma with John Lewis
column4: if what is reported to have happened was reported is contemptible
column5: I denounce it in the strongest terms. But I assure you
column6: this debate will not end today.

column1: LARSON: I agree with that.
CROWLEY: Or probably on this show.
LARSON: I agree with that.
CROWLEY: Thank you very much
column2: I appreciate it.

column1: LARSON: There is going to be a lot of work to go to...
CROWLEY: If health care reform wins passage in the House today
column2: the measure heads back to the Senate. Up next
column3: a quick tutorial on what happens next. And then a conversation with Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein and Republican Senator Orrin Hatch.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: A quick reality check for those who today's House votes will bring us to the finish line
column2: not quite
column3: not yet. If House Democrats muster the votes today
column4: two things happen. First the Senate version of health care reform will be passed by the House and will then be ready for the president to sign into law. Second
column5: House Democrats will pass a fix-it bill
column6: a companion measure of sorts to correct the things they don't like about the Senate measure. That bill has to go to the Senate. If the Senate goes the easy route
column7: they will pass the fixes without change and send it off to the president. But if the Senate changes anything
column8: if it adds or subtracts from the House measure
column9: it must go back to the House for another vote before it goes to the president.

column1: Senate Republicans have some options which could delay or change the bill
column2: including parliamentary challenges to any part of it as unrelated to the budget. Why didn't the ""Schoolhouse Rock"" teach us about this? We will do our best to get answers on what comes next from senators Orrin Hatch and Dianne Feinstein right after the break.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: As we explained
column2: even if the health care reform bill wins passage in the House later today
column3: it still has another legislative hurdle to clear
column4: back to the Senate for those changes or fixes
column5: if you will
column6: that House Democrats want.

column1: Joining us
column2: Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein of California and Republican Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah.

column1: So the other day I noticed
column2: Senator Hatch
column3: that you said it would be nuts for anyone to believe that this is the House's last word on this. You think the Senate will change the fix-it bill that's coming over to you?

column1: HATCH: Well
column2: if the rules are followed
column3: they'd have to. Because there is a Social Security component. And you can't do that on reconciliation. There's also an appropriations component as well.

column1: So if -- if the parliamentarian upholds that and Joe Biden doesn't overrule the parliamentarian
column2: which would be a first
column3: then it seems to me that it's going to have to be sent back to the House. So anybody that thinks that this is only going to be a one-time deal today in the House
column4: I think
column5: is grossly mistaken.

column1: CROWLEY: Senator Feinstein
column2: do you think it's possible for the Senate to take that bill and just go
column3: OK
column4: fine with us?

column1: FEINSTEIN: Yes
column2: I do. And I think that's exactly what we'll do. And I really disagree with my friend and colleague. I believe there are at least 51 votes there. I think the bill has been carefully vetted with the parliamentarian. I believe he will stand for each part of it.

column1: And the bill that the House passes today goes to the president. He signs it. Then the reconciliation bill comes over to us. We'll probably begin debate on Tuesday. It will be posted -- it takes some time -- begin debate on Tuesday.
Now
column2: I'm sure what Senator Hatch's party will do is submit a whole host of amendments. We'll have a major vote-a-thon. And this will go on for several days. And I believe
column3: at the end
column4: more than 51 Democrats will hold firm and will pass the reconciliation bill and we will have health care reform. I can say
column5: for my state
column6: the reconciliation bill is very important. Because we have now 8 million people without any insurance in California. The number has gone up 1 million people a year for the last two years. So this bill is necessary.

column1: CROWLEY: Senator Hatch
column2: I want to ask you about the vote-a-thon
column3: but I first want to play something Senator Reid said recently.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
SEN. HARRY REID
column2: D-NEV.
column3: SENATE MAJORITY LEADER: We're in the last minute of play. The shot clock is turned off. The other side knows what the outcome will be. So they're trying to foul us and foul us and foul us and foul us again
column4: just to keep the clock from reading zero. They're not just delaying the inevitable; they're delaying the imperative.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CROWLEY: Are you going on after -- after the shot clock has...
(LAUGHTER)
I mean
column2: you know
column3: Senator Feinstein calls it a vote-a-thon. I mean
column4: is this the Republican approach to this now
column5: is just to delay the inevitable?

column1: HATCH: Well
column2: not really. I think it's to try and get amendments passed that really are valid amendments. I think
column3: if you have a Social Security component in it
column4: it has -- it has to come back to the House. And a parliamentarian has to rule the right way.

column1: But who knows? I don't know what the parliamentarian is going to do. All I can say is this. You know
column2: as I walk around this country
column3: and I've been all over the country
column4: people come up to me from everywhere
column5: Democrats
column6: Republicans
column8: we can't afford this; we can't do this. We do not even have solid

column1: As a matter of fact
column2: the actuary at CMS said he cannot get the final scoring. They also don't include the doc fix in it
column3: which is $371 billion
column4: and that's at present worth. And that doesn't even take care of Medicaid.

column1: Of the 31 million people you're going to cover
column2: 16 million are pushed into Medicaid.

column1: I mean
column2: let me just tell you
column3: we're coming to a Europeanization of America. And the American people sense it. They feel it. They know that we can't afford this.

column1: And
column2: frankly
column3: the doc fix that they have on Medicaid...

column1: (CROSSTALK) HATCH: He's a letter -- here's a letter from my governor saying -- now
column2: for two years
column3: they say they'll hold the states free. But then you go off the clip because they cannot afford to pay for it in the federal government.

column1: And -- and Medicaid
column2: they're paying -- the doctors are getting 66 percent of what the private sector pays doctors. And they're up in arms. They're not going to take patients now. You can imagine how bad this is going to be if this bill goes through.

column1: CROWLEY: Senator Feinstein
column2: do you worry about either unintended consequences or changes in the economy that could
column3: in the end
column4: if this is made into law
column5: really ruin some aspects of health care?

column1: FEINSTEIN: Well
column2: of course. This isn't the perfect bill. We all know that.

column1: HATCH: Well
column2: that's for sure.

column1: FEINSTEIN: We all know that there are going to have to be fixes down the road
column2: just as every major program has had; Medicare has had; Social Security will likely have because of the explosion of costs.

column1: Having said that
column2: you have to look at the basics. And the basics are that we pay far more than European nations do for health care. And they have a much better performance.

column1: We're about 15 percent; France is 10 percent. And in overall performance by the World Health Organization
column2: France is ranked number one. I think we're ranked 17.

column1: We spend a lot of money
column2: but we don't necessarily spend it in the right way or the right places.

column1: Now
column2: let me just finish. This bill is really important. Because
column3: if we don't pass it now
column4: you can forget health care reform forever after
column5: I believe. So this is the opportunity. We're right at the goal line. I believe it's going to pass the House. It will be signed by the president. We should pass a reconciliation bill.

column1: And I would really appeal to my good friend
column2: Senator Hatch. Let this reconciliation bill get passed. Then
column3: you can see. If it's wrong
column4: you'll certainly say so. If it works
column5: hopefully
column6: you'll say so as well.

column1: CROWLEY: And we'll get your answer right after this
column2: because I've got to take a break. And we'll find out if you listened to her appeal
column3: right after this.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: We are back with two top senators
column2: Democrat Dianne Feinstein and Republican Orrin Hatch.

column1: When last we met
column2: she was asking if you would just let this reconciliation bill go through and see what happens. FEINSTEIN: Suggesting.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
HATCH: Well
column2: let me tell you
column3: Republicans are dedicated against this bill. We consider it an awful bill.

column1: Do you realize they're going to subsidize families that make over -- families of four that make over $80
column2: 000 a year?

column1: I mean
column2: we're getting to where 50 percent of the people in this country are going to depend on subsidies. And
column3: of course
column4: I know Dianne can't agree with that or doesn't believe in that.

column1: But -- and all I can say is -- is
column2: everywhere I go
column3: people say
column4: how do we pay for this? You know
column5: in all honesty
column6: they have jacked up the costs of Medicare. They're going to take better than $500 billion
column8: out of Medicare. They're going to increase taxes by over $500 billion. They're going to sock it to individuals who don't -- who can't afford to buy insurance. They're going to have to pay 2.5 percent of their gross income.

column1: Businesses are now going to have to pay up to $3
column2: 000 per employee if they don't provide health insurance.

column1: You reach a point where you say
column2: who is going to pay for all of this? And it's going to come down to us taxpayers. And like I say
column3: it's the Europeanization of America
column4: and that's the worst thing that could possibly happen to our country.

column1: CROWLEY: You -- you said earlier that
column2: of course
column3: there were things that worried you about the bill. If you looked at in the totality
column4: what worries you the most?

column1: Is there anything that he says that you think
column2: you know
column3: yes
column4: that is a worry of mine?

column1: FEINSTEIN: Well
column2: there -- the bill is a combination of a number of different things designed to cover more people. The bill has very big strong points. For example
column3: right away
column4: there's a $5 billion fund for people with pre-existing conditions who can't get health insurance today.

column1: HATCH: We're both for that. We're both for that.
FEINSTEIN: That's a very positive thing.
HATCH: Sure.
FEINSTEIN: So the bill
column2: when really accumulated
column3: the Congressional Budget Office says
column4: will save
column5: over 10 years
column6: $138 billion.

column1: Now
column2: Orrin will say
column3: well
column4: it's not this; it's not that; it's not the other thing. But that's the fact that we go on when we assess a bill. CROWLEY: But isn't also true
column5: Senator...

column1: FEINSTEIN: So over 10 years
column2: this bill
column3: I'm confident
column4: will not cost more.

column1: Now
column2: as I said
column3: are there certain parts that may have to be tweaked
column4: that don't work exactly right? But he has given a litany of complaints about the bill. The thrust of the bill is to provide more people with coverage.

column1: One of the good things the bill does is it reduces the nonpremium costs for those 85 percent of people that have medical health insurance. It reduces it from 20 percent to 15 percent so that more money from insurance companies will actually go for medical care. And I think that's important.
CROWLEY: Politically
column2: isn't it going to be hard to argue
column3: should this bill pass
column4: and we think it will
column5: just given the numbers
column6: to say
column8: people are now going to be -- not be thrown off their insurance because they got sick. There will be no more caps.

column1: FEINSTEIN: Exactly.
CROWLEY: There will be help for people down the road
column2: to help subsidize it. How can you argue against that? Isn't that a pretty political powerful package?

column1: HATCH: Well
column2: I'm not arguing -- I'm not arguing against that. I think Republicans certainly -- we could agree on a large percentage of things together. But there was really no effort to get us involved.

column1: All I can say is this
column2: is that everywhere I go -- and I've said it over and over -- people say
column3: how are you going to pay for this? How do you pay for it?

column1: Now
column2: the CMS actuary -- that's the actuary for the administration -- says the cost curve will not be bent
column3: that premiums are going to go up. I have to say that I believe that -- that CBO -- of course they have to decide these budgetary matters based upon the papers given them by the House of Representatives and by the Senate
column4: and those papers are stacked in favor of trying to live within our means
column5: but they don't.

column1: The fact is that they double-count in this bill. They have all kinds of other gimmicks in this bill that try to get this bill down to -- everybody knows that this
column2: extrapolated over 10 years
column3: is going to be $2.5 trillion more on top of what we're already spending
column4: $2.4 trillion.

column1: You cannot tell me that this country can afford to do that and that we can't find a way
column2: by working together
column3: to really come up with a health care system that will work and work within financial means.

column1: CROWLEY: I'm going to give you the last short word. And that is
column2: are you comfortable with the cost of this bill...

column1: FEINSTEIN: Yes.
CROWLEY: ... and comfortable the country can afford it?
FEINSTEIN: Yes. I believe we can. And I believe that will be sorted out over time.
I think there's one thing that isn't in the bill
column2: that the president was good enough to take my bill
column3: which would give the secretary of health and human services some control over the rate of premiums to ensure that they are reasonable for people who have private-sector insurance. Unfortunately
column4: the parliamentarian said that could not be added to the reconciliation bill. I have introduced it as a separate bill.

column1: I believe this is a huge problem out there. You have Anthem in California and 800
column2: 000 policies just jacking up premiums up to 39 percent in California and then saying there may be another increase in the middle of the year.

column1: And so people are being pushed off of their health insurance because of the cost of premiums. And this is one thing we need to strengthen
column2: in my view
column3: and hopefully will as a separate piece of legislation.

column1: CROWLEY: Senator Dianne Feinstein
column2: Senator Orrin Hatch
column3: I can't thank you both enough for coming. I appreciate it.

column1: FEINSTEIN: Thank you.
HATCH: Thank you.
CROWLEY: More of this on the Senate floor next week...
FEINSTEIN: Oh
column2: you bet.

column1: CROWLEY: ... we promise. (LAUGHTER)
FEINSTEIN: Thank you.
CROWLEY: Up next
column2: in our ""American Dispatch
column3: why
column4: despite the claims of some politicians
column5: it's hard to say exactly how most Americans feel about the health reform bill. And then Donna Brazile and Ben Bennett on the potential fallout for both Democratic and Republican lawmakers up for re-election this fall.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: Our ""American Dispatch"" looks at a central question. What do Americans think?
House Republican Leader John Boehner answers for Republicans.
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
BOEHNER: Because the American people are saying ""Stop
column2: and they're screaming at the top of their lungs. (END VIDEO CLIP)

column1: CROWLEY: But are they? Two polls released this week leave lots of room for debate. A Pew poll released Thursday asks
column2: ""Do you favor or oppose the current bill?""

column1: Only 38 percent said they favor it. So is Minority Leader Boehner right?
A Wall Street Journal/NBC poll asks
column2: ""Is it better to pass the Obama plan or keep the current system?""

column1: The respondents were split right down the middle.
Is it in the way the question is asked? Are more people more likely to support it when it's called the Obama plan or is it that people think some change is better than no change?
You be the judge. We will sort through the complicated politics of all this with Donna Brazile and Bill Bennett after a short break.
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: Joining me here in Washington
column2: two of my favorite people
column3: CNN political contributor and Democratic strategist Donna Brazile and CNN political contributor and host of ""Morning in America
column4: Bill Bennett
column5: who is also author of the new book ""A Century Turns."" These authors and stuff
column6: OK.

column1: The politics of all this. John Larson
column2: head of the Democratic caucus
column3: says they've got the 216
column4: done deal
column5: goes over to the Senate
column6: Dianne Feinstein all confident they're going to pass it. It's going to be law. How does this all play out politically? I want to play you something the -- two things
column8: the president said yesterday. First

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
OBAMA: I am actually confident -- I've talked to some of you individually -- that it will end up being the smart thing to do politically
column2: because I believe that good policy is good politics.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CROWLEY: OK
column2: now
column3: about two minutes later
column4: he had this to say.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
OBAMA: Now
column2: I can't guarantee that this is good politics. Every one of you know your districts better than I do.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
CROWLEY: So
column2: let's see
column3: I'm thinking we're not really sure how the politics are going to play out. What do you think? BENNETT: Yes
column4: well
column5: as a former teacher of logic
column6: he didn't contradict himself
column7: because he said I believe this will be good politics because it's good policy
column8: but I can't guarantee it. OK

column1: I think it's bad politics
column2: because I think it's bad policy
column3: and not just from a partisan point of view
column4: but let me just do it analytically. You would not have so many nervous Democrats if this looked like it was really good politics. I don't think it is.

column1: And
column2: again
column3: I think
column4: when we see how this plays out
column5: one play will be in November with the midterm elections. Another play
column6: we'll see what happens with budget issues.

column1: And since misrepresentations are all over the place in this -- in this proposal
column2: and you look at a state like Massachusetts
column3: which is a state closest to what this federal program is
column4: I think they're going to regret it. Be careful what you wish for
column5: Richard Butler (ph) said
column6: because you may get it.

column1: CROWLEY: You know
column2: Donna
column3: what the White House is counting on -- what Democrats are counting on is that
column4: after this is signed into law
column5: people will go
column6: ""Oh
column7: you mean I won't be thrown my"" -- that there will be things in there
column8: and their argument has always been
column10: they don't really know what it's in this bill."" Is that going to work?

column1: BRAZILE: Well
column2: it's true
column3: Candy
column4: that only 15 percent of voters understand what's inside the bill because we've been talking about the pie crust and not what's in the filling. And I think as soon as they understand that children with pre-existing conditions will not be kicked off their policies
column5: small businesses will have access to an exchange that will help lower their costs and provide better coverage for their employees
column6: I think as soon as they learn the details of this proposal
column7: they will become very comfortable with it.

column1: And we all know that the -- that the price that the American people will pay if Congress fails to act is that their premiums will continue to rise $10
column2: 000 over the next 15 years. This is good policy
column3: is good politics
column4: it's good for the American people
column5: it's good for the economy. There's no reason for Democrats to run away from this bill.

column1: CROWLEY: So you don't think that the Democrats are going to lose seats this November because of the health care bill?
BRAZILE: Democrats will lose seats
column2: Republicans will lose seats simply because there are open seats that will no longer go into the Democratic column. They will lose seats...

column1: CROWLEY: But not because of health care?
BRAZILE: Well
column2: health care
column3: Candy -- and some Democrats might lose because the voters are simply tired of that Democrat and may be tired of Republicans
column4: too. I don't think we should judge this bill based on who will win and who will lose if we're doing what's right for the American people
column5: we're doing what's right for taxpayers. This is a good approach to trying to solve a very longstanding problem in this country.

column1: CROWLEY: And that's how the president sold it
column2: right? It was like
column3: don't...

column1: BENNETT: Sure.
CROWLEY: ... Don't do this on politics. Do this because it's the right thing to do.
BENNETT: Look
column2: that's fine. Pericles says courage is the secret of democracy. The president has said something like that
column3: too
column4: do the courageous thing. I think some members of Congress
column5: some Democrats have heard that as
column6: ""Do what my conscience tells me
column8: so we shall -- we shall see.

column1: But hold the tape
column2: this tape. Not to be mean
column3: but Democrats will lose seats on this. They will lose a lot of seats. Again
column4: this is what the nervousness is about.

column1: Now
column2: if this turns out to surprise me and surprise a lot of people and be profoundly good policy
column3: save the tape for that
column4: too
column5: because I will say to so. But look what happened in Massachusetts. You only had 4 percent uninsured. This thing opened the floodgates. What happens when you nationalize this kind of issue? You have states like Texas and California with 25 percent and 30 percent uninsured. This could bust the budget and really hurt the country.

column1: BRAZILE: Well
column2: you know
column3: what's disingenuous about the arguments that the opponents of health care reform will constantly give is that they're worried about the deficit
column4: they're worried about the deficit. Well
column5: if we do nothing
column6: health care will...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
BRAZILE: ... consume about 20 percent to 25 percent of our GDP. If we do nothing
column2: individuals like myself and others who have individual policies will see their premiums continue to rise.

column1: If the Republicans would like to somehow or another defend 39 percent increase in health care costs
column2: children getting kicked off their policies simply because they have asthma
column3: let them go out and defend that. Democrats will defend the substance of this and let the politics play out
column4: you know
column5: in November.

column1: BENNETT: Obamacare and doing nothing are not the only options. There are lots of other plans and lots of other ideas fully fleshed out
column2: as Paul Ryan's plan that he wrote with Tom Coburn. This is a plan that never got to see the light of day
column3: never allowed a scoring by CBO. We may revisit it again in the future when we see what this one wreaks.

column1: CROWLEY: Is this -- is health care the election issue
column2: or is it really the economy?

column1: BRAZILE: It's the economy. It's the economy. It's jobs. It's people feeling secure about their own livelihood. It's the American dream that's at stake. And
column2: look
column3: Paul Ryan had a plan that covered 3 million Americans
column4: reduced the deficit by $30 billion. This is a plan that will cover 32 million additional Americans and reduce the deficit over $138 billion in the next 10 years and
column5: of course
column6: $1.2 trillion over the next 20 years.

column1: If this -- this is good policy. Republicans who are concerned about the deficit
column2: like Democrats and independents
column3: should get behind this bill.

column1: CROWLEY: Bottom line
column2: Ryan won't pass. Is it...

column1: BENNETT: Right.
CROWLEY: So it will be this. But is this the election-year issue or is it jobs?
BENNETT: It's a big part of it
column2: and jobs is a big part of it
column3: but there's a larger thing
column4: too
column5: which is Washington and distrust of government. And who do they think they are? And don't they know
column6: can't they read that a majority of us said we were opposed to this

column1: And when the costs start coming in -- and
column2: by the way
column3: when they count the doctor fix
column4: which is going to put this in deficit
column5: they will see it's more cost to the government
column6: more cost to the taxpayer
column7: higher taxes. It's going to cost the Democrats. It's bad policy
column8: bad politics.

column1: BRAZILE: Let me -- let me quote -- let me -- let me quote Janet Jackson.
CROWLEY: Make it a short quote.

BRAZILE: What have you done for me lately? You've done nothing on jobs. You've done nothing on health care. You've done nothing to help fix this economy. The American people like to vote for something
column2: not just against something.

column1: BENNETT: Well
column2: they'll have the chance. They'll have the chance. And you will have your way
column3: and the Democrats will rule on this
column4: and probably get it
column5: and then they will own the store.

column1: BRAZILE: Well
column2: we're going to still love you
column3: though.

column1: BENNETT: Well
column2: I hope so.

column1: CROWLEY: The love-fest will continue. And they will be back
column2: I promise you.

column1: BENNETT: We'll still be your favorites? We'll still be your favorites?
CROWLEY: Still my favorites
column2: I promise.

column1: BRAZILE: Thank you.
CROWLEY: Ahead
column2: my colleague and former ""State of the Union"" host John King is back here for a Sunday chat about his new show.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: Let's check some of the stories breaking this Sunday.

Congressman John Larson said earlier on this program that Democrats have the 216 votes necessary to pass health care reform in the House of Representatives. The vote is scheduled for later this afternoon. Republican Congressman Mike Pence said that his party will use every means at their disposal to oppose the measure.
It is a weekend of protests here in Washington. Opponents of the health care reform bill gathered outside the U.S. Capitol Saturday demanding that lawmakers kill the bill.
Also yesterday
column2: hundreds held a demonstration to mark the seventh anniversary of the Iraq war.

column1: And today
column2: as the House votes on health care reform
column3: thousands are expected to gather here in the nation's capital to call on President Obama and Congress to take up immigration reform.

column1: North Dakota's Red River is expected to crest today. Several hundred thousand sandbags have been placed along the river's banks to keep the water at bay. So far
column2: flooding has not been as bad as feared.

column1: Two weeks after parliamentary elections in Iraq
column2: the vote remains too close to call. Iraqi Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki wants a manual recount. He says he's asking for it to preserve the integrity of the electoral process. So far
column3: preliminary results show the prime minister's coalition is leading in seven of Iraq's 18 provinces.

column1: And Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says his government will not stop building more Jewish settlements in disputed East Jerusalem. Announcement of the move during a recent visit to Israel by Vice President Joe Biden has called a strain in U.S.-Israeli relations. The Obama administration says additional settlements will undermine the Israeli-Palestinian peace process. Prime Minister Netanyahu is set to arrive in the U.S. for talks tomorrow.
Those are your top stories here on ""State of the Union."" Up next
column2: John King
column3: the man who used to sit in this very room
column4: will be here for a preview of his new 7 p.m. show
column5: ""John King
column6: USA.""

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
CROWLEY: Loyal followers of ""State of the Union"" will want to watch -- in fact
column2: I demand that they watch my colleague
column3: John King's
column4: new broadcast
column5: ""John King
column6: USA."" It premiers tomorrow evening. It's a program with a distinctive look and feel. But this guy
column8: let me first -- to start you
column10: because you're going to be following this all next week...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
CROWLEY: We hear -- and probably the week after.
KING: And the week after.
CROWLEY: John Larson says they got the votes. Do they?
KING: Well
column2: one of the deputy whips also said this morning not quite. I believe that -- you know how this works. We will see. Just as they're casting the votes
column3: in the final minutes
column4: there will be three or four people standing in a cluster over here and three or four standing in a cluster over there. They'll be talking to the whips and the leadership sources.

column1: And a few of them said
column2: Madam Speaker
column3: if you need me
column4: I'll vote yes
column5: but I'd like to keep my job and I'd prefer to vote no. And so they'll figure it out to the very end. So there -- they would not be doing this if they weren't confident they would get there at the end. There's always a few -- little bit of trading at the end.

column1: And then -- and you have had a fascinating discussion about it this morning -- then this becomes a Washington conversation from now to November and
column2: more importantly
column3: an American conversation between now and November. In this midterm election season
column4: you know
column5: sometimes we say this isn't about anything. This is going to be about something huge.

column1: CROWLEY: It's amazing
column2: because you really could hear the campaigns revving up
column3: sitting here
column4: because everybody knows this train is -- has left the station and is about to pull up someplace.

column1: OK
column2: tell me about the show. I mean
column3: first of all
column4: a whole -- I did watch it online when you did your -- your soft -- what do they call it
column5: soft rollout or whatever that is? Just tell me about it and
column6: like
column7: what the feel is you're going for and what you're hoping to do.

column1: KING: On the set
column2: we're trying to be a little bit more relaxed and casual
column3: a little more personal. All my things are on the set. You'll see campaign buttons that I've collected for the last 25 years. You'll see a couple of Fenway Park signs and Red Sox logos. That's who I am.

column1: CROWLEY: Surprising.

KING: Surprising. But it's like trying to bring somebody in your home or your place in a relaxed way to hopefully have more open and candid conversations. Day-to-day television is a little different from Sunday television. And
column2: you know
column3: I love what you've done with this space on Sunday.

column1: And
column2: look
column3: the mission of the program is to do -- take where you start here on Sundays and then project it out in the country. When these guys talk about we're on the side of the American people
column4: let's see if the House and the Senate pass this bill if the American people feel that way between now and November
column5: so we'll go to their communities. We're in their communities this week watching the protests
column6: watching the debates
column7: the phone calls come in to all these offices. We'll do it between now and November. This is one of the things in Washington that can seem like it's an all-Washington confrontation. Health care reform affects everybody; 309 million people in the United States of America will be affected one way or another by this bill
column8: whether they like it or not. So let's cover the big debates here in Washington
column9: but connect them to the impact out in the country. And that's what we're going to try to do.

column1: CROWLEY: So when I looked at it online
column2: it really was -- it seems like you're going more for that conversational. It's not your sort of evening news broadcast. Is that the feel of it?

column1: KING: I think that's exactly right. It's a news program. It's not a traditional newscast. We want it to be a community and a conversation
column2: not cable conflict
column3: people going at it.

column1: If you want to come in -- you can be on the far left and the far right
column2: but come in to have a conversation that is about what's in the bill. Object to the specifics of the policy we're discussing -- discussing
column3: not
column4: say
column5: because you're a D and I'm an R
column6: you're evil and we're just going to yell at each other. Let's come in and let's have a conversation
column8: but it can still be about something.

column1: And also we're going to reach out to people who don't live
column2: breathe
column3: eat
column4: and sleep politics in Washington
column5: D.C.
column6: but are involved in the process
column7: people who are motivating all those conservatives. Maybe they're tea party people. Maybe they're new faces who are organizing the conservative community.

column1: And the same is on the left. As you know
column2: one of the fascinating questions in this campaign
column3: Republicans have the intensity right now
column4: and conservatives -- not always the same thing. Can the left
column5: if they pass this bill -- and that's what a lot of what this is about -- the president trying to say
column6: look
column7: we will lose if we don't get our base back in this election season. One way to try to get them back is to make the tough votes and pass this bill. So that's what we want to track.

column1: CROWLEY: ""John King
column2: USA
column3: 7 p.m. Eastern tomorrow night. Be sure and watch.

column1: KING: Thank you.
CROWLEY: We will be there
column2: as well. John and the rest of the best political team on television will also be here this afternoon for today's coverage of the health care vote. And until then
column3: for our international viewers
column4: ""World Report"" is next. For everybody else
column5: ""Fareed Zakaria GPS"" starts right now.

An Annual Report compiled by Access Integrity Unit of the Arizona Department of Public Safety.
The Arizona Department of Public Safety is pleased to participate in and serve as the coordinating agency for the Arizona Uniform Crime Reporting Program.

The purpose of the Crime in Arizona Report is to provide data regarding the nature and extent of crime throughout the State. This report does not draw conclusions as to the causes of crime. The report does provide the vital information necessary to assist law enforcement agencies
column2: government
column3: and the public in their approach to crime in our state.

column1: This report is the culmination of a joint effort by our state's law enforcement agencies to collect and organize crime data. The information contained in this report should provide a valuable overview of the crime problem.

column1: 0	"BREAKING: Malia Obama SUSPENDED After Racist Anti-White Attack Goes Viral
A few days ago
column2: a student at Harvard leaked the contents of Malia Obama’s speech final. The topic? A World Without Whites. And now it may get Malia Obama suspended.

column1: “White people are so 1960’s. Sometimes the only thing that keeps me going is the fact that they will be blended out by the time I am 30
column2: ” a recording of Obama’s speech shared on Snapchat said. “Imagine a world without white people.” Obama was of course referring to the scientific belief that if whites continue to breed at low rates in America while others races continue to breed at current rates
column3: white babies will be virtually nonexistent in our country by 2038.

column1: A post quoting Obama was shared more than 14
column2: 000 times with a reach of nearly 1 million Americans
column3: which forced Harvard to take action.

column1: “This sort of attack against any race is uncalled for
column2: ” Harvard Dean Cain Markholder said in a statement Sunday. “Ms. Obama has been informed she is suspended pending an investigation into her statement.” But it gets worse for Obama — Markholder says that if a disciplinary board finds her guilty
column3: she will “forfeit her grade for the exam” which is worth 47% of her grade according to one of the students who shared video of her racist hate speech-filled attack on whites.

column1: The dean notes that punishment for racist attacks like this can lead to “expulsion
column2: ” but we’re sure that her dad will once again bail her out of trouble."	['https://web.archive.org/web/20180414054648im_/http://onlypolitics.info/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/malia-678x381.jpg'

column4: 'https://web.archive.org/web/20180414054648im_/http://onlypolitics.info/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/logo.png'

column1: 0	"Liberal menace and purveyor of lies
column2: Nancy Pelosi (D-California)
column3: was just taken from her office in handcuffs by the United States Secret Service. While little information is available as of yet
column4: one agent did tell a reporter for the Washington Examiner that the arrest came at the direct order of the president:

column1: “Mrs. Pelosi’s arrest order comes directly from the Oval Office
column2: ” said Special Agent Matthew Derpmore
column3: “She’s wanted for questioning in a possible coup attempt against the president. That’s all we’re authorized to say at this time.”

column1: The White House OIP has confirmed that report
column2: calling Pelosi a usurper and a threat to the office of President Trump:

column1: Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi’s arrest for conspiacy to overthrow the office of the President is being taken very seriously. She is said to be at the head of a select group of congressmen who have set in motion plans to use the president’s allegedly unlawful actions to begin imeachment hearings. Without evidence and with a clear denial from the president of these allegations such actions warrant charges of conspiracy and possibly even treason.
Pelosi’s office hasn’t issued a statement yet. According to records obtained by Breitbart
column2: three other congressmen are also wanted and are currently having warrants against them served. We’ll keep you updated as the story progresses." column1: 0	"Amendment XXV
Section 1.
In case of the removal of the President from office or of his death or resignation
column2: the Vice President shall become President.

column1: Section 2.
Whenever there is a vacancy in the office of the Vice President
column2: the President shall nominate a Vice President who shall take office upon confirmation by a majority vote of both Houses of Congress.

column1: Section 3.

Whenever the President transmits to the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives his written declaration that he is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office
column2: and until he transmits to them a written declaration to the contrary
column3: such powers and duties shall be discharged by the Vice President as Acting President.

column1: Section 4.
Whenever the Vice President and a majority of either the principal officers of the executive departments or of such other body as Congress may by law provide
column2: transmit to the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives their written declaration that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office
column3: the Vice President shall immediately assume the powers and duties of the office as Acting President.

column1: Thereafter
column2: when the President transmits to the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives his written declaration that no inability exists
column3: he shall resume the powers and duties of his office unless the Vice President and a majority of either the principal officers of the executive department or of such other body as Congress may by law provide
column4: transmit within four days to the President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives their written declaration that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office. Thereupon Congress shall decide the issue
column5: assembling within forty-eight hours for that purpose if not in session. If the Congress
column6: within twenty-one days after receipt of the latter written declaration
column8: if Congress is not in session
column9: within twenty-one days after Congress is required to assemble
column10: determines by two-thirds vote of both Houses that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office
column11: the Vice President shall continue to discharge the same as Acting President; otherwise
column12: the President shall resume the powers and duties of his office."	['https://www.law.cornell.edu/sites/all/themes/liizenboot/images/LII_logo_footer.gif'

column1: 0	"Bill Clinton on Rush Limbaugh
column2: His Own Mistakes
column3: the Supreme Court
column4: Middle East Peace Former President Bill Clinton discusses the issues on ""This Week.""

column1: April 18
column2: 2010  -- Bill Clinton made mistakes as president on financial regulation
column3: he admitted in an exclusive ""This Week"" interview
column4: but Clinton stood his ground regarding the dangers of overheated political rhetoric
column5: saying Rush Limbaugh's accusation Clinton ""set the stage for violence"" with a recent speech on the subject ""doesn't make any sense.""

column1: In his first ""This Week"" interview since the passage of health care reform
column2: Clinton reflected on how the bill's success made him feel like Teddy Roosevelt to Obama's FDR. And Clinton offered advice and thoughts on some of Obama's next issues -- a Supreme Court nomination
column3: the Middle East peace process and the midterm elections.

column1: Anchor Jake Tapper asked Clinton about Limbaugh's criticism of his speech marking the upcoming 15th anniversary of the Oklahoma City bombing. In that speech
column2: Clinton warned that ""the words we use really do matter
column3: because there's this vast echo chamber
column4: and they go across space and they fall on the serious and delirious alike. They fall on the connected and the unhinged alike.""

column1: On ""This Week
column2: Clinton said
column3: ""The only point I tried to make was that we ought to have a lot of political dissent -- a lot of political argument. Nobody is right all the time. But we also have to take responsibility for the possible consequences of what we say.""

column1: Clinton said he worries about threats against President Obama and the Congress. And
column2: he worries ""about more careless language ... some of which we've seen against the Republican governor in New Jersey
column3: Gov. Christie.""

column1: A recently leaked memo from a New Jersey teacher joked about Christie dying.
I think we all have to be careful
column2: Clinton said. ""We ought to remember [that] after Oklahoma City we learned something about the difference in disagreement and demonization.""

column1: On Derivatives: 'I Was Wrong'
Clinton acknowledged that he was wrong to take what he now views as bad advice from his Treasury secretaries
column2: Robert Rubin and Larry Summers
column3: who told him the market for complex financial instruments known as derivatives ought to remain unregulated.

column1: On derivatives
column2: yeah
column3: I think they were wrong and I think I was wrong to take [their advice]
column4: Clinton said
column5: ""because the argument on derivatives was that these things are expensive and sophisticated and only a handful of investors will buy them
column6: and they don't need any extra protection and any extra transparency. The money they're putting up guarantees them transparency.

column1: The flaw in that argument
column2: Clinton added
column3: ""was that first of all sometimes people with a lot of money make stupid decisions and make it without transparency.""

column1: The former president said he also was wrong in his understanding of what a collapse in the derivative market could do to the economy.
The most important flaw
column2: he said
column3: ""was even if less than 1 percent of the total investment community is involved in derivative exchanges
column4: so much money was involved that if they went bad
column5: they could affect 100 percent of the investments
column6: and indeed 100 percent of the citizens in countries
column7: not investors. And I was wrong about that.""

column1: He now wishes he had tried to regulate derivatives while in office
column2: but he doesn't think he would have been successful.

column1: Now
column2: I think if I had tried to regulate them
column3: because the Republicans were the majority in the Congress
column4: they would have stopped it
column5: he said. ""But I wish I should have been caught trying. I mean
column6: that was a mistake I made.""

column1: Bill Clinton's Supreme Court Nominee Advice: Robe Not Required
Clinton said a robe isn't necessarily a requirement for being nominated to the Supreme Court.
Asked about his advice for President Obama as he selects a nominee to be the next Supreme Court justice
column2: Clinton said he hopes the president will ""take a look at somebody who hasn't been a judge.""

column1: The important thing
column2: Clinton said
column3: ""is that you think they're smart and they're competent and they understand the lives of ordinary people.""

column1: When asked if he or his wife
column2: Secretary of State Hillary Clinton
column3: would be suited for the job
column4: Clinton said at 63
column5: he's too old and
column6: ""I'd like to see him put someone in their late 40s
column7: early 50s on the court and someone with a lot of energy for the job.""

column1: Hillary Clinton
column2: he said
column3: would have the same advice.

column1: Diversity
column2: he suggested
column3: should also be a consideration.

column1: My advice to him would be to first of all see what the court is missing
column2: Clinton said. ""Does it matter if he puts a Catholic or a Jewish person or someone of another faith on a court? ... There would be no Protestants on the Supreme Court. Does that matter? Does there need to be another woman on the court? Should there be some other group represented?""

column1: Ecstatic Over Health Care Passage: Felt Like Teddy Roosevelt
On the recent health care reform bill
column2: Clinton said he felt like ""Teddy Roosevelt would have felt if he'd still been alive in the 1930s seeing his cousin Franklin being able to sign legislation in areas that he had advocated.""

column1: Clinton was thrilled that it passed and that he and Hillary Clinton personally lobbied for passage before the final vote on the bill.
She and I were ecstatic
column2: he said.

column1: Clinton expects more changes in the bill.
They'll have to keep working on it and putting more cost drivers in it to take the cost down
column2: he said. ""But it's a big
column3: big step. And it's a wonderful thing for the country.""

column1: Midterm Elections: Another 1994?
Clinton said the current political environment reminds him ""a little bit"" of 1994
column2: a year in which Democrats lost majorities in both houses of Congress in a Republican landslide.

column1: I think that the dissent is just as intense
column2: if not more intense
column3: he said. ""But I think the outcome of the election is likely to be far less dramatic than it was in '94.""

column1: Clinton expects Republicans to make some gains
column2: but ""I don't think they'll win either house.""

column1: Back in 1994
column2: congressional Democrats put their jobs on the line to vote for President Clinton's economic package. The recent health care vote
column3: he said
column4: was similar
column5: but the country is different now.

column1: We are culturally a different country
column2: he said. ""We are more diverse. We're more communitarian. That is
column3: we understand we have to solve a lot of these problems together.""

column1: Middle East Peace Process
Clinton said he was reluctant to offer public advice to President Obama regarding the Middle East peace process
column2: so as not to foreclose his options.

column1: But he added
column2: ""We need to do something to deprive both sides of any excuse not to engage in serious negotiations.""

column1: If President Obama puts a peace plan on the table
column2: Clinton said he will ""strongly support it.""

column1: The argument against the administration putting forward a peace plan
column2: Clinton said
column3: is that the current Israeli government ""almost certainly would reject it."" That
column4: he said
column5: could ""make us look weak.""

column1: But the Obama administration
column2: Clinton said
column3: ""may decide it's more important to have clarity and to do something that will be an action-forcing event to put them back to the table."""	['data:image/gif;base64

column1: 0	"Republican attacks on transgendered Americans and the religious fight to keep gender a binary delineation took a turn for the bizarre this week when Virginia Republican Mark Cole filed a bill that would force schools to check the genitals of their students in order to ensure that they are using facilities reserved for their “anatomical sex:”
Local school boards shall develop and implement policies that require every school restroom
column2: locker room
column3: or shower room that is designated for use by a specific gender to solely be used by individuals whose anatomical sex matches such gender designation. Such policies may also provide that a student may
column4: upon request
column5: be granted access
column6: to the extent reasonable
column7: to a single stall restroom or shower
column8: a unisex bathroom
column9: or controlled individual use of a restroom
column11: or shower. Any student who willfully and knowingly violates this section shall be liable for a civil penalty not to exceed $50. Civil penalties assessed under this section shall be paid into the Literary Fund. Any law-enforcement officer may issue a summons regarding a violation of this section.

column1: He did not deign to inform us how this would be accomplished
column2: but it’s hard to imagine any scenario that did not involve adults inspecting the genitals of children before using the bathroom. Notably
column3: it also provides for stigmatizing transgendered children by isolating them in a single person bathroom
column4: which the Department of Justice ruled in June was a violation of the student’s rights. It is a disgusting show of transphobia that has no place in our public schools; the GOP must accept that America is a multi-gendered
column5: multi-ethnic nation
column6: and no amount of perverted laws is going to change that."	"[""data:image/svg+xml
column8: 'https://staging.occupydemocrats.com/wp-content/uploads/Occupy-Democrats-Logo.png'
column18: %3Csvg%20xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'%20viewBox='0%200%20172%20172'%3E%3C/svg%3E""]"	https://occupydemocrats.com/wp-content/uploads/occupy-democrats.jpg	Virginia Republican Wants Schools To Check Children's Genitals Before Using Bathroom	http://www.occupydemocrats.com

column1: 0	"CNBC reported that Trump has substantial investments in the companies involved with the construction of the pipeline. Trump’s early decision to approve the pipeline was a conflict-of-interest
column2: and we must impeach him for it.

column1: Donald Trump’s business investments spread throughout the world. Now
column2: we know that he has ties to the Dakota Access Pipeline
column3: the one that crosses sacred Indian land.

column1: The construction of the pipeline raised the ire of Native American Sioux settlements in the area. It will cross sacred land and pollute their water supply.
The pipeline is also a threat to the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers
column2: which provide drinking water for millions of people. In addition
column3: the two rivers provide shipping avenues for commerce through the middle of the country.

column1: Opposition to the pipeline resulted in massive protests. The protests received international coverage when police and security workers for the construction firms sprayed protestors with water and beat them.
The opposition brought out many supporters
column2: too. On November 15
column4: there was a National Day of Action to protest the construction. There were massive protests in cities as Los Angeles
column5: Chicago
column6: Denver
column7: and Trump’s own Manhattan in support of the Sioux Nation.

column1: Veterans also went to the front lines of the protest to stand against the construction and the violence from the hired thugs. American heroes supporting Native American heroes.

And now we learn that “President” Trump has investments in the companies building the pipelines. No wonder the Orange Fuehrer ordered the resumption of their construction as one of his first moves as president.
This should come as no surprise since Trump ‘s financial ties are everywhere. Almost daily
column2: we hear of another financial conflict-of-interest involving the president.

column1: This involvement is another example of Trump’s unconstitutional failure to divest himself of his businesses interests. The Tenth Amendment of the Constitution prohibits him from profiting from decisions made while president. And here it is
column2: another unconstitutional violation.

column1: According to Ethics experts
column2: Trump’s decisions to pass his businesses to his two sons is not adequate. As with other presidents
column3: he must divest himself of all business interests and place them in a blind trust.

column1: The blind trust would prohibit Trump from any involvement. As he wants it
column2: his two spoiled brat sons would consult him on business decisions regularly
column3: and he would surely lie about it.

column1: The Dakota Pipeline investment is one of many illegal ones by Trump
column2: but perhaps the most controversial. If only the mainstream media will pick up the story and run with it will the public know of Trump’s support of the cruel actions of the police.

column1: We must insist that the media tell this story. With its broadcast
column2: the public will see how Trump uses the presidency for his financial gain and support his immediate impeachment.

column1: Please share this story on Facebook!"	['https://web.archive.org/web/20170310140734im_/http://www.learnprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/trump_dapl_0208.jpg'
column2: 'https://web.archive.org/web/20170310140734im_/http://www.learnprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/wp-logo.png'
column3: 'https://web.archive.org/web/20170310140734im_/https://www.facebook.com/tr?id=1173586689414819&ev=PageView&noscript=1']	https://web.archive.org/web/20170310140734im_/http://www.learnprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/trump_dapl_0208.jpg	BREAKING: Trump Caught INVESTING in Dakota Pipeline Before Signing It	https://web.archive.org

column1: 0	"Ohio Sen. Rob Portman has been busy in Washington touting the Comprehensive Addiction Recovery Act in response to a shocking number of heroin overdoses in Ohio.
The bill just passed in the Senate
column2: 94-1. (Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse was the sole ""nay
column3: saying he believes that fighting addiction is a local issue.)

column1: Ohio ranks high on the list of states reeling from the national epidemic. In Montgomery County
column2: which encompasses Dayton
column3: Ohio
column4: heroin-related deaths increased 225 percent between 2011 and 2015.

column1: Back in the 1970s
column2: the heroin on U.S. streets was the ""black tar"" variety
column3: and much of it came from southeast Asia. In 2010
column4: 80 percent of the heroin in the world came from poppy fields in Afghanistan
column5: according to the Office of National Drug Control Policy.

column1: So when Portman said that most of the heroin in America comes from Mexico’s border
column2: we were skeptical.

column1: Portman
column2: it turns out
column3: has done his homework. The Drug Enforcement Administration’s National Drug Threat Assessment of 2015 says that Mexico is the primary supplier of heroin to the United States.

column1: Southeast Asia was once the dominant supplier of heroin in the United States
column2: but Southeast Asian heroin is now rarely detected in U.S. markets
column3: the report state. ""Mexico and
column4: to a lesser extent
column5: Colombia dominate the U.S. heroin market
column6: because of their proximity
column8: and ability to satisfy U.S. heroin demand.""

column1: The report also says that Mexican ""transnational criminal organizations
column2: (the DEA’s term for drug-dealing gangs) ""pose the greatest criminal drug threat to the United States; no other group is currently positioned to challenge them.""

column1: The National Drug Threat report notes that Colombian gangs were traditionally the suppliers of wholesale cocaine and heroin to Mexican and Dominican groups. But cartels in Mexico are ramping up their roles on the supply side -- opium production in Mexico increased by 50 percent in 2014.
Mexican labs also produce fentanyl
column2: a synthetic painkiller that is 80 to 100 times stronger than morphine. Fentanyl is sometimes mixed with heroin or substituted for heroin
column3: and the DEA reports more than 700 overdoses attributed to fentanyl between late 2013 and early 2015.

column1: Drugs get past the U.S. borders mostly ""by land
column2: not by sea
column3: said Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson
column4: in the same March 8 hearing with Portman. And a 2015 Washington Post series on the surge of heroin puts the border detection rate at a scant 1.5 percent.

column1: Smugglers’ creativity defies gravity: One successful bust came when agents caught two men flying a drone carrying 28 pounds of heroin from Mexico to California.
Our ruling
Portman said that heroin is coming to the United States primarily from Mexico. He hasn’t been studying drug facts for nothing.
We rate this claim True."	['https://static.politifact.com/CACHE/images/politifact/mugs/politifactohio-ted-strickland____/c7f2efddf025301e0dd7ae538c47409f.jpg'

column4: 'http://www.facebook.com/tr?id=292850974235854&ev=PageView&noscript=1'
column5: 'https://static.politifact.com/CACHE/images/politifact/mugs/shutterstock_566530930/8ef1f10571f92f0da1a0b9bebbad2816.jpg'

column1: 0	"Last night
column2: a twitter account by the name of @solikearose tweeted out a surprising image of CNN broadcasting porn instead of Anthony Bourdain’s scheduled show Parts Unknown. And then without really much questioning
column3: a bunch of news sites ran with it
column4: claiming that the network showed the footage for about 30 minutes. Here are some screenshots grabbed by Mediaite.

column1: It looks like the chaos all started when The Independent wrote up a story from this person’s tweets
column2: which was then tweeted out by the Drudge Report. After that
column3: it spread fast. Mashable
column4: The New York Post
column5: The Daily Mail
column6: Esquire
column7: and Variety have all published a story
column8: and pretty much all of these articles are based on one or two tweets from @solikerose. Plus
column9: many of the original stories didn’t include statements from CNN or RCN
column10: the cable company that supposedly aired the porn.

column1: Fact-checking largely didn’t begin until the stories were published. The @solikearose account has since turned private
column2: and there don’t seem to be any reports of porn airing on CNN last night. RCN also released statements on twitter saying there is no evidence that porn was aired last night in Boston
column3: where @solikearose is supposedly based. ""We are in the process of researching this incident but see no evidence our CNN network feed was compromised last evening in Boston
column4: Jeff Carlson
column5: SVP and general manager of RCN Boston
column6: said in a statement to multiple outlets.

column1: CNN has also released a statement: “The RCN cable operator in Boston aired inappropriate content for 30 minutes on CNN last night. CNN has asked for an explanation.” But that still doesn’t really verify that anything occurred.
@solikearose 800-746-4726. We have not had any reports of the programming issue you mentioned on CNN in Boston. If you're still having an — RCN (@RCNconnects) November 25
@solikearose issue with that channel
column2: please DM us your address so we can troubleshoot when you're home. Thanks
column3: Melissa — RCN (@RCNconnects) November 25

column1: The appeal of the story is obvious: a network news may have aired porn for a full 30 minutes. Hilarious! And the CNN program that was supposed to be on was Anthony Bourdain: Parts Unknown. It’s a layup for body-part puns.
This is exactly how fake news spreads
But this is exactly how fake news spreads. Even if porn was aired on CNN
column2: it’s clear that a lot of publications ran with a story based on tweets from one person before verifying the facts. Many of the headlines already implicate CNN
column3: claiming the channel aired 30 minutes of porn without giving any context.

column1: The stakes might not seem very high in this case
column2: but fake news seems to have played a major role during the 2016 presidential campaign. Mistakes like this won’t be very funny when they cost us more than a laugh."	['https://cdn.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/JJ_FnfYh2eigozj1oaw-fFTEJTc=/0x0:600x358/1200x0/filters:focal(0x0:600x358):no_upscale()/cdn.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_asset/file/7533931/cnns_channel_accidentally_broadcast_hardcore_porn.jpg'
