column4: 'https://cdn.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/1JWBU7azXgf9LLvV96N9-8sdRJA=/0x0:552x484/1200x0/filters:focal(0x0:552x484):no_upscale()/cdn.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_asset/file/7533929/Screen_Shot_2016_11_25_at_10.33.00_AM.jpg'
column5: 'https://cdn.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/sye0FzRVD4YBWJrAw-iQkowVJCc=/0x96:1024x672/1600x900/cdn.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/52002051/drudgesiren.0.jpeg']	https://cdn.vox-cdn.com/thumbor/sye0FzRVD4YBWJrAw-iQkowVJCc=/0x96:1024x672/1600x900/cdn.vox-cdn.com/uploads/chorus_image/image/52002051/drudgesiren.0.jpeg	The CNN porn scare is how fake news spreads	http://www.theverge.com

column1: 0	"METHODOLOGY: The totals on these charts are calculated from PAC contributions and contributions from individuals giving more than $200
column2: as reported to the Federal Election Commission. Individual contributions are generally categorized based on the donor's occupation/employer
column3: although individuals may be classified instead as ideological donors if they've given more than $200 to an ideological PAC.

column1: 0	"John McCain will establish a market-based system to curb greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions
column2: mobilize innovative technologies
column3: and strengthen the economy. He will work with our international partners to secure our energy future
column4: to create opportunities for American industry
column5: and to leave a better future for our children.

column1: John McCain’s Principles For Climate Policy:
Climate Policy Should Be Built On Scientifically-Sound
column2: Mandatory Emission Reduction Targets And Timetables.

column1: Climate Policy Should Utilize A Market-Based Cap And Trade System.
Climate Policy Must Include Mechanisms To Minimize Costs And Work Effectively With Other Markets.
Climate Policy Must Spur The Development And Deployment Of Advanced Technology.
Climate Policy Must Facilitate International Efforts To Solve The Problem."	['https://web.archive.org/web/20080514182038im_/http://www.johnmccain.com/Images/mccain2_header_03.jpg'
column2: 'https://web.archive.org/web/20080514182038im_/http://www.johnmccain.com/Images/mccain2nav-l.gif'

column1: 0	"July 11
column2: 2010  -- JAKE TAPPER
column3: HOST: I know that there are some in the White House who feel Wall Street reform
column4: health care legislation
column5: stimulus
column6: and yet the public still overwhelmingly thinks this country is on the wrong track.

column1: Are you not getting enough credit
column2: you and the administration?

column1: JOSEPH BIDEN
column2: VICE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Look
column3: these are gigantic packages to deal with a gigantic problem we inherited. And the vast majority of the American people and a lot of people really involved don't even know what's inside the packages. And so you have
column4: for example
column5: Mr. Boehner already calling for the repeal of -- of the reform that just passed on Wall Street. People don't realize
column6: in that reform
column8: you say
column10: we've had meat inspection for 100 years ago
column11: the meat packing companies didn't like it. Automobile safety 50 years ago.

column1: People are going to look back on this very shortly and say
column2: why shouldn't we have some consumer group in -- entity looking at whether or not you can give someone a mortgage with no down payment
column3: with no -- with a teaser interest rate
column4: with no documentation
column5: etc.

column1: So it is -- people don't know that. Just like people don't know a lot of what's going on in The Recovery Act
column2: understandably
column3: because this has been so much stuff that has been flowing our way. And -- and we're facing a bunch of guys who are good guys
column4: but they're all about repeal and -- and repeat. Repeal what we're doing and go back
column5: repeal the incentives for industry to invest in solar energy. Repeal the health care bill that allows you to keep your kid on your health care policy
column6: precondi -- preexisting conditions can't deny you policies

column1: It's just going to take time. This is Jan -- this is July. The election is not until November. And I think we're going to have to firmly make our case. I think we can make it and especially in the context of who's going to be opposing us.
Compared to the alternative
column2: I think we're going to get a fair amount of credit by November and I think we're going to do fine.

column1: TAPPER: So the reason you're not getting enough credit is because the public doesn't understand everything that's happened yet?
BIDEN: Well
column2: nor could they or should they. Look
column3: in the last six months of the Bush administration
column4: they lost three million jobs. Before we got our economic package in place
column5: another 3.7 million jobs were lost in the first six months we took office. The last six months of this year -- the first six months of this year
column6: we created almost 600
column8: you know
column9: in the private market. That's not nearly enough to make up for the eight million jobs lost in the recession. But people are going to start to focus on exactly what we're doing. And all -- look
column11: at least from sitting around my dad's kitchen table and -- and the people I grew up with is when things are really tough economically and the country is in trouble
column12: all they want to know is
column13: they -- they don't expect an answer
column14: but they expect to be reassured that we're moving in the right direction.

column1: That is...
TAPPER: But they don't think that we are.
BIDEN: No. No
column2: they don't think now because I don't think they know the detail of what's going on.

column1: For example
column2: here you had the insurance industry spending hundreds of millions of dollars to make the health care bill out to be this God awful tragedy.

column1: Now what's starting off to happen?
The health care numbers are going up.
Why?
Because they're figuring out that small businesses are going to get a 30 percent tax cut. They didn't know that because of all the advertising done.
So there's a lot -- and -- and I would use health care as an example. Health care has gone from a barrage of advertising against it
column2: why it was so bad
column3: just like Wall Street reform. The financial industry spent hundreds of millions of dollars lobbying against this – this is an awful thing
column4: it's government regulation. All it is
column5: is rational control and the turning around of what the Republicans did
column6: which is let Wall Street run wild.

column1: People -- when you say to people
column2: you know
column3: we just went out and had a regulatory reform bill
column4: where I come from
column5: it's like
column6: OK

column1: They don't know what it means yet
column2: understandably. And so I think it takes time
column3: Jake.

column1: TAPPER: There's that famous saying in Washington by Mike Kinsley that a gaffe is when a politician accidentally tells the truth. Robert Gibbs experienced some of that this -- this past few days...
BIDEN: I've never had a gaffe.
TAPPER: You've never had an issue with gaffes.
(LAUGHTER)
TAPPER: No
column2: I know. So you can't relate.

column1: BIDEN: Yeah.
TAPPER: But -- but he said that enough seats are in the play in the House for the Democrats to possibly lose the House. Empirically true.
How bad are the losses going to be for Democrats?

BIDEN: I don't think the losses are going to be bad at all. I think we're going to shock the heck out of everybody. I really -- and I've been saying this now. I think even when you and I went down to North Carolina and you followed be on the recovery trip
column2: I was saying it then. I am absolutely confidence -- confident when people take a look at the what has happened since we've taken office in November and comparing it to the alternative
column3: we're going to be very -- we're going to be in great shape.

column1: Here's the deal. What Robert Gibbs also said was what he believes
column2: what I believe
column3: what the president believes
column4: we're going to win the House and we're going to win the Senate. We're not going to lose either one of those bodies.

column1: And so
column2: again
column3: this is July. November and at the time
column4: the most vulnerable time any public official finds himself in is when they have no opponent.

column1: Look at Harry Reid. You know
column2: I got -- I got kind of banged around for saying I think there was a 55 percent chance Harry Reid is going to win. Well
column3: Harry Reid
column4: when he was the -- you know
column5: on the other side of the barrage of how bad Harry Reid was
column6: was in trouble. Now Harry Reid
column8: was up 7 points. I -- he I think he -- I -- I'd bet anything -- I'm not allowed to bet
column9: but I'll bet Harry Reid wins. You're going to see that repeated.

column1: So
column2: that old -- to paraphrase Mark Twain
column3: I think the -- the reports of our demise are premature.

column1: TAPPER: The NAACP had a convention in the last week. And they passed a resolution saying that elements of the Tea Party are racist.
Do you think elements of the Tea Party are racist?
BIDEN: Well
column2: the truth is that at least elements that were involved in some of the Tea Party folks expressed racist views. We saw that on television and it was turned -- but I don't think -- I don't -- I wouldn't characterize the Tea Party as racist. There are individuals who are either members of or on the periphery of some of their things
column3: their -- their protests -- that have expressed really unfortunate comments. And
column4: again
column5: it was all over TV
column6: all over your network

column1: A black congressman walking up the stairs of the Capitol.
But I don't believe
column2: the president doesn't believe that the Tea Party is -- is a racist organization. I don't believe that. Very conservative. Very different views on government and a whole lot of things. But it is not a racist organization.

column1: TAPPER: One of the big issues in this election
column2: in this mid-term election is the economy.

column1: BIDEN: Yes.
TAPPER: Non-financial institutions are sitting on $1.8 trillion in cash money that could be spent expanding
column2: creating jobs...

column1: BIDEN: Yes.

TAPPER: -- and they're not spending it on that -- that way. A lot of members of the business community in the last week or so have been saying the reason that money is not being spent on expansion or jobs is because the business community is convinced that the Obama administration is anti-business and they're worried about what legislation
column2: what regulation is coming down the pike.

column1: Why do you think they're not spending that money?
BIDEN: Three months ago
column2: those same business leaders
column3: they were in the White House in meetings with us saying
column4: you know
column5: you're going to be surprised on the up side how many people we're going to be hiring.

column1: I think that a couple of things have happened.
One
column2: they didn't anticipate and no one anticipated the potential collapse of the European economy and the so-called Eurozone -- Greece and Spain and all of that. That put a real brake on an awful lot of people in terms of their optimism about where the world economy was going
column3: because we're affected by that indirectly.

column1: Secondly
column2: I think that the very uncertainty they had is now been settled by the passage of the reforms. They didn't know which way they were going to go. They didn't know how much was going to happen.

column1: So I think there is increased certainty now that the major reform they were worried about is law. It's passed. And they're going to know how to deal with it.
I think you see stabilization on the European side
column2: in terms of the so-called euro and the Eurozone. And I think that's going to help.

column1: So I think you're going to see them beginning to move.
TAPPER: You said that the stimulus is -- is working.
BIDEN: Yeah.
TAPPER: And you said earlier
column2: in the past week
column3: you talked about three million jobs being created by the stimulus...

column1: BIDEN: Yeah.
TAPPER: -- so far. But since the stimulus passed
column2: more than three million jobs have been lost. And before you took office
column3: three million jobs were lost.

column1: BIDEN: Yeah.
TAPPER: Was the stimulus
column2: in retrospect
column3: too small?

column1: BIDEN: Look
column2: there's a lot of people at the time argued it was too small. Actually
column3: we...

column1: TAPPER: A lot of people in your administration.
BIDEN: -- yes. A lot of people in our administration
column2: a lot of -- I mean
column3: you know
column4: even some Republican economists and some Nobel laureates like Paul Krugman
column5: who continues to argue it was too small. But
column6: you know
column7: there was a reality. In order to get what we got passed
column8: we had to find Republican votes. And we found three -- three. And we finally got it passed.

column1: So there is the reality of whether or not the Republicans are willing to play
column2: whether or not the Republicans are just about repeal and repeat the old policies or they're really wanting to do something. And I -- I'm not -- I'm not -- you know...

column1: TAPPER: So if you didn't have Republicans that you had -- if you didn't have the legislative reality...
BIDEN: I think what...
TAPPER: -- it would have been bigger?
BIDEN: I think it would have been bigger. I think it would have been bigger. In fact
column2: what we offered was slightly bigger than that. But the truth of the matter is that the recovery package
column3: everybody's talking about it having -- it's over. The truth is now
column4: we're spending more now this summer than we -- I'm calling this the recovery -- the summer of recovery. We have two
column5: three times as many highway projects going. We have significant investment in broadband for the first time now. It's starting to really ramp up because the contracts have been let. In high speed rail
column6: in wind energy.

column1: I mean
column2: where are the new jobs going to come from?

column1: And that's what we're laying the foundation for. And
column2: again
column3: this is a hard slog
column4: man. And it's counter-intuitive. It's counter-intuitive to say someone sitting at a kitchen table in Claymont
column5: Delaware
column6: who lost their jobs – by the way
column7: we saved or created three million jobs and they pick up when we lost three million.

column1: The truth is
column2: over three million people who are now working would be out of work but for this. The truth of the matter is there's an overwhelming consensus that we're not losing jobs now
column3: we're creating jobs. The argument's gone from losing jobs to are we creating them fast enough
column4: not whether we're creating them. And nothing is fast enough till you get these people back to work.

column1: TAPPER: Turning to Afghanistan...
BIDEN: Yeah.
TAPPER: -- which is foremost on a lot of Americans' minds
column2: I want to read you a quote from Jonathan Alter's new book: ""At the conclusion of an interview in his West Wing office
column3: Vice President Biden was adamant in July of 2011
column4: that we're going to see a whole lot of people moving out. 'Bet on it
column5: ' Biden said
column6: as wheeled to leave the room
column7: late for lunch with the president. He turned at the door and said once more
column8: 'Bet on it.'""

column1: Did you say that to...
BIDEN: I did say that.
TAPPER: -- to Jon Alter?
BIDEN: I did say that.
TAPPER: And what did you mean
column2: a whole lot of people...

column1: BIDEN: Well
column2: what I said...

column1: TAPPER: -- moving out?
BIDEN: -- if you read three or four paragraphs above that
column2: Jonathan was making a very valid point. He was saying a lot in the military think they outmaneuvered the president to render the July date meaningless. And I was saying that's simply not true. The military signed on. Petraeus signed on. Everybody signed onto not a deadline
column3: but a transition
column4: a beginning of a transition.

column1: TAPPER: But what does a whole lot of people moving out mean?
BIDEN: Well
column2: what I was talking about was you have -- we're going to have over 100
column3: 000 people there and two...

column1: TAPPER: More
column2: right
column3: if you include NATO troops?

column1: BIDEN: Oh
column2: yeah. I'm just talking about Americans.

column1: TAPPER: Yes.
BIDEN: A hundred and forty thousand people there. And there's going to be a drawdown of forces as we transition. There are 34 districts in Afghanistan and the plan is
column2: as we train up the Afghanis
column3: we are going to
column4: beginning in August
column5: say
column6: OK
column8: we no longer have to have American or NATO forces in that province. There will be a transition.

column1: And really what I was responding to was the idea that the president had been outmaneuvered. I was saying make it clear. And so it -- it wasn't so much numbers I meant. It could be as few as a couple thousand troops. It could be more. But there will be a transition.
TAPPER: Let's talk about the present in Afghanistan. Marjah did not as well as hoped. Kandahar has been delayed.
How is you and the president
column2: your new way forward in Afghanistan
column3: where are we in that?

column1: Are we -- are we losing?
Are we trading water?
Where are we?
BIDEN: It's too early to make a judgment. We don't even have all the troops of the so-called surge in place yet. That won't happen until August.
TAPPER: But it's not -- it doesn't seem like it's going...
BIDEN: No...
TAPPER: -- according to plan.
BIDEN: No
column2: it is -- well...

column1: TAPPER: We're losing a lot of troops.
BIDEN: Well
column2: unfortunately
column3: everyone knew that in these summer months
column4: when they can infiltrate from Pakistan under the cover of foliage and the rest and it's open
column5: that there would be more deaths. That's been the pattern. And now we're engaging them more and there are more deaths.

column1: But we still believe that the policy that the military signed onto
column2: put together initially
column3: signed onto
column4: is
column5: in fact
column6: going to work. And let me define what I mean by work. We are making considerable progress against al Qaeda
column7: which is our primary target. We're taking out significant numbers of the leadership in al Qaeda. And we are
column8: in the process
column9: which is painfully slow and difficult
column10: of training up Afghani forces in order to put them in a position they can deal with their own insurgents. There is
column12: a real attempt and a policy of trying to figure out how to reconcile those in the Taliban who are doing it for the pay
column13: who are not the Mullah Omars of the world

column1: All of this is just beginning. And we knew it was going to be a tough slog. But I think it's much too premature to make a judgment until the military said we should look at it
column2: which is in December.

column1: TAPPER: There was a recent incident involving the commanding general -- now the ex-commanding general in Afghanistan
column2: Stanley McChrystal. And I just wondered
column3: since you were one of the people mentioned disparagingly by his aides. I know he called you to apologize.

column1: BIDEN: He did.
TAPPER: I'm wondering
column2: what was your reaction when you...

column1: BIDEN: I didn't take it personally at all. I really
column2: honest to God
column3: didn't
column4: compared to what happens in politics
column5: this is -- that was a piece of cake. And it wasn't so disparaging is that I -- I was the enemy. It wasn't that I -- I wasn't the clown. I was the guy who
column6: in fact
column8: they thought. I'm not their problem. I agree with the policy the president put in place. But it was clear -- I was asked to and I did on my own survey
column12: every single one said he had to go.

column1: So we did -- we made -- the president made the right decision. He changed the personalities
column2: but not the policy. He put the strongest guy in the U.S. military and a counter-insurgency policy in place.

column1: So I think it was -- it was the absolutely necessary thing to do. The president didn't take it personally. I didn't. I met with McChrystal. The president met with McChrystal. He was -- he was really apologetic. He knew they had gone way beyond. But we also knew that if a sergeant did that
column2: if a lieutenant did that
column3: I mean no one could stay.

column1: TAPPER: Why do you think they thought of you as the enemy
column2: because you had been in favor of...

column1: BIDEN: Well
column2: because...

column1: TAPPER: -- the counter-terrorism instead of the counter-insurgency?
BIDEN: -- they -- because I had been someone who -- who offered a plan that was different in degree. But
column2: you know
column3: again
column4: I -- I -- someday I'll be able to lay out exactly what the plan I offered was. It would be inappropriate to do that because it was so close to what -- what
column5: in fact
column6: the plan ended up being that there was virtually no difference. But I got characterized because I was really very challenging to some of the assertions made.

column1: If you notice
column2: what we have is a counter-insurgency plan along the spine of the country
column3: where the population is. It's not a nationwide counter-insurgency plan. We're not engaged in nation-building
column4: which the original discussion was about. We have a rec -- we -- we have a date where we're going to go look and see whether it's working. And we have a timetable in which to transition.

column1: All of those things were things I was supporting. All those things were -- so. And to -- to conclude
column2: when -- when General Petraeus was picked the day in the office -- it was the day we were supposed to go downstairs into The Situation Room
column3: they call it
column4: to discuss the overall policy. Everyone was there. I pulled him aside and I said
column5: David
column6: there is no daylight between your position and mine.

column1: And he said
column2: I know that. Will you tell people that?

column1: TAPPER: Let's switch over now to Iraq.
BIDEN: Yes.
TAPPER: This is your first news interview since returning from Iraq.
BIDEN: True.
TAPPER: There's a -- there's a tremendous stale mat -- stalemate there.
BIDEN: Yes.
TAPPER: Since the March elections
column2: I believe the parliament there has only met for 20 minutes. And just this week in Washington
column3: the Iraqi foreign minister
column4: Zebari
column5: pleaded for more U.S. engagement. He said: ""We believe that there's a role for more engagement to help
column6: to encourage
column8: not to pick and choose the next government or the next leader
column9: but really to play a greater role in the process.""

column1: You once advocated for a three way partition of Iraq because you were not confident that Iraq's government was capable of having a strong central government. You said: ""The most basic premise of President Bush's approach that the Iraqi people will rally behind a strong central government headed by Maliki
column2: in fact
column3: looks out for their interests equitably is fundamentally and fatally flawed. It will not happen in anybody's lifetime here including the pages!""

column1: So it's -- that was from 2007.
Is it possible that you were right back then...
BIDEN: No.
TAPPER: -- that it is just impossible...
BIDEN: -- and
column2: by the way...

column1: TAPPER: -- to have a centralized government...
BIDEN: No
column2: it's -- I don't want to debate history here
column3: but I never called for a partition. I called for a central government with considerable autonomy in the regions.

column1: TAPPER: Three provinces.
BIDEN: Well
column2: it was...

column1: TAPPER: I'm...
BIDEN: -- not -- it wasn't even
column2: it was to allow them more autonomy
column3: like what's happening in Kurdistan right now
column4: like what's happening in Anbar Province right now. And so what's happening here is
column5: there is an election that's taken place. And what happened-- there's 325 plus members of what they call their core
column6: their parliament. And no one party won more than 91 seats. The two major parties
column7: one won 89 and one won 91 seats. That's Maliki and Allawi
column8: Iraqiya and the State of Law

column1: They're in negotiations right now to figure out how to allocate the power within that government. In other words
column2: share power. And it is about just that. And it's underway. And it's going to happen. There will be a central government with control of its foreign policy
column3: with control of the military. But you will see that there are going to be significant amounts of autonomy in each of the areas that exist in these provinces. That's what their constitution calls for.

column1: And
column2: look
column3: it took the Dutch six months to form a parliament the time before last. It took the -- the folks in the Netherlands six months
column4: 280 some days
column5: if I'm not mistaken. So this is -- and this is their first crack at democracy.

column1: I used the phrase politics has broken out
column2: not war. We're moving in that direction.

column1: TAPPER: And the combat mission ends at the end of August.
BIDEN: Yes.
TAPPER: And can that happen even if there isn't an Iraqi government?
BIDEN: There is a transition government. There is a government in place that's working. Iraqi security is being provided by the Iraqis
column2: with our assistance. We're going to have -- still have 50
column3: 000 troops there. We will have brought home 95
column4: 000. There is no one in the military who thinks there's any reason we can't do that

column1: So they're making real serious progress. I don't have a doubt in my mind that we'll be able to meet the commitment of having only 50
column2: 000 troops there and it will not in any way affect the physical stability of Iraq.

column1: TAPPER: You spoke to the leader of Southern Sudan...
BIDEN: I did.
TAPPER: -- recently.
BIDEN: Kiir.

TAPPER: And the referendum on whether or not Southern Sudan can break away from Sudan takes place in January. There's a lot of concern by human rights groups that that election will be riddled with fraud
column2: just like the ones in April.

column1: BIDEN: A legitimate concern.
TAPPER: The White House's point man on the Sudan is in the -- has said that the U.S. has waning influence in the region
column2: General Gration said that.

column1: Are you willing to pledge that the U.S. will make sure that they're -- that war does not break out between Sudan and Southern Sudan should that happen?

BIDEN: We're doing everything in our power to make sure this election on the referendum is viewed by the world as legitimate and fair. That's why we've been pushing the UN. That's why we've been pushing Kiir. That's why I've been working with Mbeki. That's why I've been working with President Mubarak
column2: all who have significant influence in this.

column1: And it must be viewed as credible to keep that country
column2: that region
column3: from deteriorating. The last thing we need is another failed state in the region. And I'm still hopeful. We are on it full-time. And -- I believe that we'll be able to pull -- they'll be able to pull off
column4: with our help and the UN's help
column5: they'll be able to pull off a credible election.

column1: TAPPER: What's the larger strategy for combating Islamo-terrorism or Islamic fascism
column2: as some people call it?

column1: Even if Iraq works
column2: even if Afghanistan works
column3: it pops up everywhere. It pops up in Yemen. It pops up in Somalia. It pops up in Uganda.

column1: What's the larger vision?
How does the U.S. combat that?
BIDEN: The larger vision is to appeal to the moderate Islamic states and the moderate Muslim world
column2: which is the vast majority of the world. That's the first piece.

column1: The second piece is
column2: in those areas which the radicals can feed on and breed off of is to try to help stabilize those governments
column3: not alone
column4: but with the rest of the world. And part of that is building strong countries around them
column5: as well as inside.

column1: And it's a long-term deal. But I think we're making progress. And President Obama ju-- -- you know
column2: I got asked the other day
column3: you know
column4: well
column5: you ran for president
column6: you know
column7: you're vice president. I said we got the order right. Even if I had been a great president and been elected
column8: it would have taken me four years to do what he did in one month. In one month
column9: he changed the attitude of the world about American intentions.

column1: And the Muslim world and the moderate Muslim world no longer thinks it's us or them. The most important one that we're finishing up now
column2: God willing
column3: is Iraq. Imagine Iraq as a stable country in the midst of that part of the world
column4: a very positive outcome.

column1: TAPPER: Mr. Vice President
column2: thanks for spending your time with us.

column1: BIDEN: Thank you
column2: Jake.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
KING: The Palin family bombshell.
(UNKNOWN): Bristol and Levi Johnston are not only back together
column2: they're getting married.

column1: B. PALIN: I came home from work one day
column2: and there was rose petals in the shape of a heart on my bed
column3: and then he got down on one knee and asked me to marry him.

column1: (UNKNOWN): Her engagement to Johnston happened without the approval of their parents.
(UNKNOWN): We have a statement out this morning from the Palins
column2: and they say
column3: ""Bristol
column4: at 19
column5: is now a young adult. We obviously want what is best for our children.""

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Bristol and Levi
column2: one of the many topics we will not be discussing on our roundtable this morning with George Will
column3: former Bush White House communications director Nicolle Wallace
column4: also author of the pending novel ""Eighteen Acres
column5: which my wife has not been able to put down -- thank you for joining us -- Clarence Page of the ""Chicago Tribune
column6: and former Clinton White House press secretary and ""Vanity Fair"" contributing editor Dee Dee Myers.

column1: Thank you
column2: one and all
column3: for being here. I want to start off with the interview with the vice president
column4: because as is his wont
column5: he did make some news in some various areas.

column1: George
column2: the vice president said that we are not engaging in nation-building in Afghanistan. And yet if you look at the cover of this week's ""Newsweek
column3: the president of the Council on Foreign Relations
column4: Richard Haass
column5: says
column6: ""Rethinking Afghanistan
column7: nation-building isn't working."" Are we doing nation-building in Afghanistan or are we not?

column1: WILL: We are. Nation-building is what counterinsurgency is
column2: as defined by David Petraeus. It is to protect the people. It is to make them loyal by giving them local services
column3: inventing a government
column4: in effect. That is nation-building
column5: which means that the Obama policy in Afghanistan is much more ambitious than was the Bush policy.

column1: The vice president said something else that was very interesting. He said
column2: ""We are making considerable progress against Al Qaida
column3: which is our primary target. We're taking out significant numbers of the leadership in Al Qaida."" The latter is true
column4: but they're doing that in Pakistan
column5: because
column6: as you established with Leon Panetta three weeks ago on this program
column8: ""How many Al Qaida do you think are in Afghanistan?"" Panetta
column9: ""I think at most we're looking at 50 to 100

column1: TAPPER: Nicolle
column2: one thing that I heard out of the vice president's mouth that I thought might be of interest to you was towards the end of the interview when he was talking about what -- how great it would be to have Iraq this shining example of democracy in the middle of the Middle East. Did that resonate at all with the former...

column1: WALLACE: Yes
column2: imagine that. Imagine making that case. Obviously
column3: these are the kinds of arguments that you make when public support starts to wane. And
column4: you know
column5: as the commander-in-chief -- and Obama still gets pretty decent marks in his capacity as our commander-in-chief. Republicans
column6: actually
column7: I think are encouraged by the fact that General Petraeus is -- is heading to Afghanistan to -- to replace Stan McChrystal.

column1: But where I think this will get complicated for him -- and where you already see his numbers in Afghanistan sliding -- is when he starts talking about timetables
column2: when they promise to pull troops out. It deflates the morale of the men and women of the military
column3: and it makes the public -- you know
column4: the public is very smart
column5: voters are very smart
column6: and when they hear them talk out of both sides of their mouth
column7: that's where the politics of the war and the responsibilities
column8: the solemn responsibilities as commander-in-chief collide.

column1: TAPPER: Let's talk about the roundtable -- I mean
column2: the timetable
column3: Clarence
column4: on the roundtable...

column1: PAGE: Right.
TAPPER: ... which is
column2: for the first time
column3: we've had the vice president say that when he told Jon Alter in that book that a lot of troops leaving in July 2011
column4: he said it could be as few as 2

column1: PAGE: Yes
column2: we're hearing these little rollbacks in the rhetoric all around
column3: insofar as how much of a pullout we're going have next year. And
column4: you know
column5: as the administration has said again and again
column6: it's only the beginning of the -- of the drawdown that they're shooting for
column7: and the president says it's contingent on conditions.

column1: But nevertheless
column2: any effort you make to establish security and to build internal security in Afghanistan and unify that country is nation-building because of the state of Afghanistan. It has always been a very divided collection of thousands of tribes and -- and various homelands. And General Petraeus is trying valiantly to organize all of that.

column1: But that's nation-building; I agree with George. The problem for Obama is his own base remembers that this was the good war we weren't supposed to get bogged down in. And he has become more ambitious in his goals.
TAPPER: And
column2: Dee Dee
column3: if in July 2011 it turns out only 2
column4: 000 troops leave Afghanistan
column5: I can't imagine that liberals and progressives are going to be happy about that.

column1: MYERS: Right. I mean
column2: last summer and fall
column3: the president went through an extensive process of thinking through exactly what our strategy in Afghanistan was going to be. He spent hours and hours and hours on it. He came out pretty close to where General Petraeus and the military wanted
column4: which was sending 30
column5: 000 additional troops.

column1: And he sold that to Congress by pairing it with a deadline
column2: which now -- I thought it was interesting to hear Vice President Biden talk about that not as much as a deadline but as the beginning of a transition.

column1: But when the -- the time comes -- and in the discussion leading up to that
column2: if the administration continues to try to finesse that
column3: which they've been doing
column4: I think you're going to see increasingly angry liberals. We've already seen it.

column1: People
column2: again
column3: signed onto this plan on the notion that it would be a specific period of time and not a long period of time
column4: that we wouldn't be there for 10 years or 20 years nation-building. And increasingly
column5: I think the language is getting -- is leaving a lot of wiggle room. Things on the ground have not gone as well as we had hoped a year ago.

column1: TAPPER: George
column2: something else the vice president said that I -- you and I talked about. You disagree with his assertion that the Wall Street reform bill that the president will sign this Wednesday will end uncertainty among big business.

column1: WILL: The president -- the vice president was really responding to your point about all this mountain of cash that businesses have that they're not spending
column2: because to invest is to make a wager on the future and they're uncertain about the future.

column1: The vice president referred to the financial reform bill as another of our gigantic packages
column2: another 2
column3: 300-page piece of legislation. I don't know if
column4: as someone said
column5: there are three unintended consequences on every page
column6: but there are enormous rule-makings yet to come
column7: with bureaucracies yet to be invented. It's bound to spread uncertainty
column8: and it's bound to have essentially what we had in the 1930s when the New Deal came to a grinding halt. Capital went on strike

column1: PAGE: However
column2: there is the public out there saying
column3: what's government going to do to protect us? We did just go through a financial collapse. Some kind of -- and this came after
column4: really
column5: several decades of fewer and fewer regulations
column6: less and less oversight.

column1: We need some kind of oversight. How many pages would you like
column2: George
column4: 300 too many? How about 100 pages? I mean
column5: you've got to have some detail here. And the regulations haven't even been written yet
column6: the various rules and regulations for the day-to-day operation of all this.

column1: But at least you're going to see some kind of
column2: what
column3: consumer advocacy where it wasn't there before.

column1: WALLACE: You talk to people in finance
column2: and they'll tell you
column3: we got into this crisis because the housing market became overheated. Housing is one of the most regulated industries in this country. Finance collided with an overheated housing market
column4: also one of the most heavily regulated industries in this country. So what did we do? We added more regulations and we increased the political involvement
column5: and it's a recipe for disaster.

column1: PAGE: It's regulated
column2: but I was -- I had a broker try to sell me on an interest-only mortgage
column3: because he gets a bonus for selling me on that
column4: for charging me a higher interest.

column1: WALLACE: That'll never happen
column2: because there isn't any more credit
column3: so I think we've taken care of that.

column1: PAGE: Well
column2: it won't happen again now because it's been written out of existence
column3: virtually
column4: by these new regulations
column5: as it should have been out of existence before
column6: and warnings will be out there for people ahead of time.

column1: WALLACE: But even Democrats admit that these regulations will do nothing to protect us from a similar financial collapse.
MYERS: That's not true
column2: Nicolle. I mean
column3: most people think it will help prevent -- it won't completely prevent another financial crisis
column4: but most people think it will help prevent another one and make -- and create some additional tools for managing a crisis should another one occur.

column1: You know
column2: you can't fight the last war. And so regulating against everything that happened in the last
column3: you know
column4: collapse is -- is -- is sort of short-sided. People said a lot of the same things after
column5: you know
column6: the last round of big regulation after the '29 collapse
column7: and they turned out not to be true.

column1: Now
column2: I do think George is right in -- in -- in the medium term or the short term
column3: as we've gone from the legislative phase to the regulatory phase. There's going to be a couple of years of actually writing these regulations and putting details onto the legislation
column4: and that's going to be a tough time.

column1: But I think it's encouraging that the markets didn't go crazy on Thursday and Friday in response to this passing. They went crazy in response to the fact that there was lower-than-expected profits on Wall Street.
TAPPER: A lot of people in the White House think that if it weren't for the recession
column2: all the unemployment
column3: people would be paying attention to the fact that this is a big legislative accomplishment. Obviously
column4: not everyone agrees that it's a good accomplishment
column5: but for a president to achieve this
column6: health care reform
column8: the president deserves credit. Is -- is that true

column1: MYERS: Yes
column2: I think -- I think it's amazing how much he's been able to do
column3: whether you agree or disagree with the content of these packages. As a legislative accomplishment
column4: these are huge.

column1: But I think the president and the administration are not getting much credit
column2: and I think the number-one reason
column3: the most important number
column4: and in some ways the only one that matters is 9.5.

column1: You know
column2: you still have millions of people -- we -- we lost 7 million jobs in the last couple of years. Now
column3: we've gone from losing 750
column4: 000 jobs a month in the spring of last year to creating somewhere around 100
column5: 000 private-sector jobs a month now. That's a huge turnaround
column6: and the stimulus contributed to that. But unemployment is still 9.5.

column1: WILL: A huge turnaround doesn't explain the cognitive dissonance of this administration. It's campaigning across the country in what it calls ""recovery summer
column2: postulate being we're in a recovery
column3: but
column4: they say
column5: we really need another stimulus
column6: because the first two stimuli did not bring us a recovery.

column1: TAPPER: I appreciate the proper Latin. I want to show...
(LAUGHTER)
PAGE: It's about time.
TAPPER: I want to show a couple numbers in terms of polling numbers for President Obama that are not positive
column2: the results of a new ABC News-Washington Post poll. On President Obama's handling of the economy
column3: do you approve of President Obama's handling of the economy? Last month
column4: 50 percent approved. This month
column5: 43 percent
column6: a seven-point drop in just one month

column1: And here's the reason why
column2: if you look at this number
column3: this larger chart. As unemployment has gone up
column4: up
column5: up
column6: the president's approval has gone down
column8: down.

column1: And yet
column2: Nicolle
column3: I want to ask you this: If you look at the poll on the public's confidence in different groups to handle the economy
column4: Obama is 43 percent
column5: a horrible number for him
column6: Democrats in Congress
column8: Republicans in Congress

column1: WALLACE: OK. Hang on to that 26 and look at this number: 51 percent of the same voters in that poll want Republicans to take control of Congress.
TAPPER: Why?
WALLACE: They don't even trust us
column2: and they want us to take control of Congress.

column1: TAPPER: I know
column2: but...

column1: WALLACE: That is how desperately they want to stop Obama's agenda. Now -- now
column2: I think it's noble for Democrats to defend the expansion of the role of the federal government in our financial system. I think it's noble to defend Obamacare.

column1: But the truth is
column2: it has ignited a disdain for the expansion of the federal government
column3: and it's not just among Tea Partiers. I know there's a lot of attention paid to them. The ABC-Post poll has 40 percent of respondents identifying themselves as independents. That is the former Obama coalition.

column1: TAPPER: George?
WILL: Well
column2: I think that's absolutely right. The country is not saying we like Republicans; they're saying we don't like the current agenda. And the Republicans are standing there. They are the alternative.

column1: PAGE: This is the funny thing about this -- you talk about cognitive dissonance. We have a public in the midst of high unemployment that wants less spending. That was not predicted by this administration
column2: and certainly it runs counter to what -- to what liberals normally call for
column3: certainly counter to what worked for FDR. We can talk about what happened during the Great Depression
column4: George.

column1: But the fact is that -- that I think
column2: if unemployment weren't so bad right now
column3: people would feel a lot better about Obamacare and the stimulus packages
column4: et cetera
column5: but the problem
column6: as long as unemployment is up
column7: the public isn't going to appreciate the president's handling of the economy.

column1: WILL: The false liberal assumption is that economic hard times move the country to the left. It's not true
column2: and it didn't happen in the 1930s. Before the '36 election and after the '36 election
column3: in which Roosevelt carried 46 of 48 states
column4: Democrats said they wanted him to be more conservative
column5: and only about 18 percent of Democrats said they wanted to increase spending. Those are Democrats.

column1: PAGE: Being as they were enjoying the benefits of Social Security and those other programs that...
(CROSSTALK)
WALLACE: Ronald -- Ronald Reagan
column2: too
column3: found himself with low approval ratings
column4: and -- and a tough economy.

column1: TAPPER: His numbers track -- you and I were talking about this...
WALLACE: With Obama.
TAPPER: His numbers track with Obama's very closely.
WALLACE: But he did the opposite. He crafted an agenda that -- that so appealed to the political center that it created an entire new class of voters
column2: the Reagan Democrats. Obama has gone the opposite direction and seems only interested in expanding government
column3: increasing its role in people's lives
column4: and -- and
column5: you know
column6: I think will have the opposite impact that Reagan's did.

column1: TAPPER: You know
column2: Nicolle
column3: you talked about the Tea Partiers
column4: and that gives me an opportunity to change the subject to something else that happened this week that was very interesting. The NAACP had its convention
column5: and they passed a resolution
column6: one they have not yet released to the public
column7: that condemns racism among the Tea Party movement. And here is an interview with NAACP President Ben Jealous.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) JEALOUS: Tea Party members have called congressmen the n-word
column2: have called congressmen the f-word. We've seen them carry racial signs. And whenever it happens
column3: the membership tries to shirk responsibility. If the Tea Party wants to be respected and wants to be part of the mainstream in this country
column4: they have to act in a responsible way.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: Clarence
column2: why did the NAACP spend so much time or at least get so much attention for condemning the Tea Party movement? Is this an important priority for them?

column1: PAGE: Rightly or wrongly
column2: they are voicing the sentiments that a lot of African-Americans feel and the liberal establishment
column3: if you will. And we can debate over whether or not congressmen really were called the n-word or not. It's a he said/he said dispute.

column1: But what's more fundamentally important
column2: Jake
column3: is a year ago we were talking about
column4: is the NAACP still relevant when you've got a black president? Now the NAACP is on page one leading the domestic discussion this week. This is probably the most talked-about issue of the week.

column1: And they are diametrically opposed to the Tea Party in virtually every way
column2: demographically
column3: philosophically
column4: et cetera. It makes sense that they would be in dispute. But this is all being played out on talk shows like this one
column5: and I think we're doing a very good job of it.

column1: WILL: Precisely. There's nothing like name-calling and a kind of left-wing McCarthyism to enable the NAACP to make a desperate lunge for its vanished relevance. You say that this episode that he's talking about and the vice president made an oblique reference to it is he said/he said
column2: whether or not the n-word was used. It's a he said and four television cameras monitoring that event say it didn't happen.

column1: PAGE: A lot of noise. People were yelling things of all kinds
column2: so...

column1: WILL: A talk radio host in this country has offered $100
column2: 000 to anyone who can produce a shred of evidence that it happened.

column1: PAGE: Right.
WILL: A hundred thousand dollars still on the table.
PAGE: Well
column2: that's only one of many issues. Look at -- look at the signs. Look at the statements that have been made. Look at -- look at the blatant racial insensitivities
column3: some of it on both sides
column4: you know
column5: but the fact of matter is that we do have the modern version of what you and I remember as white backlash back in the '60s
column6: George
column8: the hard hats
column9: et cetera. After the civil rights revolution
column15: same thing now. It's more than just race. We are talking about deficits and big spending and all
column16: but there is a backlash against Obama's election. And -- and that

column1: TAPPER: They -- what the vice president said was that he didn't think the Tea Party movement was racist
column2: but that there were racist elements of it. And I think anybody who watches the parades
column3: sees the photographs can -- can say that there are certainly individuals who are part of the movement who say things that are racist.

column1: And
column2: in fact
column3: Tea Party organizers Jenny Beth Martin and Mark Meckler wrote this op-ed in Politico in which they said
column4: ""Like all movements
column5: the Tea Party has its fringe. President Barack Obama's domestic terrorist friends from the 1960s anti-war past never represented the Americans of good conscience who opposed the Vietnam War. In a similar vein
column6: the racist posters of a few at a Tea Party rally do not represent the feelings or behavior of Americans who believe in this movement. At Tea Party Patriots
column7: we will continue to condemn the fringe elements of the movement and any expression of racism or bigotry. We sincerely hope that the Obama While House
column8: the NAACP
column9: and the liberal left will follow our lead and do the same in their own ranks.""

column1: But that is an acknowledgement that they
column2: too
column3: see racism in some of these events.

column1: WALLACE: And a very important one. I -- I don't understand why this one is difficult. I mean
column2: I think it's incumbent -- forget about the leadership of the Tea Party movement. But them aside for a second.

column1: Any member of this powerful
column2: promising and very relevant movement should stand up and condemn anything that you wouldn't want to see your children participate in. And I can't imagine there's any parent in America who would approve of any of the racist signs that show up at any rally.

column1: So I think this is easy. I don't think this is about the leadership. I don't think this is about waiting for the leaders of your movement. And people say
column2: oh
column3: they're young
column4: it's not clear where the structure -- forget about that. Any individual at a rally where -- where -- where any sign or insinuation of racism appears should condemn it. And it'll only strengthen the movement and make them more relevant.

column1: MYERS: But I agree with everything
column2: except I think there is a role for the leaders. It's not -- why -- where is Dick Armey? Where is Sarah Palin? It's an easy thing to say exactly what you just said. And the members should do it
column3: but so should the leaders
column4: because
column5: you know
column6: there's an op-ed piece in Politico
column7: but most Americans don't hear that or don't know...

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: Sarah Palin actually condemned the NAACP.

column1: MYERS: Right.
TAPPER: She just denied that there was any racism at all.
MYERS: And I think that's -- I mean
column2: look
column3: that's
column4: on its face
column5: not true. There are elements -- and they're not the core elements
column6: and I don't think the movement is -- is prime facie racist
column8: and they should be repudiated. So where are the leaders? It seems like a no-brainer.

column1: PAGE: And what's important here politically is that the Tea Party
column2: like any other political movement
column3: wants to win over those moderates
column4: those swing voters out there
column5: if you will.

column1: MYERS: They should.
PAGE: And if they are an embarrassment to their fellow conservatives
column2: they break their own coalition up
column3: and so this -- this becomes a very relevant thing here. This is not just political correctness as some people want to dismiss it.

column1: MYERS: But I think it's interesting -- and
column2: Clarence
column3: you might want to comment -- we thought that -- or a lot of people -- I don't know if we thought -- but there seem to be people who said the election of Obama meant we were -- achieved a post-racial status in American society
column4: and I think this -- the heat around this discussion this week shows that we're a long way from a post-racial America.

column1: PAGE: I said then we'll be post-racial when we're post-racism
column2: but we still have racism
column3: sexism
column4: et cetera
column5: out there
column6: always will. We're human beings. But this
column8: was a -- was just an awakening of conservatives who were rather shocked for a variety of reasons by Obama's election
column9: not just race. I think that was a minor element
column10: compared to the philosophical swing and -- and just this big cultural shift.

column1: TAPPER: George
column2: we only have 30 seconds
column3: but -- but do the -- the Tea Party leaders that I just read their op-ed
column4: do they have a point in that we demand the conservatives to condemn isms in their side
column5: but not liberals?

column1: WILL: Well
column2: what -- during the many protests against George W. Bush and the pictures of him with a Hitler moustache and the swastikas associated with him
column3: I don't recall -- I may be wrong -- but I don't recall a clamor of denunciation from the Bush's critics.

column1: TAPPER: All right. Now
column2: one thing...

column1: PAGE: I agree with that.

TAPPER: One thing that the roundtable is going to weigh in on in the -- in the -- in the green room episode that's going to be available on abcnews.com is Aaron Sorkin buying the rights to John Edwards' story
column2: so please stay tuned. And also there you can also find our fact checks. We've teamed up with PolitiFact to fact-check the show."	['http://abcnews.go.com/ThisWeek/week-transcript-biden/null'
column3: 'data:image/gif;base64
column4: R0lGODlhAQABAIAAAAAAAP///yH5BAEAAAAALAAAAAABAAEAAAIBRAA7']	http://abcnews.go.com/ThisWeek/week-transcript-biden/null	'This Week' Transcript: Biden	http://abcnews.go.com

column1: 0	"Michigan Assembly Plant
Wayne
column2: Michigan

column1: 4:22 P.M. EST
THE PRESIDENT: Thank you
column2: everybody! (Applause.) Give Mia a big round of applause for that outstanding introduction. (Applause.) Well
column3: hello
column4: Michigan! (Applause.) Happy New Year to everybody.

column1: AUDIENCE: Happy New Year!
AUDIENCE MEMBER: I love you!
THE PRESIDENT: I -- what was that? I love you back. (Laughter.)

I want to thank all the outstanding leaders that we’ve got here today. I want to introduce some of them. We’ve got Secretary of Labor Tom Perez here. (Applause.) We’ve got Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan here. (Applause.) Senator Gary Peters is in the house. (Applause.) Congresswoman Debbie Dingell is here. (Applause.) Your outstanding CEO
column2: Mark Fields
column3: is here. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: I have to say I love the Secret Service
column3: I love the Beasts that they put me in and -- that’s what we call the cars I drive in
column4: “the Beasts.” So I like my ride these days. And it was made in Michigan
column5: too. (Applause.) But I just had a chance to look at these new Mustangs
column6: and I’ve got to say that the Mustangs have a little more style
column7: a little more flavor. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: Bill Ford is in the house. (Applause.) Surprisingly enough
column2: we talked a little bit about Sunday. (Laughter.) Now
column3: listen
column4: I’m a Bears fan. You beat us twice. But even a Bears fan has to admit --

column1: AUDIENCE MEMBER: We got hosed!
THE PRESIDENT: -- that that was a little suspect. (Applause.) I have never seen anything like that before. I would have been pretty irritated. Were you irritated? Oh
column2: yes. (Laughter.) But all I can say -- because I’m used to saying this
column3: I’m a Bears fan -- there’s always next year. (Laughter.) And look
column4: you’ve got a lot to be hopeful for. First of all
column5: you’ve got one of the best defenses in the league. (Applause.) A fine young quarterback
column6: Megatron. And if there’s one thing that you can take to the bank when talking about Detroit is that Detroit always comes back. (Applause.) Detroit always comes back. (Applause.)

column1: And that’s why I’m here today. One of my New Year’s resolutions is to make sure that more Americans in Wayne
column2: more Americans in Michigan
column3: more Americans all across this great country -- that everybody feels like they’re coming back. And there is no doubt
column4: thanks to the steps that we took early on to rescue our economy and to rebuild it on a new foundation
column5: we are entering into the New Year with new confidence that America is coming back. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: you don’t have to take my word for it. The facts are the facts. And let’s face it
column3: a lot of times the media doesn’t like reporting on good news
column4: but every once in a while
column5: it’s important for us to hear some good news
column6: not to make us complacent
column7: but to give us confidence that if we work harder
column8: we can make even more good news.

column1: So here’s how we begin this year. Last year
column3: was the strongest year for job growth since the 1990s. (Applause.) Since the 1990s. (Applause.) We’ve now had a 57-month streak of private sector job creation. We’ve created nearly 11 million new jobs. That’s the longest stretch in our history of private sector
column4: uninterrupted job creation. (Applause.)

column1: Here’s another way of thinking about it. Since 2010
column2: we
column3: America
column4: have put more people back to work than Europe
column5: Japan
column6: and every other advanced economy combined. (Applause.) Combined. (Applause.) And let me tell you what’s leading the way: American manufacturing. After a decade of decline
column7: American manufacturing is in its best stretch of job growth since the 1990s. Here in Michigan
column8: manufacturers have created more than 100
column10: helping to cut your unemployment rate in half.

column1: So we’re making more stuff. We’re selling it around the world. America is the number-one producer of oil
column2: the number-one producer of gas. It’s helping to save drivers about a buck-ten a gallon at the pump over this time last year. (Applause.) And the cars that you make help everybody go a little further on that gallon of gas. (Applause.)

column1: Thanks to the Affordable Care Act -- also known as Obamacare -- (applause) -- about 10 million Americans gained health insurance just over this last year. We’ve cut our deficits by about two-thirds. I’d like people to think about that
column2: because when they do surveys of
column3: like
column4: ordinary folks on the street and they ask them
column5: are the deficits going up or are they coming down
column6: everybody automatically assumes
column8: government spending and deficits must be going up. Deficits have come down by two-thirds since I took office -- by two-thirds. They’re going down. (Applause.) And after 13 long years
column9: our war in Afghanistan has come to a responsible end
column10: which means more of our brave troops have come home and spent time with their families during the holidays. (Applause.)

column1: So the point is we’re moving. These six years have been tough
column2: demanded hard work
column3: demanded sacrifice on everybody’s part. You guys know that more than most. Which means that as a country
column4: we have every right to be proud of what we’ve got to show for all that hard work.

column1: America’s resurgence is real. Don’t let anybody tell you otherwise. We’ve got the best cards and we are doing better than just about anybody else on Earth. And now that we’ve got some calmer waters
column2: now that the worst of the crisis is behind us
column3: if we all do our part
column4: if we all pitch in
column5: then we can make sure that this rising tide is actually lifting all the boats
column6: not just some. We can make sure that the middle class is the engine that powers American prosperity for decades to come.

column1: And that’s going to be the focus of my State of the Union address in a couple of weeks -- building on the progress that we’ve already made. But I’ve got to admit I’ve only got two years left in office -- I didn’t want to wait for the State of the Union to talk about all the things that make this country great and how we can make it better. So I thought I’d get started this week. (Applause.) I figured
column2: why wait? It’s like opening your Christmas presents a little early.

column1: So today I’m here in Detroit
column2: going to talk about the incredible things that have happened in the auto industry and what more we can do with manufacturing. Tomorrow
column3: I’m going to visit Arizona
column4: a state that was hit about as hard as anybody by the housing crisis
column5: because we want to talk about how we're making homeownership a reality for more middle-class families.

column1: On Friday
column2: I’m going to go to Tennessee
column3: a state that's making big strides in education
column4: to show how we can help every American get the education they need to get ahead in this new economy.

column1: But today
column2: I wanted to come here to Michigan because this state proves no matter how tough times get Americans are tougher. (Applause.) Plus I wanted to see the new Mustang. (Laughter.)

column1: Now
column2: let’s just take a minute and think about what you've had to fight through. A few years ago
column3: nearly one in five autoworkers got a punch in the gut with a pink slip. The year before I took office
column5: 000 jobs vanished in this industry -- 400
column6: 000. Sales plunged 40 percent. And then as the financial crisis built
column7: we faced what once seemed unimaginable when just two of the Big Three -- GM and Chrysler -- were on the brink of failure.

column1: Now
column2: this is the heartbeat of American manufacturing right here. And it was flat-lining. And we had a choice to make. We could have kept giving billions of taxpayer dollars to the auto industry without asking for accountability or change in return. But that would have just kicked the problem down the road. We could have done nothing
column3: which some people said we should do
column4: and let those companies fail. But think about what that would have meant for this country. The suppliers
column5: the distributors
column6: the communities that depend on the workers who patronize the restaurants and shop at the stores
column7: all those companies would have gone under also.

column1: And
column2: look
column3: the fact is nobody was in a stronger position than Ford. Bill and the team had done a great job steering Ford through tough times
column4: but Bill and others are the first to admit that you could have had a cascading effect if the whole supply chain in the U.S. auto industry starts declining. Then Ford could have gone under
column5: too. Plants would have shuttered. We would have lost this iconic industry
column6: sold for scraps. And folks like you -- the men and women who built these companies with your hands -- would have been hung out to dry. And the communities you depended on -- the schoolteachers
column8: the servers in the diner and
column10: the barkeep -- (laughter and applause.) I’m just saying. (Laughter.) Are you a barkeep
column11: or you’re just waving at me? (Laughter.) But everybody would have been affected. Their jobs were at stake

column1: And it’s more than that. The jobs in the auto industry have always been about more than a paycheck. They're a source of pride for generations. It was representative of what it meant to get into the middle class. You work hard in this job
column2: you could afford to raise a family
column3: buy a house
column4: go on vacation
column5: retire with some dignity. You knew you were making something that people could count on. It meant something. Every car you sent off the line brought you that step closer to doing the right thing by your family and giving something to your kids
column6: and having a sense of security in your life. So plants like this one built more than just cars -- they built the middle class in this country. And that was worth fighting for. (Applause.)

column1: So in exchange for the help
column2: we demanded responsibility. We said to the auto industry
column3: you’ve got to change with the times. Plants retooled. Plants restructured. Labor and management worked together
column4: settled their differences. Everybody put some skin in the game. Everybody made some sacrifices. It wasn’t just some
column5: it wasn’t just the workers who gave something up -- everybody.

column1: And that's how things work best
column2: by the way
column3: when everybody is in it -- when workers and businesses work together; when whoever is in the board room and folks on the floor
column4: they both understand they’re in it together. And we believe America is best when everybody is in it together. And we rejected the false choice that either unions or businesses could succeed but not both. We said
column5: you know what
column6: what’s going to work for the company is also going to work for that worker
column8: which means when the company is doing better
column9: then the workers have got to get their share as well. (Applause.)

column1: And Ford rejected the false choice that they could either take care of their shareholder or take care of their worker -- they did both. And the company benefited and America benefited. We believed in shared sacrifice and that shared sacrifice leads to shared prosperity.
Now
column2: I’ve got to tell you
column3: I was talking to the Detroit News -- they were asking
column4: what was it like when you were making this decision? I just want everybody to be clear. It was not popular. Even in Michigan
column5: it wasn’t popular. I remember they did a poll and
column6: like
column8: it was like only 10 percent were in favor. (Laughter.) And you don’t have to be a genius political analyst to say

column1: And
column2: look -- and it wasn’t on my to-do list when I ran for President. I wasn’t expecting to have to do this. But I ran not to be just doing the popular things
column3: I ran not just to do the easy things
column4: I ran to do the right thing. And saving the American auto industry was the right thing to do. (Applause.) Betting on you was the right thing to do. (Applause.) It was the right thing to do. And that bet has paid off for America
column5: because the American auto industry is back. (Applause.)

column1: Now
column2: part of the reason that we wanted to start this trip here is not just because I wanted to see the new Mustang
column3: not just because the American auto industry is back
column4: but because last month we actually marked a milestone. Last month
column5: the rescue of the auto industry officially came to an end. The auto companies have now repaid taxpayers every dime and more of what my administration invested in you. (Applause.) You paid the taxpayers back with your hard work
column6: with your dedication. (Applause.)

column1: And over the past five years
column2: this industry created about 500
column3: 000 new jobs. Last year
column4: American autoworkers churned out cars faster than any year since 2005. Ford has brought jobs back from Mexico
column5: created nearly 24
column6: 000 new jobs across this country
column8: 800 new jobs right here in this plant. (Applause.) And after more than a century since Henry Ford introduced the moving assembly line
column9: you’re reinventing it -- one production line for gas
column12: plug-in vehicles. That’s the first in the world
column14: Michigan. (Applause.) First in the world. (Applause.) That’s always cool when you do something first.

column1: And you’re helping rebuild the middle class for the 21st century. Just down the road in Lincoln Park
column2: UAW-Ford Joint Apprenticeship Program is providing workers with hands-on training in the skills that employers need for the jobs of tomorrow. And nationally
column3: by the way
column4: 87 percent of all apprentices are employed after they complete their apprenticeship program
column5: with an average starting wage of $50
column6: 000. So the more folks we get into apprenticeships
column7: the more folks are getting middle-class jobs.

column1: And that’s why I called on last year for businesses across the country to create more and expand more apprenticeship programs. And since then
column2: we’ve seen the largest increase in apprenticeships in nearly a decade. And now my administration is investing $100 million in an American Apprenticeship Grant competition. We’re going to build on this momentum. We’re going to expand successful programs. We want young people to see that they have opportunities. They don’t all have to go to a four-year college. They can get an apprenticeship
column3: save some money
column4: start working -- (applause) -- build a family
column5: buy a home
column6: get some Lions tickets. (Laughter and applause.)

column1: Because everybody came together here and worked together
column2: folks are better off. And some of the most high-tech
column3: fuel-efficient
column4: high-powered
column5: heart-pounding
column6: good-looking
column8: fuel-efficient cars in the world are once again designed
column10: forged and built not in Europe
column12: right here in the United States of America. (Applause.) Right here in America. (Applause.)

column1: So because of you -- because of you
column2: manufacturing has a future in this country. Management has actually grown faster than other parts of the economy. And companies are now saying
column3: you know what
column4: we got to get back to America. We got to relocate. We were offshore
column5: and now they're saying
column6: oh
column8: America is back. We better get back in there. And that means because of you
column9: the middle class has a future in this country.

column1: And the auto industry has proved that any comeback is possible -- and by the way
column2: so has Motor City. (Applause.) So has a Motor City. (Applause.) A year and a half ago
column3: Detroit became the largest city ever to file for bankruptcy. Today
column4: under the leadership of Mayor Duggan
column5: Detroit is charting a new course. Businesses and private investors are making big investments
column6: including Ford
column7: which is helping to launch a tech startup incubator downtown. New restaurants and stores are popping up. Residents are fighting blight
column8: securing abandoned homes

column1: We’re seeing stories of young people who left town for other opportunities
column2: didn't think they could make it here
column3: and suddenly they're saying
column4: you know what
column5: maybe I want to get back to Detroit -- hoping to be part of the rebirth of this city.

column1: Now
column2: this city still faces big challenges
column3: but you’re coming back. Just like the auto industry is going to have to continue to come up with new ideas and new designs and address competition. It never stops. We got to stay hungry. We can't be complacent. Just like America has got to still keep on working. Just like the Lions got to still come up with a little more work. (Applause.) But we're coming back.

column1: And one thing is for sure -- we may not all root for the Lions
column2: but America is rooting for Detroit. (Applause.) America is rooting for Detroit. (Applause.) We want the Motor City strong. And behind the stories of plants and cities and economic data
column3: it’s people. It’s all of you.

column1: So I’ll just close with a story of a guy named Ramone -- because we’re rooting for guys like Ramone. Ramone spent eight years in the military
column2: served in Afghanistan
column3: served in Iraq. Ramone here? Raise your hand
column4: Ramone. (Applause.)

column1: So Ramone is somebody who fought for our freedom
column2: fought for our security. But sometimes we give lip service to supporting our troops
column3: and then when they come home they get lost. So when Ramone came home
column4: he had a hard time finding a job because it was a tough economy. He didn’t want to be a burden on his family
column5: so he moved into a homeless shelter
column6: took whatever work he could get. And then
column8: a VA counselor that he’d been working with handed him an application from Ford. Ford was hiring for new shifts.

column1: Imagine what Ramone felt the day he knocked on his grandpa’s door -- his grandfather who had spent 25 years building Mustangs in Dearborn -- and Ramone was able to tell his grandfather he got a job at Ford. (Applause.) And now Ramone has got his own place. And now Ramone has got a good job right on the line here in Wayne. And every day
column2: he’s doing just what his grandfather did. And he’s proud. He’s punching in and building some of the best cars in the world. (Applause.)

column1: If you want to know what America is about
column2: about grit and determination and hard work and sacrifice and looking out for one another and not giving up
column3: think about Ramone. Think about Detroit. Think about the auto industry. Think about the Midwest. Think about Michigan. Think about America.

column1: When our assembly lines grind to a halt
column2: we work together
column3: we get them going again. We don’t give up. We get up
column4: we fight back. We come back stronger than before. Thanks to the hard work of people like you
column5: America is coming back. And I’m going to be on your side every step of the way. (Applause.)

column1: Thank you
column2: Michigan. God bless you. God bless America. (Applause.)

column1: END

column1: 0	"If you were shocked by Friday’s job report
column2: if you thought we were doing well and were taken aback by the bad news
column3: you haven’t been paying attention. The fact is
column4: the United States economy has been stuck in a rut for a year and a half.

column1: Yet a destructive passivity has overtaken our discourse. Turn on your TV and you’ll see some self-satisfied pundit declaring that nothing much can be done about the economy’s short-run problems (reminder: this “short run” is now in its fourth year)
column2: that we should focus on the long run instead.

column1: This gets things exactly wrong. The truth is that creating jobs in a depressed economy is something government could and should be doing. Yes
column2: there are huge political obstacles to action — notably
column3: the fact that the House is controlled by a party that benefits from the economy’s weakness. But political gridlock should not be conflated with economic reality.

column1: Our failure to create jobs is a choice
column2: not a necessity — a choice rationalized by an ever-shifting set of excuses."	['https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/04/02/opinion/paul-krugman/paul-krugman-facebookJumbo.png'

column1: WASHINGTON
column2: D.C. –

column1: President Obama has ordered a $200
column3: life-sized
column4: bronze statue of himself
column5: with plans to install it in the entryway of the White House. The president says that his legacy “should not be diminished
column6: ” and that this is the only way he can “keep an eye” over Trump

column1: “I have been president for only eight years
column2: and in that time
column3: I have done what no other presidents could do in all their time in total
column4: ” said Obama. “I have created a legacy that should not be diminished. I have created something that no future president will be able to do. In that regard
column5: I have commissioned this statute
column6: with plans to have it permanently erected in the entryway of the White House
column7: so that all who enter can remember me fondly.”

column1: The statue will not be allowed to be removed
column2: as every president is allowed to leave one thing in the White House that must never be touched by future presidents. William Howard Taft left his giant bathtub. Bill Clinton left one of his saxophones. George W. Bush left a piece of mirror and a rolled up hundred.

column1: 0	"(APPLAUSE)
She has made history not just because she's a woman who has done what no woman has done before
column2: but because she is a leader who inspires millions of Americans with her strength
column3: her courage
column4: and her commitment to the causes that brought us here tonight.

column1: I congratulate her on her victory in South Dakota
column2: and I congratulate her on the race that she has run throughout this contest.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
We've certainly had our differences over the last 16 months. But as someone who's shared a stage with her many times
column2: I can tell you that what gets Hillary Clinton up in the morning -- even in the face of tough odds -- is exactly what sent her and Bill Clinton to sign up for their first campaign in Texas all those years ago
column3: what sent her to work at the Children's Defense Fund and made her fight for health care as first lady
column4: what led her to the United States Senate and fueled her barrier-breaking campaign for the presidency: an unyielding desire to improve the lives of ordinary Americans
column5: no matter how difficult the fight may be.

column1: And you can rest assured that when we finally win the battle for universal health care in this country -- and we will win that fight -- she will be central to that victory.
(APPLAUSE)
When we transform our energy policy and lift our children out of poverty
column2: it will be because she worked to help make it happen.

column1: Our party and our country are better off because of her
column2: and I am a better candidate for having had the honor to compete with Hillary Rodham Clinton.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
There are those who say that this primary has somehow left us weaker and more divided. Well
column2: I say that
column3: because of this primary
column4: there are millions of Americans who have cast their ballot for the very first time."
