column1: 0	"Four million people dropped off the food stamp rolls in one month
column2: according to the latest numbers on food stamp enrollment from the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).

column1: The latest USDA data show that the number of participants in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
column2: the government program that administers food stamps
column3: dropped from 45
column5: 795 in October 2017 to 41
column7: 868 in November 2017 — a staggering decrease of 4

column1: Even though there was a temporary spike in enrollment
column2: mostly concentrated in a few states that caused the national average of food stamp enrollment to spike
column3: nationwide enrollment in the program as a whole is still on a steady decline.

column1: Enrollment in the program sharply increased by 3.5 million during the first month of fiscal year (FY) 2018 (October 2017) mostly due to heavy increases in temporary SNAP enrollment in hurricane-affected states such as Florida and Texas.
In Florida alone
column2: food stamp participation soared by 2.5 million from September to October due to the state administering Disaster Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (D-SNAP) benefits to poor residents affected by Hurricane Irma.

column1: The USDA’s Food and Nutrition Service approved Florida’s request to administer these special D-SNAP benefits beginning September 10

A spokesperson for Florida’s Department of Children and Families (DCF) — the program that administers food stamp benefits in Florida — confirmed with Breitbart News that the dramatic increase in SNAP enrollment in the state was due to disaster relief
column2: but that most food stamp recipients were not normal beneficiaries of the food stamp program.

column1: “The dramatic increase in SNAP recipients in the fall was related to the state’s administration of the federal disaster SNAP program following the impact of Hurricane Irma. To qualify for the federal disaster food assistance program
column2: individuals must have lived or worked in one of the 48 declared counties on September 5
column3: and NOT be a customer in the regular food assistance program
column4: ” said DCF Communications Director Jessica Sims.

column1: Sims added that DCF handed out D-SNAP benefits totaling more than $1 billion to 3.1 million people in the months following Hurricane Irma
column2: but the state curtailed its D-SNAP benefit program on December 3.

column1: The sharp decline in food stamp enrollment over one month reflects how states like Florida have curtailed their temporary food stamp benefit programs for those affected by natural disasters.

But it also highlights an ongoing downward trend in food stamp enrollment that has been going on for several years since state legislatures enacted welfare reform measures designed to get people back into the workforce.

The Trump administration announced that it would adopt some of these state welfare reform measures — such as requiring food stamp recipients to work a certain number of hours per week — and implement them at the federal level
column2: causing nationwide food stamp enrollment to plunge even further.

column1: Over the past year since President Donald Trump took office
column2: enrollment in SNAP dropped by two million. The latest food stamp numbers show that the downward trend over the past year — and every year after 2013 — is continuing."	['https://media.breitbart.com/media/2020/03/GettyImages-1171541953-200x150.jpeg'

column1: 0	" -- Though he touts his outstanding memory
column2: when Donald Trump was asked under oath about his dealings with a twice-convicted Russian émigré who served prison time and had documented mafia connections
column3: the real estate mogul was at a loss.

column1: Even though the man
column2: Felix Sater
column3: had played a role in a number of high-profile Trump-branded projects across the country.

column1: “If he were sitting in the room right now
column2: I really wouldn't know what he looked like
column3: ” Trump testified in a video deposition for a civil lawsuit two years ago.

column1: In recent weeks
column2: the Republican Presidential candidate has been fending off critics who have accused him of embellishment
column3: insensitivity and in some cases inaccuracy for his descriptions of the Muslim response to 9/11. Trump also dismissed outrage at his purported mocking of a disabled New York Times reporter
column4: saying he simply does not remember meeting the scribe.

column1: Away from the spotlight
column2: Donald Trump has also been seeking to minimize his past business ties with Sater
column3: the Russian émigré who appeared in photos with Trump
column4: and carried a Trump Organization business card with the title “Senior Advisor to Donald Trump.”

column1: Asked last week about Sater by The Associated Press
column2: Trump again seemed unable to retrieve a solid memory of the man. ""Felix Sater
column3: boy
column4: I have to even think about it
column5: he told the reporter. ""I'm not that familiar with him.""

column1: Trump and Sater can be seen together in photographs attending a Denver business conference in 2005
column2: and the two men posed on stage together at the 2007 launch party for the Trump SoHo Hotel and Condominium project. And in 2010
column3: according to Trump’s lawyer
column4: Sater was provided business cards by the Trump Organization identifying him as a “senior advisor"" to Trump.

column1: Sater has declined repeated requests for an interview
column2: citing the advice of his attorney. But he has not been shy about posting items online touting his ties to Trump. On his website
column3: he called the Trump SoHo his “most prized project.” For years he identified himself on his online resume at the LinkedIn website as having been a ""senior advisor"" to Trump in 2010-2011. Last month
column4: after ABC News asked Trump’s attorney about it
column5: that portion of Sater’s online resume was deleted.

column1: The “senior advisor” title stands in sharp contrast to how Trump and his aides have repeatedly described the nature of their connection with Sater
column2: including in response to questions from ABC News.

column1: Alan Garten
column2: Trump’s General Counsel
column3: initially told ABC News that Trump “had no real direct relationship with Felix Sater” and that Sater was not an advisor to Donald Trump “in my mind
column4: and not in anyone at the Trump Organization's mind.”

column1: A few days later
column2: Garten confirmed the authenticity of Sater’s Trump business card with the “senior advisor” title which included a Trump Organization email address and phone number. But the lawyer said the title was not reflective of Sater’s actual role. It was common practice in the real estate industry
column3: he said
column4: to provide business cards and bestow titles “in order for brokers to be able to make initial introductions.”

column1: Donald Trump exits the Budweiser Events Center after talking at the Bixpo 2005 convention in Loveland
column2: Colo.
column3: Sept. 14
column4: 2005. Felix Sater appears in the red tie on Trump's left. Cyrus McCrimmon/Denver Post/Getty Images

column1: Garten said Sater was “never employed by or on the payroll of the Trump organization” and that “no deals ever came from those activities” in 2010. But Garten declined to respond to emails and phone messages with further questions
column2: including whether Sater was provided office space or compensated by the Trump organization in any other way. Images of Sater’s business card were wiped from the internet shortly after ABC News asked Garten about it.

column1: Trump’s extensive business relationships are garnering fresh attention as the public is becoming better acquainted with the real estate mogul-turned-politician who has catapulted into front-runner territory in the race for the GOP presidential nomination.

The cast of characters who participated in Trump’s many development deals touch on a topic the candidate regularly cites on the campaign trail -- his judgment at the helm of his real estate empire. Trump says his “tremendous” record of success is one of his most important qualifications to become President of the United States.
The connection to Felix Sater dates to the early 2000's when the Trump Organization worked on several occasions with a small development firm based in Trump Tower called the Bayrock Group
column2: where Sater was an executive until 2007.

column1: As Trump explained it during a 2013 deposition
column2: the relationship began when Bayrock was a tenant in his Trump Tower office building
column3: when “somebody from Bayrock
column4: I'm not exactly sure
column5: came to see -- either myself or one of my children” with a proposal for a development deal. “It could have been Felix Sater
column6: it could have been -- I really don't know who it might have been
column8: “but somebody from Bayrock.”

column1: Donald Trump is deposed under oath during a civil lawsuit in November 2013. Obtained by ABC News
Sater had already served prison time for a grisly 1991 assault at the El Rio Grande restaurant and bar in New York. According to court documents
column2: Sater allegedly told a man at the bar
column3: “I’ll kill you. I’ll rip your f****** head off and stick it down your throat.” Sater then allegedly grabbed a frozen margarita from the bar
column4: flung the contents in the air
column5: smashed the glass on the bar
column6: and stabbed the man in the cheek and neck
column8: lacerating face and neck and severing nerves. He was convicted of first degree assault.

column1: As he began his work with Bayrock
column2: Sater was also awaiting sentencing for his role in what authorities called a $40 million “pump and dump” stock scam. Federal prosecutors announced in a March 2
column3: 2000 press release that Sater had pleaded guilty in the federal racketeering case
column4: and was found to have been collaborating with members of four New York mob families. Sater and others had “planned and carried out a series of fraudulent securities schemes and then laundered tens of millions of dollars in illicit profits
column5: ” the release said.

column1: Prosecutors said Sater and others had “enlisted the help of individuals affiliated with organized crimes families of La Cosa Nostra to protect and promote their criminal activities.”
Sater avoided prison after FBI agents testified at his sentencing hearing that he had become an important government witness on both mob-related and national security matters
column2: heralded by federal agents for his cooperation. His lawyer
column3: Robert Wolf
column4: told the Associated Press that some of the information about Sater in public records and lawsuits is defamatory. Wolf told the AP that credits Sater's stint as a government cooperator with potentially saving American military lives
column5: although he did not provide details. Wolf told the AP to write about Sater's past ""at your own risk"" but did not cite specific concerns.

column1: During this period
column2: Sater’s role at Bayrock was not clearly defined. He at various times appeared in company emails and other records as the “chief operating officer” or “managing director.” In a 2010 deposition Sater said titles at the firm varied. “I was probably number two man in the company
column3: ” he said. “The actual position
column4: I don't remember what it was.”

column1: While the Trump SoHo project was considered a success
column2: four other Bayrock projects were either never built or were finished by others. Some of them resulted in lawsuits from unhappy investors. In each case
column3: Trump was not the actual developer of the project and was
column4: instead
column5: paid a fee to license the use of his name and potentially operate the hotel projects.

column1: During this period
column2: Trump and Bayrock also collaborated on a proposal for the 600
column3: 000-square-foot Trump International Hotel and Residences
column4: Phoenix
column5: that was to include a spa
column6: swimming pools
column8: ” and “a world-class celebrity chef restaurant.”

column1: The project never got off the ground
column2: however
column3: and in a 2007 lawsuit filed in state court against “the Trump/Bayrock Organization
column4: ” the plaintiff alleged that Sater threatened one of the Arizona partners in the deal
column5: a man named Earnest Mennes. Sater was alleged to have told Mennes he would call in a relative to “electrically shock Mr. Mennes' testicles
column6: cut off Mr. Mennes' legs
column7: and leave Mr. Mennes dead in the trunk of his car.”

column1: Sater’s lawyer calls the allegation “an outright fabrication” made as part of a lawsuit demanding a financial settlement.
Reached in Arizona
column2: Mennes said the matter had been settled out of court and he could not discuss it. Mennes said he reflects proudly on the time he worked on the Trump project
column3: and considers Trump a masterful businessman. Trump’s lawyer said he was unaware of the allegations in the Arizona lawsuit.

column1: Trump’s attorney says the real estate mogul had minimal interaction with Sater on the various joint ventures with Bayrock
column2: and so had no reason to probe deeply into his background.

column1: “To be clear
column2: ” Garten told ABC News
column3: “Mr. Sater's involvement in the projects
column4: the projects that went forward
column5: SoHo and Fort Lauderdale
column6: may have existed in the beginning
column7: but long term there was very little involvement.”

column1: Sater's alleged ties to organized crime were more widely publicized in December 2007 when The New York Times published an article featuring Sater’s ties to Trump and describing his “tangled past.” The article reported that Sater “had been an ‘unindicted co-conspirator’ and a key figure in a $40 million scheme involving 19 stockbrokers and organized crime figures from four Mafia families.”
Sater told the Times that activity was in the past. “I’m trying to lead an exemplary existence
column2: ” he said then. “Old
column3: bad luggage is not something anyone wants to remember.”

column1: While Sater’s criminal conviction had been publicized
column2: much of his role in the racketeering case had until that point been kept secret -- sealed by the government because Sater had become a “cooperator” on a range of matters.

column1: Sater’s attorney provided ABC News with a copy of a public statement from Attorney General Loretta Lynch
column2: whose New York office had enlisted cooperation from Sater when she was serving as a U.S. Attorney.

column1: “The defendant in question
column2: Felix Sater
column3: provided valuable and sensitive information to the government during the course of his cooperation
column4: ” her statement said. He provided information “crucial to national security and the conviction of over 20 individuals
column5: including those responsible for committing massive financial fraud and members of La Cosa Nostra.”

column1: Garten said Trump read the 2007 Times report and was “surprised.”
“He had no idea
column2: ” Garten said. It “was the first time that both the Trump organization and Bayrock learned of Mr. Sater's background.”

column1: Garten added
column2: “When you go into business with another company
column3: you're going to vet that company certainly
column4: but you're not going to vet every employee
column5: it’s just not appropriate.""

column1: Once that information became publicly known
column2: Garten initially told ABC News
column3: Trump “cut all ties” with Sater. But
column4: Garten then acknowledged
column5: the Trump organization continued to listen to deals pitched by Sater well after that.

column1: Asked why Trump would listen to a deal brought by a twice-convicted felon with alleged mafia ties
column2: Garten told ABC News
column3: “You’re going to look at the deal
column4: you’re not going to look at the broker.”

column1: During his 2013 deposition
column2: when asked about how much he knew about Sater’s past
column3: Trump said he knew Sater had “got into trouble because he got into a barroom fight which a lot of people do.” And
column4: he added
column5: “I don’t know him very well
column6: but I don’t think he was connected to the mafia.”

column2: the BBC pressed Trump asking why he didn’t say “You’re fired!” to Sater after reports surfaced alleging Sater had ties to organized crime
column3: Trump ultimately rose from his chair mid-interview.

column1: “I hate to do this
column2: but I do have that big group of people waiting so I have to leave
column3: ” he said
column4: walking out of the room.

column1: Trump said during the deposition four months later he could not recall doing the BBC interview.
In August
column2: the Washington Examiner asked Trump's campaign manager
column3: Corey Lewandowski
column4: about the mogul’s past dealings with Sater. ""I have no idea who Felix Sater is
column5: he has nothing to do with the Donald J. Trump for President presidential campaign
column6: Lewandowski replied. ""I've never heard of the guy.”

column1: For investors who put money into those Trump-branded projects based on the reputation of the man behind the name brand
column2: news that one of the people involved
column3: Sater
column4: had such a checkered criminal history was distressing.

column1: Cathy Cather
column2: a Fort Lauderdale healthcare consultant
column3: invested and lost money in the Trump condominium hotel project in her hometown – which failed in part because of the economic collapse. She told ABC News she made her decision in part based on glossy brochures emblazoned with Trump’s photos and such slogans as ""There is luxury... And then there is THE TRUMP EXPERIENCE.""

column1: “I invested because it was Trump
column2: ” Cather told ABC News.

column1: ABC News' Randy Kreider and Alex Hosenball contributed to this report."	['https://s.abcnews.com/images/Politics/GTY_trump_sater_lf_151020_16x9_992.jpg'

column1: Obama Hits Clinton on NAFTA Support
LORAIN
column2: Ohio (AP) — Barack Obama accused Democratic presidential rival Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday of trying to walk away from a long record of support for NAFTA
column3: the free trade agreement that he said has cost 50
column4: 000 jobs in Ohio
column5: site of next week's primary.

column1: At the same time
column2: he said attempts to repeal the trade deal ""would probably result in more job losses than job gains in the United States.""

column1: One day after Clinton angrily accused him of distorting her record on the North American Free Trade Agreement in mass mailings
column2: the Illinois senator was eager to rekindle the long-distance debate
column3: using passages from the former first lady's book as well as her own words.

column1: Ten years after NAFTA passed
column2: Senator Clinton said it was good for America
column3: Obama said. ""Well
column4: I don't think NAFTA has been good for America — and I never have.""

column1: The fact is
column2: she was saying great things about NAFTA until she started running for president
column3: Obama told an audience at a factory that makes wall board
column4: located in a working class community west of Cleveland.

column1: A couple years after it passed
column2: she said NAFTA was a 'free and fair trade agreement' and that it was 'proving its worth.' And in 2004
column3: she said
column4: ""I think
column5: on balance
column6: NAFTA has been good for New York and America

column1: The trade agreement has long been unpopular in the industrial Midwest
column2: where critics blame it for lost jobs and shuttered factories
column3: many of which once employed union workers who tend to vote Democratic.

column1: Ohio and Texas both hold primaries next week
column2: with 334 delegates combined
column3: and former President Clinton has said publicly his wife probably needs to win both of them if she is to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

column1: Vermont and Rhode Island also hold primaries on March 4
column2: but have far fewer delegates and have not attracted nearly as much attention.

column1: On another issue
column2: Obama said he was not concerned that Republicans might attempt to depict him as unpatriotic if he becomes the Democratic nominee.

column1: Asked about a series of events
column2: such as not placing his hand over his heart during the national anthem
column3: he said
column4: ""The way I will respond to it is with the truth. That I owe everything I am to this country.""

column1: He also said patriotism had more than one definition
column2: and that Republicans had presided over a war ""in which our troops did not get the body armor they needed"" or were sent into the war zone without enough training.

column1: Polls show Clinton with a narrowing lead in Ohio
column2: where trade has long been a sensitive issue.

column1: Given that backdrop
column2: the issue is the core of Obama's drive to win the Ohio primary and possibly force Clinton from the race.

column1: At the news conference
column2: he noted that she had said Saturday that the agreement was negotiated by President George H.W. Bush
column3: and passed and signed into law while her husband was in the White House.

column1: He said Clinton has ""essentially presented herself as co-president during the Clinton years. Every good thing that happened she says she was a part of and so the notion that you can selectively pick what you take credit for and then run away from what isnt politically convenient
column2: that doesnt make sense.""

column1: On Saturday
column2: Clinton called attention to her plan to fix problems with NAFTA and a commitment against any future trade deals ""unless they are positive for American workers.""

column1: To an audience of Boilermakers Union members and their families
column2: Obama promised the same thing
column3: with particular attention paid to labor and environmental concerns.

column1: Now
column2: if we're honest with ourselves
column3: we'll acknowledge that we can't stop globalization in its tracks and that some of these jobs aren't coming back
column4: he said. ""But what I refuse to accept is that we have to stand idly by while workers watch their jobs get shipped overseas."""	['https://web.archive.org/web/20080226201453im_/http://ap.google.com/hostednews/img/vertical-space.gif'

column1: 0	"McCain renews attacks on Obama links to radical
MIAMI
column2: Florida (AFP) — Republican John McCain renewed his attacks on Barack Obama's ties to a 1960s radical here Wednesday as he targeted voters in the key battleground state of Florida.

column1: McCain
column2: who has refrained from linking Obama to Bill Ayers during recent campaign speeches
column3: went back on the offensive six days before the November 4 polls in an interview with a Spanish-language radio station in Miami.

column1: I think this whole issue of the relationship with Bill Ayers needs to be known by the American people
column2: he told Radio Mambi. ""Senator Obama said it was just a guy in the neighborhood. We know much more than that.""

column1: Ayers was a member of the ""Weathermen"" movement
column2: classified by the FBI as a ""domestic terrorist organization
column3: which carried out a series of attacks to protest the Vietnam War
column4: including on the Pentagon and US Capitol.

column1: Obama met Ayers early in his political career in 1995 but his campaign has said he has not spoken by phone or exchanged e-mail messages with him since Obama became US senator in 2005.
McCain went on to accuse the Los Angeles Times of refusing to publish a video it had obtained of Ayers attending an event with a member of the Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO).
I don't care much about an old
column2: washed-up unrepentant terrorist
column3: and his wife who was on an FBI top 10 wanted list
column4: McCain said.

column1: But we should know about their relationship
column2: including apparently information that is held by the Los Angeles Times concerning an event that Mr Ayers attended with a PLO spokesman.""

column1: McCain appeared to be referring to a Los Angeles Times article from April which said Obama knew and attended a farewell party for Rashid Khalidi
column2: a former PLO spokesman
column3: during his academic career in Chicago. The article makes no mention of Ayers's presence at the event.

column1: The Los Angeles Times refuses to make that videotape public. I'm not in the business of talking about media bias but what if there was a tape with John McCain with a neo-Nazi outfit being held by some media outlet?
I think the treatment of the issue would be slightly different
column2: he said
column3: saying Ayers had a ""long relationship"" with Obama
column4: who was eight years old when the Weathermen were waging their radical campaign.

column1: It's not that Barack Obama was eight years old when Mr Ayers was committing acts of terror
column2: it's all about the long relationship on foundations
column3: for his book and launching his political career in Mr Ayers living room
column4: McCain said.

column1: The interview was one of several given by the 72-year-old senator to local radio in Miami as he attempts to woo the influential Hispanic vote in Florida
column2: a state he almost certainly must win in order to take the White House.

column1: Later McCain took aim at recent comments by former Cuba president Fidel Castro
column2: who had ridiculed the former pilot's low grades at naval academy.

column1: I notice in the past couple of days that Fidel has made his preferences known in the campaign and had some very unkind things to say about me
column2: McCain said. ""My feelings are hurt.""

column1: More than one million Cuban-Americans live in Florida
column2: and McCain said he was acutely aware of the group's possible influence in the election race.

column1: He attempted to tap into anti-Castro sentiment by vowing to ""restore freedom and democracy"" on the island
column2: criticizing Obama for advocating a policy of diplomatic engagement.

column1: I think we all know that the Cuban-American vote can be vital to whether I win Florida or not
column2: McCain said. ""So I do want to say again that we will never waver in our mission to restore freedom and democracy."	['https://web.archive.org/web/20081202093502im_/http://afp.google.com/hostednews/img/vertical-space.gif'

column1: 0	"The public had him pegged all wrong
column2: he complained. Donna Hanover shared a painful memory several years ago in an interview with The New York Times. On the night of his defeat
column3: Mr. Giuliani crumpled at the foot of their bed and asked
column4: ''Do they really think I'm mean?''

column1: Looking toward a 1993 rematch
column2: the candidate would find ways to become new and improved. He spent hundreds of hours in a self-designed seminar
column3: inviting experts to tutor him on urban reforms. He also submitted to a political airbrushing by new strategists. Weight was lost
column4: a tan was added. He danced a two-step at a hoedown in SoHo
column5: greeting people with ''Howdy.''

column1: At heart
column2: however
column3: Mr. Giuliani was still the scrappy prosecutor in a city where voters seemed willing to blame the incumbent for a staggering murder rate
column4: homelessness and a general sense of disorder. He believed then -- as he does now -- ''that in New York
column5: you have to be a fighter.''

column1: He beat Mr. Dinkins by a margin of two percentage points
column2: becoming the city's first Republican mayor in a generation. His campaign themes were true to his roots: part nostalgia
column3: part law and order. He promised nothing less than to restore a better quality of life.

column1: His inaugural speech seemed the dare of a new sheriff
column2: busting through the saloon doors. ''The era of fear has had a long-enough reign
column3: '' he said. ''As of this moment
column4: the expressions of cynicism -- New York is not governable
column5: New York is not manageable
column6: New York is not worth it -- all of these I declare politically incorrect.''

column1: Mr. Giuliani considered himself a warrior in the free-for-all between cops and robbers. He was the people's choice for top cop
column2: and
column3: therefore
column4: to oppose him was to rob the public of its collective will.

column1: In his third month as Mayor
column2: the one-time political science major had occasion to describe his philosophy of government at a New York Post forum on crime. His passage from the liberal beliefs of his younger years was complete."	['https://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/images/icons/defaultPromoCrop.png']	https://static01.nyt.com/newsgraphics/images/icons/defaultPromoCrop.png	RACE FOR CITY HALL: The Republican Candidate; A Mercurial Mayor's Confident Journey	http://query.nytimes.com

column1: 0	"ROCHESTER
column2: New Hampshire – During a radio interview this morning
column3: Hollywood actor Bill Murray took a moment to praise Rochester
column4: New Hampshire residents who had helped him with a mechanical issue with his rental car as he passed through the city recently:

column1: “We were just leaving the city limits of Rochester
column2: New Hampshire when the damn car overheated or something so I pulled it over to the side of the road and within just a minute or two there were a couple of cars that pulled over to help me out. I told them that I was on the phone with the rental car company but one of them had a brother who owned a tow truck and a few minutes later it was there and he towed it to a place nearby to get fixed.

column1: So then the one guy finds out that I’m not from there and offers to take me in to get lunch while my car is getting fixed and I’m thinking
column2: “Sure
column3: what the hell.” So we drove to the finest dining spot in Rochester – some place called Wild Willy’s – and get a burger. Great freakin’ burger too. These guys had no idea who I was either which made my day
column4: honestly.

column1: I’m telling you
column2: these people in Rochester are the real deal. I’m gonna move there after I retire
column3: ” Murray said with a laugh.

column1: Murray added later
column2: “You have to understand
column3: this is something that would’ve never happened in L.A.! So yeah
column4: that’s my story about Rochester. It’s nice to know there are still places like this in America.”

column1: photo by David Shankbone / CC BY 2.0 / cropped"	['https://web.archive.org/web/20161226221619im_/http://newsdaily12.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/Bill-Murray.jpg']	https://web.archive.org/web/20161226221619im_/http://newsdaily12.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/Bill-Murray.jpg	Bill Murray Had This to Say About Rochester
column2: New Hampshire Residents – News Daily 12	https://web.archive.org

column1: 0	"President Donald Trump has finally given Congress the authorization to pursue charges against Hillary Clinton.
Jason Chaffetz
column2: the Chairman of the United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
column3: informed the committee that he had a meeting with President Trump who gave him permission to investigate whatever he wants. Chaffetz also hinted that charges against Hillary could be happening soon.

column1: Here is what Chaffetz said:
“President Trump visited Philadelphia when we were at our planning and strategy session. I went backstage with the President. Here’s what he said: ‘You do a great job. Listen
column2: I understand I’m the president and you have a job. You do the oversight. Don’t slow down. Go after everything you want to go after. You look at everything you want to look at.’ If you sat there and heard what he said to me about pursuing oversight and government
column3: you would be inspired. And for him to convey a message of ‘don’t slow down
column4: ’ I think was a good message.”

column1: WATCH:
The news that President Trump supports the investigation comes just days after the Oversight Committee ordered James Comey
column2: (now former) FBI Director
column3: to release the contents of Hillary Clinton’s email server. This means that the lawless and reckless behavior of Hillary Clinton hasn’t yet escaped from a full-blown investigation.

column1: Without Obama and Comey to cover her back now
column2: Hillary Clinton may finally be indicted. It’s about time she is held responsible for her countless crimes and for betraying our country. She has to answer for that
column3: and now that President Trump is in control
column4: she won’t make it out of this investigation so easily.

column1: 0	"David Hogg
column2: a senior at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School
column3: knows what gunshots sound like: His father worked in law enforcement
column4: and taught him about weapons and how to handle them. So when Hogg heard a “pop” while sitting in an AP environmental science class around 2:30 p.m. Wednesday
column5: he told his teacher it sounded strangely like a gunshot. But there had been a fire drill that very morning and talk of a “Code Red” exercise to prepare for an active shooter. This must just be a surprise drill
column6: he reasoned.

column1: And then the fire alarm sounded. Dutifully acting on it
column2: Hogg and other students tried to exit the building. A janitor—Hogg doesn’t know his name but calls him an angel—knew where the shots were coming from and sent the students back. Then a culinary arts teacher
column3: Ashley Kurth
column4: pulled Hogg and others inside
column5: locked the door
column6: and made them hide in a closet. Checking Twitter and Instagram
column7: Hogg—who’s an editor at the school’s TV station—found the news that the shooting was real and ongoing.

column1: The shots continued for what felt like an eternity. Hogg considered the possibility that he would not live to see the end of the day.
“While I was in there
column2: I thought
column3: ‘What impact have I had? What will my story be if I die here?’” Hogg told TIME in the hours following the ordeal. “And the only thing I could think of was
column4: pull out my camera and try telling others. As a student journalist
column5: as an aspiring journalist
column6: that’s all I could think: Get other people’s stories on tape. If we all die
column8: and that’s how we get the message out there
column9: about how we want change to be brought about.”

column1: In the wake of Wednesday’s mass shooting
column2: in which at least 17 were killed and more than a dozen others wounded
column3: that cry for change is echoing across this normally quiet
column4: almost bucolic Florida community of 30
column5: 000 on the edge of the Everglades
column6: which draws residents seeking sprawling homes and room to run horses. It’s being heard across Broward County
column8: Scott Israel
column9: is prodding Florida officials to provide more funding for mental health
column10: as well as laws that would prevent a person with psychological problems from being able to legally acquire a gun. And it’s becoming a rallying cry for people here and across the U.S. who are wondering what
column12: changes from one mass shooting to the next.

column1: “When do we say
column2: that’s not acceptable
column3: something has to change?” asked Hogg
column5: his voice breaking.

column1: Hogg’s sister Lauren
column2: a freshman at the high school
column3: is fearing the worst: one of her friends had still not been located late Thursday. Nikolas Cruz
column4: the suspect who has been charged with 17 counts of murder
column5: had been expelled from the school a year ago and appears to have targeted a building full of ninth-graders.

column1: RELATED VIDEO: Florida Shooting Survivor Calls for Action
Will Gilroy is one of the freshmen who escaped the gunman’s wrath. He is still waiting for word about classmates that haven’t been located. Like Hogg
column2: Gilroy thought the shooting wasn’t real at first. But then he heard the sirens. He listened to his teacher’s orders and crowded into a closet with about 20 others. He was in there
column3: he says
column4: for about an hour.

column1: “It was hot in there. We were packed in tight
column2: ” he told TIME. “Some students were crying. The teacher had paper plates and we used them to fan ourselves.” Inside the closet Gilroy began texting with his mother
column3: Kristi Gilroy
column4: who teaches second and third grade in at Country Hills Elementary just down the road. She too was on lockdown
column5: with kids who stayed for after-school ccare. She was relieved to know her only son was alive. But the shooter was still at large. Cruz was eventually caught just down the road from their house
column6: trying to escape with the rest of the crowd.

column1: “My husband is ex-military
column2: so it’s not like we’re anti-gun. But an AR-15?” Kristi Gilroy said. “You tell me
column3: how big of a gun does a person need?” Douglas is closed for the rest of the week as teens and teachers struggle to make sense of the carnage. But Kristi Gilroy faces the difficult job of going back to school Thursday
column4: waiting for news of the dead and injured
column5: which might
column6: she feared
column7: include children she’d taught when they were younger.

column1: The usual questions arose Thursday about whether it was too soon to talk about gun control. Some local officials seemed ready to toss out the oft-heard script
column2: the prayers for families and praise for first responders. “Now
column3: now is the time for this country to have a conversation about sensible gun control laws in this country
column4: ” Broward County School Superintendent Robert W. Runcie told reporters. “Our students are asking for that.”

column1: President Trump spoke Thursday morning
column2: taking on the grim task of comforter-in-chief
column3: but offering no specific proposals.

column1: “To every parent
column2: teacher
column3: and child who is hurting so badly
column4: we are here for you
column5: whatever you need
column6: whatever we can do
column8: ” Trump said. “We are all joined together as one American family
column9: and your suffering is our burden also.”

column1: Attorney General Pam Bondi
column2: speaking to reporters on Thursday
column3: said that she’d been sitting with parents until 3:30 a.m. “Having to tell parents that a child
column4: 14 years old
column5: is dead
column6: is the hardest thing you have to do in your career
column8: her eyes full of tears.

column1: To some
column2: however
column3: words of comfort won’t be enough. “When do we actually stand up? I think it’s the time that we all stand up
column4: ” Hogg demanded. “If you don’t call your Congressman and do it again and again and not give up
column5: it’s going to be your child that’s next. And that’s horrifying.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Parkland waits. Waits for the names of the innocent who were gunned down before they could graduate
column3: or in some cases
column4: finish the ninth grade. Waits for news of funeral arrangements for a beloved football coach and security guard. Waits to hear if the children still in the hospital pull will through. Waits for someone to convince their teenagers that it’s okay to go back to school
column5: that they’re safe
column6: and that nothing like this will happen again.

column1: 0	"Published on Mar 8
In the Weekly Republican Address
column2: Sen. Rob Portman of Ohio outlines a Senate Republican Jobs for America plan designed to bring back opportunity
column3: spark an economic recovery and make it possible again for every citizen to have a shot at the American Dream. President Obama and congressional Democrats have tried to tax
column4: spend and regulate American prosperity
column5: says Portman
column6: but those ideas haven't worked. ""We know we can do better
column7: and it starts by putting our trust back in the American people
column8: says Portman
column9: who calls for reforming the corporate tax code
column10: ratifying free trade agreements and approving construction of the Keystone pipeline
column20: 'https://i.ytimg.com/vi/F4L5TM7UatA/hqdefault.jpg?sqp=-oaymwEiCKgBEF5IWvKriqkDFQgBFQAAAAAYASUAAMhCPQCAokN4AQ==&rs=AOn4CLDrqIrx2NMfmKjyrW15lY5boH9F9Q']	https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Vp6x3mEU4ok/maxresdefault.jpg	3/8/14 Sen. Rob Portman (R-OH) delivers Weekly GOP Address on American jobs	http://www.youtube.com

column1: 0	"U.S. Senator Ben Sasse issued the following statement regarding the news that the administration will impose massive steel and aluminum tariffs on our allies in Canada
column2: Mexico
column3: and the European Union.

column1: This is dumb. Europe
column2: Canada
column3: and Mexico are not China
column4: and you don’t treat allies the same way you treat opponents. We’ve been down this road before—blanket protectionism is a big part of why America had a Great Depression. 'Make America Great Again' shouldn’t mean 'Make America 1929 Again.'"""	['https://statse.webtrendslive.com/dcs222ghgh6w4r4w3u7m96f7h_1p5i/njs.gif?dcsuri=/nojavascript&WT.js=No&WT.tv=10.4.0&dcssip=www.sasse.senate.gov'
column5: 'https://www.sasse.senate.gov/public/vendor/_skins/sasse/images/seal.png']	https://www.sasse.senate.gov/public/vendor/_skins/sasse/images/seal.png	Sasse Statement on Trade War	https://www.sasse.senate.gov

column1: Return to Transcripts main page
CNN LIVE EVENT/SPECIAL
Republican Presidential Debate
Aired June 5
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
WOLF BLITZER
column2: HOST: Let's begin our questioning.

column1: Right now Tom Fahey of the New Hampshire Union Leader with the first question.
TOM FAHEY
column2: NEW HAMPSHIRE UNION LEADER: Thanks
column3: Wolf.

column1: Governor Romney
column2: I wanted to start by asking you a question on which every American has formed an opinion.

column1: We have lost 3
column2: 400 troops
column3: civilian casualties are even higher
column4: and the Iraqi government does not appear ready to provide for the security of its own country. Knowing everything you know right now
column5: was it a mistake for us to invade Iraq?

column1: MITT ROMNEY
column2: FORMER GOVERNOR OF MASSACHUSETTS: Well
column3: the question is
column4: kind of
column5: a non sequitur
column6: if you will. What I mean by that -- or a null set -- that is that if you're saying let's turn back the clock and Saddam Hussein had opening up his country to IAEA inspectors and they'd come in and they'd found that there were no weapons of mass destruction
column7: had Saddam Hussein therefore not violated United Nations resolutions
column8: we wouldn't be in the conflict we're in.

column1: But he didn't do those things
column2: and we knew what we knew at the point we made the decision to get in.

column1: I supported the president's decision based on what we knew at that time.
I think we were underprepared and underplanned for what came after we knocked down Saddam Hussein.
By the way
column2: Harry Reid was wrong. We did not lose the war in Iraq. And that's not the sort of thing you say when you have men and women in harm's way.

column1: We did
column2: however
column3: not do a great job after we knocked down Saddam Hussein and won the war to take him down and his military.

column1: And at this stage
column2: the right thing for us to do is to see if we could possibly stabilize the central government in Iraq so that they can have stability
column3: and so we can bring our troops home as soon as possible.

column1: Not to do that adds an enormous potential risk that the whole region could be embroiled in a regional conflict. BLITZER: Governor
column2: thank you
column3: but the question was
column4: knowing what you know right now -- not what you knew then
column5: what you know right now -- was it a mistake for the United States to invade Iraq?

column1: ROMNEY: Well
column2: I answered the question by saying it's a non- sequitur. It's a non -- null set kind of question
column3: because you can go back and say
column4: ""If we knew then what we know now
column5: by virtue of inspectors having been let in and giving us that information
column6: by virtue of if Saddam Hussein had followed the U.N. resolutions
column7: we wouldn't be having this discussion.""

column1: So it's a hypothetical that I think is an unreasonable hypothetical.
And the answer is: We did what we did. We did the right thing based on what we knew at that time. I think we made mistakes following the conduct or the collapse of Saddam's government.
FAHEY: Mayor Giuliani
column2: same question to you. Knowing what you know right now
column3: was it a good decision?

column1: RUDY GIULIANI
column2: FORMER MAYOR OF NEW YORK CITY: Absolutely the right thing to do. It's unthinkable that you would leave Saddam Hussein in charge of Iraq and be able to fight the war on terror.

column1: And the problem is that we see Iraq in a vacuum. Iraq should not be seen in a vacuum. Iraq is part of the overall terrorist war against the United States.
The problem the Democrats make is they're in denial. That's why you hear things like you heard in the debate the other night
column2: that
column3: you know
column4: Iran really isn't dangerous; it's 10 years away from nuclear weapons.

column1: Iran is not 10 years away from nuclear weapons. And the danger to us is not just missiles. The danger to us is a state like Iran handing nuclear weapons over to terrorists.
So it has to be seen in that light. And we have to be successful in Iraq.
BLITZER: Senator McCain
column2: arguably going to war is the most important decision a member of the Senate can make.

column1: Did you read the national intelligence estimate
column2: which included all the caveats on whether or not there were weapons of mass destruction in Iraq?

column1: SEN. JOHN MCCAIN (R)
column2: ARIZONA: I did not read that particular document. I received hundreds of briefing
column3: tens and hundreds of hours of study and background and information on it. And the fact is that the sanctions were breaking down. The sanctions were not going to hold. We had a multi-billion dollar scandal in the form of oil for food.

column1: The fact is that Saddam Hussein had used weapons of mass destruction before on his own people and on his enemies. And if he'd gotten them again
column2: he'd have used them again. That was his commitment and his belief
column3: that he was going to. And we did the right thing.

column1: The problem was the mismanagement of the conflict.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: Senator Brownback
column2: you're also a member of the United States Senate. Did you read that classified national intelligence estimate?

column1: SEN. SAM BROWNBACK (R)
column2: KANSAS: I don't remember that report. I had a number of briefings and I held a number of committee hearings. At that time
column3: I was chairing the Middle East Subcommittee on Foreign Relations. And we held hearings on this topic and what was taking place and what Saddam was doing.

column1: But the issue is that we've got to put forward
column2: now
column3: a political plan. And that's something I'm going to introduce tomorrow
column4: a political plan to create a three-state solution in Iraq: a Kurdish state
column5: a Sunni state
column6: a Shia state. Because Iraq is more three groups held together by exterior forces. And that's what we've lacked is a political plan to get us moving forward in success.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: Governor Gilmore
column2: let me go to you. You chaired this commission. Do you think it was appropriate that members of Congress would authorize the president to go to war without reading that national intelligence estimate?

column1: JIM GILMORE
column2: FORMER GOVERNOR OF VIRGINIA: You know
column3: I think the people who are in Congress who are responsible for sending this country to war
column4: with the enormous dangers that it has geopolitically and strategically
column5: ought to read at least that kind of material. I know they get a lot of stuff and they can't read everything.

column1: But you know what
column2: Wolf? I think the true business is this: The interests of the United States is in creating as much stability as possible in the Middle East. There is a very great danger to this country: our interests in Israel
column3: our interests in energy and in other ways. There is a giant danger of the Middle East becoming an unstable place.

column1: Saddam Hussein was unstable
column2: and so taking him out was good there. But we certainly didn't anticipate the further instability that was to come after.

column1: BLITZER: We're going to bring all of you in
column2: but I want to go to Scott Spradling of WMUR for the next question.

column1: SCOTT SPRADLING
column2: WMUR-TV: Thanks
column3: Wolf.

column1: Senator McCain
column2: we've just spent a few minutes looking back. I'd ask you to look forward now
column3: if you will.

column1: Since June 1st there have been at least 17 confirmed deaths of American soldiers in Iraq. Approximately 100 U.S. troops are dying there every month. If our top military commander in Iraq
column2: General Petraeus
column3: reports back to Congress this September that the surge hasn't significantly improved the situation on the ground
column4: what then?

column1: MCCAIN: Well
column2: let me say
column3: first of all
column4: I know how frustrated and saddened all Americans are. This morning I was with the family of Matthew Stanley of Wolfeboro
column5: who sacrificed his life. And our hearts and our sympathy goes out to all those who have sacrificed their lives in this conflict.

column1: I (inaudible) think this strategy needs to be given a chance to succeed. We haven't barely gotten the fifth brigade over there
column2: which is part of this strategy.

column1: I am convinced that if we fail and we have to withdraw
column2: they will follow us home. It will be a base for Al Qaida. And we will be facing greater challenges and greater sacrifices than that already made by Matthew Stanley and his family.

column1: There is no doubt in my mind that this will become a base for terrorism
column2: there will be chaos in the region. And when Senator Clinton says this is Mr. Bush's war
column3: that this is President Bush's war -- when President Clinton was in power
column4: I didn't say that Bosnia
column5: our intervention there was President Clinton's war. When we intervened in Kosovo
column6: I didn't say it was President Clinton's war.

column1: What Senator Clinton doesn't understand that presidents don't lose wars. Political parties don't lose wars.
Nations lose wars
column2: and nations lose the -- have the consequences of failure.

column1: BLITZER: Senator...
MCCAIN: We must succeed in this conflict.
BLITZER: ... the question was
column2: if General Petraeus says...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... it's not working so far in September
column2: what do you do then?

column1: MCCAIN: Then you have to examine the options.

And I'll tell you the options: One is the division that Sam described. You would have to divide bedrooms in Baghdad because Sunni and Shia are married to each other. You have 2 million Sunni and 4 million Shia living in Baghdad together.

You would have to -- you withdraw to the borders and watch genocide take place inside Baghdad. You watch the destabilization of Jordan. You see further jeopardy of Israel because of the threats of Hezbollah and Iranian hegemony in the region.
All of the options I could run through with you. My friend
column2: none of them are good. That's why we must succeed and give it a chance to succeed.

column1: BLITZER: All right.
Now
column2: let me bring in Governor Thompson.

column1: Go ahead
column2: same question to you: If General Petraeus says it's not working in September
column3: what should the U.S. do then?

column1: TOMMY THOMPSON
column2: FORMER HHS SECRETARY: The first thing the president should do is demand the al-Maliki government to vote as to whether or not they want the United States to stay in Iraq. We've been there four years. Give the government the responsibility of voting.

column1: If they vote ""yes
column2: how are they going to help us win this war? If they vote ""no
column3: we should redeploy our forces outside.

column1: Secondly
column2: there are 18 territories in Iraq
column3: geographically defined. Those 18 territories
column4: just like 50 states in America
column5: should elect their state leaders. And if they do so
column6: the Shiites will elect Shiites
column8: Kurds will elect Kurds. And you know something? People will go to those particular territories
column9: and you get rid of this civil war internecine.

column1: Number three...
BLITZER: All right...
THOMPSON: ... I would like to have the oil revenue proceeds -- very quickly -- oil revenue proceeds split: one-third to the federal government
column2: one-third to the states
column3: and one-third to every man
column4: woman and child. And that will get everybody a stake in their country.

column1: BLITZER: Let me bring in Congressman Duncan Hunter.
Congressman
column2: if it's not working at that point
column3: how much longer should the United States stay?

column1: REP. DUNCAN HUNTER (R)
column2: CALIFORNIA: Well
column3: Wolf
column4: you know
column5: I read that NIE report
column6: and I held briefings before we made the vote to go in and invited everybody
column8: to get the classified information.

column1: And this depends -- the turnover of the security apparatus depends on one thing: reliable Iraqi forces.
You've got 129 Iraqi battalions. We've trained them up. We've got a lot of them in the fight. Over the next three to four months
column2: we need to get them all in the fight
column3: get them that combat capability. When they're combat-hardened
column4: we rotate them in
column5: we displace American heavy combat forces off that battlefield
column6: and Americans come home. And

column1: BLITZER: Thank you.
HUNTER: ... I can tell you
column2: as the chairman of the Armed Services Committee for the last four years
column3: I have the credentials to leave Iraq the right way.

column1: BLITZER: Congressman Ron Paul
column2: how much longer should the United States stay in Iraq?

column1: REP. RON PAUL (R)
column2: TEXAS: The sooner we come home
column3: the better. If they declare there's no progress in September
column4: we should come home. It was a mistake to go
column5: so it's a mistake to stay.

column1: If we made the wrong diagnosis
column2: we should change the treatment. So we're not making progress there and we should come home.

column1: The weapons weren't there and we went in under U.N. resolutions. And our national security was not threatened. We're more threatened now by staying.
BLITZER: Governor Huckabee
column2: do you have confidence in the government of Iraq...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
... the government of Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki
column2: that he's going to do what needs to be done?

column1: MIKE HUCKABEE
column2: FORMER GOVERNOR OF ARKANSAS: I think there's some real doubt about that
column3: Wolf.

column1: But I want to remind all of us on this stage and the people in the audience that there's a reason that this is such a struggle. And I think we miss it over here in the West.
Today's the birthday of Ronald Reagan. We all would believe that Ronald Reagan is the one who ended the Cold War and Ronald Reagan is the one who helped bring about the collapse of the Soviet Union.
But there's a group of people who don't believe that
column2: and that's the Taliban. They believe they brought about the demise of the Soviet Union because of the way they fought in Afghanistan.

column1: And what I want to just mention is that it is not the size of the dog in the fight
column2: it is the size of the fight in the dog. And we underestimate -- grossly underestimate how fierce this dog is and how determined they are to destroy every last one of us.

column1: BLITZER: All right.
Congressman Tom Tancredo
column2: what do you say?

column1: REP. TOM TANCREDO (R)
column2: COLORADO: I'll tell you this
column3: that if it comes to that point in that time that you described
column4: that the surge is apparent that it is not working
column5: I did support it. I hope to God it does work. I hope I'm wrong. I hope we pacify Iraq.

column1: However
column2: if it is apparent that we cannot
column3: then we have to do and tell the Iraqis the exact same thing that Benjamin Franklin said when he came out of the convention in 1787 and somebody said to him
column4: ""Dr. Franklin
column5: what have you given us?"" And he said
column6: ""A republic

column1: It is exactly that time and it is exactly that thing that we have to say to the Iraqi government: ""We have given you this. We bought it with our blood and sweat. It is now up to you to keep it.""
And I want the Iraqis to be in fact patrolling Baghdad. If they need vehicles
column2: you let them have the vehicles. But I want them patrolling their city and putting their lives at risk.

column1: Then we move out.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I want to go to the next question. I want to go back to Tom.
Tom
column2: go ahead.

column1: FAHEY: Senator Brownback
column2: President Bush has stated that states that sponsor terrorism are no different than terrorists themselves. Yet Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice recently met with Iranian officials to discuss security in Iraq. Iran is a known support of Hezbollah
column3: Hamas.

column1: Did President Bush make the right call in opening a dialogue with Iran?
BROWNBACK: I think he made a right call on saying that about terrorist states
column2: particularly Iran. But I think we have to at times talk with them in different situations.

column1: Like
column2: before we went into Afghanistan
column3: we talked with Iran. It wasn't we were negotiating. We didn't open up formal diplomatic relations and we shouldn't.

column1: Iran is the lead sponsor of terrorism. Ahmadinejad just this past week called for the destruction of Israel
column2: continues to call for attacking of the United States.

column1: On Iraq
column2: I think we need to talk with them. I think we have to confront them aggressively for what they are
column3: which is the lead sponsor of terrorism in the world. I think we need to push the sanctions forward more aggressively. I think we need to work with the labor union movement that's developing inside of Iran. You had a bus driver strike that recently took place.

column1: And I think we have to show that purpose and resolve
column2: that we're going to confront these guys and we're going to stand with our allies like Israel
column3: we're going to stand against them oppressing and pushing us
column4: and trying to fund terrorists against us.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: Congressman Hunter
column2: let me bring...

column1: BROWNBACK: Senator
column2: if you don't mind.

column1: BLITZER: Excuse me
column2: Senator.

column1: BROWNBACK: That's OK.
BLITZER: Congressman Hunter
column2: let me bring you back in. Do you agree with Senator Brownback that President Bush made the right decision in opening a direct dialogue with Iran?

column1: HUNTER: With two conditions. And I think that you do have a dialogue with everybody
column2: whether they're adversaries or friends.

column1: The two conditions are: Number one
column2: they are moving deadly equipment across the border that is killing Americans in Iraq.

column1: We have license to utilize anything that we want to use: special operations
column2: intelligence
column3: whatever it takes to stop that deadly equipment from moving across the border and hitting Americans in Iraq. And we don't give that up with these talks.

column1: Secondly
column2: they've got about 1
column3: 000 centrifuges now working
column4: enriching the material that can make
column5: at some point
column6: a nuclear device. The United States reserves the right to preempt
column7: and we may have to preempt that nuclear weapons program. We cannot allow them to have a nuclear device.

column1: With those two caveats
column2: talk to your enemies.

column1: BLITZER: If it came down to a preemptive U.S. strike against Iran's nuclear facility if necessary
column2: would you authorize as president the use of tactical nuclear weapons?

column1: HUNTER: I would authorize the use of tactical nuclear weapons if there was no other way to preempt those particular centrifuges.
When the Osirak reactor was hit in '86
column2: when the six F-18s came over the horizon and knocked that out
column3: they didn't need anything but conventional weapons.

column1: Probably it's going to take a little more than that. I don't think it's going to take tactical nukes.
BLITZER: What do you think
column2: Mayor? Do you think
column3: if you were president of the United States and it came down to Iran having a nuclear bomb
column4: which you say is unacceptable
column5: you would authorize the use of tactical nuclear weapons?

column1: GIULIANI: Part of the premise of talking to Iran has to be that they have to know very clearly that it is unacceptable to the United States that they have nuclear power. I think it could be done with conventional weapons
column2: but you can't rule out anything and you shouldn't take any option off the table.

column1: And during the debate the other night
column2: the Democrats seemed to be back in the 1990s. They don't seem to have gotten beyond the Cold War. Iran is a threat
column3: a nuclear threat
column4: not just because they can deliver a nuclear warhead with missiles. They're a nuclear threat because they are the biggest state sponsor of terrorism and they can hand nuclear materials to terrorists.

column1: And we just saw it just last week in New York
column2: an attempt by Islamist terrorists to attack JFK airport; three weeks ago
column3: an attempt to attack Fort Dix.

column1: These are real problems. This war is not a bumper sticker. This war is a real war.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Let me bring Governor Gilmore in.
What do you say about the potential use of tactical nuclear weapons if that's what it takes to go deep underground and destroy those Iraqi facilities?
GILMORE: One of the central problems of the Middle East is the desire for Iran to dominate that portion of the world
column2: because of what they are doing. And that is why I believe that they are seeking this kind of nuclear capacity. That is one of the reasons why we are
column3: in fact
column4: in Iraq.

column1: And that's why our soldiers
column2: when they fight and die there
column3: are in fact serving the interests of the United States. Nobody ought to have any doubt about that.

column1: With respect to Iran
column2: the policy I would follow would be dual.

column1: Number one
column2: we need to work with our European allies in order to put in appropriate sanctions. We need to communicate directly with the Iranians that we are going to offer them an opportunity to work with us.

column1: But we are also going to say that having a nuclear weapon is unacceptable; they need to understand it. And all options are on the table by the United States in that instance.
BLITZER: All right. Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: Governor Romney
column2: I want to get you on the record. Do you agree with the mayor
column3: the governor
column4: others here
column5: that the use of tactical nuclear weapons
column6: potentially
column7: would be possible if that were the only way to stop Iran from developing a nuclear bomb?

column1: ROMNEY: You don't take options off the table
column2: but what you do is stand back and say
column3: ""What's going on here?"" You see what's happening in Sudan and Afghanistan
column4: in Iraq and Iran. All over the world
column5: we're seeing the same thing happening
column6: and that is people are testing the United States of America. And we have to make sure they understand that we're not arrogant; we have resolve. And we have the strength to protect our interests and to protect people who love liberty.

column1: For that to happen
column2: we're going to have to not just attack each one of these problems one by one
column3: but say
column4: how do we help move the world of Islam so that the moderate Muslims can reject the extreme?

column1: And for that to happen
column2: we're going to have to have a strong military and an effort to combine with our allies in such a way
column3: we combine for an effort to help move Islam toward modernity.

column1: That's what we're going to have to do
column2: instead of looking at each theater one by one and saying
column3: ""We'll bomb here
column4: we'll attack here
column5: we'll go to Sudan.""

column1: I watched the Democrats...
BLITZER: Thank you.
ROMNEY: ... they don't think there's a war on terror.
BLITZER: Thank you.
ROMNEY: There's a war going on
column2: and we need a broad response to make sure that these people have a different vision.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: All of you are going to have an opportunity to weigh on all of these questions as well.
If you're hearing some sounds out there
column2: it's lightning here in Manchester
column3: New Hampshire. Those are the crackling sounds that you're hearing.

column1: Let's go back to Scott.
SPRADLING: Thanks
column2: Wolf.

column1: Congressman Tancredo
column2: let's talk immigration.

column1: TANCREDO: OK.
SPRADLING: You oppose the immigration reform compromise
column2: calling it
column3: quote
column4: ""the worst piece of legislation to come down the pike in a long time."" Just this morning in Manchester
column5: you vowed to oust any senator who supports the bill
column6: including possibly New Hampshire's senior Senator Judd Gregg
column8: and says to your comments that you are part of the know-nothing wing of the political spectrum.

column1: In the meantime
column2: the president says his plan is the last best chance for serious immigration reform.

column1: He's criticized conservatives for being obstructionists.
With that tension at stake
column2: if this becomes law
column3: what are the consequences for the country?

column1: TANCREDO: They are incredible
column2: and they are disastrous.

column1: And that is exactly why I have said what I've said
column2: and that is why I have consistently tried to impress upon the American public the seriousness of this issue.

column1: We're not just talking about the number of jobs that we may be losing or the number of kids that are in our schools and impacting our school system or the number of people that are abusing our hospital system and taking advantage of the welfare system in this country. We're not just talking about that.
We're talking about something that goes to the very heart of this nation: whether or not we will actually survive as a nation.
And here's what I mean by that.
What we're doing here in this immigration battle is testing our willingness to actually hold together as a nation or split apart into a lot of balkanized pieces.
We are testing our willingness to actually hold on to something called the English language
column2: something that is the glue that is supposed to hold us together as a nation.

column1: We are becoming a bilingual nation. And that is not good.
And that is the fearful part of this. The ramifications are much
column2: much more significant than any that we've been discussing so far.

column1: And so
column2: yes
column3: I have said dramatic things. And
column4: yes
column5: I am willing to do whatever is necessary to try to stop this piece of legislation. And that includes go after any Republican that votes for it
column6: because the Republicans can stop this.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you. Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Mayor Giuliani
column2: what do you think the consequences for the nation are if this immigration plan proposed by President Bush goes through?

column1: GIULIANI: The problem with this immigration plan is it has no real unifying purpose. It's a typical Washington mess. It's everybody compromises -- four or five compromises.
And the compromises leave you with the following conclusion: The litmus test you should have for legislation is
column2: is it going to make things better? And when you look at these compromises
column3: it is quite possible it will make things worse. The organizing purpose should be that our immigration laws should allow us to identify everyone who is in this country that comes here from a foreign country.

column1: They should have a tamper-proof I.D. card. It should be in a database that allows you to figure out who they are
column2: why they're here
column3: make sure they're not illegal immigrants coming here for a bad purpose
column4: and then to be able to throw out the ones who are not in that database.

column1: We can do that. Credit card companies...
BLITZER: Thank you.
GIULIANI: ... take care of data that is greater than that.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: I want to get to Senator McCain in a moment
column2: but first
column3: Governor Romney
column4: Senator McCain has accused you of flip-flopping on this issue
column5: in effect.

column1: Yesterday in Miami
column2: he said the following: ""Pandering for votes on this issue while offering no solution to the problem amounts to doing nothing. And doing nothing is silent amnesty.""

column1: What do you say to Senator McCain?
ROMNEY: Well
column2: he's my friend. He campaigned for me two times. I consider him a friend. I'm not going to make this a matter of personal politics. It's an issue that's way too important for that.

column1: My view is that we should enforce our immigration laws.
And this bill
column2: unfortunately
column3: has at least one provision that's a real problem. It's the Z visa.

column1: And what it allows is people who have come here illegally to stay here for the rest of their lives -- not necessarily as citizens; they have to wait 13 years to become citizens. That's not the point.
The point is: Every illegal alien
column2: almost every one
column3: under this bill
column4: gets to stay here. That's not fair to the millions and millions of people around the world that would love to come here
column5: join with family members
column6: bring skill and education that we need.

column1: It's simply not fair to say those people get put ahead in the line of all the people who've been waiting legally to come to this country.
(APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: All right
column2: Senator McCain
column3: this is your chance. I'd like you to respond as someone who is the co-author of this legislation.

column1: MCCAIN: Well
column2: first of all
column3: I agree with Judd Gregg. He's a great senator.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Second of all
column2: Rudy
column3: you just described our legislation
column4: so I'd be glad to have further conversation with you
column5: because it does account for people who are here illegally.

column1: It does have an employment verification system. And it weeds out those who shouldn't be here
column2: and it gives others a chance to remain in this country.

column1: Look
column2: this is a national security issue
column3: first and foremost. Ever since 9/11
column4: it's a national security issue.

column1: People came to Fort Dix
column2: New Jersey
column3: from across our southern border and tried to kill our soldiers.

column1: For us to do nothing is silent and de facto amnesty.
What we have done is what you expect us to do
column2: my friends
column3: and that's come together with the president of the United States
column4: the leader of our party
column5: Democrat and Republican
column6: conservative Republicans like Jon Kyl
column8: Saxby Chambliss and Trent Lott
column9: and sit down and figure out an approach to this problem.

column1: And it is a serious national security problem.
We need to act
column2: my friends. And if someone else has a better idea
column3: I'd love to have them pursue -- give it to us.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
(APPLAUSE)
Hold on.
MCCAIN: That can get...
BLITZER: Senator...
(CROSSTALK)
AUDIENCE MEMBER: ... a better idea!
MCCAIN: That will get the support of enough people so that we can pass legislation.
This isn't the bill that I would have written
column2: but it does...

column1: BLITZER: All right. Thank you.
MCCAIN: ... it does satisfy our national security challenges
column2: which are severe and intense. And we cannot 12 million people washing around America illegally
column3: my friends. (CROSSTALK)

column1: MCCAIN: And I hope you'll examine the legislation.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: MCCAIN: And I hope we can move forward with it. And we can make it better.
BLITZER: All right.
MCCAIN: But it's our job to do the hard things...
BLITZER: Mayor
column2: go ahead.

column1: MCCAIN: ... not the easy things.
(APPLAUSE)
GIULIANI: I've read the 400 pages. And this is part of the problem in Washington: They say things and then it's not in the legislation.
There are four or five different methods of identification
column2: not one.

column1: It does not provide information about who exited the United States. Now
column2: tell me how you're going to figure out who's in the United States if you can't figure out who's left the United States.

column1: And finally
column2: it doesn't provide for a uniform database. Many countries have this. The United States doesn't have it.

column1: On September 11th
column2: when we tried to figure out who was in this country
column3: it took weeks to figure out who were the right people and who weren't
column4: because there isn't such a database. And that is a fatal flaw in this legislation. And wishing it away doesn't make it possible.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Governor Romney
column2: what would you do with the 12 million or so illegal immigrants who are
column3: right now
column4: in this country?

column1: ROMNEY: Well
column2: one is to enforce the law as it exists. The law that was passed in 1986...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
The law passed in 1986 asked for us to secure the border and said also to put in place an employment verification system.
Neither one of those was done. So let's make sure that we enforce the law as it exists.
And if you want to improve this bill
column2: well
column3: one thing you could do to make it better is to take that Z visa and make it temporary instead of a permanent right to stay in America. That's simply just not fair.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: I want to stay on immigration. Everybody's going to have a chance to weigh in. But let's go back to Tom for another question on immigration.
FAHEY: Congressman Hunter
column2: whether we like it or not
column3: in cities across America
column4: counties across America
column5: including your district in San Diego
column6: illegal immigrants are doing jobs that American citizens don't want
column8: in hotels

column1: If you have your way and they all leave this country
column2: who's going to fill those jobs?

column1: HUNTER: Well
column2: first
column3: I disagree with that premise
column4: because when they made the sweep on the Swift plants -- those were the meat- packaging plants in Iowa; took out some 850 people who were working there illegally several months ago -- there were American citizens lined up the next day to get their jobs back at 18 bucks an hour.

column1: And let me tell you
column2: this is a disastrous bill. And John McCain is right in saying that this is a national security issue. And it is: border enforcement.

column1: Then the Hunter bill
column2: which was signed by the president on the 26th of October
column3: mandating 854 miles of double fence -- not that scraggly
column4: little fence you show on CNN all the time
column5: Wolf
column6: that people get across so easily.

column1: If they get across my fence
column2: we sign them up for the Olympics immediately.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
We've got a big fence.
But 854 miles of double border fence was mandated to be constructed. Homeland Security has a billion bucks
column2: cash on hand. It's been six months
column3: and they've done 11 miles.

column1: So this administration has a case of the slows. And I think they slowed the fence down so that they could come out with the amnesty at the same time
column2: put the two together
column3: and the Bush-McCain-Kennedy bill would then be accepted by conservatives and liberals alike.

column1: It's a bad bill.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Senator Brownback
column2: what do you say about this notion of a pathway toward citizenship for these 12 million illegal immigrants who are in the country right now? Under what circumstances would you let them begin that path?

column1: BROWNBACK: I don't think you create any new paths to citizenship. But I also think you allow them to be able to use paths that they would currently qualify for
column2: and to be able to get in the back of the line. And that's part of leadership and getting something resolved.

column1: I think
column2: you know
column3: we can go on a lot of slogans here. And I've been around this issue for a while. I was in Congress in 1994
column4: elected then. We did the first immigration bill I was involved in then in 1996.

column1: You know what? That was an enforcement-only bill in 1996. And we had 7 million undocumented here in the country then. We're at 12 million to 20 million now.
The point of saying that -- and my colleagues and people up here
column2: everybody is concerned that we get something done and get something right.

column1: I think if you do exterior enforcement
column2: border enforcement
column3: you do aggressive interior enforcement
column4: and then you work on a comprehensive solution interior
column5: that's something that a lot of people are going to be upset with but that can work and move us forward. And it's better than not doing anything.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you. So you support this pending compromise legislation?
BROWNBACK: If we can hold together those things in it. Those things have to be in it.
BLITZER: You're with Senator McCain.
BROWNBACK: If those things are in it.
BLITZER: What about you
column2: Governor Thompson?

column1: THOMPSON: Wolf
column2: the first thing you have to do is you've got to secure the border. Securing the border is going to allow everything else to follow.

column1: But unless you secure the border
column2: it is not right to give 12 million individuals who have illegal rights in this country status before that border is protected.

column1: There should be no amnesty. And this bill
column2: no matter how you cover it
column3: is an amnesty bill.

column1: And the people in this country do not believe in that bill. And they believe very much that the best hope for us to have a secure border
column2: just like Congressman Hunter has been talking about and every other Republican up here.

column1: Have a secure border
column2: then move on. But don't do it the other way. BLITZER: Thank you
column3: Governor.

column1: Congressman Paul
column2: I want you to weigh in on this as well. I believe -- and correct me if I'm wrong -- you voted to support that 700-mile fence along the border between the United States and Mexico. Did you?

column1: PAUL: I did.
BLITZER: What about Canada? Is there a need for a similar fence along the border between...
PAUL: No.
BLITZER: ... the United States and Canada?
PAUL: No
column2: because that bill -- probably the fence was my weakest reason for doing that
column3: but for other reasons
column4: to enforce the law was important. And border security is important.

column1: And we talked about amnesty
