column2: which I'm positively opposed to.

column1: But one thing that has not been mentioned here
column2: which I think is very
column3: very important: If you subsidize something
column4: you get more of it. So we subsidize illegal immigration. We reward it by easy citizenship
column5: either birthright or amnesty. But we force our states and our local communities to pay for the health care
column6: to pay for the education. Why wouldn't they bring their families?

column1: And because of our economic conditions
column2: we do need workers. But if we had a truly free-market economy
column3: the illegal immigrants would not be the scapegoat. We would probably need them
column4: and they would be acceptable. But because of economic conditions
column5: they have become the scapegoat.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: The other night
column2: Sunday night
column3: I asked the eight Democratic presidential candidates whether or not they thought English should be the official language of the United States. Only one of them said English should be the official language of the United States.

column1: If there's someone here who doesn't believe English should be the official language of the United States
column2: please speak up right now.

column1: MCCAIN: I think it's fine.
I would like to remind you that we made treaties with Native Americans such as the Navajos in my state
column2: where we respect their sovereignty and they use their native language in their deliberations. It's not a big deal. But Native Americans are important to me in my state.

column1: Everybody knows that English has to be learned if anyone ever wants to move up the economic ladder. That is obvious.
And part of our legislation
column2: by the way
column3: is a requirement to learn English.

column1: And by the way
column2: 30 percent of the people who are in this country illegally never came across our borders
column3: my friends. They overstayed their visas. That's why it has to be a comprehensive approach.

column1: And I'm proud of the support of the president and his brother
column2: Governor Jeb Bush
column3: who was governor of the state of Florida. People who have to deal with this issue every day understand we have to act
column4: my friends.

column1: And we can have our own ways to improve it. But if we don't address this issue
column2: we are going to pay a heavy price. Because something bad could happen when 12 million people are in this country illegally
column3: 2 million of them having committed serious crimes.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: I see people raising their hands.
But the question was
column2: I'd only like those to speak up who believe that English should not necessarily be the official language of the United States.

column1: Is there anyone else who stands with Senator McCain specifically on that question?
All right. We're going to go back to Scott.
Go ahead
column2: Scott.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
BLITZER: Scott
column2: go ahead.

column1: HUNTER: Wolf
column2: if I've got -- if I have reservations in my district
column3: can I speak up also?

column1: BLITZER: You'll have an opportunity.
Go ahead
column2: Scott.

column1: SPRADLING: OK. This question's for Governor Gilmore.
Conservative credentials is the topic
column2: sir. You've gotten a lot of mileage out of lumping Messrs. Giuliani
column3: McCain and Romney together by calling them Rudy McRomney.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
Now
column2: with former Senator Fred Thompson likely to join you at the next debate
column3: in your opinion
column4: is he conservative enough for America or are we changing the name now to Rudy McRomneyson?

column1: (LAUGHTER)
GILMORE: Well
column2: we've gotten a little mileage out of Rudy McRomney. I know the mayor one time said that it would make a good ticket
column3: and it would. But it isn't a conservative ticket. And we don't know what Fred Thompson is either.

column1: I think he's a fine man. He served in the Senate a term and a half. Let's see exactly what his views are.
I'm coming forward and offering my views as a 40-year battler for conservative values and conservative principles on behalf of the people of the United States.

And I have the record to back it up. I've been a prosecutor. I've been an attorney general. I've been a governor. I governed as a conservative. I cut taxes for the people of the Commonwealth of Virginia. I've stood by these principles for years and years.
The question is that when Fred Thompson comes into the race
column2: as I believe he will -- and maybe even Speaker Gingrich may come into the race. They'll have to stand on their records and stand on their credentials and offer their ideas the same way that every person here on the stage is doing.

column1: I look forward to that day
column2: and I look forward to the debate.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: Governor Thompson
column2: is there a need for another Thompson in this race?

column1: (LAUGHTER)

THOMPSON: I think that anybody with a Thompson name should get involved if they want to get involved. It's a great name. He's a great candidate. And I think it will help the Republican Party to have him in.

I just would like to say that if you're talking about conservatism -- and that's what you're talking about -- there isn't a candidate on either side of the aisle that has had as many vetoes as I have.
Nobody has reduced taxes as much as I have.
And if you're talking about a reliable conservative
column2: it is this Thompson
column3: Tommy Thompson
column4: not the other
column5: that's the conservative.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor. Thank you
column3: Governor.

column1: Mayor Giuliani
column2: there was some news here today. A Catholic bishop in Rhode Island said some words about your position on abortion
column3: suggesting that it was similar to Pontius Pilate's personal opposition to Jesus Christ's crucifixion
column4: but allowing it to happen anyway. How does that make you feel when you hear words like that from a Catholic bishop?

column1: GIULIANI: Well
column2: Catholic bishop -- any religion (inaudible).

column1: BLITZER: That's the lightning that's having an effect on our system.
GIULIANI: I know.
(LAUGHTER)
I guess I'm here by myself.
Look
column2: for someone who went to parochial schools all his life
column3: this is a very frightening thing that's happening right now.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
But the reality is I respect
column2: you know
column3: the opinion of Catholic (inaudible) and religious leaders of all kinds. Religion is very important to me. It's a very important part of my life.

column1: But ultimately
column2: as (inaudible) been in public life most of my life and taken oaths of office to enforce the law
column3: I've got to make the decisions that I think are the right ones in a country like ours.

column1: And my view on abortion is that it's wrong
column2: but that ultimately government should not be enforcing that decision on a woman.

column1: That is my view that I -- I consult my religion. I consult my reading of the Constitution. I consult my views of what I think are important in a pluralistic society
column2: and the reality that we have to respect the fact that there are people that are equally as religious
column3: equally as moral
column4: that make a different decision about this
column5: and should government put them in jail?

column1: BLITZER: You made
column2: Governor Romney
column3: this decision on abortion
column4: opposing abortion
column5: relatively recently.

column1: Why should conservatives out there
column2: people who oppose abortion
column3: believe you?

column1: ROMNEY: Well
column2: people can look at my record. I'm not going to apologize for the fact that I became pro-life. I served as governor. As I was governor
column3: as we were debating cloning and as we were debating also embryo farming
column4: I said Roe v. Wade has gone too far.

column1: I want to make it very clear that I'm pro-life. People here in New Hampshire have seen that I fought for life. I fought also for traditional marriage
column2: to keep taxes down
column3: to have education in our schools that includes abstinence education. I've fought for English immersion in our schools.

column1: They know that I've got conservative credentials. And that's one of the things that brings me to this race.
But there's something bigger in conservatism that I don't think we've spoken about. And that is that America is a land of opportunity. And our future is going to be far brighter than our past
column2: not just as we overcome these challenges
column3: but as we take advantage of the new opportunity of the 21st century.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you very much
column2: Governor.

column1: Let's go back to Tom for the next question.
(APPLAUSE)
FAHEY: (inaudible) do not believe in evolution. You're an ordained minister. What do you believe? Is it the story of creation
column2: as it is reported in the Bible or described in the Bible?

column1: HUCKABEE: It's interesting that that question would even be asked of somebody running for president. I'm not planning on writing the curriculum for an 8th-grade science book. I'm asking for the opportunity to be president of the United States.
But you've raised the question
column2: so let me answer it.

column1: In the beginning
column2: God created the heavens and the Earth. To me
column3: it's pretty simple. A person either believes that God created this process or believes that it was an accident and that it just happened all on its own.

column1: And the basic question was an unfair question
column2: because it simply asked us in a simplistic manner whether or not we believed
column3: in my view
column4: whether there is a God or not.

column1: Well
column2: let me be very clear: I believe there is a God. I believe there's a God who was active in the creation process.

column1: Now
column2: how did he do it and when did he do it and how long did he take
column3: I don't honestly know. And I don't think knowing that would make me a better or a worse president.

column1: But I'll tell you what I can tell this country: If they want a president who doesn't believe in God
column2: there's probably plenty of choices. But if I'm selected as president of this country
column3: they'll have one who believes in those words that God did create.

column1: And as the words of Martin Luther
column2: here I stand. I can do no other. And I will not take that back.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Governor
column2: but I think the specific question is
column3: do you believe literally it was done in six days and it occurred 6
column4: 000 years ago?

column1: HUCKABEE: No
column2: I did answer that
column3: Wolf. I said
column4: I don't know.

column1: My point is
column2: I don't know. I wasn't there.

column1: (LAUGHTER) But I believe
column2: whether God did it in six days or whether he did it in six days that represented periods of time
column3: he did it. And that's what's important.

column1: But
column2: you know
column3: if anybody wants to believe that they are the descendants of a primate
column4: they are certainly welcome to do it. I don't know how far they will march that back.

column1: But I believe that all of us in this room are the unique creations of a god who knows us and loves us
column2: and who created us for his own purpose.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Senator Brownback
column2: you recently elaborated on your position on this
column3: and I wonder if you'd want to spend 30 seconds and tell our audience out there where you stand on the issue of evolution.

column1: BROWNBACK: I'd be happy to.
And it's interesting that we're doing this here at St. Anselm's
column2: who this -- that saint had a philosophy of faith seeking reason.

column1: And that's the issue that's missing here
column2: if I could highlight that point
column3: is that I believe that we are created in the image of God for a particular purpose. And I believe that with all my heart.

column1: And I'm somebody
column2: I've had cancer in the past
column3: I've had a season to really look at this and study it and think about the end of life. And I am fully convinced there's a god of the universe that loves us very much and was involved in the process.

column1: How he did it
column2: I don't know.

column1: One of the problems we have with our society today is that we've put faith and science at odds with each other. They aren't at odds with each other. If they are
column2: check your faith or check your science
column3: and we should have a discussion.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you.
BROWNBACK: And we should engage faith and reason like St. Anselm did.
BLITZER: Thank you.
BROWNBACK: That's something we should do.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator Brownback.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Senator McCain
column2: do you believe creationism should be taught alongside evolution in the nation's schools?

column1: MCCAIN: No
column2: I believe that that's up to the school districts. But I think that every American should be exposed to all theories.

column1: But I can't say it more eloquently than Pastor Huckabee -- Governor Huckabee just did. And I admire his description because I hold that view.
The point is that the time before time
column2: there's no doubt in my mind that the hand of God was in what we are today. And I do believe that we are unique
column3: and I believe that God loves us. But I also believe that all of our children in school can be taught different views on different issues.

column1: But I leave the curricula up to the school boards.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator
column3: for that.

column1: Governor Romney
column2: there was a recent poll here in New Hampshire.

column1: Ten percent said they wouldn't vote for you because you're a Mormon. And last week
column2: we saw that picture of that man who refused to shake your hand because you are a Mormon.

column1: What would you like to say to the voters out there tonight about your faith
column2: about yourself and about God?

column1: ROMNEY: Well
column2: President Kennedy some time ago said he was not a Catholic running for president
column3: he was an American running for president. And I'm happy to be a proud member of my faith.

column1: You know
column2: I think it's a fair question for people to ask
column3: what do you believe? And I think if you want to understand what I believe
column4: you could recognize that the values that I have are the same values you'll find in faiths across this country.

column1: I believe in God
column2: believe in the Bible
column3: believe Jesus Christ is my savior. I believe that God created man in his image. I believe that the freedoms of man derive from inalienable rights that were given to us by God.

column1: And I also believe that there are some pundits out there that are hoping that I'll distance myself from my church so that that'll help me politically. And that's not going to happen.
(APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor
column3: for that.

column1: Congressman Paul
column2: you ran for president once before as a libertarian. What do you say about this whole issue of church and state and these issues that are coming forward right now?

column1: PAUL: Well
column2: I think we should read the First Amendment
column3: where it says
column4: ""Congress shall write no law
column5: and we should write a lot less laws regarding this matter. It shouldn't be a matter of the president or the Congress. It should be local people
column6: local officials.

column1: The state should determine so many of these things that we just don't need more laws determining religious things or prayer in schools. We should allow people at the local level. That's what the Constitution tells us.
We don't need somebody in Washington telling us what we can do
column2: because we don't have perfect knowledge. And that's the magnificence of our Constitution and our republic. We sort out the difficult problems at local levels
column3: and we don't have
column4: you know
column5: one-case-fit- all.

column1: Because you have a Supreme Court ruling
column2: like on Roe v. Wade
column3: it ruined it for the whole country. And that's why we shouldn't have it at a central level.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Let's go back to another question from Tom.
FAHEY: This is for Mayor Giuliani.

Sea levels around the world are rising. Average temperatures are increasing. A U.N. report written by scientists from 113 countries recently said that climate change is very likely man-made and may affect us for centuries to come.
Is science wrong on global warming? And what
column2: if any
column3: steps would you take as president to address the issue of climate change?

column1: GIULIANI: I think we have to accept the view that scientists have
column2: that there is global warming
column3: and that human operation
column4: human condition contributes to that.

column1: And the fact is that there is a way to deal with it and to address it in a way that we can also accomplish energy independence
column2: which we need as a matter of national security.

column1: It's frustrating and really dangerous for us to see money going to our enemies because we have to buy oil from certain countries. We should be supporting all the alternatives.

We need a project similar to putting a man on the moon. That project started with Eisenhower. It was carried out by Kennedy and then Johnson and then Nixon. And that was two Democrats and two Republicans working (inaudible) Democrats working in the national interest.
BLITZER: Thank you. Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: I want Governor Romney to weigh in as well.
There's a perception
column2: at least among some
column3: that Republicans are -- at least the Republican Party -- very close to big oil. A lot of Americans are suffering now from the price of gasoline -- high price of gasoline. What do you say to the audience out there who believes that there's too much of an alliance
column4: if you will
column5: between the big oil companies and Republicans?

column1: ROMNEY: Well
column2: first of all
column3: Rudy Giuliani is right
column4: in terms of an Apollo project to get us to energy independent. And the effects of that on global warming are positive. It's a no-regrets policy. It's a great idea.

column1: Secondly
column2: with regards to big oil
column3: big oil is making a lot of money right now. And I'd like to see them using that money to invest in refineries.

column1: Don't forget that when companies earn profit
column2: that money's supposed to be reinvested in growth. And our refineries are old.

column1: Someone said to me -- Matt Simmons
column2: an investment banker down in Houston -- he said
column3: ""Our refineries today are rust
column4: with paint holding them up.""

column1: And we need to see these companies
column2: if they're making that kind of money
column3: reinvest in capital equipment.

column1: But let's not forget that where the money is being made this year is not just -- and throughout these years -- is not just in Exxon and Shell and the major oil companies. It's in the countries that own this oil.
Russia last year took in $500 billion by selling oil. Ahmadinejad
column2: Putin
column3: Chavez -- these people are getting rich off of people buying too much oil.

column1: And that's why we have to pursue
column2: as a strategic imperative
column3: energy independence for America.

column1: And it takes that Apollo project. It also takes biodiesel
column2: biofuel
column3: ethanol...

column1: BLITZER: Thank you.
ROMNEY: ... cellulosic ethanol
column2: nuclear power
column3: more drilling in ANWR.

column1: We have to be serious also about efficiency.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: ROMNEY: And that's going to allow us to become energy- independent.
BLITZER: Senator McCain
column2: do you have a problem at this time with these oil companies making these huge profits?

column1: MCCAIN: Sure. I think we all do. And they ought to be reinvesting it. And one of the areas that they ought to be involved in is nuclear power. Nuclear power is safe. Nuclear power is green
column2: does not emit greenhouse gases. Nuclear power is used on Navy ships which have sailed around the world for 60 years without an accident.

column1: And of course we ought to be investing in alternate energy sources.
Recently there was a group of retired military officers who said that climate change and energy independence is a national security issue. It is. We've got to reduce our dependence on imported oil.

We can do it through a wide variety of alternative fuels. But we have to be serious about it and we're going to have to go to places where we have never gone before. And nuclear power is one of the major issues
column2: but also all kinds of ethanol as well.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: Let me bring Congressman Paul back into this conversation.

column2: President Bush signed an energy bill that provided billions of dollars in tax break subsidies to the oil companies
column3: with the goal of boosting domestic production. At a time of these record profits
column4: do you believe these companies need a helping hand from the federal government?

column1: PAUL: I don't think the profits is the issue. The profits are OK if they're legitimately earned in a free market. What I object to are subsidies to big corporations when we subsidize them and give them R&D money. I don't think that should be that way. They should take it out of the funds that they earn.
But also
column2: you can't discuss energy without discussing our foreign policy.

column1: Why do we go to the Middle East? We know the oil is very important about the Middle East and why we're there. Why did we
column2: our government
column3: help overthrow Mosaddeq in 1953? It had to do with oil.

column1: So
column2: our foreign policy is designed to protect our oil interests.

column1: The profits
column2: that's not the problem. It's the problem that we succumb to the temptation to protect oil interests by literally going out and fighting wars over oil.

column1: BLITZER: Governor Gilmore
column2: you agree?

column1: GILMORE: I agree that if you make profits of the open marketplace
column2: that that's an appropriate thing to do. I also believe that they should be going in and putting this additional money into additional drilling
column3: into additional exploration.

column1: But it's going to have to be bigger than that. We're going to have to in fact look to all sources: ethanol
column2: biomass
column3: coal
column4: clean coal
column5: the opportunities for natural gas
column6: and nuclear power. And by the way
column7: nuclear power will help this whole issue of global warming.

column1: And one more point in direct answer to your question: The Kyoto treaty was
column2: in fact
column3: fatally flawed. That was a treaty that in fact was going to basically just transfer our money directly to Russia for nothing
column4: because they were going to get credits because simply that their economy had declined.

column1: The truth is
column2: we're going to have to get a program in place
column3: an international diplomatic answer
column4: that is going to include every nation of the world in this entire project. And that includes China and India.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: Let me bring Scott back for the next question.
SPRADLING: Congressman Paul
column2: a question for you.

column1: Most of our closest allies
column2: including Great Britain and Israel
column3: allow gays and lesbians to openly serve in the military. Is it time to end don't ask/don't tell policy and allow gays and lesbians to serve openly in the U.S. military?

column1: PAUL: I think the current policy is a decent policy.
And the problem that we have with dealing with this subject is we see people as groups
column2: as they belong to certain groups and that they derive their rights as belonging to groups.

column1: We don't get our rights because we're gays or women or minorities. We get our rights from our creator as individuals. So every individual should be treated the same way.
So if there is homosexual behavior in the military that is disruptive
column2: it should be dealt with.

column1: But if there's heterosexual sexual behavior that is disruptive
column2: it should be dealt with.

column1: So it isn't the issue of homosexuality. It's the concept and the understanding of individual rights. If we understood that
column2: we would not be dealing with this very important problem.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Governor Huckabee
column2: I want you to weigh in as well.

column1: Do you believe it's time to allow homosexuals to serve openly in the United States military?
HUCKABEE: Wolf
column2: I think it's already covered by the Uniform Code of Military Conduct. I think that's what Congressman Paul was saying: It's about conduct; it's not about attitude.

column1: But I'd like to ask you. You said a moment ago that you were going to all give us a chance to deal with the issue of immigration.
BLITZER: We're going to come back to that.
HUCKABEE: And I hope you'll do that.
BLITZER: We will. We'll come back to immigration.
HUCKABEE: You held us to it
column2: and now I want to hold you to it
column3: so...

column1: BLITZER: We're going to come back...
HUCKABEE: ... if you could give us that opportunity.
BLITZER: We're going to come back to immigration.
But right now
column2: we're talking about allowing gays to serve openly in the military. But you're opposed to that?

column1: HUCKABEE: I just said I think it's a matter -- it's not -- you don't punish people for their attitudes; you punish them if their behavior creates a problem. And it's already covered by the Uniform Code of Military Conduct.
BLITZER: So you wouldn't change existing policy.
HUCKABEE: What?
BLITZER: You wouldn't change existing policy.
HUCKABEE: I don't think that I would. I think it's already covered by the existing policy that we do have
column2: in fact.

column1: BLITZER: Mayor Giuliani
column2: recently we've learned that several talented trained linguists -- Arabic speakers
column3: Farsi speakers
column4: Urdu speakers -- trained by the U.S. government to learn those languages to help us in the war on terrorism
column5: were dismissed from the military because they announced they were gays or lesbians.

column1: Is that
column2: in your mind
column3: appropriate?

column1: GIULIANI: This is not the time to deal with disruptive issues like this.
Back in 1994 we went through this. And it created a tremendous amount of disruption. Colin Powell
column2: I think
column3: was still the head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff before he left at the beginning of the Clinton administration.

column1: He came to the view that this was a good policy.
And I think in time of war
column2: in a time where we're trying to deal with this transition to a new kind of warfare that we have to be fighting -- and we haven't gotten all the way there yet. We need a hybrid army
column3: we need to look at nation-building as part of what we have to teach our military. I don't think this would be the right time to raise these issues.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you.
GIULIANI: And I think we should rely on the judgment of our commanders in a situation like this. They know what's disruptive and what's not. And at a time of war
column2: you don't make fundamental changes like this.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: Governor Romney
column2: the mayor referred to the don't ask/don't tell policy
column3: which was implemented during the Clinton administration
column4: after Bill Clinton became president.

column2: you were quoted as saying that you advocated gays being able to serve openly and honestly in our nation's military.

column1: The question to you is
column2: do you still feel that way?

column1: ROMNEY: No
column2: actually when I first heard of the don't ask/don't tell policy I thought it sounded awfully silly and didn't think that'd be very effective
column3: and I turned out to be wrong.

column1: It's been the policy now in the military for
column2: what
column4: 15 years? And it seems to be working.

column1: And I agree with what Mayor Giuliani said
column2: that this is not the time to put in place a major change
column3: a social experiment
column4: in the middle of a war going on.

column1: I wouldn't change it at this point. We can look at it down the road. But it does seem to me that we have much bigger issues as a nation that we ought to be talking about than that policy right now.
BLITZER: Senator McCain
column2: you've been involved in military matters virtually your whole life. What do you say?

column1: MCCAIN: We have the best-trained
column2: most professional
column3: best- equipped
column4: most efficient
column5: most wonderful military in the history of this country. And I'm proud of every one of them.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
There just aren't enough of them. So I have to rely on our military leadership
column2: in whom we place the responsibility to lead these brave young Americans in combat as we speak.

column1: So I think it would be a terrific mistake to even reopen the issue. It is working
column2: my friends. The policy is working.

column1: And I am convinced that that's the way we can maintain this greatest military. As much as I revere the greatest generation
column2: as much as I love my own generation
column3: this is the very best. Let's not tamper with them.

column1: BLITZER: Is there anyone here who believes gays and lesbians should be allowed to serve openly in the United States military?
If you do
column2: speak up now.

column1: Scott
column2: go ahead with your question.

column1: SPRADLING: Gentlemen
column2: last night
column3: we asked Democrats
column4: if they were elected
column5: what role would they use former President Clinton? I'm not going to ask you that.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
But
column2: Governor Thompson
column3: I'd like to know
column4: seeing as how you were a member of President Bush's Cabinet as health and human services secretary
column5: how would you use George W. Bush in your administration?

column1: THOMPSON: I certainly would not send him to the United Nations.
(LAUGHTER)
I believe George W. Bush has tremendous characteristics. He's very honest. He's very straightforward.
I would put him out on a lecture series
column2: talking to the youth of America about honesty
column3: integrity
column4: perseverance
column5: passion
column6: and serving the public.

column1: George W. Bush believes very much in public service
column2: as does his father
column3: as does his brothers
column4: as does his mother.

column1: I think he could be a wonderful spokesperson
column2: making sure that young people realize that public service is a very noble cause and something that young people should aspire to
column3: like all the young people here on this campus should also have the opportunity to serve in public life.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Senator Brownback
column2: same question to you: If you're elected president
column3: what would you ask your predecessor to do?

column1: BROWNBACK: Well
column2: I would talk with him about it first
column3: and I would ask him about it. I think he would probably take a position the way his dad did
column4: saying
column5: ""You know
column6: I think you need to have your time in the limelight. And I will be willing to help out if you have a tragedy overseas.""

column1: His father has been excellent
column2: in the tsunami that hit Sri Lanka and other places
column3: in helping fund-raising.

column1: He's been a wonderful ambassador in those sorts of situations.
And frankly
column2: I think that's the right role for an ex-president. And I really think
column3: in many respects
column4: President Clinton has not assumed the right role of an ex-president
column5: where he's injected himself a lot more on policy issues that haven't been appropriate
column6: and he really should defer more to the person that's in the job.

column1: There's one person that's president at a time
column2: and that's the way it should be.

column1: BLITZER: Congressman Tancredo
column2: I see you anxious to weigh in.

column1: TANCREDO: Thank you.
Some time ago
column2: in 2003 I think it was
column3: that I got a call from Karl Rove
column4: who told me that
column5: because of my criticism of the president
column6: I should never darken the doorstep of the White House.

column1: I have been so disappointed in the president in so many ways since his -- actually for the last several years
column2: not just the immigration issue
column3: but several other things
column4: including the No Child Left Behind and the massive increase in government that we call prescription drug -- Medicare prescription drug
column5: that I'm afraid I would have to tell the president of the United States -- I mean
column6: as president
column7: I would have to tell George Bush exactly the same thing Karl Rove told me.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: Governor Huckabee...
(APPLAUSE)
... you served
column2: as you reminded us
column3: a long time as a governor
column4: Republican governor of Arkansas. Your old job is now in Democratic hands. Here in New Hampshire
column5: the GOP has suffered some significant losses as well. And the Republicans lost the majority in the House and the Senate
column6: as you well know.

column1: Simple question: What's happened to the GOP?
HUCKABEE: Lost credibility
column2: because we didn't do what we were hired to do.

column1: When you're elected
column2: you're hired to do a job. You're hired to cut spending
column3: lower taxes
column4: bring more government back to the local people. We did the polar opposite. And the people fired us.

column1: And I think
column2: in many ways
column3: though there were some good people that got caught up in the tsunami of the 2006 elections
column4: the Republican Party
column5: as a whole
column6: deserved to get beat.

column1: We've lost credibility
column2: the way we bungled Katrina
column3: the fact that there was corruption that was unchecked in Washington
column4: and the fact that there was a feeling that there was not a proper handling of the Iraqi war in all of its details
column5: and the indifference to people pouring over our borders.

column1: And let me just add this
column2: Wolf. There are a lot of people for whom the immigration issue is like a lot of them. They see Washington not taking the kind of positions to build a fence
column3: and they know that when they go to the airport to get on an airplane
column4: they have to show photo I.D.
column5: they have to go through layers of security
column6: and they don't understand why someone across an international border doesn't have to do the same thing.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you. Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Congressman Hunter
column2: I want to just -- because he raised the issue -- he raised the issue of corruption.

column1: Do you think it would be appropriate for President Bush to pardon Lewis ""Scooter"" Libby
column2: who was sentenced today to 30 months in prison for his role in the CIA leak case?

column1: HUNTER: You know
column2: I think
column3: Wolf
column4: to make a determination on that
column5: you'd have to look at the transcript.

column1: I'll tell you a couple of transcripts I have looked at
column2: and that's the agents
column3: Compean and Ramos
column4: who were given 11 and 12 years respectively for stopping a drug dealer bringing 750 pounds of drugs across the border.

column1: I've looked at their transcript; I would pardon Compean and Ramos right now.
(APPLAUSE)
And let me say
column2: with respect to what Mike said
column3: we've got to bring back the Reagan Democrats to this party
column4: because we need the Reagan Democrats for Republican leadership to work.

column1: And we're going to have to get a good trade bill that brings jobs back to this country. We're going to have to stop China from cheating on trade
column2: build the middle class
column3: build jobs
column4: Wolf. That's what strengthens the Republican Party.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: I just want to do a quick ""yes"" or ""no."" And I'm going to go down the rest of the group and let everybody just tell me ""yes"" or ""no"": Would you pardon Scooter Libby?
(UNKNOWN): No.
GILMORE: No. I'm steeped in the law. I wouldn't do that.
BROWNBACK: No
column2: not without reading the transcript.

column1: HUCKABEE: Not without reading the transcript.
MCCAIN: He's going through an appeal process. We've got to see what happens here.
GIULIANI: I think the sentence was way out of line. I mean
column2: the sentence was grossly excessive in a situation in which
column3: at the beginning
column4: the prosecutor knew who the leak was...

column1: BLITZER: So
column2: yes or no
column3: would you pardon him?

column1: GIULIANI: ... and he knew a crime wasn't committed. I recommended over a thousand pardons to President Reagan when I was associate attorney general. I would see if it fit the criteria for pardon. I'd wait for the appeal.
I think what the judge did today argues more in favor of a pardon because...
BLITZER: Thank you.
GIULIANI: ... this is excessive punishment.
BLITZER: All right.
GIULIANI: When you consider -- I've prosecuted 5
column2: 000 cases.

column1: BLITZER: I'm trying to get a yes or no.
(LAUGHTER)
GIULIANI: Well
column2: this is a very important issue. This is a very
column3: very important -- a man's life is at stake. And the reality is
column4: this is an incomprehensible situation.

column1: They knew who the leak was.
ROMNEY: Hey
column2: Wolf
column3: can I explain...

column1: GIULIANI: And ultimately
column2: there was no underlying crime involved.

column1: BLITZER: All right.
ROMNEY: This is one of those situations where I go back to my record as governor. I didn't pardon anybody as governor
column2: because I didn't want to overturn a jury.

column1: But in this case
column2: you have a prosecutor who clearly abused prosecutorial discretion by going after somebody when he already knew that the source of the leak was Richard Armitage.

column1: He'd been told that. So he went on a political vendetta.
BLITZER: Was that a yes?
ROMNEY: It's worth looking at that. I will study it very closely if I'm lucky enough to be president. And I'd keep that option open.
BLITZER: Senator?
BROWNBACK: Yes. The basic crime here didn't happen. What they were saying was that the identity of an agent... BLITZER: All right.
Governor?
BROWNBACK: ... was revealed
column2: but that agent has to be in the field for that to be a crime. That didn't occur.

column1: BLITZER: Governor?
THOMPSON: Bill Clinton committed perjury at a grand jury
column2: lost his law license. Scooter Libby got 30 months. To me
column3: it's not fair at all.

column1: But I would make sure the appeal was done properly
column2: and then I would examine the record.

column1: BLITZER: Congressman?
TANCREDO: Yes.
BLITZER: Yes.
All right. We heard from all of them.
(APPLAUSE)
We're ready to take -- go into part two of tonight's debate right now
column2: where voters from New Hampshire will have an opportunity to ask their questions. We have some work to do here on the stage.

column1: While we move some chairs around
column2: move out the podiums
column3: while we do all that
column4: and you'll be able to see it
column5: viewers of WMUR are going to go back to their studios. For the rest of you
column6: I'm going to bring in my colleagues
column8: part of the best political team on television
column9: to give us a sense of this debate so far.

column1: Our debate here will resume in about three minutes.
(BREAK)
BLITZER: We're now set for our voters here to ask questions. Our pool of voters here are either registered Republicans or independents
column2: but they're likely -- likely to vote Republican in New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation primary.

column1: We brought them together with the help from the New Hampshire Political Library and the New Hampshire Institute of Politics. CNN producers have interviewed all of them. Working with me in this half of the debate is Jennifer Vaughn from our partner WMUR-TV.
Jennifer
column2: who has the first question?

column1: JENNIFER VAUGHN
column2: WMUR-TV: Thank you
column3: Wolf.

column1: And good evening to you all tonight. I have Erin Flanagan with me tonight.
Hi
column2: Erin.

column1: QUESTION: Hi
column2: Jennifer.

column1: VAUGHN: You live in Bedford
column2: New Hampshire.

column1: QUESTION: I do.
VAUGHN: You have a question about the war in Iraq
column2: which is something that is deeply personal to you.

column1: QUESTION: It is. Unfortunately
column2: my beloved little brother
column3: 1st Lieutenant Michael Joseph Cleary
column4: was killed in action in Taji
column5: Iraq
column6: eight days before he was to return home on December 20th of 2005.

column1: He was the best of the best and answered the call to serve our country.
My family has been devastated by the loss.
As a member of an American family who has suffered so greatly at the choices made by the current administration
column2: I desperately would like to know what you as commander in chief would do
column3: both in the halls of the American government
column4: to bring the parties together
column5: as well as on the desert sands of the Middle East to bring this conflict to a point in which we can safely bring our troops home.

column1: VAUGHN: Erin
column2: thank you.

column1: Congressman Hunter
column2: let's begin with you on that.

column1: HUNTER: OK. Absolutely.
The key to leaving -- and
column2: incidentally
column3: thank you for his service.

column1: And I want to let you know
column2: my son...

column1: (APPLAUSE)
I want to let you know that my son Duncan
column2: the day after 9/11
column3: joined the Marine Corps
column4: quit his job
column5: did two tours in Iraq. He's in Afghanistan right now.

column1: First
column2: I want you to know that it's worth it.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
What he did was worth it.
And if we can achieve a country in Iraq that will not be an state sponsor of terrorism for the next 5 to 10 to 20 years
column2: that will be a friend
column3: not an enemy
column4: of the United States
column5: and will have a modicum of freedom
column6: that is in the national interest of the United States
column7: just like establishing a free Japan on the other side of the Pacific was in our interest after World War II
column8: just like providing freedom and a protective shield for Salvador in Central America was in our interest.

column1: So what I would do
column2: and what we need to do right now
column3: and we are doing
column4: is standing up the Iraqi army. There is 129 battalions of Iraqis that we've trained and equipped.

column1: We need to start moving them into the combat zones where they displace the heavy American combat forces. Then we can pull our forces out. We can bring them home or send them wherever Uncle Sam needs them again.
BLITZER: Thank you.
HUNTER: That's how we leave Iraq the right way.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: Senator Brownback
column2: I'd like you to weigh in.

column1: BROWNBACK: If I could.
And thank you for your family's service and what your brother did. That's incredible and an incredible gift that he and your family have given us.
And I think you've identified the right thing. It's not about leaving
column2: and it's not about being defeated. It's about getting the situation to a point that we can turn it over to Iraqis
column3: and then us pull back from the front of the line.

column1: That's why I'm putting forward tomorrow a bill
column2: and this would be about a three-state solution in Iraq -- a Kurdish state
column3: a Sunni state
column4: a Shia state -- with Baghdad as the federal city
column5: in a loose
column6: weak
column7: federated system; oil revenues equally divided.

column1: And it's a bipartisan bill. We will have bipartisan support.
We've got to pull together here to win over there.
BLITZER: Senator...
BROWNBACK: And we can do this together
column2: but we haven't put yet forward
column3: this administration
column4: a political solution that will be long- term and durable.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you. Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: BROWNBACK: That's what we've got to do.
BLITZER: Senator McCain
column2: is that a good idea
column3: to divide up Iraq into three separate...

column1: BROWNBACK: It's not divided. It's three states
column2: one country.

column1: MCCAIN: It's not -- ma'am
column2: I want to tell you thank you for your brother's service and sacrifice to our country. We are proud of you and your endurance
column3: and we're proud of your sacrifice.

column1: This war -- I'm going to give you a little straight talk. This war was very badly mismanaged for a long time. And Americans have made great sacrifices
column2: some of which were unnecessary because of this management of the war -- mismanagement of this conflict.

column1: I believe we have a fine general. I believe we have a strategy which can succeed
column2: so that the sacrifice of your brother would not be in vain
column3: that a whole 20 million or 30 million people would have a chance to live a free life in an open society
column4: and practice their religion
column5: no matter what those differences are.

column1: And I believe that if we fail
column2: it will become a center of terrorism
column3: and we will ask more young Americans to sacrifice
column4: as your brother did.

column1: This is long and hard and tough. But I think we can succeed.
And God bless you.
(APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: Jennifer
column2: go ahead with your next question.

column1: VAUGHN: Cynthia Kiernan is here with us tonight.
Cynthia
column2: you live in Merrimack
column3: New Hampshire.

column1: QUESTION: Yes.
VAUGHN: You can go ahead and stand up.
And you brought your husband with you?
QUESTION: Yes. Michael served in Iraq.
And we have a question regarding the government in Iraq. Everyone's talking about
column2: ""Pull our troops out; pull our troops out."" Well
column3: considering they've lived under a dictatorship for the last 30 years or so
column4: what are we going to do to make sure they have a government in place before we do pull our troops out and they're able to help themselves? Otherwise
column5: we're just putting them in a position to accept another terrorist leader.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
VAUGHN: Congressman Paul?
PAUL: Well
column2: we've had four years to do this and it hasn't worked.

column1: The biggest incentive for them to take upon themselves the responsibility is just for us to leave.
PAUL: We don't need to lose 100 men and women every month
column2: more than a thousand per year.

column1: And so
column2: if you want it done
column3: you want them to take over
column4: you've got to give them an incentive.

column1: So I think we should immediately stop patrolling the streets. That's a policeman's job. It's not the work of the Army. We're not fighting a military battle. We're in a different type of warfare right now.
So the sooner we recognize that
column2: the sooner we can make sure that no more Americans will die.

column1: We have a lot of goodness in this country. And we should promote it
column2: but never through the barrel of a gun. We should do it by setting good standards
column3: motivating people and have them want to emulate us.

column1: But you can't enforce our goodness
column2: like the necons preach
column3: with an armed force. It doesn't work.

column1: Woodrow Wilson was telling us about that
column2: in promoting democracy a long time ago.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you.
PAUL: It doesn't work and we have to admit it.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Let me bring Mayor Giuliani in.
I don't know if you consider yourself a neocon
column2: but go ahead and respond to what Congressman Paul said.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
GIULIANI: Michael
column2: thank you very much for serving us
column3: and thank your family for their tremendous sacrifice.

column1: I'd like to put it in a slightly different context. I believe that your service for us and your brother's sacrifice is one of the reasons we're safe now in the United States.
I believe that this terrorist war began way back in the 1970s. They attacked us in 1993 in New York. They attacked us again in 2001 in a horrible way.
And I believe that what we're doing in Iraq
column2: if we can get it right
column3: is going to help reduce the risk for this country. And if we get it wrong
column4: this is going to be much
column5: much worse for us.

column1: And part of what we have to do and we haven't done right is take on that responsibility of nation-building. We created that responsibility for ourselves when we overthrew Saddam Hussein
column2: which we did very effectively. It was one of the greatest military actions in American history
column3: overthrowing Saddam Hussein.

column1: But we didn't accomplish the second step. People can only embrace democracy when they have an orderly existence. And we have to help provide that. We didn't want that role
column2: but it is our role.

column1: And we have to train our military to do it.
We should probably have an IraqStat program
column2: in which we measure how many people are going to school
column3: how many factories are open
column4: how many people are going back to work.

column1: We had to get into the nitty-gritty of putting an orderly society together in Iraq. It is not too late to do it.
And I'd just like to ask
column2: I'd just like to ask one question I didn't get to ask before
column3: when you said
column4: if General Petraeus comes back in September and reports that things aren't going well
column5: what are we going to do?

column1: But suppose General Petraeus comes back in September and reports that things are going pretty well. Are we going to report that with the same amount of attention that we would report the negative news?
(APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Jennifer
column2: go ahead.

column1: VAUGHN: Kysa Crusco is here with us tonight.
Hi
column2: Kysa.

column1: QUESTION: Hi.
VAUGHN: You live in Manchester
column2: New Hampshire. You are an attorney.

column1: QUESTION: I am.
VAUGHN: OK. What's your question tonight?
QUESTION: My question is whether you believe that a conservative platform can also include a conservationist agenda. And
column2: if so
column3: how?

column1: VAUGHN: Governor Gilmore?
GILMORE: The question was whether or not a conservative agenda can also have a conservation agenda. And I think that it can.
Certainly
column2: when I was governor of the state of Virginia
column3: we worked very hard in order to make Virginia a beautiful place and a place where we could in fact be welcoming to people
column4: and that it would be a nice community for people to visit.

column1: But at the end of the day
column2: this is going to come down to the question of whether or not conservatism can match up with energy independence
column3: which is a national security issue and it is a fundamental part of conservatism.

column1: Conservatism means empowering people. It means cutting taxes and controlling government spending. It also means national security. And national security means a lot of different elements right at this time. And we're discussing some of them tonight.
And I can assure the people who are families here tonight
column2: their young people
column3: young men and women who are on the battle lines
column4: and people who are committing their lives
column5: they are in fact serving the national interests of this country in a time of major crisis.

column1: The other two issues
column2: however
column3: would also go to the issue of the immigration issue
column4: which I want to come back to at some point
column5: but also energy independence.

column1: And energy independence also can serve the interests of conservation...
BLITZER: All right.
GILMORE: ... particularly if we use nuclear power and other clean forms of energy so that we can in fact make this a clean society that is also safe and secure for the nation.
BLITZER: Thank you very much
column2: Governor.

column1: Congressman Tancredo
column2: do you believe true conservatives should be doing more to protect the environment?

column1: TANCREDO: Yes.
I think that that's absolutely imperative
column2: and I think so because
column3: frankly
column4: you've got a conservative model to pick from. I mean
column5: you know
column6: Teddy Roosevelt
column8: put this stamp on that -- the whole issue of conserving the environment

column1: There's nothing anti-conservative about doing anything like that.
And you know what else you can do in order to foster that? You do it through conservative principles. You make it profitable for people to do exactly that
column2: to put -- to make conservation an issue that hits people in the pocketbook
column3: or they can profit by getting involved in conservation.

column1: That's one way the free market really works perfectly. We've seen it happen all over the world. We can see and we will put conservation to work -- conservation practices to work in the United States through conservative principles. We have a lock on that.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: Jennifer
column2: go ahead.

column1: VAUGHN: Good evening
column2: sir. You are Doug Hall.

column1: QUESTION: Yes.
VAUGHN: I understand that you're the town moderator for Chichester
column2: New Hampshire.

column1: QUESTION: I am.
VAUGHN: What's your question tonight?
QUESTION: I know a business owner in northern New Hampshire who was on vacation in Spain last year for about three weeks. While he was there
column2: he had to buy refills for prescription drugs
column3: brand name drugs
column4: and he discovered in buying those drugs that he could buy his refills there for $600 less than he could buy them here in New Hampshire. So since then
column5: he said he is going to take a trip over to Spain and get his vacation paid for to buy his drugs.

column1: My question to you is
column2: why is this? And if you are elected president
column3: is there anything you would do to address it?

column1: VAUGHN: Mayor Giuliani?
GIULIANI: What I would do is change the whole model that we have for health insurance in this country.
The problem with our health insurance is
column2: it's government and employer-dominated. People don't make individual choices. It's your health. You should own your health insurance.

column1: We should be giving you a major tax deduction
column3: 000 for a family
column4: so you can buy your own health insurance. If you buy health insurance for $8

column1: Then we should have a health savings account
column2: in which you can put some money aside to pay for your ordinary medical expenses.

column1: Health insurance should become like homeowners insurance or like car insurance. You don't cover everything on your homeowners policy. If you have a slight accident in your house
column2: if you need to refill your oil with your car
column3: you don't cover that with insurance. But that is covered in many of the insurance policies
column4: because they're government-dominated and they're employer-dominated.

column1: What the Democrats suggested on this stage two nights ago was socialized medicine. There was a man in California who said to me
column2: ""When we make health insurance free
column3: just wait and see how expensive it will become.""

column1: And the reality is that we need a free market. We need 100 million Americans making different decisions. It will bring down the cost of health insurance. It will bring down the cost of prescription medicines.
Free-market principles are the only things that reduce costs and improve quality. Socialized medicine will ruin medicine in the United States. BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Congressman Hunter
column2: you live on the border
column3: San Diego
column4: not far from Mexico. A lot of Americans go to Mexico to buy cheaper prescription drugs. A lot of Americans in this part of the country go to Canada to buy cheaper prescription drugs.

column1: What should we here in the United States be doing to bring down the price of prescription drugs?
HUNTER: And
column2: Wolf
column3: the fabulous Grampy
column4: my father-in-law
column5: who lives with us
column6: is one of those people that trots down and goes through the border at Yuma and does that. So lots of Americans do that.

column1: But here's what happens. Eighty percent of the new drugs and new inventions that save our lives
column2: that help preserve the lives of the relatives of everyone who's in this particular room right now
column3: 80 percent of those inventions are made in the United States because we have free enterprise
column4: where people can go out
column5: invest. And maybe they drill three dry holes in trying to produce a good drug that will save somebody's lives. Then maybe they hit the jackpot and they produce something that will save people and help their health.

column1: They then recover their money in the United States. And what they have left over
column2: in terms of market
column3: they put into the Third World. But Third World countries like Mexico could never provide the amount of money that it takes to make those inventions. Otherwise
column4: they would.

column1: Here's what we have to do: We need to be able to buy our health care insurance across state lines
column2: Wolf. Right now the same single policy that can be purchased in Long Beach for $73 costs $334 in New Jersey.

column1: The states lock up the insurance industry. They won't let Americans buy across state lines
column2: just like they do everything else. If we're able to do that...

column1: BLITZER: Thank you.
HUNTER: ... we're going to bring down the cost of health insurance.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: Jennifer
column2: let's go back to another question.

column1: VAUGHN: Also on the topic of health care tonight
column2: this is a question from our wmur.gather.com blogger
column3: who is Joshua Williamson.

column1: Joshua asks
column2: ""Millions of Americans are dissatisfied with the current state of our health-care system
column3: and U.S. employers are at a disadvantage due to the high cost of health insurance. What would you do to fix the health-care system? And would you support implementing a single-payer system
column4: in which the government acts as the insurer in order to save enough money to cover the millions of uninsured and to lower premiums for the rest of the U.S. population?""

column1: Governor Thompson
column2: let's have you weigh in on that.

column1: THOMPSON: You know
column2: I've been here for two debates. We never had one question on health care. Thank that person for talking about health care.

column1: Number one
column2: we spend $2 trillion on health care. That's 16 percent of the gross national product. Ninety-three percent of the cost of health care goes into waiting until after you become sick. Only 7 percent of the money is used to keep you well in the first place.

column1: We got to completely transform the health care system
column2: make it a wellness system and make it a prevention system.

column1: Secondly
column2: we have 125 million Americans that have one or more chronic illnesses. In order to change this
column3: we have to educate the American people about tobacco
column4: about diabetes
column5: about cardiovascular and about obesity.

column1: You do that
column2: you'll be able to change health care.

column1: The third thing
column2: 25 percent of Americans use two-thirds of the cost of health care. If you manage those diseases
column3: you can reduce that down to 50 percent and save lots of money.

column1: Fourth
column2: information technology
column3: electronic medical record
column4: a patient bill of rights and be able to have e-prescribing. And if you do that
column5: you're going to be able to save billions of dollars.

column1: If you just go paperless
column2: ladies and gentlemen
column3: you will save 10 percent of the cost of health care.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor
column3: very much.

column1: Governor Romney
column2: you worked with the Democrats in the state legislature in your home state
column3: the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. You worked with Ted Kennedy to come up with a program that provides some -- mandates
column4: in effect
column5: the individual health insurance coverage.

column1: Some conservatives say this is simply big government
column2: more liberal involvement in people's lives.

column1: What do you say to those conservatives who are critical of the way you handled this issue in Massachusetts?
ROMNEY: Well
column2: I want to talk to the people
column3: not just to those conservatives who are critical. And the people of this country recognize they've got some real concerns in health care. And I learned after I was governor a short bit of time -- I talked to people and they say
column4: ""If I lose my job
column5: I'm going to lose my insurance. And my insurance premiums are getting higher and higher and higher.""

column1: And I talked to small-business people
column2: and they said
column3: ""I can't afford the policies anymore.""

column1: And we said
column2: ""You know
column3: we've got to find a way to get everybody insured. And the last thing we want is to have the government take over health care
column4: because anything they take over gets worse
column5: not better.

column1: We're going to turn to Washington
column2: because Washington makes a mess. Washington is all talk.

column1: And we said
column2: ""We need to find a way to get everybody in our state insured with private insurance.""

column1: The half a million who didn't have insurance
column2: all the people worried that if they lost their job
column3: they'd lose insurance
column4: we said
column5: ""We've got to find a way to get them insured without raising taxes
column6: without a government takeover.""

column1: And that's what we did. It relies on personal responsibility.
This is a big issue for this country. Every Democrat up there is talking about a form of socialized medicine
column2: government takeover
column3: massive tax increase.

column1: We have to stand up and not just talk about it. I'm the guy who actually tackled this issue. We get all of our citizens insured. We get people that were uninsured with private health insurance.
We have to stand up and say
column2: ""The market works. Personal responsibility works.""

column1: We're going to have insurance for all of our citizens they can afford
column2: that's theirs
column3: that's portable. They never have to worry about losing it. That's the answer.

column1: Thank you.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Jennifer
column2: go ahead.

column1: VAUGHN: Thank you
column2: Wolf.

column1: Next question comes from you
column2: sir. Your name is Max Latona.

column1: QUESTION: Yes
column2: it is.

column1: VAUGHN: You live in Manchester
column2: New Hampshire. What do you do for a living
column3: sir?

column1: QUESTION: I teach philosophy here at Saint Anselm College.
VAUGHN: And what's your question tonight?
QUESTION: My question is a simple one: In your opinion
column2: what is the most pressing moral issue facing this country today? And
column3: if you're elected president
column4: how would you address that issue?

column1: VAUGHN: Governor Huckabee
column2: you are an ordained minister. What is the most pressing moral issue in this country?

column1: HUCKABEE: Well
column2: it looks like I'm getting all the moral questions tonight
column3: and I guess that's a good thing.

column1: (LAUGHTER)
That's better than getting the immoral questions. So I'm happy to get those.
(LAUGHTER)
HUCKABEE: I really believe that
column2: if you define it a moral issue
column3: it is our respect
column4: our sanctity and our understanding of the value of every single human life.

column1: Because that is what makes America a unique place on this planet: We value every life of an individual as if it represents the life of us all.
Many of us who are pro-life
column2: quite frankly
column3: I think
column4: have made the mistake of giving people the impression that pro-life means we care intensely about people as long as that child is in the womb. But beyond the gestation period
column5: we've not demonstrated as demonstrably as we should that we respect life at all levels
column6: not just during pregnancy.

column1: We shouldn't allow a child to live under a bridge or in the backseat of a car. We shouldn't be satisfied that elderly people are being abused and neglected in nursing homes. It should never be acceptable to us that people are treated as expendable -- any people.
But the unique part of our country is that we elevate and we celebrate human life. And if you look at us with a contrast to the Islamic jihadists
column2: who would strap a bomb to the belly of their own child
column3: march him into a crowded room
column4: set the detonator and kill innocent people
column5: they celebrate death; we celebrate life.

column1: It's the fundamental thing that makes us unique
column2: and it keeps us free. I pray we never
column3: ever abandon that basic principle.

column1: BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Governor.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Mayor Giuliani
column2: what is the most pressing moral issue in America today?

column1: GIULIANI: I think the governor is correct. I would put it in maybe a slightly different way. We have great gifts in this country that come to us from God. We have a country in which we have freedom of religion
column2: freedom of press
column3: freedom for the individual
column4: the right to elect our own officials. And the reality is that in some of the world
column5: much of the world
column6: that doesn't exist.

column1: And I think the challenge for our generation is going to be
column2: are we able to share those gifts in an appropriate way with the rest of the world?

column1: If we can bring along the Middle East
column2: if we can bring along those countries that are presently our enemies
column3: and get them to see the values of these ideals
column4: if we have the moral strength to be able to explain it to them in the way Ronald Reagan was able to do with communism
column5: then we can end up having the peace that we want.

column1: And we should not -- we should never become pessimistic about this. Remember
column2: this is the country that was at war with Vietnam just a short while ago. We're friends now.

column1: BLITZER: All right.
GIULIANI: This was a country that was at war with Japan
column2: Italy and Germany a generation ago. They're some of our best friends today.

column1: We have great resources in this country. And watching the strength of America when we believe in the essential ideals that we have -- they're not just American ideals; they come from God. And I think it's our moral obligation to find the right way to share that with the rest of the world.
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Mayor.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
Congressman Paul
column2: what is the most pressing moral issue in the United States right now?

column1: PAUL: I think it is the acceptance just recently that we now promote preemptive war. I do not believe that's part of the American tradition.
We
column2: in the past
column3: have always declared war in defense of our liberties or go to aid somebody. But now we have accepted the principle of preemptive war. We have rejected the just war theory of Christianity.

column1: And now
column2: tonight
column3: we hear that we're not even willing to remove from the table a preemptive nuclear strike against a country that has done no harm to us directly and is no threat to our national security.

column1: I mean
column2: we have to come to our senses about this issue of war and preemption and go back to traditions and our Constitution and defend our liberties and defend our rights
column3: but not to think that we can change the world by force of arms and to start wars.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Congressman.

column1: Senator Brownback really wants to weigh in
column2: as well.

column1: BROWNBACK: Thank you.
And thank you for the question from a philosopher.
I think it's the life issue clearly
column2: and I'm pro-life and I'm whole life.

column1: And one of the things I'm the most -- the proudest about our party about is that we've stood for life. We've been a party that has stood for a culture of life. And it was in our platform in 1980
column2: and it continues today.

column1: And with that respect -- and I have respect for my other colleagues -- that's why I don't think we can nominate somebody that's not pro-life in this party
column2: because it is at our core.

column1: We believe that every life is beautiful
column2: is sacred
column3: is a child of a loving God from natural -- from conception to natural death.

column1: And that applies not only here and in the womb
column2: it applies to somebody that's in poverty
column3: it applies to the child in Darfur.

column1: And that philosophy
column2: being pro-life and whole life
column3: is something I think can really help move us forward as a country and as a party.

column1: (APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Senator
column2: if Rudy Giuliani got the Republican presidential nomination
column3: would you be able to support him?

column1: BROWNBACK: That question came up at the first debate
column2: and I stated that this is something that we as a party have struggled with. I have great respect for the mayor. I don't think we're going to nominate somebody that's not pro-life.

column1: BLITZER: Would you be able to support him?

BROWNBACK: I can support and will support the nominee of our party. But our party has stood on principles. It's a party of principles. It's not a party of personalities. We lose when we walk away from our principles.
That's when we have trouble. And that's the country wants us to do...
BLITZER: Thank you
column2: Senator.

column1: BROWNBACK: ... is to stand for principles.
(APPLAUSE)
BLITZER: Jennifer
column2: go ahead.

column1: VAUGHN: Next question tonight from Neil Capano.
Neil
column2: you are an airline agent.

column1: QUESTION: Yes
column2: I am.

column1: VAUGHN: You live in Manchester
column2: New Hampshire.

column1: You have a question tonight for Governor Romney.
QUESTION: Yes
column2: I do.

column1: First of all
column2: I would like to thank all of you for joining us tonight in beautiful Manchester
column3: New Hampshire. However
column4: my question is for Governor Romney exclusively.

column1: You've been accused of -- you've been accused of flip-flopping on immigration.
Just earlier tonight you indicated "	['http://i.a.cnn.net/cnn/.element/img/1.5/ceiling/cnnCeildivider.gif'

column1: 0	"Transcript below:
MIKA BRZEZINSKI: With us now Republican Representative from Indiana and Chairman of the House Republican Conference
column2: Congressman Mike Pence. He's also Chairman of the American Energy Solutions Group which will introduce the House GOP's answer to the nation's energy problem in a bill later today. Morning Joe has an exclusive look at the details.

column1: JOE SCARBOROUGH: I want to ask him a question.
BRZEZINSKI: Okay
column2: fine.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: I laughed this morning when I heard the President talking about fiscal responsibility. I support PAYGO and I'm sure you support PAYGO but as Dylan Ratigan said
column2: ""the cow is already out of the barn.""

column1: REP. MIKE PENCE: Well
column2: that's right
column3: Joe. I really do believe there is a little bit of symmetry here between the issue of PAYGO and the energy legislation that Republicans are going to be introducing today. What the Democrats have and are planning to bring to the floor this month is essentially a national energy tax. This so-called ""cap and trade bill"" is a means of paying for all of the runaway federal spending that we've seen under the last Administration and redoubled and increased.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Can you explain that because we hear about cap in trade. Break it down for us as simply as you can. What does that mean for americans and their energy problem?

REP. PENCE: What it means all in the name of climate change this new regime of limiting carbon emissions from all different sources of energy production in this country but i don't think you need to look any further than the President himself
column2: Joe
column3: who literally said his cap and trade proposals were to pass
column4: that utility rates
column5: his words now
column6: would
column7: ""necessarily skyrocket"". John Dingle of Michigan and the Commerce Committee said people don't realize this is a tax and a
column8: ""great big one."" Republicans today are going to unveil a plan that takes us in the direction of energy independence.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Trying to break this down. So where people would mainly feel it is in their power bills every week?
REP. PENCE: Places like Indiana where I'm from would see a potential doubling of their utility rates but also
column2: remember; the cost of energy goes into virtually every product we consume. This national energy tax according to some estimates could mean additional energy costs across the board of some $3
column3: 000 or more per year per household. We have a better way. We have a better solution. We're going to unveil it this morning. I'm glad to do so exclusively here on Morning Joe. The Republicans' all-of-the-above strategy
column4: we're going to say yes to giving the American people more access to American oil
column5: more domestic exploration for natural gas and coal
column6: yes to renewables like wind and solar and we're going to say a deafening yes to nuclear energy. We're going to commit this country or call on this country to build 100 new nuclear power plants in the next 20 years.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Your alternative energy source
column2: obviously we're not there yet. The federal government may need to step in and get involved in helping the private sector.

column1: REP. PENCE: It really does
column2: Joe. We want to capture some of the revenues from offshore drilling and put it into a renewable trust fund that will be available in the development of alternative and renewable sources of energy. We just don't need to pass legislation like cap in trade that will amount to a national energy tax
column3: harm our economy at a time
column4: quite frankly
column5: when every American small business is struggling to make ends meet. There's a better way. Republicans will outline that today and I have a feeling - I just have a gut feeling there's a lot of concern even among many Democrats on capitol hill about the national energy tax looking for a better solution and I believe the American Energy Act we introduce today will be part of that.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: I think you're exactly right. A lot of Democrats are concerned. a lot of Republicans I know are concerned about the way we use energy in this country. I mean
column2: do you agree with me and a lot of conservatives that there's nothing conservative about a country that has 4% of the world's population spending 25% of the world's energy?

column1: REP. PENCE: Percentages I don't get as concerned about as the notion that appears. Joe
column2: you served on the house floor with great distinction. Remember the quote up on the wall by Daniel Webster that speaks about the resources of this country
column3: the natural resources of this country
column4: the genius of this country. He said let us call forth this nation's power. Part of that power is innovation. Part of that power is finding alternative sources of energy like wind
column5: energy and solar. Oil and coal
column6: natural gas and clean coal technologies. We just don't need to pass the Democrat cap in trade plan
column7: to answer with innovation and alternatives. That's the Republican solution.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Teddy Roosevelt
column2: of course
column3: also talked a lot about conservation.

column1: REP. PENCE: That's right.
SCARBOROUGH: That's something we can do right now.
REP. PENCE: That's right.
SCARBOROUGH: Is that part of your package
column2: too?

column1: REP. PENCE: That's exactly right. You're one of my favorite Teddy Roosevelt Republicans
column2: Joe
column3: and we're going to make a real commitment to conservation in this legislation but
column4: remember
column5: the national energy tax is all about paying for all this spending. People should see it as no other way. They want to pass a national energy tax so you pay and they go on spending. That's the real PAYGO. Republicans have a better solution and we're looking forward to showing it to the American people.

column1: SCARBOROUGH: Thank you for coming here and talking to us about it first
column2: Congressman Pence. Thank you so much."	['https://web.archive.org/web/20090617192953im_/http://www.gop.gov/resources/images/navigation/06_on.jpg'
