column1: 0	"Roosevelt Room
11:27 A.M. EDT
THE PRESIDENT: Thank you all for being here today. It’s a great honor for you to share your personal stories of struggle under the enormous strain imposed on you by the very
column2: very failed and failing Obamacare law. Secretary Price and I
column3: along with my entire administration
column4: and a lot of people in the Senate and a lot of people in the House are committed to repealing and replacing this disastrous law with a healthcare plan that lowers cost
column5: expands choice
column6: and ensures access for everyone.

column1: You represent the millions of Americans who have seen their Obamacare premiums increase by double digits and even triple digits. In Arizona
column2: the rates were over 116 percent last year -- 116 percent increase. And the deductibles are so high you don’t even get to use it.

column1: Many Americans lost their plans and doctors altogether
column2: and one-third of the counties -- think of it
column3: one-third only have one insurer left. The insurance companies are fleeing. They’re gone; so many gone. The House bill to repeal and replace Obamacare will provide you and your fellow citizens with more choices -- far more choices at lower cost. Americans should pick the plan they want. Now they’ll be able to pick the plan they want
column4: they’ll be able to pick the doctor they want. They’ll be able to do a lot of things that the other plan was supposed to give and it never gave. You don’t pick your doctor
column5: you don’t pick your plan -- you remember that one.

column1: We’re not going to have one-size-fits-all. Instead
column2: we’re going to be working to unleash the power of the private marketplace to let insurers come in and compete for your business. And you’ll see rates go down
column3: down
column4: down
column5: and you’ll see plans go up
column6: up
column7: up. You’ll have a lot of choices.

column1: You’ll have plans that nobody is even thinking of today. They will have plans that today nobody has even thought about
column2: because the market is going to enforce that
column3: with millions and millions of people wanting healthcare. More competition and less regulation will finally bring down the cost of care
column4: and I think it will bring it down very significantly. Unfortunately
column5: it takes a while to get there
column6: because you have to let that marketplace kick in
column7: and it’s going to take a little while to get there. Once it does
column8: it’s going to be a thing of beauty. I wish it didn’t take a year or two years
column9: but that’s what’s going to happen
column10: and that’s the way it works. But we’re willing to go through that process.

column1: Working together
column2: we’ll get the job done. And I have to say this just in closing
column3: and then I want to hear some of your stories
column4: and we’ll let the press stay for your stories if you like. But the press is making Obamacare look so good all of a sudden. I’m watching the news -- looks so good. They’re showing these reports about ""this one gets so much and this one gets so much.""

column1: First of all
column2: it covers very few people. And it’s imploding. And ’17 will be the worst year. And I said it once
column3: I’ll say it again -- because Obama is gone -- things are going to be very bad this year for the people with Obamacare. They’re going to have tremendous increases.

column1: And the Republicans
column2: frankly
column3: are putting themselves in a very bad position -- and I tell this to Tom Price all the time -- by repealing Obamacare -- because people aren’t going to see the truly devastating effects of Obamacare. They’re not going to see the devastation in ’17 and ’18 and ’19. It'll be gone by then
column4: whether we do it or not. It’ll be imploded off the map.

column1: So the press is making it look so wonderful so that if we end it
column2: everyone is going to say
column3: ""Oh
column4: remember how great Obamacare used to be
column5: remember how wonderful it used to be
column6: it was so great."" It’s a little bit like President Obama. When he left
column7: people liked him. When he was here
column8: people didn’t like him so much. That’s the way life goes. That’s human nature.

column1: The fact is
column2: Obamacare is a disaster. And I say this to the Republicans all the time: By repealing it
column3: by getting rid of it
column4: by ending it
column5: everyone is going to say
column6: ""Oh
column7: it used to be so great."" But it wasn’t great. And I tell Tom Price and I tell Paul Ryan
column8: I tell everyone of them -- I say
column9: the best thing you can do politically is wait a year
column10: because it’s going to blow itself off the map. But that’s the wrong thing to do for the country
column11: it’s the wrong thing to do for our citizens.

column1: So with that
column2: I’d like to introduce some of the folks and you could say a few words about your experience with Obamacare. And perhaps the press will even report it. (Laughter.)

column1: Would you like to start?
MS. COUEY: Yeah
column2: thank you for this opportunity
column3: Mr. President.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Thank you. Thank you.

MS. COUEY: Our rates are three times what they were before Obamacare started. We have one provider in our county. We have very little options for what we can and cannot do. We’re a small-business owner; we’re actually not a brick-and-mortar
column2: we are cattle ranchers. We can’t afford our equipment if we’re paying these rates year after year after year.

column1: Our food source is in jeopardy because of this healthcare law. It’s my basic --
THE PRESIDENT: I know. Sorry. Don't worry. Don't worry. This is what’s happening. It’s gone up three times
column2: and then you have to pay -- if you don’t want to use it
column3: you have to pay. That’s the all-time beauty. If you don’t want to use it
column4: you have to pay. And
column5: Tom
column6: you have to pay big league
column8: well
column11: I’m paying too much. If I don’t use it
column12: I have to pay a penalty. And do you have to pay penalties? Do you ever do that

column1: MS. COUEY: We haven’t as of yet
column2: but we were uninsured in December. They dropped us for the fourth time
column3: after we paid over $50
column4: 000 last year for healthcare expenses.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: And it’s gone up triple.
MS. COUEY: Yes.
THE PRESIDENT: And before Obamacare
column2: you actually had good healthcare.

column1: MS. COUEY: We did. We had a fantastic plan.
THE PRESIDENT: A lot of people -- nobody ever takes that into account. I’m not saying the system before was good
column2: because it wasn’t
column3: but millions of people had great healthcare that they loved.

column1: Now
column2: when you start deducting those millions of people from the so-called people that are happy
column3: you have a very small number of people that are happy. That
column4: I can tell you.

column1: How about you?
PARTICIPANT: Well
column2: we’re kind of the same story as Carrie. In 2009
column3: I left a full-time job to be a stay-at-home mom to two kids. For our family
column4: it was never an option to get government assistance; we just don’t believe our neighbors should work harder so that we don’t have to. So my husband said
column5: if you can pay for our insurance -- which at the time was $650 a month for private health insurance for a family of four -- then that was fine.

column1: From 2009 to 2015
column2: that private insurance went up by 102 percent. Finally
column3: his employer told us in 2015
column4: when it went up the final time an additional 34 percent
column5: that they couldn’t carry our family anymore
column6: so I had to enter back into the workforce but I couldn’t find a job that offered health insurance. So we entered under Obamacare
column7: and we believed the sales pitch that
column8: ""If you like your doctor you can keep your doctor.""

column1: So even though we were going to have to pay $1
column2: 300 a month for Obamacare
column3: we thought we’d still be okay with our doctors. We were on it for five months. Our pediatrician for our children wouldn’t take it
column4: my doctor wouldn’t take it
column5: so we paid them $8
column6: 000 in five months and were never able to use it.

column1: And I think what makes our family story unique is
column2: we’re by no means wealthy. In 2014
column3: when we entered the exchange
column4: we made $53
column5: 000 as a family
column6: my husband and I together -- that was our gross income. And then in 2015
column7: we made together -- since I had gone back to work -- $74
column8: 000. But when you look at paying $10
column9: 000 in health premiums and insurance -- and health costs --

column1: THE PRESIDENT: So it’s been a rough go.
PARTICIPANT: It has
column2: it’s been hard.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: How have you found Obamacare?
PARTICIPANT: We’ll be so happy to see it gone. I mean
column2: it’s almost put our family in financial ruin
column3: and I think that’s the story for a lot of people.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: It’s put businesses in financial ruin.
PARTICIPANT: That’s right.
THE PRESIDENT: It’s one of the biggest costs -- it has been disastrous for businesses.
Go ahead
column2: sir.

column1: MR. SEIFE: Yes
column2: first of all
column3: Mr. President
column4: thank you for having us here.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Thank you.
MR. SEIFE: I think it’s a great opportunity to talk to the American people
column2: people like ourselves that have struggled with the healthcare law.

column1: I myself am from Miami. I haven’t had very much time to prepare
column2: but the President of the United States calls and I’m here. (Laughter.) So it just so happened I had -- every single year for the past couple of years I’ve had a different insurance every single year. Before
column3: I had an individual plan
column4: my wife and I -- my wife is an attorney
column5: I’m a computer programmer; I’m a small business
column6: my wife is a small business. And I just don’t understand what happened. I have a daughter with a disability. We’ve changed our plan every year.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: So your insurance was good before Obamacare.
MR. SEIFE: Oh
column2: absolutely. I never had --

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Many people are like that. Many
column2: many plans were great before Obamacare. They were so happy. And that doesn’t justify the system before Obamacare
column3: but people are miserable now
column4: and it’s putting people out of business and it’s putting them in the poorhouse.

column1: Go ahead.
MR. SEIFE: It’s just that we had to -- they cancelled our plans
column2: and I couldn’t understand why they cancelled our plans. So we had no other choice. I remember the President of the United States say that individual plans will not be covered
column3: you need to have an employer-based plan. I do not work for the government
column4: I do not work for a large employer.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Very unfair.
MR. SEIFE: We are ground zero. My case is ground zero for the healthcare law.
THE PRESIDENT: And you represent a lot of people in the same situation.
MR. SEIFE: Absolutely.
THE PRESIDENT: It’s very unfair.
MR. SEIFE: Like my friend here
column2: she’s in the same situation. And I think it’s very
column3: very unfair. And I think that the real scenario was that this law was supposed to implode
column4: like you were saying. And my parents are from -- came from communist Cuba
column5: they know what socialism is all about. So I know what socialism is
column6: and that’s pretty much what -- this whole system was meant to have one single provider.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: it turns out it's so expensive it’s almost not socialism when you think about it. (Laughter.) You have to pay so much.

column1: What do you think? Go ahead.
MS. SERTICH: I’m from Arizona
column2: and I can tell you that the 116-percent increase is real
column3: it’s not a myth. I lost my plan three times during the Obamacare era. After losing it this year I decided to opt out. So right now I do not have traditional healthcare.

column1: And I went from a $365-a-month premium last year to a $809-premium this year.
THE PRESIDENT: And a higher deductible.
MS. SERTICH: The deductible was going to be $6
column3: no copays. So if I went to the doctor
column4: I would be paying out of my pocket
column5: and it just didn’t seem like a good use of my money. I thought I would be a better steward of that $17
column6: 000 at the end of the year should I have reached my deductible
column7: and just decided to opt out. I went into a faith-based share program
column8: and I’m doing that.

column1: One of the reasons I felt like I can do this -- totally taking a leap of faith -- is because I think -- I know you’re going to get this taken care of. So I thought it’s only going to be for a year. I will be on this program
column2: I will opt out of traditional healthcare
column3: or health insurance. And I think you’re going to get it done.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: You have a lot of people in Arizona paying a big penalty?
MS. SERTICH: Yes.
THE PRESIDENT: You’re paying the penalty?
MS. SERTICH: Well
column2: and my husband also owns his own business and can’t afford to offer insurance to employees. And his employees who are also in the independent market
column3: it’s just getting too much. And I’ve had individual insurance for 25 years
column4: since I started my business. So I’ve always been in that individual market
column5: I’ve always done what was right. I took responsibility for myself
column6: made sure I was covered for healthcare because I’m a businessperson
column7: I don’t want any huge healthcare expenses to affect the money that could be going to my business now having to go to a health expense.

column1: So I was in my mid-20s when I said
column2: you know what
column3: I’ve got to get -- we’ve got to get square with this
column4: I have to have independent insurance. So
column5: I have.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: thank you very much. The people of Arizona have been hit very
column3: very hard. At least 116 percent. Here’s the bad news: It’s going to go up more this year. Now
column4: if we repeal it
column5: nobody is going to know that
column6: and the press is going to say how wonderful it was
column8: gee
column9: we miss Obamacare. That’s the problem. It’s the biggest problem I have
column10: Tom. We’re going to do them a big favor
column11: but it’s not the right way.

column1: Go ahead.
MR. BROWN: Mr. President
column2: thank you.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Thank you very much
column2: Louis.

column1: MR. BROWN: My name is Louis Brown. I work for the Christ Medicus Foundation. I'm an attorney by trade. In 2009
column2: when the Affordable Care Act was going through Congress -- what became the Affordable Care Act -- I was working for the Democratic National Committee at the time. I resigned my position because I could tell that the Democratic bill that was going through Congress wanted to publicly fund abortion
column3: and that’s not something that I could go along with. So I resigned my position
column4: later worked for Congressman Dan Lungren in Congress
column5: and went on to eventually work for the Christ Medicus Foundation. And we’re focused on building a culture of life
column6: protecting religious liberty in healthcare
column8: prohibiting the public funding of abortion
column9: and also prohibiting non-discrimination against pro-life medical providers.

column1: Especially as an African American
column2: I'm a graduate of Howard University School of Law.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Good school.
MR. BROWN: Yeah. Thank you
column2: Mr. President. And I know from Saint John Paul II -- he said that all of our human and civil rights that we believe in as Americans
column3: that we share as Americans -- the right to healthcare
column4: the right to medical care
column5: to housing
column6: to all of these different things -- are illusory if the right to life isn’t defended with maximum determination.

column1: Seventeen million African Americans
column2: it’s shown
column3: that probably have been aborted since Roe v. Wade. And I supported you in the presidential election
column4: gave several speeches in Michigan telling folks to vote pro-life in the general election
column5: and I’m really happy that you’re here to continue the bipartisan belief that there should be no taxpayer-funding of abortion
column6: and also really to support your effort to show that the patient
column8: should be at the center of our American healthcare system
column9: not the government. The government has its place
column10: but the patient should be the center. So I’m happy to support you

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Thank you. That’s so nice. Thank you
column2: I appreciate it. Great job.

column1: Yes
column2: go ahead.

column1: DR. SETHI: Mr. President
column2: thank you so much for inviting me. My name is Dr. Manny
column3: and I run a nonprofit called Healthy Tennessee
column4: and across Tennessee I’m a trauma surgeon. But what we do is --

column1: THE PRESIDENT: I’ll be in Tennessee on Wednesday.
DR. MANNY: We look forward to hosting you
column2: sir.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: I’ll see you there.
DR. MANNY: Yes
column2: sir. We do these large community events in rural Appalachia
column3: across Tennessee
column4: where we host these health fairs taking care of patients. So it’s really a grassroots effort -- something that you understand better than anybody -- where people come out just to help people. Doctors
column5: nurses on the ground
column6: helping folks with preventative medicine
column7: educating folks. That’s what we do.

column1: But the one thing I’ve been seeing across Tennessee is that folks really can’t afford these rising premiums. So what they’re doing is
column2: effectively
column3: they’re paying the tax penalty because it’s cheaper and it works out better than paying for the insurance. And so that’s been a big problem that we’re seeing across the state. So thank you so much for what you’re doing to tackle this problem.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: So you’ve seen a big problem
column2: and the way out of the problem is to do a plan much more like the plan we’re going to get done.

column1: DR. MANNY: Yes
column2: sir.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: We’ll get that out -- without penalties too
column2: by the way. People don’t mention all of the facts.

column1: You know
column2: the other thing about what we’re talking about -- we really have a three-phase plan. They only want to talk about the first phase. The first phase is just the most basic of phases
column3: and then you have phase two
column4: which is largely done by our Secretary
column5: and then you have phase three
column6: which is a lot of the bells and whistles. But they don’t want to talk about the bells and whistles. So they’re really comparing things to something that won’t be there for long.

column1: And the reason we have to do it that way is because of Congress. I’d love to do it all in one package
column2: but if you did it that way
column3: it can’t get done. So we’re going to get something done that’s going to be terrific.

column1: I appreciate it. Thank you
column2: doctor
column3: very much.

column1: Yes
column2: sir. Go ahead.

column1: MR. BROWN: Thank you
column2: Mr. President. I’d like to thank you for the opportunity to be here today. I
column3: too
column4: am from Tennessee
column5: and I
column6: too

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Good.
MR. BROWN: And the effect that I’ve had through Obamacare is my wife's and my daughter's insurance is supplied through her work
column2: I buy my own. And I’ve seen the increases
column3: since Obamacare
column4: to the tune of about $5
column5: 000 a year
column6: just for me. And I have considered taking the option of the penalty because -- my problem with the penalty is
column8: if I opt out of the program
column9: and buy a private plan -- just a catastrophic plan because I’m a very healthy man -- if I take that option
column10: not only is my income penalized
column11: but my wife’s income as well
column12: because she makes a considerable more amount of money than I do
column13: but she has insurance. So I don’t think that’s fair.

column1: And I don’t think -- the rate increase is just astronomical
column2: and I’m in the county that only has one option -- BlueCross BlueShield of Tennessee --and I’ve got about $540-a-month premium for the $7
column3: 000 out-of-pocket deductible before I see any help at all. And I even got to pay a high premium for a plan that I don’t need or don’t want --

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Will you be able to continue
column2: in the years to come
column3: if you have to keep going like this?

column1: MR. BROWN: They’re dropping out every day -- the suppliers in other counties. There’s 35 counties in Tennessee that has no options at all right now. I don’t know what those folks do.
THE PRESIDENT: You know what that means? That means somebody is going to make a lot of money. You know that. They’re going to make a lot of money. (Laughter.) Somebody is going to -- well
column2: a few. You’re not going to make it. They’re going to make it. There are people very happy about this situation.

column1: MR. BROWN: Thank you for the opportunity to be here.
THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: I appreciate. Thank you
column3: Joel.

column1: Doctor?
DR. ARMSTRONG: Yes
column2: sir. Well
column3: I’m a physician in Texas
column4: and thank you for allowing me to be here today. And I’ll tell you
column5: what I’ve seen is that a lot of patients really are not adequately covered by Obamacare. It was supposed to cover people who had -- like everyone has said here -- with the rising premiums and the rising deductibles. I take care of patients in the hospital
column6: and the patients are shocked to get a $20
column8: and to find that they’re responsible for $6
column9: 000 of that because their deductible is so high. And that’s just the situation that cannot continue.

column1: Medicaid expansion under Obamacare really doesn’t cover folks either
column2: because many physicians are not even taking Medicare. They’re not accepting it any longer in the outpatient setting. And so folks who have chronic medical illnesses
column3: like cancer -- I mean
column4: my wife is a breast cancer survivor
column5: and most of her treatment was actually as an outpatient. It was very expensive outpatient care. Most physicians don’t even accept Medicaid
column6: so those patients are still uncovered.

column1: And so the Medicaid expansion really hasn’t covered them. The folks who have Obamacare insurance really are inadequately covered as well because they’re still paying extremely high premiums and then having to pay extremely high deductibles. And so it’s really --
THE PRESIDENT: And do they even reach it with the high deductibles? They don’t even reach it for the most part.
DR. ARMSTRONG: You know
column2: oftentimes they do not
column3: unless they have some sort of serious medical problem
column4: and they’re in the hospital
column5: and it’s very expensive -- they don’t even reach their deductible oftentimes. And so it’s unfortunate. So I really appreciate it.

column1: I actually read the bill that’s been produced that’s coming out of the House now
column2: and I really like a lot of the changes in it. I think that this is going to correct a lot of the issues that Obamacare has had. So I really appreciate what you all are doing.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: I appreciate it
column3: doctor. Thank you. Say hello to your wife.

column1: DR. ARMSTRONG: Yes
column2: sir. I will. Thank you.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Very nice. Thank you.
Gina.
MS. SELL: Hi
column2: Mr. President
column3: I’m Gina. I’m from Wisconsin. I’m a nurse
column4: I’m a mom
column5: and I am part of that huge group of middle-class families that were impacted by the ACA.

column1: Before ACA
column2: we had insurance that was eventually cancelled
column3: and I had written a letter to our senator just asking him
column4: what do I do? Do I quit my job completely so that we can obtain a subsidy -- a job that I love
column5: as a nurse in a hospital that I love? Or do I uproot my family and try to find a job with benefits that doesn’t even cover the medical --

column1: THE PRESIDENT: So the healthcare is -- the Obamacare forced you to actually -- in a sense
column2: forces you
column3: economically and almost potentially
column4: to get another job.

column1: MS. SELL: Right.
THE PRESIDENT: Even though you like your job.
MS. SELL: Right. So I did end up getting a full-time position at the hospital that I worked at. But that came with a price because I was working three days a week
column2: and spending time with my small children
column3: who are my number-one priority. And after the ACA
column4: I was forced -- because we could not afford a premium of $1
column5: 200 per month and a deductible that didn’t cover anything -- to find a job with benefits.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Meaning the deductible was so high that
column2: essentially
column3: unless you had a really big problem
column4: you wouldn’t even be able to use it.

column1: The deductible was so high that essentially unless you had a really big problem
column2: you wouldn’t even be able to use it.

column1: MS. SELL: Correct
column2: yes. And we're still in that boat. I mean
column3: right now our deductible is $6
column4: 500. And so if I have a child who's extremely sick
column5: it's going to cost me hundreds of dollars. Just last week
column6: my daughter had a fever
column7: and I sent her to school for three days straight because I had to work to afford our assurance
column8: and I couldn’t afford to bring her to the doctor. So it has been devastating for our family.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: It's really not having insurance at all. A lot of Obamacare
column2: you don’t really have insurance because the deductibles are so high that you really don’t have insurance
column3: if you think about it.

column1: All right. Thank you very much. Good luck.
MS. SELL: Thank you.
THE PRESIDENT: Yes
column2: sir.

column1: MR. KNOX: Mr. President
column2: thank you very much for hosting us. This is great. I have to start with something. As I was leaving the house
column3: my 11-year-old ran up to me and said
column4: ""Dad
column5: I'd like to have you give this to Mr. President for me."" (Laughter.)

column1: THE PRESIDENT: What do you have there? I wished I looked that good. (Laughter.)
MR. KNOX: ""Dear President Trump
column2: it is a great honor to be able to write to the President of the USA. I think you are a great President and a great man. Also
column3: don't worry
column4: the picture of you on the front of this looks nothing like you."" (Laughter.)

column1: THE PRESIDENT: (Laughter.) That's very nice. Thank you. Thank you. I wish I looked that good.
MR. KNOX: So I had the privilege of meeting with Secretary Price and Vice President Pence in Cincinnati about a week and a half ago at a roundtable
column2: and I'll share with you what I shared with them. I started with a quote from the great President
column3: Ronald Reagan
column4: who said
column5: ""The most terrifying words in the English language are we're from the government and we're here to help.'"" (Laughter.) Kind of my feeling on healthcare.

column1: Frankly
column2: I think that the system was broken before the last administration got their hands on it. I started my company 21 years ago
column3: and I had a vision of wanting to provide 100 percent full family healthcare for as long as I had a company
column4: because I really felt in my heart that it was the right thing to do. I was one of the last holdouts. But
column5: sadly
column6: after about 15 years
column7: I really had a choice of either having a company or being able to provide my employees that level of healthcare. And that's sad. I tell my wife all the time -- you can have anything you want
column8: we just can't everything we want. We have the best healthcare system in the world -- we do -- but it needs to be fixed -- whether it's small business owners
column10: I'm on several boards in the Midwest in manufacturing.

column1: What we'd like to see is not a government-operated market
column2: but a free market. I sell (inaudible) equipment for a living. We have a trade show every year
column3: and there's hundreds and hundreds of people selling competitive products. If we had a healthcare show in my town
column4: there would be three or four people under that roof. And as a businessman yourself
column5: you know what that does to driving down costs or the lack thereof. So we would like to see more of a free-market solution
column6: going back to what made this country great -- entrepreneurialism instead of empowerments; work ethics instead of welfare. And that's what we'd like to ask you for. And I'd like to say thank you very much.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: As you know
column2: that's what we're doing largely
column3: but we also have to take care of people that can't afford to be in a position like you are. So we're going to do that. Largely
column4: I think beyond everything
column5: if you look at what's going to happen -- the competitive bidding -- every element of what we're doing is competitive bidding
column6: but we have to take care of people who need the help. And there are a lot of people like that.

column1: MR. KNOX: There's always been a safety net in the United States
column2: and there should be. And
column3: unfortunately
column4: when I see 50
column5: 000 -- or 50 million Americans taking assistance in -- you know
column6: they're market food stamps. That's like -- for the people who really can't provide for themselves
column8: we're all charitable people who are Americans
column9: we're the most generous nation on the face of the Earth. So I totally believe in safety nets for those who need them

column1: THE PRESIDENT: We’re going to help a lot of people
column2: but we are going to be very much free market people. They can afford -- and they'll be off the cost.

column1: Go ahead
column2: Stan.

column1: MR. SUMMERS: I'm Mr. Stan Summers from Box Elder County
column2: northern Utah. I think I'm probably the only other elected official here besides you guys. It's been an interesting ride to watch the healthcare system in the last 26 years. When my son was born
column3: he was three and a half months premature
column4: 26 years ago. And we had really good insurance. We basically didn’t have to pay anything out of pocket besides what we were doing from where I worked. As time went on
column5: you could kind of tell the healthcare system has been a little bit broke
column6: and then all of a sudden the ACA -- and I'm not going to call it the other word -- I call it the last President's healthcare program. I don’t want to say that name.

column1: So anyway --
THE PRESIDENT: Other than that
column2: you like him a lot
column3: right? (Laughter.)

column1: MR. SUMMERS: Yeah
column2: exactly. (Laughter.) It's gotten to the point where I own a couple of businesses too and do the things that I have to do. I actually ran for government so I could have insurance -- and won. But now I'm looking at these people
column3: saying
column4: how can I provide insurance for them without raising taxes and doing these things that are happening -- because everything has gone up. Utah didn’t expand Medicaid -- we weren’t a part of that -- and we can see why now
column5: because of the things that are happening throughout the nation with states and companies and everybody else going bankrupt.

column1: So it got to the point where I ended up -- not only with my businesses -- I have to drive a school bus to keep my wife at home with my kid that was ill. So now I own three businesses
column2: I drive a school bus
column3: and I'm an elected official
column4: to be able to continue to do the things that I need to do with healthcare. The last three -- well
column5: the last three years --

column1: THE PRESIDENT: So it's gone through the roof.
MR. SUMMERS: Oh
column2: I got a $6
column3: 000 deductible -- HSA -- but I will meet that again in three months. So I'm at -- I think my wife said morning
column4: at 4
column6: 900 bucks already this year in March to be able to meet my out-of-pocket. And so by the time April comes
column7: I would have met that to be able to continue to do. And if there was one thing I probably could ask you about -- and my boy has got a rare disease
column8: and I appreciate you talking about the rare [disease] community in your speeches -- is that if somebody has cancer or somebody has a rare disease or continues to have problems
column9: why do we have to do a deductible every year?

column1: So I’m sitting there at Christmas going
column2: okay
column3: my deductible has been met for six or eight months
column4: and I’m going to turn around and have to do it again for the same disease
column5: for the same symptoms
column6: for the same everything.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: That's interesting. Tom
column2: could you answer that? That would be interesting.

column1: SECRETARY PRICE: It’s all about the risk and spreading the risk with insurance over a period of time. But it is a challenge for individuals with chronic disease
column2: there’s no doubt about it.

column1: MR. SUMMERS: And I appreciate you even thinking about it and talking about grassroots
column2: and when you're talking about all the people that we support with the farmers and ranchers
column3: and the small-business people
column4: and the people that are in manufacturing
column5: our county is one of the largest manufacturing counties in the nation per capita. And Nucor would love to tell you thanks -- Nucor Steel would love to tell you thanks for everything you've been doing.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Nucor has been very good. It’s going to get better
column2: too.

column1: MR. SUMMERS: And we've got a ton of those. The space program -- we used to make the shuttle boosters out of ATK Thiokal. And we’d love to have the space program. I got a really good friend.
THE PRESIDENT: Those days are gone
column2: but they're coming back.

column1: MR. SUMMERS: I’ve got a friend that's going to go up in the next little bit
column2: Lieutenant Commander Scott Maker Tingle
column3: who is headed up on a spaceship from Russia. But he would love to come back to the United States and be able to go up through the United States. So all those jobs I know will come back with you.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: Gary Cohn
column3: who is sitting right next to you
column4: he’s a big believer in what you're saying -- right
column5: Gary?

column1: MR. SUMMERS: If there’s anything we can do to help you
column2: the counties are behind you. We can find you low-hanging fruit to be able to pick off that tree to help with jobs. Just let us know where we can help.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Good. Thank you
column2: Stan.

column1: MR. SUMMERS: Thank you for your time.
THE PRESIDENT: Would you have anything to say
column2: Tom
column3: generally speaking?

column1: SECRETARY PRICE: Well
column2: let me start
column3: Mr. President -- really powerful about the consequences of the current law
column4: and you hear people’s lives that have been affected in remarkably adverse ways that sometimes you don't think about as it relates to healthcare -- whether it’s businesses that haven’t been able to survive
column5: or individuals who need to take three
column6: four
column7: five jobs; moms that can't be with their kids when they want. This is about real people. It’s about real patients.

column1: And so working with you and your leadership
column2: we are really excited about the opportunity to put in place a patient-centered system where patients and families and doctors are making decisions
column3: and not Washington
column4: D.C.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: What about the concept that -- and everybody knows it’s happening -- that Obamacare is imploding
column2: that if we don't do anything
column3: it’s not even going to be around in another year? The insurance companies are fleeing. But now it seems to be getting this wonderful press like it’s a wonderful thing
column4: and it’s a horrible thing actually
column5: and getting worse. And ’17 will be
column6: by far

column1: SECRETARY PRICE: Yes.
THE PRESIDENT: Because a lot of things were put into ’17. But ’17 is going to be worse
column2: and I assume ’18 will be worse even than ’17. So it’s essentially gone. How do you respond to that? Because I’ve been telling you
column3: ""Why don't we wait? Just let it implode
column4: and let’s not take the blame."" I’ve been telling you that as an option. It’s not an option I like
column5: frankly
column6: but it’s certainly an option. How do you respond to that?

column1: SECRETARY PRICE: I think ’18 can be better if we implement the law and we utilize the regulatory process to make some --
THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: I’m not saying that. I’m saying
column3: if we don't implement the law
column4: what happens with Obamacare? What’s going on with Obamacare?

column1: SECRETARY PRICE: What you’ll see is a magnification of all these stories around this table: more businesses being harmed
column2: more individuals not having the kind of income that they -- disposable income that they would use
column3: more moms and dads not able to care for their kids in the way that they believe to be most appropriate
column4: more people getting insurance but no care. This is about real people’s lives
column5: and that's why it’s so important.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Getting insurance but not being able to use it because the deductibles are so high.
SECRETARY PRICE: That's exactly right.
THE PRESIDENT: And you hear these stories where they're paying a fortune for insurance
column2: and then you hear how high their deductible is. And unless they have a tragedy in their family
column3: they're never going to be able to use it.

column1: SECRETARY PRICE: Yes
column2: this fellow has to -- $13
column3: 000 before the insurance kicks in. That's what he has to pay -- $13

column1: MR. SEIFE: That's like not having insurance.
SECRETARY PRICE: That's like not having insurance.
THE PRESIDENT: Well
column2: keep working it.

column1: MS. SERTICH: They're catastrophic plans now.
SECRETARY PRICE: Exactly.
THE PRESIDENT: He’s been working very hard
column2: and he’s doing a great job.

column1: Mr. Vice President
column2: do you have anything to say?

column1: THE VICE PRESIDENT: Mr. President
column2: I think what unequivocally these great Americans see in high relief is you're someone who puts people over politics. And I just want to thank all of them for coming
column3: and in front of the national media
column4: talking about the real world and impacts of Obamacare. You've said it consistently over the last two years that Obamacare has failed. But these people are emblematic of the Americans that Obamacare has failed. And I just am so grateful for their time
column5: but so grateful for your compassionate leadership in driving the Congress and driving our nation toward better healthcare outcomes for them and better solutions built on those American principles of more consumer choices
column6: more free market
column8: as you said
column9: the caring for the most vulnerable by allowing our states to innovate and medicate in ways that will create even better healthcare coverage than they have today.

column1: THE PRESIDENT: Thank you
column2: Mike. Thank you
column3: everybody. Thank you very much.

column1: Q Mr. President
column2: do you have any message for those who are concerned about losing their insurance
column3: whether it be Medicaid or higher costs (inaudible)?

column1: THE PRESIDENT: It will get better. If we're allowed to do what we want to do
column2: it will get better -- much better. Hopefully it will get very good.

column1: Q So will it take long?
THE PRESIDENT: It takes a period of time. Thank you
column2: press.

column1: END
12:00 P.M. EDT"	['https://web.archive.org/web/20170313220530im_/https://www.whitehouse.gov/sites/whitehouse.gov/files/images/twitter_cards_default.jpg'

column1: Zero

column2: 000 support troops? 18
