column1: 0	"'This Week' Transcript: McKay
column2: Napolitano
column3: Salazar and Allen

column1: Transcript: ""This Week"" with Lamar McKay McKay
column2: Janet Napolitano
column3: Ken Salazar and Thad Allen

column1: TAPPER: Good morning. We'll get to our main story on the oil spill in a moment
column2: but first a breaking news from overnight. A car bomb discovered in New York's Times Square. Police cleared thousands of people from the streets after finding an SUV loaded with propane tanks
column3: gasoline
column4: black powder and a timing device
column5: the makings of what appeared to be a crude car bomb. The situation is now safe
column6: but joining me this morning is Secretary of Homeland Security Janet Napolitano. And Secretary Napolitano
column7: I just wanted to ask you a couple of questions about this.

column1: First of all
column2: I know that the federal government is treating this as a potential terrorist attack and that you have some evidence
column3: you're dusting for fingerprints. But this attempted attack resembles car bomb attempts in London and Scotland in 2007. How concerned are you that this is not an isolated incident?

column1: NAPOLITANO: Well
column2: right now
column3: we have no evidence that it is anything other than a one-off
column4: but we are alerting state
column5: local officials around the country
column6: letting them know what is going on. The forensics are being done. As leads evolve or develop
column7: they will all be tracked down. This is getting attention. FBI
column8: Department of Homeland Security

column1: TAPPER: I got to think that Times Square is one of the most surveilled areas in the entire world. How close are we to finding a suspect?
NAPOLITANO: Well
column2: right now
column3: it is heavily surveilled
column4: and as you know
column5: there are cameras all over
column6: and so tape is being reviewed. But traditional forensics are being done in addition to that. Looking for fingerprints
column8: the license plate number
column9: looking at the timer -- the (inaudible) of the explosive device. Right now it doesn't look like it's all a very sophisticated one
column11: but looking into that. So there is a lot of work that's being done
column12: and then of course other intel being developed
column13: and that will evolve as the day goes on.

column1: TAPPER: How concerned should the American people be?
NAPOLITANO: Well
column2: Times Square I think is now safe
column3: and I believe that right now
column4: we have no information other than it is a one-off. But nonetheless
column5: we are alerting state and local law enforcement
column6: everybody to be on their toes.

column1: TAPPER: OK
column2: great. We'll come back to you and other Obama administration officials in a second. Right now
column3: we're going to turn to our main interview
column4: and that is the President Obama is heading down to the Gulf Coast this morning for his own assessment of the oil spill
column5: a massive slick almost the size of Connecticut. It's making its way to the Louisiana coast
column6: threatening wild life
column7: the environment and the economic livelihood of residents there. Meanwhile
column8: efforts to plug the gush almost a mile below the surface have failed.

column1: Joining me now for an exclusive interview is Lamar McKay
column2: chairman and president of BP America
column3: which owned the well and was leasing the rig that blew up. He joins us from company headquarters in Houston. Mr. McKay
column4: thanks for joining us
column5: and first of all
column6: our condolences to the families of the workers who lost their lives.

column1: MCKAY: Thank you
column2: Jake
column3: and thank you for the opportunity to be here today. This has been a tragic event. As you mentioned
column4: we had 11 people lose their lives. We've had people seriously injured
column5: and we've got an event of enormous proportion that we're dealing with.

column1: TAPPER: OK
column2: BP's plans to stop this leak include an underwater dome that you're trying to build to contain the leak
column3: and a whole other rig to drill a relief well
column4: what is the latest on the situation? The relief well could take up to three months to drill. Where are we in this process?

column1: MCKAY: Jake
column2: let me explain for your viewers exactly what's going on. We've got effectively three fronts of attack that we are aggressively pursuing in partnership with the government. One is effectively stopping the source
column3: stopping the well from flowing. The second one is as -- and these are in parallel -- is to work a containment system
column4: a collection system sub-sea to be able to effectively channel the flow up a pipe and into a processing system that we can control at the surface. Then the third is dealing aggressively
column5: aggressively with the spill offshore and trying to fight that spill offshore
column6: and the fourth is to deal with the -- deal with the
column7: if the oil touches the shore
column8: to deal with the cleanup and deal with the impacts on shore. Those are sorts of the fronts that are under way.

column1: You mentioned the containment system. We call it the containment dome. That has been fabricated. The engineering is being finalized to get that mobilized and deployed. That will probably be in six to eight days
column2: we'll have that deployed.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: just so you know
column3: we're still working hard
column4: still working hard on the blowout preventer and see if we can actuate this piece of evidently failed equipment. And as you can imagine
column5: this is like doing open-heart surgery at 5
column6: 000 feet
column8: with robot-controlled submarines.

column1: TAPPER: The government says currently 5
column2: 000 barrels of oil a day are spilling into the gulf. Some experts say it might be five times that
column4: 000 barrels of oil a day. How much oil do you think is spilling into the gulf?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: the estimates of how much oil is coming out are very difficult because you can't measure in any way accurately
column3: so effectively what we're doing with the help of NOAA and the rest of the government agencies is understand that volume that is inferred essentially by surface expression on the top of the water. So I don't know the volume. The volume uncertainty -- there is a large uncertainty range around the 5
column4: 000 barrels.

column1: Our spill response is designed to take that uncertainty into account
column2: and we're responding for that full range of uncertainty with all the resources that we can
column3: in conjunction with the government.

column1: TAPPER: Obama administration officials have expressed in recent days concerns that BP is not doing enough. Other officials have said that you don't have the resources. Should the government take over this operation?
MCKAY: I think we're
column2: as we said from day one
column3: we're throwing every resource that we've got at this
column4: and this is now an industry effort. It's not just a BP effort. It's an effort in conjunction with the government. And I think the partnership that we've got between industry and the government has rallied an effort that is unprecedented in size
column5: and I think that that effort is actually working pretty well. It will continue to be flexed and expanded where it needs to
column6: and I think
column8: the point here is we are doing everything possible that we know of -- and I believe I'm talking about the collective we here -- to control the source first. That's our first priority. While in parallel
column9: fighting the thing offshore as far as -- as far as possible and as effectively as possible
column10: and then dealing with the cleanup and issues and impacts on shore should they occur.

column1: TAPPER: Your company
column2: BP
column3: has a spotty safety record
column4: most horrifically in 2005
column5: an explosion at a refinery in Texas that killed 15 workers; other incidents involving leaks have been blamed on cutting corners on financial reasons. How confident are you that this accident had nothing to do with cutting back on safety to save a buck?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: the investigations are going to show the cause of this accident
column3: and we want those investigations to be done. My belief that is that that does not have anything to do with it. I believe we've got a failed piece of equipment. We don't know why it failed yet in this contracted rig
column4: and BOP system will figure that out.

column1: But let me just tell you
column2: our focus
column3: our focus right now is dealing with the source of the oil
column4: dealing with it on the surface
column5: and dealing with it on the beach or the marsh if it occurs.

column1: TAPPER: Your initial filing to the government
column2: to the Mineral Management Service for 2009 before you drilled on this spot made this assessment
column3: quote
column4: ""An accidental oil spill could cause impact to the beaches. However
column5: due to the distance to shore
column6: 48 miles
column7: and the response capabilities that would be implemented
column8: no significant adverse impacts are expected. BP Exploration and Production Incorporated has the capability to respond to the maximum extent practicable to a worst-case discharge
column13: and yet BP does not seem to have the capability to respond. How can the public trust BP's assessments of risk and how can the public trust anything you guys say?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: I think we are responding very
column3: very aggressively. As you may know
column4: we had a response planned
column5: filed for the drilling of this well that incorporates various capability around the Gulf Coast. That spill response plan was activated as soon as this event occurred. It has been extremely aggressive. It will continue to be extremely aggressive
column6: and I believe the response -- this is
column8: we must understand
column9: this is -- this is a very low likelihood but very high impact response -- sorry
column10: incident -- and the response is matching that incident.

column1: TAPPER: I just have a couple more questions. Just a few months ago
column2: a BP executive protested proposed new safety regulations for oil rigs
column3: writing to the government that quote
column4: ""while BP is supportive of companies having a system in place to reduce risks
column5: accidents
column6: injuries and spills
column7: we are not supportive of extensive proscriptive regulations."" Will BP continue to fight and lobby against safety regulations?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: I would characterize the letter you're talking about slightly differently. That letter was in response to the government's request for input on safety regulations that the MMS was looking at. The rest of the letter actually recommends improvements and specific recommendations around safety regulations should they choose to change them. So we're not fighting anything about safety. Safety is the number one priority. We're going to figure out what happened here
column3: and that is going to help the MMS and help ourselves and help the industry get safer
column4: so we're not fighting anything about safety.

column1: TAPPER: All right
column2: last question
column3: Mr. McKay. You had several fail/safe mechanisms on this rig
column4: and they all failed. Since you don't yet know what caused this accident
column5: will you stop all operations until you know? How can the American people trust that there won't be another explosion at another BP facility?

column1: MCKAY: Well
column2: we're working in conjunction with the government on understanding everything we can understand as quickly as we can. We're not going to do anything that we think is unsafe. We're doing extra tests on various pieces of equipment to make absolutely sure they will work in the condition they're intended to work in.

column1: We won't do any work if we don't think it can be carried out safely and without impact. But we are working very closely with the government in trying to understand this and see if there should be any changes quickly.
TAPPER: All right. Lamar McKay
column2: thank you so much for joining us. We really appreciate your time.

column1: MCKAY: Thank you.
TAPPER: And we're now joined by a powerhouse roundtable. As always
column2: George Will
column3: from the National Action Network
column4: the Reverend Al Sharpton
column5: from HBO's ""Real Time with Bill Maher
column6: Bill Maher
column8: and Katrina vanden Heuvel from The Nation.

column1: Thanks
column2: one and all.

column1: George
column2: I've heard some conservative critics say that this oil slick is President Obama's Katrina. Is it?

column1: WILL: No. It might come as a news bulletin to the president himself
column2: but he's not responsible for everything
column3: and bad things happen. This is a reality check for a nation that's ravenous for energy and has to be and always has been. Getting our sources of energy has risks.

column1: The Exxon Valdez called our attention to the fact that it's very dangerous shipping oil across the surface of the ocean. Since the Exxon Valdez
column2: there have been seven larger tanker spills. You can go up to West Virginia
column3: where 29 miners are being mourned today
column4: and they will tell you about the risks of mining coal. No one says stop mining coal because of this.

column1: TAPPER: Reverend
column2: some critics -- not just from the right -- are saying that the Obama administration was slow. The New York Times editorial board faulted the Obama administration. Is that unfair criticism?

column1: SHARPTON: Well
column2: I think so. I think that when you look at the fact that
column3: first of all
column4: this has been an evolving crisis -- this did not happen -- unlike Katrina
column5: where you had a natural disaster that immediately blanketed the whole area and we were watching it live on television
column6: this got worse over time.

column1: And I think that there's evidence that the White House has put out -- I've not talked to them
column2: but I've read this on their Web site -- of how they met each rising crisis with personnel there
column3: cabinet members there
column4: now the president going
column5: unlike George Bush
column6: that said he didn't see the crisis
column7: and we sat there four or five days and watched it live on television. So I think any analogy is absolutely ridiculous.

column1: TAPPER: Bill
column2: I was watching your show Friday night...

column1: MAHER: Morning.
TAPPER: ... and you said
column2: in language more suitable for premium cable...

column1: MAHER: I promise I won't here. They're so nervous about that.
TAPPER: ... that you're surprised President Obama isn't getting more
column2: shall we say
column3: guff for...

column1: MAHER: Exactly.
TAPPER: ... for this crisis.
MAHER: Yes
column2: I think he should. You know
column3: he owns this issue now
column4: because it was only a few weeks ago that he came out for offshore drilling. And I would say philosophically this is -- you know
column5: the problem
column6: I think
column7: a lot of people on the left have with this country and have for many years
column8: is that there's no one who really represents our point of view.

column1: There's two parties who want to fight the war on terror with an army in Afghanistan. There's two parties who want to drill offshore. Where is the other side on this?
So
column2: you know
column3: I could certainly criticize oil companies
column4: and I could criticize America in general for not attacking this problem in the '70s. I mean
column5: Brazil got off oil in the last 30 years. We certainly could have.

column1: But it is very disappointing
column2: I think
column3: for this president to be taking a position
column4: as he had -- and I guess he's backpedaling now on it
column5: I hope. I mean
column6: I hope there's a flip-flop I can believe in there. But...

column1: TAPPER: There's a slogan for you
column2: flip-flops I can believe in.

column1: MAHER: I could believe in that one
column2: and I hope he does.

column1: TAPPER: Matt
column2: where's the public on this issue?

column1: DOWD: Well
column2: I think the public -- I mean
column3: first of all
column4: the public doesn't think there's any equal nature to Katrina and this. I mean
column5: Katrina
column6: obviously
column7: evacuated -- having to evacuate an entire area and what that issue was
column8: was such a different issue than this.

column1: But I think where the public is on this
column2: if you put this in the context of what happened in West Virginia and the mine disaster and this in context of Katrina
column3: even though it was different
column4: and this in context in many things
column5: I think the public sits there and says
column6: ""Who's in charge? Who is accountable
column7: and who can -- what governmental entity can actually be effective in doing anything?""

column1: And I think that ultimately is where the public is. It's just another example of a fact that we cannot trust the government to do anything that we need them to do
column2: from mines to even a belief (ph) on health care to -- to the oil spill. It's a loss of faith
column3: I think
column4: again
column5: in the government.

column1: VANDEN HEUVEL: What we've seen are the risks are too great. Offshore drilling is the problem
column2: not the solution. This is not Katrina
column4: 500 dead
column5: hundreds of thousands homeless.

column1: I think more important is to understand that we now need a government that is going to regulate a company
column2: BP
column3: which was a serial abuser of workers and of safety regulations. Just like Massey
column4: we need regulations...

column1: TAPPER: Massey
column2: with the -- with the West Virginia mine.

column1: VANDEN HEUVEL: ... tough enforcement -- the mines -- we need a government that understands that. I would also point out that this was the week that for the first time an offshore wind farm was approved. And George Will may not see a future in that
column2: but I believe we need a Manhattan Project
column3: an Apollo Alliance to ramp up public and private investment.

column1: At the moment
column2: energy companies spend 0.25 percent on R&D. We can do better. We are a nation which should do better
column3: George
column4: and not rely on dirty energy
column5: which just compounds the problem affecting this country and the planet.

column1: TAPPER: Mr. Will
column2: your name has been invoked.

column1: WILL: Well
column2: one in five steps of an approval process has now been taken for the wind farm
column3: vigorously opposed by people who are all in favor of renewable energy elsewhere
column4: because they think it'll spoil their view.

column1: TAPPER: This is the wind farm off the coast of Massachusetts that a lot of people...
WILL: The wind farm on Cape Cod
column2: yes.

column1: TAPPER: ... including the Kennedy family
column2: were fighting tooth and nail.

column1: WILL: Right. And -- and
column2: by the way
column3: wind farms kill a lot more birds daily than are probably going to be killed in this oil spill.

column1: And so -- but I'd like to go back to Bill. Could you just explain to me in what sense Brazil got off oil?
MAHER: I believe they did. I believe they
column2: in the '70s
column3: they had a program to use sugarcane ethanol. And I believe that is what fuels their country.

column1: WILL: I think they still burn a lot of oil and have a lot of it offshore.
VANDEN HEUVEL: But
column2: George
column3: you're a man who understands there are always alternatives in politics and in science. We can -- you know
column4: why should we be relying on what we are now seeing the risks of?

column1: And
column2: by the way
column3: we can do better with existing oil fields. We can get as much from existing oil fields
column4: which the oil companies for profit reasons aren't doing much with. So I just think we have seen the risks and we need to take action. It is just too much to look at what is going on in the gulf and what will happen if it moves into the Arctic.

column1: And I agree with Bill. I think President Obama was pandering when he moved to this offshore drilling stance. But I think this White House has the ability
column2: unlike previous White Houses
column3: to understand and see the light and take a different step.

column1: MAHER: And could we have judges fact-check this on Brazil? I don't know...
(CROSSTALK)
MAHER: ... dreamed that about Brazil.
(CROSSTALK)
MAHER: ... and Brazil
column2: let's get back to the United States. I think that Katrina's right. I think that there's a challenge here. And I think that the president and the country has to deal with the reality that we're facing.

column1: And I think that the reality is that usually it's not about who's going to speak for the left or right. It's
column2: who's going to be right on these issues? We see what can happen here. Now what do we do about it? And I think that
column3: clearly
column4: a failure to stand up and lead at this point is something that all of us would criticize.

column1: But I'm not convinced that this president won't. I think he's going down there
column2: he's going to reassess. And I think that we've got to see where that goes and if he goes
column3: right
column4: support him
column5: and I think he will.

column1: But I think to act like this is Katrina
column2: I think this is the step without -- beyond the realm of a sane discussion.

column1: TAPPER: OK. We're going to take a quick break and come back
column2: and the roundtable will discuss the far less controversial issue -- that's sarcastic -- about immigration law and Florida Governor Charlie Crist's declaration of independence. And later
column3: of course
column4: the Sunday funnies.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
COLBERT: There is an impending environmental disaster looming right off our nation's fragile coastline. I'm speaking
column2: of course
column3: about the new wind farm off of Cape Cod. What if it breaks and we have a catastrophic wind spill?

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
(UNKNOWN): And if the feds won't come in and protect us
column2: then we will come forward and protect ourselves. We -- we have no other choice. We have -- we have a right
column3: Greta
column4: to feel free in our state and to feel safe. And with what's going on
column5: we have many
column6: many people that feel that they are not safe.

column1: (UNKNOWN): Si se puede! Si se puede! Si se puede!
OBAMA: If you are a Hispanic American in Arizona
column2: if you don't have your papers and you took your kid out to get ice cream
column3: you're going to be harassed
column4: that's something that could potentially happen
column5: that's not the right way to go.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: And we're back with our roundtable. As always
column2: George Will
column3: the Reverend Al Sharpton from the National Action Network
column4: the host of HBO's ""Real Time with Bill Maher
column5: Bill Maher
column6: Matthew Dowd
column8: and Katrina vanden Heuvel of The Nation.

column1: Reverend Sharpton
column2: I want to start with you. You're going to be participating in leading a march and a rally and a vigil in Arizona on Wednesday to protest this immigration reform law. What do you think the citizens of Arizona should do with the fact that there is this big illegal immigration problem?

column1: SHARPTON: Well
column2: first of all
column3: I think we need to have real immigration reform from a federal level. The federal government is supposed to set immigration policy
column4: and I think that all of our forces ought to really try to put the pressure there
column5: which is something all of us advocated doing the last two general elections.

column1: To try and now say that because that has not happened -- and all of us agree it should -- that we're now going to have state law and open the door to racial profiling is what we're objecting to and protesting on Wednesday and have said since the law was signed Friday before last.
And this
column2: unlike many of the critics of those of us that protest this
column3: this is not about protecting illegal immigrants. This is about protecting legal citizens. If you are Hispanic or thought to be Hispanic in the state of Arizona
column4: you can be faced (ph) and subjected to an harassment that other citizens should not. That's a violation of equal protection under the law.

column1: We would not tolerate that to people that look like George if this was a law saying we're looking for people that look Canadian in the state of Vermont. That would be racial profiling.
Citizens that are here
column2: that have -- that have not broken any laws should not be subjected to anything different than any other citizens. It's not about illegal immigrants. It's about legal Latino citizens that should not be targeted
column3: and this law does that.

column1: TAPPER: Matthew?
DOWD: To me
column2: Arizona is a sideshow
column3: and it's symptomatic of a bigger problem. And I don't think this is about the Arizona law. This is about people in a state -- and it's out going on all over the country -- that they see a federal government that's unwilling to enforce a law that's already on the books.

column1: There is an immigration law on the books. It is illegal to come into this country. Arizona for years and years and years
column2: including under the previous guest
column3: Governor Napolitano
column4: has asked the federal government to enforce the law
column5: which they refuse to do in this -- in this context.

column1: So it's not about a new law passed. It's about a state says that we think the federal government should enforce the law. They're not enforcing the law
column2: so we're going to enforce the law.

column1: I don't think it's the right response. I think we need the federal government to step up and actually perform an immigration policy. But it's not about Arizona.
(CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: The federal law...
TAPPER: Reverend Sharpton...
(CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: ... does not say that
column2: based on reasonable suspicion of the police
column3: they can go after someone which targets people that are Latino
column4: since you're dealing with a problem with Mexicans coming across the border. The federal law does not say that
column5: does not target that. We agree the federal laws should be looked at
column6: reformed
column8: but to say that you're going to sacrifice the civil rights of Latinos and people of color because the federal government has not moved forward

column1: TAPPER: George?
WILL: The Arizona law does not say that there should be racial profiling. And let me tell you what the...
(CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: Well
column2: then why did they just reform it over the weekend...

column1: (CROSSTALK)

WILL: Let me tell you what the federal law says. ""Every alien 18 years of age and older shall at all times carry with him and have in his personal possession a certificate of alien registration or alien registration receipt card issued to him."" That's been federal law for 58 years.
All that Arizona has done is say we at the state level are going to reinforce the federal law. This is legal. In 2008
column2: the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals
column3: the most liberal circuit court in this country
column4: affirmed the constitutionality of an Arizona law that made it a state crime for employers to hire illegal immigrants. This is not bizarre behavior on Arizona's part.

column1: SHARPTON: The state law does not say -- the state law says that a policeman
column2: under reasonable suspicion -- it did not -- it does not say that in the federal law -- can go and make someone produce and document their citizenship. It does not say what you just read...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: With all due respect
column2: Mr. Will
column3: that is not what that federal law says. And the recognition of that is the state of Arizona's legislature just refined what they said over the weekend. They conceited that we were right and they had to refine it.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
WILL: ... 50 years of case law refining the concept of reasonable suspicion. This is not a blank slate
column2: Reverend.

column1: VANDEN HEUVEL: Mr. Will
column2: why is the law enforcement community in Arizona so deeply divided? I find that an interesting problem.

column1: SHARPTON: Absolutely.
VANDEN HEUVEL: You have police chiefs who believe that this will endanger the public safety and security of the state and its citizens. You also have -- these are pragmatic
column2: not moral reasons
column3: even though this bill is state-sanctioned racial profiling and draconian
column4: ugly
column5: mean-spirited -- but you have a $3 billion budget deficit in Arizona. This may well loot that state's treasury as they fight this bill.

column1: You're going to have economic boycotts
column2: which you disagree with
column3: but you're going to have them
column4: as you had them to push that state to respect Martin Luther King holiday.

column1: And finally
column2: you have a situation where the crime rates in Arizona have declined over this last decade
column3: and you have a border guard which has tripled since 2004. The budget has increased money for security. I personally think the security piece is overstated. You want to ensure an orderly flow of people and goods. But you need a humane pathway to citizenship.

column1: TAPPER: Bill
column2: what do you say to Arizona's citizens who are frustrated with the federal government
column3: the law is not being enforced
column4: there is an influx of illegal immigrants -- some of them
column5: obviously not all of them
column6: but some of them are involved in crimes -- what are they supposed to do?

column1: MAHER: Well
column2: I would hope the Constitution of the country is a little more important to them. I know that's asking a lot.

column1: WILL: What constitutional provision does this violate?
MAHER: Well
column2: I mean
column3: nobody's been able to articulate a scenario where the police are stopping people for any other reason than they look Mexican and poor. You know
column4: it kind of reminds me of -- what
column5: was it Potter Stewart on the Supreme Court said about pornography
column6: ""I know it when I see it""? That seems to be the standard the police are now using with immigration.

column1: TAPPER: I think what...
SHARPTON: There's something called equal protection under the law.
(CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: The law has -- the law has -- to be fair to Governor Jan Brewer of Arizona
column2: she signed an executive order the same day that she signed a law that said that a person's race alone cannot be enough to be reasonable suspicion. There needs to be more than...

column1: SHARPTON: And now she's come back this weekend with something else. So are we going to keep redoing it? I think you'd have to concede that had this not been raised and these protests had not -- they would not themselves be now doing the moonwalk against their own bill.
DOWD: Jake
column2: I think the situation is -- we keep falling back into an Arizona problem. The majority of the country...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: People in Arizona have an Arizona problem.
DOWD: No
column2: the people of this country have an immigration problem.

column1: SHARPTON: I agree.
DOWD: The majority of this country supports what Arizona did
column2: the majority of the country. And two-thirds of people in Arizona support this. Do I think that the Arizona response is the right thing? No. But do I think that it represents a frustration with the federal government
column3: just like what's going on in Wall Street -- the people of this country see Washington -- Democrats and Republicans -- complicit in what we do.

column1: We don't enforce the laws on Wall Street
column2: so we have a huge problem there. We don't enforce the immigration laws
column3: so states like Arizona react in this way
column4: which I don't think is actually reasonable. But I -- it's reasonable for them to be frustrated with the problem.

column1: TAPPER: Bill?
MAHER: The government intrusion
column2: you know
column3: government power is something that really bothers conservatives
column4: unless it's directed toward people who aren't white. You know
column5: I mean
column6: it does seem like there's some of that going on there. I mean...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: Let me just interject. To be fair to conservatives
column2: Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell
column3: a conservative Republican
column4: and Florida Congressman Connie Mack have had some tough words about parts of this law. Here's McDonnell on Tuesday.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MCDONNELL: I'm concerned about the whole idea of carrying papers and always have to be able to prove your citizenship. That brings up shades of some other regimes that were not particularly helpful to democracy and civil rights.
(END VIDEO CLIP)
TAPPER: And Florida Congressman Connie Mack said in a press release
column2: ""This law of frontier justice
column3: where law enforcement officials are required to stop anyone based on reasonable suspicion that they may be in the country illegally
column4: is reminiscent of a time during World War II when the Gestapo in Germany stopped people on the street and asked for their papers without probable cause.""

column1: George
column2: these are conservative Republicans
column3: very -- I mean
column4: nobody would question Bob McDonnell's bona fides as a conservative. And they are voicing serious concern about this law.

column1: WILL: Yes. To enter Mr. McDonnell's Capitol building or to enter the House office building where Connie Mack works
column2: you have to show a government-issued ID. I mean
column3: this is -- this is synthetic hysteria by a herd of independent minds called our political class right now that has decided to stand up and worry about the Constitution being shredded by measures that have ample history of being sustained against constitutional challenges.

column1: Now
column2: Mr. Maher just said
column3: if I heard him right
column4: that conservatives basically are racists and they like government intrusion only against people who aren't white. I mean
column5: that's the level...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: We'll come to you in one second...
(CROSSTALK)
MAHER: Can you -- can you imagine if some of the -- what's going on with the Tea Party rallies
column2: if they were a group of black people
column3: you know
column4: waving guns
column5: coming up armed
column6: talking about how you might -- you know
column7: hinting about how you might have to take matters into your own hands if the government doesn't do what you want? Do you think the reaction in this country would be...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: ... very important point that needs to be addressed. When you say
column2: Mr. Will
column3: that if you go to Mr. McDonnell's building or Congressman Mack's building
column4: you have to show ID
column5: that is the point. Everyone has to show ID. They do not have guards stand there and say
column6: ""Only you that I deem to be reasonably suspect because I think you come from a particular group that may be entering the building to do harm
column7: we're going to search you."" Everyone is searched.

column1: This is not the case in the Arizona law. This is not the case of what's going on in the raids with Sheriff Arpaio there. And this is not what we're protesting. If everyone was subjected to that
column2: like the buildings you referred to
column3: there would be no cause for concern.

column1: VANDEN HEUVEL: And for George to talk about synthetic hysteria
column2: I mean
column3: your colleague at the Washington Post
column4: Michael Gerson
column5: took serious issue with the column you wrote underneath
column6: saying that this issue is going to sort Republicans and conservatives politically

column1: I think Latino-bashing
column2: which is what this is
column3: is ultimately political suicide for the Republican Party. I also think...

column1: WILL: Have you read the Democratic immigration bill?
VANDEN HEUVEL: I also think that
column2: on the media front
column3: I very much hope that Reverend Sharpton's march in Arizona next week
column4: as the marches on Wall Street demanding accountability for jobs lost and greed
column5: what it's done to this country
column6: get the same attention as six Tea Partiers amassed on a corner get in the media.

column1: (CROSSTALK)
MAHER: Let me defend myself
column2: because I was -- just what he said about rephrasing my -- I would never say -- and I have never said
column3: because it's not true -- that Republicans
column4: all Republicans are racist. That would be silly and wrong. But nowadays
column5: if you are racist
column6: you're probably a Republican.

column1: TAPPER: Well
column2: let's leave that...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
MAHER: And that is quite different.
TAPPER: Let's leave that topic -- that's a -- that's a whole other roundtable conversation.
But
column2: George
column3: you did bring up a topic about the Democratic immigration reform bill that I wanted to touch on
column4: because Democrats are now shopping around -- they're trying to find Republican co-sponsors for their immigration reform bill. And it is a tough immigration reform bill. I mean
column5: it does have a path to citizenship
column6: but it also has some tough measures in there.

column1: WILL: It says enforcement first
column2: close the border
column3: later we will worry about comprehensive reform. It could have been written by Republicans.

column1: TAPPER: And
column2: also
column3: part of it is -- and
column4: Bill
column5: you touched on this on your show the other night -- is it has a national ID card. Here's part of the Democratic bill that says
column6: ""The card will possess biometric identifiers in the form of templates that definitively tie the individual user to the identity credential within five years of the date of enactment. This fraud-proof Social Security card will serve as the sole acceptable document to be produced by an employee to an employer for employment verification purposes.""

column1: This is the Democratic bill.
SHARPTON: So I'm sure Mr. Will is going to endorse that this morning and make news.
TAPPER: Well
column2: but do you have an issue with that?

column1: SHARPTON: I'm asking him.
TAPPER: But I'm asking you
column2: and it's my show. Do you -- do you -- do you...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: Do you have an issue with that?
SHARPTON: I would have some very serious questions about some of the aspects of the Democratic bill
column2: but I'm going to see what ultimately ends up being the Democratic bill. And I'm sure a lot of us in the civil rights community will question parts of it.

column1: What I go back to
column2: though
column3: it is interesting to me that those on the right that is headed by Brother Will here has not cheered this on. If he said it could have been written by a Republican
column4: then why didn't he write in his column this morning that he supports it?

column1: WILL: What enforcement of immigration laws do you support?
SHARPTON: You don't answer a question with a question. I'm asking you
column2: would you support the bill...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
WILL: Let the record show...
(CROSSTALK)
WILL: Let the record show that the Reverend Sharpton stipulates no enforcement...
(CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: ... answer to my question.
(CROSSTALK)
VANDEN HEUVEL: ... overweighted on enforcement.
SHARPTON: Absolutely.
VANDEN HEUVEL: By the way
column2: I think the security card is a non-starter
column3: because you have the coalition of privacy advocates meeting those who are deeply suspicious of government. I don't think that goes anywhere.

column1: But I do think we need to fight for a comprehensive reform bill
column2: and the Republicans are not signing on anything.

column1: DOWD: OK
column2: so -- so we can give some proper history to this
column3: the first person to really offer and push for comprehensive immigration reform was George W. Bush
column4: which the Democrats and every -- at every place and every time on everything tried to stop. To me...

column1: VANDEN HEUVEL: Not Senator Kennedy.
DOWD: ... if we don't -- to me
column2: this conversation is another example why people that tune in and people that think they're going to get an answer from Washington
column3: from Democrats or Republicans
column4: on almost any issue
column5: whether it's protecting the environment
column6: whether it's stopping things on Wall Street
column8: whether it's enforcement of any law
column9: that is why they're fed up.

column1: Now
column2: we can discount the Tea Party movement and say
column3: ""Oh
column4: they're a bunch of crazies."" They are symptomatic of a situation in the country which has lost total faith and trust in what goes on...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: We only have -- Katrina
column2: I'm sorry -- we only have 30 more seconds
column3: and
column4: Bill
column5: I do want to give you the last word to respond to George. What should be done to protect the border?

column1: MAHER: I pass.
(CROSSTALK)

VANDEN HEUVEL: There are other movements -- there are other movements outside of Washington. You talked just about the Tea Partiers. The thousands who've massed this past week to protest what Wall Street has done to our economy...
SHARPTON: Absolutely.
VANDEN HEUVEL: ... the immigration rights marches...
(CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: There are clear immigration problems...
(CROSSTALK)
SHARPTON: ... for opening the borders
column2: but that does not excuse violating people's civil rights. One does not have to be sacrificed...

column1: (CROSSTALK)
TAPPER: Reverend Sharpton
column2: I'm afraid we're going to have to leave it there.

column1: SHARPTON: And it's your show.
TAPPER: And it's my show. And you guys will talk about Charlie Crist -- we didn't get time to do that. We'll talk about that in the green room
column2: and the roundtable will continue in the green room on abcnews.com. Later
column3: check out our fact checks. ""This Week"" and PolitiFact have joined together to fact check our newsmakers
column4: only on ""This Week.""

column1: END."	['https://s.abcnews.com/images/site/printlogo.jpg']		'This Week' Transcript: McKay
column2: Napolitano
column3: Salazar and Allen	http://abcnews.go.com

column1: 0	"A fact sheet on Senator Obama's plan to protect consumers is available HERE
Remarks of Senator Barack Obama
Credit Cards Event
Wednesday
column2: June 11

column1: Chicago
column2: Illinois

column1: Before we begin
column2: I just wanted to say a word about the flooding devastating so many communities. We were scheduled to be holding this event in Iowa
column3: but we decided to cancel it because we didn't want to divert state resources from going to help with flood relief.

column1: My heart goes out to the families in Iowa
column2: Wisconsin
column3: Illinois and across the Midwest
column4: who have been forced to flee their own homes
column5: and leave their businesses and communities behind. Right now
column6: many of them are wondering when they'll be able to return
column7: and what they'll find when they get there. Well
column8: we cannot assure them that their communities will be rebuilt overnight
column9: but we can assure them that they will be rebuilt – because we'll work to ensure that the full resources of our state and federal government are there to help. And I will do everything in my power to see to it that those resources get to the people who need them as swiftly as possible.

column1: You know
column2: over the next two weeks
column3: I'm going to be talking a lot about what we can do to build an economy that works for all Americans. Because for families all across this country
column4: our economy hasn't been working for quite some time. I've met Americans who are doing everything right – who are working that extra shift
column5: or taking on that extra job – but are still struggling just to make ends meet. And a big part of the reason is that they're paying $4 a gallon for gas
column6: and skyrocketing costs for groceries
column8: and college tuition – at a time when their wages have stayed the same.

column1: As a result
column2: many of them are falling deeper and deeper into debt
column3: and a lot of that debt is being put onto credit cards. Over the past 15 years
column4: average household credit card debt has tripled. The typical family is now nearly $10
column5: 000 in the red. And bankruptcy rates have steadily climbed over the past year.

column1: Now
column2: let's be honest. Part of why our debt crisis is so bad is that some folks are making reckless decisions – racking up big credit card bills by purchasing flat-screen TVs and other luxury goods that they know they can't afford. And they should have to face the consequences of those decisions.

column1: But many more Americans aren't falling into debt because they made an irresponsible decision; they're falling into debt because credit card companies are pushing them over the edge. For too long
column2: credit card companies have been using unfair and deceptive practices to trick Americans into signing agreements they can't afford. The contracts you sign when you get a card have gone from being one page-long a few decades ago to more than thirty pages-long today. And they're often filled with traps and fine print that only a credit card executive could understand. These companies have been crossing the line to boost their bottom line.

column1: But rather than stop this outrage
column2: Washington has let them get away with it. And it's no wonder – because the credit card companies have spent millions in recent years financing political campaigns and lobbying Congress to get laws written to their liking. In the first quarter of this year alone
column3: one such industry group spent nearly $800
column4: 000 on lobbying.

column1: This has to stop. We cannot let the rules of the game continue to be rigged against ordinary Americans. We need a President who will look out for the interests of hardworking families
column2: not just their big campaign donors and corporate allies.

column1: And that will be a real difference in this election
column2: because when it comes to Washington letting credit card companies get away with all this
column3: John McCain has been part of the problem. When he had the chance to help families avoid falling into debt
column4: John McCain sided with the credit card companies. When he had the chance to protect teenagers and college students from deceptive credit card practices
column5: he sided with the credit card companies. And when I fought against the credit card industry's bankruptcy bill that made it harder for working families to climb out of debt
column6: he supported it – and he even opposed exempting families who were only in bankruptcy because of medical expenses they couldn't pay.

column1: Just look at the proposals he's been making on this campaign. He's calling for nearly $2 trillion in corporate tax cuts over the next decade
column2: but he hasn't even proposed a single measure to protect hardworking Americans from credit card companies that are trying to take advantage of them.

column1: Well
column2: that's not the kind of change that the folks I've met are looking for. They're looking for a President who will fight for them
column3: and restore fairness to our economy. That's the kind of President I'll be. I'll put a middle class tax cut into the pockets of hardworking families – a tax cut that will give 95% of all families $1
column4: 000 in relief.

column1: I'll eliminate income taxes for seniors making less than $50
column2: 000 a year. And I'll protect the rights of ordinary Americans by cracking down on companies that are trying to deceive them.

column1: That's why back in November
column2: I proposed a plan to help ensure that credit cards don't become the next subprime crisis. It starts with making sure that we have a system that's open and transparent. To help you understand the risks that are involved in signing up for a credit card
column3: I'll create a five-star rating system. That way
column4: Americans can compare credit card companies and avoid those that are stacking the deck against them.

column1: Now
column2: don't get me wrong. We all have a responsibility to pay what we owe. But we have to ensure that the amount we're paying is fair. That's why I've proposed a Credit Card Bill of Rights. The first thing we'll do under this bill of rights is ban unilateral changes to credit card agreements. You should pay the rate you signed up for. If the credit card company wants to raise that rate
column3: you should be able to opt out of the agreement.

column1: Second
column2: we'll ban rate changes on past debt. If a credit card company wants to raise interest rates
column3: then that new
column4: higher rate should apply to the debt you add going forward
column5: not what you already owe. The store can't change the price of what you bought after you bought it and neither should your credit card. Third
column6: we'll ban interest on transaction fees. If you're late in making a payment
column7: you have to pay a late fee. But you shouldn't be paying a fee for paying a fee.

column1: It's time Washington established some rules of the road to level the playing field for hardworking families. It's time we had an economy that worked for companies and consumers alike. That's what my campaign is all about. So the American people will have a clear choice in November: you can choose an approach that sides with the credit card companies when it really counts; or you can choose to finally have a President who looks out for Main Street
column2: not just Wall Street; a President who fights each day to put the American dream within reach for all Americans. And that's the kind of President I intend to be. Thank you." column1: 0	"In February of 2016
column2: we announced the sale of our Etch A Sketch and Doodle Sketch brands in a move designed to allow us to focus on its metal lithography business and invest in its manufacturing operations in Bryan.

column1: Begin official Release:
The Ohio Art Company
column2: a business and community leader for more than 100 years
column3: announced today that it has sold its Etch A Sketch and Doodle Sketch brands in a move designed to allow it to focus on its metal lithography business and invest in its manufacturing operations in Bryan. Ohio Art’s first lithography press was installed in its Bryan
column4: Ohio facility in 1912 and the company has since specialized in precision printing and beautiful color reproduction that is protected to withstand the rigors of stamping and fabrication. The company has been a leader in the metal lithography business for more than a century and company CEO Elena West confirms that
column5: “Ohio Art is squarely focused on continuing to build its reputation as one of the premier metal lithographers in North America.”

column1: The company also underscored its continued commitment to the Bryan
column2: Ohio community and has been working with local business leaders to more effectively utilize its Bryan facility. G&M Media Packaging and Reece Brothers Digital Printers have both signed on as tenants and Wilton Keck Recycling has purchased warehouse space for their upstart commercial recycling business. The company is also leasing warehouse space to two local manufacturers in need of additional staging.

column1: “We are very pleased to be able to partner with these local businesses to provide them with quality space and support services and
column2: most importantly
column3: keep these companies and jobs right here in Bryan
column4: ” notes Martin Killgallon
column5: President. “Our commitment to the community is important to our strategy and we look forward to continuing to partner with other local businesses.”

column1: The Etch A Sketch and Doodle Sketch brands have been sold to Spin Master Corp.
column2: a leading global children’s entertainment company that creates
column3: designs
column4: manufactures and markets a diversified portfolio of innovative toys
column5: games
column6: products and entertainment properties. “We are very happy that children around the world will continue to be able to enjoy Etch A Sketch
column7: one of the world’s most iconic toys
column8: as Spin Master is committed to building upon the success that The Ohio Art Company has created and sustained for more than 50 years

column1: 0	"The government has implemented a new regulation requiring a governor to be placed on all motorcycles by mid-January 2017. The purpose of the mandatory governor would be to prevent motorcyclists from exceeding a speed of 75- miles per hour. The regulation aims to drastically reduce the amount of annual motorcycle fatalities in the United States.
Many are not surprised by the regulation as politicians have been asking for stricter safety features to be implemented on motorcycles for the past several decades. In 2014
column2: the government offered all major motorcycle manufactures including Harley-Davidson
column3: Yamaha
column4: Honda
column5: Ducati
column6: Kawasaki
column8: and BMW a large tax-incentive to begin implementing governors on all newly manufactured motorcycles
column10: all relevant manufactures declined to take advantage of the additional tax-incentive
column11: requiring government officials to return to the drawing board.

column1: Members of the U.S. Department of Transportation or U.D.O.T were supportive of the regulation and heavily involved in its roll-out. According to U.S. Department of Transportation representative James Littleton
column2: the motorcycle governor regulation was long past due and made a comparison to the governors placed on traditional automobiles. Littleton told reporters during a press-conference that each year approximately 8
column3: 265 motorcycle fatalities occur throughout the United States. According to Littleton
column4: the vast majority (approximately 73%) of motorcycle fatalities are the result of motorcyclists driving at unsafe speeds.

column1: When asked why the regulation would only allow motorcyclists to maintain a speed below 75-miles per hour
column2: Littleton made the following comment to reporters
column3: “This is a crucial safety regulation that should have been implemented at least 20-years ago
column4: now that we are finally implementing it
column5: we want to ensure we do it right. With the exception of a few states that allow for 80-miles per mile freeway driving (Idaho
column6: Montana
column8: Utah
column9: and Wyoming) and Texas who allows for speeds of up to 85-miles per hour on the freeway
column10: most states allow a maximum speed of 75-miles per hour. We wanted to make it easy for motorcyclists in most all states to easily obey their respective posted speed limit.”

column1: According to Littleton
column2: motorcyclists in the few states that periodically allow for speeds exceeding 75-miles per hour
column3: governors allowing speeds up to 80-85-miles per hour may eventually be implemented
column4: however in the meantime
column5: police officials in these states have been given direction to avoid citing motorcyclists for such infractions as obstructing the flow of traffic when relevant.

column1: Officials expect all motorcyclists and motorcycle manufactures to be in compliance with the new regulation by mid to late January 2017
column2: however may file for a temporary 30
column4: or 90-day extension under select circumstances. According to Littleton
column5: citations and fines will be imposed on both motorcyclists and motorcycle manufactures who fail to remain in compliance with the regulation.

column1: According to Littleton
column2: designated motorcycle mechanic and auto-body shops in each state will be permitted to install the mandatory governors on motorcycles manufactured and sold prior to the implementation of the regulation at a subsidized rate. Littleton did not have details regarding the government subsidized repair readily available
column3: however told reporters that he expects the subsidized cost to be around $35 to the consumer.

column1: Littleton concluded the press conference by informing reporters that the U.S Department of Transportation is currently working diligently to release all relevant information pertaining to the new regulation on the U.D.O.T website.

0	During a time when the Republican Party’s presumptive nominee
column2: Donald Trump
column3: should be working to bring the party together and prepare for the primary battle against Hillary Clinton
column4: he continues to deepen the divide between Republicans and Americans alike.

column1: Trump’s recent attack on U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel because of his Mexican-American background prompted Sen. Lindsey Graham to round up the Republicans who have previously endorsed Donald Trump
column2: and persuade them to take it all back.

column1: Graham claimed that Trump’s racist remarks were “the most un-American thing from a politician since Joe McCarthy.”
“If anybody was looking for an off-ramp
column2: this is probably it
column3: ” Graham told The New York Times.”

column1: Senator Graham elaborated on this during an interview with NBC News’ Hallie Jackson.
“There are a lot of people who want to be loyal to the Republican Party
column2: including me
column3: ” he said. “But there’ll come a point in time where we’re gonna have to understand that it’s not just about the 2016 race
column4: it’s about the future of the party and I would like to support our nominee. I just can’t.”

column1: Donald Trump claimed that Judge Gonzalo Curiel
column2: who is presiding over the Trump University case
column3: has been biased toward him because of his Latino heritage.

column1: “I couldn’t disagree more with a statement like that
column2: ” Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.) said Sunday.

column1: “Those kinds of comments are very serious to me
column2: ” Rep. Susan Collins (R-Maine) said to News radio WGAN. “They are completely unacceptable
column3: and what they indicate — which is why I think this is so serious — is a lack of respect for our judicial system and for the separation of powers doctrine that is enshrined in the Constitution.”

column1: Although many Republicans
column2: including House Speaker Paul Ryan
column3: have condemned Trump’s accusations
column4: they continue to support him."	['https://web.archive.org/web/20170322070001im_/https://i2.wp.com/truetrumpers.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/michelle-obama.jpg?resize=310%2C165'

column1: 0	"Earlier this week
column2: I spoke at the Freedom Fest in Norfolk
column3: Virginia; and
column4: evidently
column5: the media was asked to leave – not by me
column6: that’s for sure. I want my message out
column7: so despite reporters making up a story about “Palin people kicking us out” (uh
column8: the “Palin people” entourage would consist of one person – my 15-year-old daughter
column9: Willow – and I have no doubt she could take on any reporter
column10: but I know for certain she didn’t “kick ‘em out” of the event). Anyway
column11: here are some of the key issues I spoke about.

column1: DEFENSE SPENDING
It takes a lot of resources to maintain the best fighting force in the world – especially at a time when we face financial uncertainty and a mountain of debt that threatens all of our futures.
We have a federal government that is spending trillions
column2: and that has nationalized whole sections of our economy: the auto industry
column3: the insurance industry
column4: health care
column5: student loans
column6: the list goes on – all of it at enormous cost to the tax payer. The cost of Obamacare alone is likely to exceed $2.5 trillion dollars.

column1: As a result of all these trillion dollar spending bills
column2: America’s going bust in a hurry. By 2020 we may reach debt levels of $20 trillion – twice the debt that we have today! It reminds me of that joke I read the other day: “Please don’t tell Obama what comes after a trillion!”

column1: Something has to be done urgently to stop the out of control Obama-Reid-Pelosi spending machine
column2: and no government agency should be immune from budget scrutiny. We must make sure
column3: however
column4: that we do nothing to undermine the effectiveness of our military. If we lose wars
column5: if we lose the ability to deter adversaries
column6: if we lose the ability to provide security for ourselves and for our allies
column7: we risk losing all that makes America great! That is a price we cannot afford to pay.

column1: This may be obvious to you and me
column2: but I am not sure the Obama Administration gets it. There isn’t a single progressive pet cause which they haven’t been willing to throw billions at. But when it comes to defense spending
column3: all of a sudden they start preaching a message of “fiscal restraint.” Our Defense Secretary recently stated the “gusher” of defense spending was over and that it was time for the Department of Defense to tighten its belt. There’s a gusher of spending alright
column4: but it’s not on defense. Did you know the US actually only ranks 25th worldwide on defense spending as a percentage of GDP? We spend three times more on entitlements and debt services than we do on defense.

column1: Now don’t get me wrong: there’s nothing wrong with preaching fiscal conservatism. I want the federal government to balance its budget right now! And not the Washington way – which is raising your taxes to pay for their irresponsible spending habits. I want it done the American way: by cutting spending
column2: reducing the size of government
column3: and letting people keep more of their hard-earned cash.

column1: But the Obama administration doesn’t practice what it preaches. This is an administration that won’t produce a budget for fear that we discover how reckless they’ve been as fiscal managers. At the same time
column2: it threatens to veto a defense bill because of an extra jet engine!

column1: This administration may be willing to cut defense spending
column2: but it’s increasing it everywhere else. I think we should do it the other way round: cut spending in other departments – apart from defense. We should not be cutting corners on our national security.

column1: THE U.S. NAVY
Secretary Gates recently spoke about the future of the US Navy. He said we have to “ask whether the nation can really afford a Navy that relies on $3 to $6 billion destroyers
column2: $7 billion submarines
column3: and $11 billion carriers.” He went on to ask
column4: “Do we really need... more strike groups for another 30 years when no other country has more than one?”

column1: Well
column2: my answer is pretty simple: Yes
column3: we can and
column4: yes
column5: we do because we must. Our Navy has global responsibilities. It patrols sea lanes and safeguards the freedoms of our allies – and ourselves. The Navy right now only has 286 ships
column6: and that number may decrease. That will limit our options
column8: lessen our ability to secure our allies and deter our adversaries. The Obama administration seems strangely unconcerned about this prospect.

column1: OBAMA’S FOREIGN POLICY INHERITANCE
When George W. Bush came into office
column2: he inherited a military that had been cut deeply
column3: an al Qaeda that had been unchallenged
column4: and an approach to terrorism that focused on bringing court cases rather than destroying those who sought to destroy us. We saw the result of some of that on 9/11.

column1: When President Obama came into office
column2: he inherited a military that was winning in Iraq. He inherited loyal allies and strong alliances. And thanks to the lamestream media pawing and purring over him
column3: he had the benefit of unparalleled global popularity. What an advantage! So their basic foreign policy outlines should have been clear. Commit to the War on Terror. Commit to winning – not ending
column4: but winning the war in Afghanistan. Commit to the fight against violent Islamic extremism wherever it finds sanctuary. Work with our allies. Be resolute with our adversaries. Promote liberty
column5: not least because it enhances our security. Unfortunately
column6: these basic principles seem to have been discarded by Washington.

column1: THE WAR ON TERROR
His administration has banned the phrase “war on terror
column2: ” preferring instead politically correct nonsense like “overseas contingency operations.” His Homeland Security Secretary calls acts of terrorism “man-caused disasters.” His reckless plan to close Guantanamo (because there’s no place to go after it’s closed) faces bipartisan opposition now.

column1: The Attorney General just announced that a decision about where to try terrorists like 9/11 master mind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed would not be announced until after the mid-term elections. Is there something he’s afraid to tell us?

The President’s new National Security Strategy does not even use the word “Islamic” when referring to violent extremism. Does he think the ideology of those who seek to kill Americans is irrelevant? How can we seek to defeat an enemy if we don’t acknowledge what motivates them and what their ultimate goals are? President Obama may think he is being politically correct by dropping the term
column2: but it flies in the face of reality. As Senator Joe Lieberman noted
column3: refusing to use the word Islamic when describing the nature of the threat we face is “Orwellian and counterproductive.”

column1: AFGHANISTAN
In Afghanistan
column2: it is true that President Obama approved deploying additional forces to the conflict – most
column3: but not all the troops requested by commanders on the ground. But it took months of indecision to get to that point
column4: and it came at a very high price – a July 2011 date to begin withdrawal.

column1: This date was arbitrary! It bears no relation to conditions on the ground. It sends all the wrong signals to our friends and to our enemies. We know our commanders on the ground are not comfortable with it.
As that great Navy war hero
column2: Senator John McCain recently put it: “The decision to begin withdrawing our forces from Afghanistan arbitrarily in July 2011 seems to be having exactly the effect that many of us predicted it would: It is convincing the key actors inside and outside of Afghanistan that the United States is more interested in leaving than succeeding in this conflict.”

column1: Does the President really believe the Taliban and al Qaeda won’t be empowered by his naming of a starting date for withdrawal? They now believe they can beat him simply by outlasting us. What sort of effect does he think this will have on the morale of our troops – and of our allies?
ALIENATING OUR ALLIES
It’s not the only area where the Obama administration has failed our allies. They escalated a minor zoning issue in Jerusalem into a major dispute with our most important ally in the Middle East
column2: Israel. They treated the Israeli Prime Minister shabbily in Washington. When a Turkish sponsored flotilla threatened to violate a legal Israeli blockade of Hamas-run Gaza
column3: the Obama Administration was silent. When Israeli commandos were assaulted as they sought to prevent unmonitored cargoes from being delivered to Hamas terrorists
column4: the Obama Administration sent signals it might allow a UN investigation into the matter – an investigation that would be sure to condemn our ally Israel and bemoan the plight of Hamas. Loyal NATO allies in central Europe were undermined by the cancellation of a missile defense program with virtually no warning. At the same time
column5: Russia and China are given preferential treatment
column6: while remaining silent on their human rights violations.

column1: CODDLING ADVERSARIES
Meanwhile
column2: the Obama Administration reaches out to some of the world’s worst regimes. They shake hands with dictators like Hugo Chavez
column3: send letters to the Iranian mullahs and envoys to North Korea
column4: ease sanctions on Cuba and talk about doing the same with Burma. That’s when they’re not on one of their worldwide apology tours.

column1: Do we get anything in return for all this bowing and apologizing? No
column2: we don’t. Yes
column3: Russia voted for a weak sanctions resolution on Iran
column4: but it immediately stated it could sell advanced anti-aircraft missile to Iran anyway
column5: and would not end its nuclear cooperation. In response to North Korea’s unprovoked sinking of a South Korean Navy ship
column6: China warned us not to take part in military exercises with our ally.

column1: And while President Obama lets America get pushed around by the likes of Russia and China
column2: our allies are left to wonder about the value of an alliance with the U.S. They have to be wondering if it’s worth it.

column1: AN “ENEMY-CENTRIC” FOREIGN POLICY
It has led one prominent Czech official to call Obama’s foreign policy “enemy-centric.” And this “enemy-centric” approach has real consequences. It not only baffles our allies
column2: it worries them. When coupled with less defense spending
column3: it signals to the world that maybe we can no longer be counted on
column4: and that we have other priorities than being the world leader that keeps the peace and provides security in Europe
column5: in Asia and throughout the world.

column1: Together with this enemy-centric foreign policy
column2: we see a lessening of the long
column3: bipartisan tradition of speaking out for human rights and democracy. The Secretary of State said she would not raise human rights with China because “we pretty much know what they are going to say.” Democracy promotion programs have been cut. Support for the brave Iranians protesting their government was not forthcoming because President Obama would rather try to cut a deal with their oppressors.

column1: When the world’s dictators see the United States unconcerned with human rights and political freedom
column2: they breathe a sigh of relief
column3: because they know they have a free hand to repress their own people.

column1: This goes against the very ideals on which our republic was founded. There is a long bipartisan tradition of speaking out in favor of freedom – from FDR to Ronald Reagan. America loses something very important when its President consigns human rights and freedom to the back burner of its international priorities.
A DIFFERENT VIEW OF AMERICA
We have a President
column2: perhaps for the very first time since the founding of our republic
column3: who doesn’t appear to believe that America is the greatest earthly force for good the world has ever known.

column1: When asked whether he believed in American exceptionalism
column2: President Obama answered
column3: “I believe in American exceptionalism
column4: just as I suspect that the Brits believe in British exceptionalism and the Greeks believe in Greek exceptionalism.” Amazing. Amazing.

column1: I think this statement speaks volumes about his world view. He sees nothing unique in the American experience? Really? Our founding
column2: and our founding mothers and fathers? Really? And our history over the past two and half centuries?

column1: Really? He sees nothing unique in an America that fought and won two world wars and in victory sought not one inch of territory or one dollar of plunder? He sees nothing unique in an America that
column2: though exhausted by conflict
column3: still laid the foundation for security in Europe and Asia after World War II? He sees nothing unique in an America that prevailed against an evil ideology in the Cold War? Does he just see a country that has to be apologized for around the world
column4: especially to dictators?

column1: President Obama actually seems reluctant to even embrace American power. Earlier this year when he was asked about his faltering Middle East peace process
column2: he said “whether we like it or not
column3: we remain a dominant military superpower.” Whether we like it or not?! Really? Mr. President
column4: this may come as news to you
column5: but most Americans actually do like it. And so do our allies. They know it was our military might that liberated countless millions from tyranny
column6: slavery
column7: and oppression over the last 234 years. Yes
column8: we do like it. As a dominant superpower
column9: the United States has won wars hot and cold; our military has advanced the cause of freedom and kept authoritarian powers in check.

column1: It is in America’s and the world’s best interests for our country to remain the dominant military superpower
column2: but under President Obama’s leadership that dominance may be slipping away. It’s the result of an agenda that reeks of complacency and defeatism.

column1: (I went on from there to talk about our need to end the negative
column2: defeatist attitudes of those in leadership. I spoke further on American exceptionalism
column3: and Willow and I ended a great evening with some great patriots. Sorry the media chose to report anything other than what actually happened at the event.)

column1: - Sarah Palin

0	Getting ballot access can be hard for smaller campaigns with fewer resources. Darrell Castle
column2: the candidate for the Constitution Party
column3: is on the ballot in more than two dozen states. Castle said his campaign has faced ballot access obstacles in California
column4: Texas and Oklahoma. “Those states are virtually impossible for a party like mine because they cost so much money
column5: ” Castle said.

column1: Castle isn’t on the ballot in Oklahoma. To be on the ballot there required signatures from at least 3 percent of all votes cast in the state in 2012
column2: or about 40
column3: 000 signatures. Castle says this would likely require hiring professionals who often charge a few dollars for each signature.

column1: 0	"I came to Washington to fight for a smaller government and get spending under control
column2: not shut the government down. In fact
column3: I have repeatedly voted to fund the government in the last few days.

column1: The shutdown isn't good for anyone in our community or our country. MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa has furloughed more than 1
column2: 500 employees
column3: putting our national security at risk before Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel sent them back to work this week. Veterans in my district are facing a possible future suspension in claims processing. Tax refunds can't go out. Citrus growers can't access the E-Verify system to ensure work authorization is approved
column4: which limits their hiring ability.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: President Barack Obama and Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid have been unreasonable and unwilling to negotiate
column3: which led to this government shutdown. We can end this if they would join us at the table and compromise
column4: but Senate leaders and our president won't budge.

column1: I want to be clear: I have never supported Obamacare and have voted more than 40 times to defund it
column2: delay it
column3: or repeal it. I went a step further and introduced an amendment to the continuing resolution that would ensure that the full extent of Obamacare applies to members of Congress
column4: the president
column5: the vice president and staff. The House passed my amendment with bipartisan support. Unfortunately
column6: the Democratic-controlled Senate hasn't passed any of these bills and refused to even vote on my amendment. We are badly mistaken to think there is any hope of the president eliminating his signature legislation

column1: Shutting down the government has had zero impact on Obamacare. Unfortunately
column2: some were led to believe that Obamacare would immediately cease if the government shut down. The reality is
column3: however
column4: that despite the government being shut down for multiple days
column5: Obamacare continues to be implemented with all of its glitches and problems. That is because about 70 percent of Obamacare is funded through mandatory funding while the current funding battle only addresses discretionary funding — it doesn't even touch mandatory funding.

column1: Since its grand opening on Oct. 1
column2: Obamacare has been an abject failure. Countless technical glitches have prevented enrollees from accessing the online exchanges
column3: and there are endless reports of consumer sticker shock from the high cost of Obamacare insurance premiums. Americans deserve to know that Obamacare is a disaster. Yet these failures and many more have been overshadowed by the government shutdown and the debate over a continuing resolution that
column4: by law
column5: could never fully defund Obamacare.

column1: Obamacare will fall under its own weight of complexities
column2: costs and inconsistencies
column3: all at the expense of the American people. The best way to repeal Obamacare is to let it take effect
column4: point out its impact
column5: win control of the Senate
column6: and elect a president who will support its repeal.

column1: In the few years since I was elected to Congress in 2010
column2: we have achieved huge savings and taken monumental steps. For the first time since the Korean War
column3: total federal spending has gone down for two years in a row. We need to continue to take steps forward
column4: shedding off our ""excessive funding weight"" one pound at a time. That is why I would support a continuing resolution that funds the government at sequestration levels for one year.

column1: We need to get the government running again and end this shutdown so that our communities can get back on their feet.
Rep. Dennis Ross
column2: R-Lakeland
column3: represents the 15th Congressional District that covers part of western Polk and eastern Hillsborough counties
column4: including Brandon and the University of South Florida. He wrote this column exclusively for the Tampa Bay Times."	"['https://www.tampabay.com/resizer/M5BGUbbLQhYV787De9WONsDPfIg=/800x450/smart/arc-anglerfish-arc2-prod-tbt.s3.amazonaws.com/public/KNXW6JGKCII6TODGIBWI6S7HAY.jpg'

column1: 0	"Colorado Rockies Baseball Team To Sell Marijuana Brownies At Their Concession Stands
DENVER
column2: COLORADO –

column1: With the new laws in effect in Colorado
column2: major sports organizations are looking for ways to cash in on the newest legal cash crop in the state.

column1: Sources are reporting that Major League Baseball’s Colorado Rockies plan to sell food items which contain marijuana at concession stands during games next season.
The first item on the list? Pot Brownies.
An official within the Rockies organization stated that the Rockies organization has given the green light to concession stands selling marijuana brownies.
High ranking officials in the Rockies organization say they are thrilled at the new menu item since they note that it will bring in tens of thousands of dollars per month.

The Rockies head office is hoping that the sale of marijuana brownies will also boost sales of other concession items. What better way to sell concessions that to give everyone in the stadium the munchies?

SIDENOTE: An inside source with the organization said that it appears that the strain of marijuana that will be used in the making of the marijuana brownies will be Durango Bango which is considered to be the very best weed in the Rocky Mountain State."
