column2: McCain says By Adam C. Smith
column3: Times Political Editor

column1: In print: Thursday
column2: June 5
column3: 2008 SCOTT KEELER | Times Story Tools E-mail this story Contact the editor Print this story Comment on this story Social Bookmarking [+] Digg Facebook Stumbleupon Reddit Del.icio.us Newsvine ADVERTISEMENT [EDMUND D. FOUNTAIN | Times] Mike Hughes of Largo
column4: Pam Wilson of Indian Rocks Beach and Nora Harvey of Dunedin sit outside the Renaissance Vinoy Resort in St. Petersburg protesting Sen. John McCain’s fundraiser there Wednesday. About 50 people
column5: including Democrats and union members
column6: came out against the presumptive Republican nominee for president
column7: whom they called “McSame” as President Bush. Wilson made signs for the protest. Jack Ganzell of Dunedin
column8: far right
column9: says he came out because he wanted to see what was going on. Related Links Audio: Excerpts of McCain's interview with the Times' Adam Smith ST. PETERSBURG — Charlie Crist may not yet have a full gubernatorial term under his belt
column10: but Sen. John McCain said Wednesday Crist has enough experience to be vice president. ""Oh
column11: I am sure that in many respects Charlie Crist is qualified. He's had other offices. As we know
column12: he was attorney general as well. This is a big and diverse state
column13: McCain said in an interview Wednesday evening before a $1
column14: 000-per-person private fundraising reception. ""But we haven't moved anywhere on the process that he would be under
column15: the presumptive Republican presidential nominee stressed. ""We have a large number of people that we are considering
column16: but I just don't mention anybody's name because then it starts a process that could end up in an invasion of their privacy."" In a taped interview to air Sunday on Political Connections on Bay News 9
column17: McCain said he will reach out to supporters of Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton and noted his independence from President Bush on such issues as government spending and climate control. ""I promise them that I'll be the president of all the people
column18: not just Republicans or anybody else
column20: McCain said. ""I realize that I have to get independents and Democrats if I'm going to win this election."" He also decried the giant Confederate flag that's been proposed to fly near the intersection of Interstates 4 and 75 in Hills­borough County. McCain has faced this issue before
column21: and has voiced profound regret for not taking a stand against a rebel flag atop the South Carolina statehouse during the 2000 GOP primary. ""It's a free country
column22: McCain said of the flag in Hillsborough
column23: but he said the Civil War memorial group behind the flag plans ""should consider the feelings and sensitivities on this issue at a time like this in America where we want to move forward."" Now that the Democratic nominee has been chosen
column24: McCain knows he faces an opponent in Sen. Barack Obama who is more inspiring and energetic on the stump. McCain isn't worried. ""I think people are very interested in substance
column26: he said. McCain also struck on a theme of his campaign
column27: suggesting Obama lacks the experience and knowledge to be president. But polls show a strong majority of American voters think invading Iraq was a mistake
column28: which is what Obama said all along. When asked if Obama showed better judgment in opposing the invasion
column29: McCain defended the war as the right call because ""every intelligence agency in the world believed that (Saddam Hussein) had weapons of mass destruction."" What about Florida's Bob Graham
column30: the former Senate Intelligence Committee chairman who argued at the time that invading Iraq would divert attention and resources from more urgent threats
column31: particularly al-Qaida? ""I respect Sen. Graham enormously
column32: but I don't think there's any doubt that Saddam Hussein
column33: who had acquired and used weapons of mass destruction before
column36: where we had to fight one war with him
column37: that his intent was … to acquire and use weapons of mass destruction
column38: McCain replied. The private fundraising reception at the Renaissance Vinoy Resort in St. Petersburg kicked off a three-day Florida swing
column39: which includes a speech to newspaper editors in Orlando today and an event touting his environmental credentials in the Everglades on Friday. Obama campaign spokesman Bill Burton dismissed McCain's efforts to cast himself as anything but a continuation of President Bush's agenda. ""While John McCain has a record of occasional independence from his party in the past
column40: last year he chose to embrace 95 percent of George Bush's agenda
column41: including his failed economic policies and his failed policy in Iraq
column42: Burton said referring to McCain's voting record. ""No matter how hard he tries to spin it otherwise
column43: that kind of record is simply not the change the American people are looking for or deserve."" McCain said he supports the antigay marriage ballot initiatives in Florida and California
column44: even though the Republican governors of both states have little interest in those efforts. While he voted against a federal marriage amendment proposal
column45: McCain noted that he supported a similar initiative in his home state of Arizona
column46: where voters rejected the idea. ""I think it's important to preserve the unique status of a marriage between men and women
column47: McCain said. ""I respect the views of others who don't hold that view
column48: but I also think that we have a process in our states to amend our constitutions to reflect the will of the majority of the people."" Adam C. Smith can be reached

column1: 0	"Obama Demands Investigation into Subprime Loan Discrimination
Thursday
column2: October 18

column1: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
CONTACT: Amy Brundage
Asks FTC to examine whether minority homeowners are being targeted with high-priced loans
WASHINGTON
column2: D.C. – U.S. Senator Barack Obama (D-IL) today sent the following letter to FTC Commissioner Deborah Platt Majoras
column3: calling on her to investigate the marketing practices of subprime lenders and the brokers of subprime loans to determine whether minority borrowers have been victims of discrimination. According to recent studies
column4: and an editorial in the New York Times
column5: there is increasing evidence that black and Hispanic borrowers were more likely to be steered to high-cost subprime loans than other borrowers. Hundreds of thousands of African American families – many of whom probably should have been eligible for lower cost prime loans instead of riskier subprime loans – could potentially lose their homes in the coming years.

column1: In the letter
column2: Obama requests that the FTC investigate whether there is evidence that lenders or brokers target poor or minority borrowers with higher cost products
column3: whether lenders are engaging in deceptive marketing practices
column4: and whether the lack of lower-cost borrowing options has disproportionately disadvantaged minority borrowers.

column1: The text of the letter is below:
October 18
The Honorable Deborah Platt Majoras
Federal Trade Commission
600 Pennsylvania Avenue
column2: N.W.

column1: Washington
Dear Commissioner Majoras:
I am writing to bring to your attention the attached editorial from yesterday's New York Times which begins: ""Evidence is mounting that during the housing boom
column2: black and Hispanic borrowers were far more likely to be steered into high-cost subprime loans than other borrowers
column3: even after controlling for factors such as income
column4: loan size and property location."" (""Subprime in Black and White
column5: The New York Times
column6: October 17

column1: In reality
column2: such evidence has been mounting since the 1990s when the Clinton Administration found that subprime loans in 1998 were over four times more prevalent in predominantly black neighborhoods in New York than in predominantly white neighborhoods. More recent studies have found similar examples of potentially discriminatory lending patterns.

column1: Last year
column2: for example
column3: the Center for Responsible Lending found that for most types of subprime home loans
column4: minority borrowers are more likely to pay higher rates than white borrowers even after accounting for differences in credit scores
column5: loan to value ratios
column6: and other underwriting criteria. And just this week another analysis confirmed that even high-income black borrowers are more likely than comparable white borrowers to have risky and costly subprime loans.

column1: Black families are paying more for home loans than similarly situated white families. Effective action to address this disparity is long overdue. I call upon the FTC to investigate the marketing practices of subprime lenders and the brokers of subprime loans to determine if minority borrowers have been the victims of discrimination.
Among other things
column2: the Federal Trade Commission is charged with protecting consumers from unfair or deceptive marketing acts or practices. Many subprime loans include sales practices or loan features that are potentially unfair and deceptive for borrowers. Some practices
column3: such as yield-spread premiums
column4: which encourage mortgage brokers to steer borrowers into the most costly products
column5: or prepayment penalties
column6: which enable lenders to offer mortgages that are unsupported by sound underwriting principles
column7: appear to be the source of significant problems faced by many subprime borrowers.

column1: With an estimated 53% of African American borrowers in 2005 receiving subprime loans
column2: and more than 60% of subprime loans containing prepayment penalties
column3: the risks particularly for African American homeowners are substantial. Indeed
column4: hundreds of thousands of African American families – many of whom probably should have been eligible for lower cost prime loans instead of riskier subprime loans – are expected to face loss of their homes in the coming years.

column1: I request that you begin a thorough investigation within five days and provide a status report to my office within 15 days on the following questions:

1) Whether there is evidence of lenders or brokers specifically targeting poor or minority borrowers with higher cost products than would otherwise be justified based on legitimate underwriting criteria.
2) Whether the marketing of lending products to poor or minority borrowers has been deceptive or unfair. Specifically
column2: whether the disclosure of yield-spread premiums and prepayment penalties has been sufficiently transparent to borrowers and whether such or similar sales and pricing practices have been disproportionately detrimental to minority borrowers.

column1: 3) Whether the lack of lower-cost borrowing options
column2: including those regulated by the Federal government
column3: in predominantly minority communities even for higher-income borrowers
column4: has disproportionately disadvantaged minority borrowers in their efforts to realize the dream of affordable home ownership and wealth building.

column1: Thank you for your assistance protecting all consumers from the pernicious affects of predatory and discriminatory lending practices which undermine the American dream.
Sincerely
Barack Obama
United States Senator

0	Barton: Medicare Drug Program Drawing Participants by the Thousands WASHINGTON - U.S. Rep. Joe Barton
column2: R-Texas
column3: chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee
column4: made the following statement today during the full committee hearing on the Administration's FY '07 Health Care Priorities: ""Good afternoon. Let me begin by welcoming Secretary Michael Leavitt today to the Energy and Commerce Committee. We look forward to hearing him testify about the Administration's Fiscal Year 2007 Health Care Priorities. ""First
column5: Mr. Secretary
column6: I want to thank you for your assistance in developing the important reforms we put into place for the Medicaid program starting this year. As a former governor yourself
column7: you understood and appreciated the need to improve this program. Through passage of the Deficit Reduction Act
column8: we will sustain Medicaid for those people who most often need health care and to get good get their health care through good jobs in a thriving economy instead of from a government welfare program. The reforms we adopted recently are beginning to rescue the program from the threat of financial collapse. I look forward to working with you to see that the governors get the tools they need to better manage the program and deliver its benefits to the poor of their states. ""I want to briefly highlight at least some of the changes in the law that have not recently received the public attention that they deserve. According to the Congressional Budget Office
column10: 000 disabled children covered by the Family Opportunity Act will receive improved health care services as a result of the recently passed Deficit Reduction Act. The new law will provide access to new home and community based care to 120
column12: 000 nursing home residents to return to their communities through the Administration's Money Follows the Person Demonstration. These are the true results of Medicaid reform - better access to better care for those who most need our assistance. ""There is still much to be done to improve long-term care service delivery and financing as well as to promote Medicaid managed care. I have received the administration's proposals regarding additional improvement to the Medicaid program and I look forward to working with you this year on them. ""This year the secretary and the administration also are required to administer the new Medicare prescription drug benefit. Making this program succeed is a high priority of yours
column13: and it is a high priority of this committee that I chair. ""Since it began
column14: critics have tried to make patients believe that they are not smart enough to understand the new Medicare drug benefit
column16: and that signing up isn't worth their time because it cannot save them any money. The critics are simply wrong. They were wrong when they complained about the Medicare prescription drug card. They were wrong when they said nobody would offer any insurance plans. And they are wrong now. ""Some sense political advantage in condemning the program and others can't bring themselves to admit that free markets actually work. Transparency and competition will drive down prices and provide lower costs to consumers. Even if the critics don't get it
column17: Medicare beneficiaries certainly do. That is why over 3.6 million Medicare beneficiaries have already signed up for the new benefit. You told me earlier today that there are close to 24 million Americans that have been enrolled in the program
column19: and enrollment is increasing at approximately 250
column20: 000 people per week. That sounds like a success story to me. If you add that to the fact that the premiums which we estimated at $37 a month is now down to an average $27 per month
column21: that appears to me to be a successful program. ""This is a huge undertaking and there are going to be glitches. My goal is the same as yours: Get rid of the glitches. The committee will work closely with yourself and Dr. Mark McClellan at CMS to get problems noticed and solved. We will have the first of what will likely be several hearings on this topic on March 1
column22: when Dr. McClellan will testify before the Health subcommittee. I expect that we ask him very direct questions about where the problems are and what CMS is doing to fix them. ""Another high priority for the committee will be the reauthorization of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and related programs. I want to restate my deep commitment to reauthorizing the NIH and would ask for the secretary's assistance in working out the technical details so that we can enact this long overdue legislation. In addition
column23: the authorization for the Ryan White CARE Act has now lapsed. I believe that funding unauthorized programs is not a responsible practice
column24: and I anticipate that the committee will work to reauthorize these programs this year. ""I also intend to work with you this year on ways to reform Medicare reimbursement
column25: and particularly focus on physician payment reform. In order to preserve access to Medicare services for future generations
column26: we must look at how we are spending our Medicare dollars today and what are the incentives are for our physician community to continue providing quality health care. ""Another top priority of the committee will be to work with you on the proposals outlined in the Administration's budget to provide consumers with greater access to comparative price and quality data about their health care providers. I could go on

0	"This is a rush transcript from ""Fox News Sunday
column2: May 28
column3: 2017. This copy may not be in its final form and may be updated.

column1: CHRIS WALLACE
column2: FOX NEWS ANCHOR: I’m Chris Wallace.

column1: Keeping America safe after the terror attack in England. What steps is the government taking this Memorial Day weekend?
(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
JOHN KELLY
column2: HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY: It's a constant threat and we always have to be vigilant.

column1: WALLACE: We’ll discuss the investigation into the bombing and the response here in the U.S. with the secretary of homeland security
column2: General John Kelly
column3: live
column4: only on ""Fox News Sunday.""

column1: Then
column2: new reports the president's son-in-law Jared Kushner discussed setting up a secret communications channel between the Trump transitions in the Kremlin. We’ll ask our Sunday panel where this takes the expanding probe into Russian interference.

column1: Plus
column2: President Trump returns from his first trip overseas to a domestic agenda in trouble
column3: from ObamaCare repeal and replace to the budget
column4: some on Capitol Hill wonder whether Congress will pass anything.

column1: SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM
column2: R-SOUTH CAROLINA: Yes
column3: definitely dead on arrival.

column1: SEN. DICK DURBIN
column2: D-ILLINOIS: This is step backwards. You’re not going to make America great again with this budget.

column1: WALLACE: We’ll break down the president's priorities and prospects with a number two Democrat in the Senate
column2: Dick Durbin
column3: and Republican senator
column4: Dr. Bill Cassidy.

column1: And our power player of the week flying high for the Blue Angels.
UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Boy
column2: is it sweet when we put all that together and get that synergy and you feel that fuzz.

column1: WALLACE: All
column2: right now
column3: on ""Fox News Sunday.""

column1: (END VIDEOTAPE)
WALLACE: And hello again on this Memorial Day weekend from Fox News in Washington.

President Trump is back at the White House arriving late last night after a largely successful nine-day trip to the Middle East and Europe. But he returns to a spreading scandal about links between the Kremlin and some of his current and former advisors
column2: and to a domestic agenda that stalled in Congress.

column1: We’ll get to all of that this hour
column2: but we begin with terror
column3: that suicide bombing at a concert in Manchester
column4: England
column5: that killed 22
column6: just the first of four savage attacks this week around the world.

column1: Joining us now
column2: the man in charge of keeping America safe
column3: the secretary of homeland security
column4: General John Kelly.

column1: Mr. Secretary
column2: welcome to ""Fox News Sunday.""

column1: Before we get to terror
column2: let me ask you about the hot story in Washington now. These revelations about Jared Kushner trying to set up a back channel to the Kremlin
column3: through the Soviet and -- the Russian ambassador. Your reaction to that? Is there anything improper with that?

column1: KELLY: Well
column2: I don't know if it's true or not. I know it’s being -- it's being reported in the press.

column1: WALLACE: It has been confirmed to me the conversation took place.
KELLY: OK. Then I would just tell you
column2: Chris
column3: that I think any channel of communications back or otherwise with a country like Russia is a good thing. I mean
column4: multiple ways to communicate back and forth is a good thing with a country I think
column5: and particularly a country that’s like Russia. So
column6: it doesn’t -- it doesn't bother me.

column1: I mean
column2: you just have to assume
column3: obviously
column4: that what you’re getting is -- may or may not be true
column5: they may be working you. But that's the whole point. I mean
column6: that communication goes into the White House as a data point in terms of discussion. So
column7: I don't see the big deal.

column1: WALLACE: Let me -- you say you don't see a big deal?
KELLY: No
column2: I think any time you have channels of communication with a country
column3: particularly one like Russia
column4: I wouldn’t criticize it.

column1: WALLACE: But you talked about a data point into the White House. This is during the transition.
KELLY: Right.
WALLACE: These were private officials.
KELLY: Right.
WALLACE: We have one president at a time. Does that make a difference?
KELLY: You know
column2: I mean
column3: obviously
column4: during the transition period
column5: the people in transition
column6: the incoming Trump administration is not in a position to do anything to inhibit with the Obama administration literally days before they transitioned out. So
column8: as they begin to build relationships
column9: there's nothing wrong with that. As they begin to build their own situational awareness with Russia in this case
column10: I don't see an issue here.

column1: WALLACE: OK. Let's turn to your day job. What's the latest on the Manchester bombing? Have they rolled up the network that was supporting the bombers
column2: and what have you learned from this plot that will help you better protect the U.S. homeland?

column1: KELLY: I mean
column2: I don't know what the -- actually the better way to put it
column3: I can't comment on whether they finish their investigations
column4: or roll -- you know
column5: completed rolling up on the network that we’re dealing with. But I would just say that this is -- yes
column6: I’ve said it many times
column7: it really is a generational struggle. This is one tragedy in line with dozens of other tragedies in the world.

column1: I mean
column2: last week
column3: you had Manchester
column4: you had Egypt
column5: you had Indonesia
column6: you had the Philippines
column7: all ISIS-inspired or ISIS-controlled terrorist attack.

column1: WALLACE: Was there something different about this network and the way this was pulled off that says to you
column2: gee
column3: we've got to up our game?

column1: KELLY: Well
column2: it’s this kind of -- in my view
column3: there's kind of three types of terrorist attacks. The most sophisticated that we look at
column4: that is against aviation
column5: that's the hardest to do but it's the biggest payoff for these people.

column1: Then you have kind of the middle of the road one
column2: which I think this one was. It’s a network. It's hard to do. You have to construct a bomb and all
column3: and then you have kind of the low-end where -- I mean
column4: just as tragic but you have people running people over in trucks
column5: that kind of thing.

column1: But this is just the way terrorism is today and I think it will be around for many
column2: many years to come. You know
column3: the good news is those officials in the United Kingdom
column4: Europe
column5: around the world are relentless. They are just as relentless in terms of trying to prevent these things as the terrorists aren't trying to create them.

column1: The good news is
column2: for our country
column3: we have not had an outside the United States terrorist attacks since 9/11. And that goes to the issue of those that fight our away game
column4: that’s DOD
column5: NSA
column6: CIA
column7: and those that fight the home game. That’s DHS
column8: FBI

column1: WALLACE: Let me pick up on this
column2: because part of the story this week was the leak of information about the bomber and the bombing that made its way into the U.S. media
column3: and that set off this exchange.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
THERESA MAY
column2: BRITISH PRIME MINISTER: I made clear to President Trump that the intelligence that is shared between our law enforcement agencies must remain secure.

column1: REX TILLERSON
column2: SECRETARY OF STATE: We take full responsibility for that. And we
column3: obviously
column4: regret that that happened.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: How was this kind of sensitive information leaked to ""The New York Times""? And
column2: General
column3: why is it that whether it's politics or terror
column4: our intelligence agencies
column5: our law enforcement agencies
column6: can't keep a secret?

column1: KELLY: It's outrageous. When I call -- immediately after the attack
column2: I called my counterpart in U.K.
column3: offered my condolences. By the way
column4: the third time I’ve offered her
column5: Amber Rudd
column6: my condolences in 120 days. That's how frequent this kind of -- these terrorist attacks are happening.

column1: Anyways
column2: she rightfully and very graciously accepted the condolences and leaned into me on this leak. It's outrageous. I don't know why people do it. It jeopardizes not only investigations
column3: it puts people's lives in jeopardy.

column1: I don't why people do it
column2: but they do. And that's the world we live in.

column1: WALLACE: Let's get to what you're going to try to do to protect the homeland. There are a lot of crowded events in the summer
column2: concerts
column3: sporting events. How do you harden these soft targets like this concert? And do you have new thoughts because this person didn't get into the event
column4: he was outside the event
column5: what do you do about parameters?

column1: KELLY: We -- one of the great things about America
column2: there's many great things but we are a free and open society. And in many -- and I wouldn't change that at all. But that's also one of our vulnerabilities. People can live their lives day in and day out
column3: privacy issues
column4: all of that
column5: it's a good thing. It’s what America is all about. But as I say
column6: that is a vulnerability.

column1: The good news is to all Americans
column2: I mean
column3: the good news is that local state law enforcement today -- not to even go down the issue of the FBI
column4: DHS -- it's in their DNA now to harden. We are just about as hard as we can be. I don't know if there's a way to prevent these kinds of things in the kind of society we live in.

column1: WALLACE: Let me pick up on that
column2: because I want to play a clip of your testimony before Congress this week. Here it is.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
KELLY: It's everywhere
column2: and that’s -- you know
column3: that's the nature of this threat that we are dealing with. As horrible as Manchester was
column4: my expectation is we’re going to see a lot more of that kind of attack.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: A lot more of that kind of attack
column2: here in the U.S.?

column1: KELLY: I think we’re relatively -- we have no specific -- we have threats all the time
column2: but no
column3: right now
column4: specific threat. But that goes to the fact that we are over here and not over there.

column1: The fact is that it's the caliphate is being destroyed
column2: that is Syria and Iraq
column3: there are large numbers of returning fighters
column4: Western Europe
column5: and
column6: you know
column7: in many cases like this guy that did this thing in Manchester
column8: he’s a citizen of the U.K. In this case
column9: he’s a passport holder. I don't if the U.K. had any idea that he was outside -- that he was in Libya
column10: but I think he’s also traveled to other points.

column1: The point is
column2: they have a real threat and it's growing
column3: it’s metastasized
column4: as fighters come back from the caliphate to be I believe to be more of this kind of thing.

column1: The good news is
column2: all decent people
column3: all decent governments
column4: and it doesn't matter whether we are politically close to them or not
column5: all governments for the most part are sharing tremendous amounts of information
column6: passport-type information
column8: travel information. But
column10: people like this are below the radar.

column1: WALLACE: I want to pick up on aviation because you are in the process of making some big decisions on aviation. And I want to do a lightning round
column2: quick questions
column3: quick answers.

column1: Are you going to ban laptops from the cabin on all international flights both into and out of the U.S.?
KELLY: I might. That's a quick answer.
WALLACE: Yes
column2: well
column3: expand a little bit.

column1: KELLY: Well
column2: there’s a real threat. Numerous threats against aviation
column3: that's really the thing that they are obsessed with
column4: the terrorists
column5: the idea of knocking down an airplane in flight
column6: particularly if it’s a U.S. carrier
column7: particularly if it's full of mostly U.S. folks
column8: people. It's real. You know that I implemented I think on the 21st of March a restriction on large electronic devices in the cabins from ten points of origin.

column1: WALLACE: Right.
But there was talk
column2: as you say
column3: about all international flights both into and out of the U.S. When you say you might
column4: when are you going to make that decision and what’s going to determine it?

column1: KELLY: (INAUDIBLE) follow the intelligence. The very
column2: very good news is that we are working incredibly close with friends and partners around the world. We're going to
column3: and in the process of defining this
column4: but we are going to raise the bar for generally speaking aviation security much higher than it is now.

column1: So -- and there’s new technologies down the road
column2: not too far down the road that we will rely on. But it is a real sophisticated threat and I will reserve that decision until we see where it's going.

column1: WALLACE: Another lightning round question
column2: I do need a quick answer here because we’re running of time. The TSA is testing tighter screening of carry-ons
column3: and the idea that people who bring their carry-ons are going to have to unpack them and put food in one bin
column4: and electronics in the another bin
column5: and paper in another bin.

column1: Are you going to spread that nationwide and what’s that going to do to the screening lines?
KELLY: Yes
column2: I mean
column3: the reason we’ve done
column4: TSA
column5: of course
column6: works for me. The reason we've done that is because of -- people trying to avoid the $25 or $50 or whatever it is to check a bag are now stuffing your carry-on bags to the point of
column8: they can't get any more in there. So
column9: the more you stuff in there
column10: the less the TSA professionals that are looking at what's in those bags through the monitors
column11: they can't tell what's in the bags anymore. So

column1: WALLACE: So
column2: are you going to do that nationwide?

column1: KELLY: We might
column2: and likely will.

column1: WALLACE: Soon?
KELLY: Well
column2: what we’re doing now is working out the tactics
column3: techniques and procedures
column4: if you will
column5: in a few airports to find out exactly how to do that with the least amount of inconvenience to the traveler.

column1: WALLACE: A couple final questions I want to ask about the travel ban. The Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals issued a ruling this week continuing the stay on President Trump's revised travel ban -- and I want to put up -- the chief judge called it
column2: the revised travel ban: an executive order that in text speaks with vague words of national security
column3: but in context drips with religious intolerance
column4: animus and discrimination.

column1: Mr. Secretary
column2: judge after judge has said that this is a Muslim man that violates the Constitution.

column1: KELLY: They are dead wrong.
WALLACE: Well
column2: I mean
column3: you say that
column4: but they are the ones who were --

column1: KELLY: They are wrong. Remember the seven
column2: now six countries? These were the same countries identified by the Obama administration that we should be extra cautious about and backed up
column3: you know
column4: by the United States Congress. That's where those seven countries came from.

column1: The fact is that in those countries
column2: we have very little ability to actually verify
column3: vet the people that are coming out of those countries. So
column4: what the president and it's not a travel ban
column5: remember. It’s the travel pause. What the president said
column6: for 90 days
column7: we were going to pause in terms of people from those countries coming to the United States that would give me time to look at additional vetting to see --

column1: WALLACE: OK. I want to pick up on that and why you’re even talking about the travel ban
column2: because I want to put some numbers on. Take a look at this.

column1: The first executive order that was issued on January 27th banned citizens from seven nations from entering the U.S. for 90 days
column2: suspended the refugee program for 120 days
column3: as you say
column4: a pause
column5: while you set up an extreme vetting program. It's now been 121 days since that first order. So
column6: why don't you have the program in place?

column1: KELLY: We are actually implementing it. The irony here is
column2: had it stood
column3: we would have had the 90 days to study. We’re not even studying what would be procedures
column4: because we are enjoined and can't do that. In the meantime --

column1: WALLACE: You can't study extreme vetting?
KELLY: No. We’re -- the irony again is we can't study it
column2: but I’m just guessing
column3: and implementing.

column1: But we are going to find implement ways to determine who this -- an individual is
column2: and remember
column3: most of these countries have no passports. They have no police. They have no intelligence. Many of the countries in question don't even have a U.S. embassy there to help us vet. The U.N. will tell you it's almost impossible to vet these people from these countries because there are no passports and all the rest of it.

column1: We have to figure out a way to determine who they are and why they come into the United States. Otherwise
column2: we’re guessing. And this president and John Kelly doesn't want to guess when it comes to national security and protection of the U.S. population.

column1: WALLACE: Secretary Kelly
column2: thank you. Thanks for sharing part of your holiday weekend with us.

column1: KELLY: Absolutely. Thanks.
WALLACE: Up next
column2: new reports that Jared Kushner attempted to set up a back channel between Russia and the Trump transition. We’ll bring in our Sunday group to discuss the expanding Russia probe.

column1: Plus
column2: what would you like to ask the panel about the continuous leaks in Washington? Just go to Facebook or Twitter @FoxNewsSunday
column3: and we may use your question on the air.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
HILLARY CLINTON
column2: D-FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: We were furious about the past presidential election of a man whose presidency would eventually end in disgrace with his impeachment for obstruction of justice.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: Hillary Clinton talking about Richard Nixon in her commencement speech at Wellesley College
column2: but clearly taking a shot at President Trump. By the way
column3: Nixon resigned before he was actually impeached.

column1: And it's time now for our Sunday group: the head of Heritage Action for America
column2: Michael Needham
column3: Charles Lane of The Washington Post
column4: Gerald Seib from The Wall Street Journal
column5: and National Security Council staffer
column6: Gillian Turner.

column1: And just to catch you up
column2: President Trump returns home to reports that his son-in-law
column3: Jared Kushner
column4: met with the Russian ambassador to the U.S.
column5: Sergey Kislyak
column6: in December
column7: and that they discussed setting up a secret secure channel between the Trump transition and the Kremlin. That communications link reportedly to be based in a Russian diplomatic facility in Russia.

column1: A source close to the Trump administration tells me the conversation did take place but he says it was the ambassador who proposed the back channel
column2: not Kushner
column3: so the Russian military could talk with Trump advisors about the situation in Syria and the source points out that the secure link was never set up.

column1: So
column2: with that as a preface
column3: Gerry
column4: your reaction to the Kushner story
column5: and how does this complicate the already complicated investigation of links between the Kremlin and the Trump transition?

column1: GERALD F. SEIB
column2: THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: Well
column3: look
column4: I mean
column5: back channels are not unusual
column6: they are not unprecedented. This one might have seemed perfectly innocent. Two problems though with it. One is
column8: it seems to violate as you suggested earlier in the show the only one president at a time rule. And the second one is it’s Russia
column9: after a campaign in which the Russian connection to the campaign
column10: the Russian interference in the campaign was a big issue.

column1: And I think the fact that it was at a time when people were looking for whether there were going to be signs of special favors for Russia as a result of help they might have given President Trump
column2: then-President-elect Trump during the campaign
column3: that's what makes this a big story
column4: is the context of the conversation as much as the actual content.

column1: WALLACE: Michael
column2: I want to ask you
column3: one
column4: whether it's a big story
column5: and
column6: secondly
column7: about the talk we are hearing
column8: that is just rampant in Washington today about major changes in the White House that they’re going to set up a rapid response operation to deal with all the incoming leaks
column9: that the president has hired at least one criminal defense lawyer and may be process of hiring a team and the staff is urging the president to let the lawyers vet his tweets. I mean
column10: it really does sound like they’re going on a war footing on this.

column1: MICHAEL NEEDHAM
column2: CEO
column3: HERITAGE ACTION FOR AMERICA: Yes
column4: I don't know if it's a major story
column5: there are several investigations going on. They probably should be allowed to work their course. It's kind of exhausting reading some of these new stories and trying to figure out what did you read three weeks ago that’s just being recycled
column6: versus what new?

column1: I think it's smart for the administration to try to put this stuff to the side
column2: have
column3: you know
column4: a team that looks at these issues
column5: and another team that looks at a lot of real policy issues
column6: which are closer to the American people. You have the most conservative
column7: exciting budget that's come out in a decade.

column1: WALLACE: We’re going to get to the agenda in the next segment.
(CROSSTALK)
WALLACE: I mean
column2: at the very least
column3: it seems dumb.

column1: NEEDHAM: Clearly
column2: the optics of these are awful
column3: and I think that especially when you have people who are new to the political system coming in and getting advice from a guy in Mike Flynn who probably didn't show the best judgment through a lot of this
column4: you know
column5: dumb might be a good word for it. I don’t know. You know
column6: I think Kushner said a couple of weeks ago that he was happy to participate with the Senate investigation. He said he’s happy to participate with this investigation.

column1: You are at a disadvantage when you are the focus of an investigation and your lawyers are saying
column2: don't participate
column3: don't comment
column4: and everyone else in the country seems more than eager to talk about it. So
column5: I think a little prudence in keeping our mouth shut while we let the investigations play out is probably fair and we’ll see what comes up in them.

column1: WALLACE: You talk about the fact that they're all the stories and sometimes it's hard to remember what you've heard this week and what you heard last week. And this gets to the question of leaks. I asked our staff to put together
column2: let's put it up on the screen
column3: a list of the headlines from just the last two weeks. This is just Sunday two weeks ago until today. And as you can see
column4: there's been a torrent of disclosures from intelligence and law enforcement officials.

column1: Gillian
column2: as somebody who worked in the government
column3: have you ever seen anything like this? And
column4: you know
column5: the conservatives talk about a deep state
column6: that there are people embedded in law enforcement and embedded in the intelligence community that are trying to bring this president down. It sure seems like it's true.

column1: GILLIAN TURNER
column2: FORMER WHITE HOUSE NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL: So
column3: to me on the question of leaks
column4: it seems that without a doubt leaks of information today are the number one threat to U.S. national security interest across the globe. And I think for evidence of that
column5: we need look no further than the very public reprimand
column6: we the United States had to endure from Britain earlier this week
column7: in the wake of the Manchester attacks. A reminder that the British-U.S. intelligence cooperation
column8: relationship
column9: is one of the closest that has ever existed. And in my lifetime
column11: I have not seen something so public

column1: (CROSSTALK)
WALLACE: Most of these leaks aren’t about national security. They are about Trump's political security.
TURNER: Yes. And so
column2: this gets to the question of the deep state. So
column3: I’m somebody who likes to push back against the narrative having been a civil servant in the government. Again
column4: in the national security community is different than the political community
column5: the rest of the policy community. But I will say that from I have seen and experienced
column6: it does not exist.

column1: There is not this liberal --
WALLACE: How do you define this?
TURNER: There isn’t a liberal core of people -- put it this way
column2: Chris
column3: for a hard fact
column4: more than 50 percent of the federal workforce today is made up of people that joined the government prior to President Bush's tenure in office. So
column5: the idea that these are Obama holdovers is simply not true
column6: it's not the case.

column1: I think that when we talk about why individuals leak information
column2: the explanations are as varied as human beings’ psychology. So
column3: for example
column4: a lot of things we are seeing leaked about the president are probably being leaked by his senior staff to hurt one another. That's not unique to the Trump administration.

column1: WALLACE: We ask you for questions for the panel and we got some different reactions in this question of leaks.
Adri Ane sent us on Facebook: Do whistleblowers hold a vital role in the health of a democracy holding those in power to accountability?
But chuck Coo had a different take: Simple question. If our intelligence agencies are as good as advertised
column2: why can't they find the leakers?

column1: Chuck
column2: how do you answer both of them about leaks?

column1: CHARLES LANE
column2: THE WASHINGTON POST: Well
column3: as a member of the press
column4: and is a believer in the role of the media and holding government accountable
column5: I’m not going to come out against leaks
column6: because
column8: for all the leaks that may cause this or that official trouble
column9: there's going to be another one that does play an important role in accountability.

column1: But going back to what Gillian said
column2: I think part of the reason that these leaks are flowing so uncontrollably to the viewer’s question is the factional struggle within this administration. You know
column3: we have this famous dispute between Bannon and Kushner that supposedly was papered over. But I wouldn't be surprised if
column4: you know
column5: those were present two currents
column6: to put it politely
column7: within the White House that are trying to get bad stories out about one another.

column1: And this goes to your point about the staff shakeup and so on and so forth. You can shake up the staff all you want
column2: but if man at the top is not laying out a clear and consistent line
column3: is not himself modeling behavior
column4: for example
column5: by not blowing an Israeli source in a meeting with a foreign government
column6: that sets the tone that this stuff is not really on

column1: NEEDHAM: I take your point about the responsibility of the press and how leaks play into as it requires a responsible press also. That when James Fallows of The Atlantic today put side-by-side The Washington Post in The New York Times and how they treat
column2: I think it was three unnamed sources in the White House talking about Jared Kushner and his desire to be here and stay here
column3: this is not an urgent story. This is not something that’s getting out there.

column1: I don't think you see in the press
column2: The Times and The Washington Post
column3: the way they are playing this kind of using leakers to try to unearth the truth and taking two months like --

column1: (CROSSTALK)
WALLACE: We need to --
NEEDHAM: It’s kind of getting ridiculous.
WALLACE: We need to -- because we’re going to run out of time. Let me simply say
column2: we're just receiving information. It’s people who had sworn
column3: oftentimes taken legal oaths not to divulge the information
column4: they are the ones putting it out. We’re just the recipients.

column1: All right. We have to take a break here. We’ll see you a little later.
When we come back
column2: Senators Dick Durbin and Bill Cassidy. Is the president's agenda
column3: both his new budget and the new effort to repeal and replace ObamaCare in trouble?

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
WALLACE: Coming up
column2: President Trump releases his budget.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
DONALD TRUMP
column2: PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: My administration is laying a foundation to build a future of economic prosperity and achieve American greatness.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: But does it have any chance of getting through Congress?
Two key senators join us next.
(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
WALLACE: A look outside the beltway of the Indianapolis Motor speedway
column2: home to this weekend's Indianapolis 500.

column1: Back from his first foreign trip
column2: President Trump's focus will now shift to his domestic agenda
column3: his new budget and a bill to repeal and replace ObamaCare.

column1: Joining us to discuss the president's priorities from Springfield
column2: Illinois
column3: the Senate’s number two Democrat
column4: Dick Durbin. And here in Washington
column5: Louisiana senator and doctor
column6: Bill Cassidy
column7: who’s on both the Senate Finance and Health Committees.

column1: Well
column2: senators
column3: before we get to the Trump agenda
column4: I’ve got to ask you about the big story in Washington. This weekend
column5: the Jared Kushner story
column6: discussions about setting up a possible back channel with Russia.

column1: Senator Durbin
column2: what's wrong with that?

column1: SEN. DICK DURBIN
column2: D-ILLINOIS: The bottom line
column3: of course
column4: is we now have a special counsel in Bob Mueller. I have the highest level of confidence in him. And I hope that he will follow all the evidence
column5: all the leads
column6: and all the suggestions. And I’m sure he will.

column1: WALLACE: Do you have any specific comment about the Kushner conversation and whether or je should keep his security clearance?
DURBIN: Well
column2: of course not. I mean this is a rumor at this point and whether it is something that should be followed up on
column3: I’ll trust Bob Mueller's judgment.

column1: WALLACE: Senator Cassidy
column2: are you troubled by this?

column1: SEN. BILL CASSIDY
column2: R-LOUISIANA: I agree with Dick’s assessment. And I’ll say
column3: when you speak to folks back home
column4: voters across the nation
column5: they’re more concerned about their climbing health care premiums and the need to have jobs with better wages and better benefits. This will play out. We will know eventually. Right now Americans need help with their premiums.

column1: WALLACE: Well
column2: you know what then gentlemen
column3: let's switch to health care. And the Congressional Budget Office
column4: non-partisan
column5: released its score of the House bill this week. And let's put the numbers up on the screen. It would reduce the deficit $119 billion over ten years
column6: but 23 million more people would be uninsured by 2026. The cost of insurance
column8: for a 64-year-old earning $27
column10: 700 a year under ObamaCare to more than $13
column11: 000 under the GOP bill. Here's what Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer said this week.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER
column2: D-NY
column3: MINORITY LEADER: Unless you’re a healthy millionaire
column4: Trumpcare is a nightmare. This report ought to be the final nail in the coffin of the Republican effort to sabotage our health care system.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: Senator Cassidy
column2: is Schumer right?

column1: CASSIDY: So the Senate will write its own bill. And it shouldn't be the final coffin because right now there's families sitting around their kitchen table
column2: they’re play $20
column6: 000 a year for premiums and there's about to be a 40 percent increase in many states in these premiums. Cassidy-Collins
column7: a bill I’ve introduced with Susan Collins
column8: we have four co-sponsors.

column1: WALLACE: Yes
column2: we’re going to get into that in a --

column1: CASSIDY: But that said
column2: actually would -- would -- would meet that family’s needs and I think it should be a place we go and those families are asking us to address those issues.

column1: WALLACE: So -- so what would you say to Americans? How should they regard the House bill?
CASSIDY: The House product
column2: the Senate will have its own product. We will go to conference. But I think the Senate product
column3: I'm hopeful
column4: will be more likely to address their needs.

column1: WALLACE: Senator Durbin
column2: I know what you’re going to say
column3: and the CBO certainly indicates there are problem with repeal and replace
column4: but ObamaCare has its own problems. You heard Senator Cassidy mentioned some of them. Blue Cross Blue Shield of Kansas City just announced this week that it has lost $100 million through 2016 and that it is going to pull out of exchanges. That means that in 25 counties in western Missouri they may have no insurer at all. Doesn’t something have to be done dramatically?

column1: DURBIN: Well
column2: it should be. But first we ought to have an administration that supports our health care system. What the Trump administration has done since day one is to find ways to cut off support for our current health care system
column3: lack of advertising
column4: for example
column5: to bring new people on board so we have larger insurance pools and lower premiums. We have to have an effort made to sustain the current system while we repair it. We shouldn’t be sabotaging it.

column1: WALLACE: Wait
column2: wait
column3: wait
column4: wait
column5: senator --

column1: DURBIN: But let’s look at the bottom line here. What the Republicans --
WALLACE: Senator Durbin
column2: let me just point out
column3: when Blue Cross Blue Shield of Kansas City says they’ve lost $100 million in 2016
column4: you can't blame that on Trump. He wasn't president.

column1: DURBIN: No
column2: of course it is not a situation where the system we have is perfect
column3: and it isn't. I voted for it. And it needs to be repaired. And I think Bill Cassidy and Susan Collins are at least willing to sit down in a constructive fashion and deal with that. Bill and I have had conversations about that. I'm sorry that the two of them are not in the room with the 13 apostles that Senator McConnell’s chosen to come up with the Republicans plan. I wish Bill and Susan were in there.

column1: WALLACE: All right
column2: let -- let -- let me bring Senator Cassidy back
column3: because let's talk about the Collins
column4: Susan Collins
column5: the Republican senator from Maine
column6: and Cassidy plan. And here are some of the highlights of that plan. Keep most ObamaCare taxes to pay for a replacement instead of an individual mandate. That would end. Auto enroll people in insurance so they have to opt out
column7: not opt in. And let states keep most of ObamaCare if they want.

column1: Senator
column2: it's a very interesting plan
column3: but I don't have to tell you there are some of your more conservative colleagues in the Senate who are never going to go for this because they’re --

column1: CASSIDY: That’s --
WALLACE: I mean they’re already upset that they say the House plane leaves too much of ObamaCare in place. You're leaving more of it in place.
CASSIDY: A couple things. It is the conservative solution. The conservative thinks the power should return to individuals and to states. We do that. The power that ObamaCare gave
column2: took from states
column3: we give back. And you can't say you’re a conservative and we believe in states’ rights
column4: and then tell states what they can't do. If a blue state wishes to do a blue thing
column5: God bless them.

column1: And as regard to taxes
column2: it isn't so much that we have to keep these taxes. As a fiscal conservative
column3: I do think we need to pay for things. We have to balance our budget. We just say those taxes should be addressed in comprehensive tax reform
column4: not piecemealed beforehand. I will repeat
column5: the Cassidy-Collins plan is the conservative solution.

column1: WALLACE: But have you gotten any buy-in
column2: and let me just take a few names
column3: from Ted Cruz
column4: from Rand Paul
column5: from Mike Lee? And what are the chances
column6: honestly
column7: that the Senate won't pass anything
column8: that this health care reform is going to die?

column1: CASSIDY: I can't speak for those senators you listed. I will say that between -- aside from Susan and I
column2: there’s four other Republicans who support it. Now what would really be --

column1: WALLACE: That’s six. You need 44 more.
CASSIDY: But of all the plants out there
column2: we’re the one that have the most support. And there are others who are very much interested. But I’ll also say to my friend Dick Durbin
column3: if we had Democrats involved
column4: because we do allow a blue state to do a blue thing. That’s states’ rights. That if they can’t -- if we had 25 Democrats and 40 Republicans
column5: it wouldn't be a Republican plan
column6: it wouldn't be a Democratic plan
column7: it would be an American plan.

column1: WALLACE: OK
column2: let me quickly -- because I want to get to the budget briefly. But -- but
column3: real quickly
column4: Senator Durbin
column5: any Democratic buy-in?

column1: DURBIN: As long as we take repeal off the table
column2: there are a lot of Democrats who want to bring a chair to the table. I'm one of them. Let’s sit down together with Bill Cassidy and Susan Collins. I don't agree with their -- many aspects of their start-up plan
column3: but it's a good faith effort to do two things
column4: reduce the cost of health insurance and expand the reach of health insurance. That should be our national goal.

column1: WALLACE: All right
column2: now there's the Trump budget that was released this week
column3: and let's go through some of the highlights of that. Here are some of the key increases in spending. For the military
column4: increase by 10.1 percent
column5: border security by 6.8 percent
column6: but EPA is cut 31.4 percent
column8: and NIH
column10: by 18.2 percent. Here's how Trump budget director Mick Mulvaney explained it.

column1: (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
MICK MULVANEY
column2: DIRECTOR
column3: OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET: Compassion needs to be on both sides of that equation. Yes
column4: you have to have compassion for folks who are receiving the federal funds
column5: but also you have to have compassion for the folks who are paying it.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: Senator Durbin
column2: I know you’re going to bash the Trump budget
column3: but -- but don't we have to cut spending at some point? Are we just going to keep piling up the national debt?

column1: DURBIN: Well
column2: that's a very -- very important question that you asked
column3: Chris
column4: but the question is
column5: where you cut it and how you cut. I do not believe you make America great again by cutting medical research to the lowest level in 12 years. I don't think you make America great again by saying to working families
column6: it's now more expensive for your kids to borrow money for student loans. You certainly don't make us a great nation by cutting back in infrastructure. All those three things are in the Trump budget. So if we’re going to have priorities
column7: let's look at the things that are important for building jobs and opportunity in the future.

column1: WALLACE: Senator Cassidy
column2: how dead -- I know it's dead -- but how dead is the Trump budget?

column1: CASSIDY: So class -- typically
column2: in fact
column3: always
column4: the Senate and the House write their own budget
column5: but it does reflect the president's goals. I actually agree with those goals
column6: but would take a different approach. Let’s speak of Medicaid
column7: which under their budget is cut. Medicaid is unsustainable
column8: both for states and for the federal government. It has to be reformed. But as a physician who worked with Medicaid patients
column9: I know that benefit has to also be preserved. I've actually worked on legislation that would bend the cost curve
column10: at the same time reform it so that states would not go bankrupt trying to continue their Medicaid program.

column1: WALLACE: But --
CASSIDY: We have elements of that in the Cassidy-Collins plan. We share the goal
column2: we just have a different way to get there.

column1: WALLACE: But just real quickly
column2: though. I know you’re concerned about the Gulf Coast and Louisiana. Are you OK with cutting EPA? You’re a doctor. Are you OK with these kinds of big cuts in NIH?

column1: CASSIDY: Again
column2: I think the best way to control future health care spending is to find that cure for Alzheimer's. I agree with the goal. I have a different approach. If we find a cure for Alzheimer’s
column3: which postpones or heals
column4: then those folks are not taking a trillion dollars out of our economy with their illness. Rather they are contributing
column5: that capital is used for something else. We can actually get at this in a different light.

column1: WALLACE: Senator Cassidy
column2: Senator Durbin
column3: I want to thank you both for coming in and thank you for your time
column4: especially in this holiday weekend.

column1: CASSIDY: Thank you.
WALLACE: Up next
column2: President Trump wraps up his first foreign trip
column3: but his troubles here at home haven't gone away. Our panel comes back to discuss both.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
TRUMP: We made extraordinary gains on this historic trip to advance the security and prosperity of the United States
column2: our friends and our allies.

column1: (END VIDEO CLIP)
WALLACE: President Trump at the end of his first foreign trip giving himself good reviews
column2: which is what presidents always do.

column1: And we’re back now with the panel.
Gillian
column2: how do you think the president did on this trip and why do you think he seemed to get along so much better with the leaders in the Middle East than he did with our allies in Europe?

column1: TURNER: So I really divide the trip into two parts conceptually. It’s helpful. So the first is really going around and touching on major worlds -- the world’s major three religions
column2: excuse me
column3: Chris
column4: Christianity
column5: Judaism and Islam. And I think that that part of the trip went relatively well. We had some pushback from the media about certain protocol optics
column6: like
column8: like what was donning the heads of Melania and Ivanka Trump. That's fine.

column1: I think the second part of the trip was really NATO-focused. And there the president’s speech actually got a lot of criticism. But I think for the first time the administration cabinet-wide is actually striking the right tone on NATO
column2: by which I mean they’re focusing on recommitting themselves to the importance of the alliance and they backtracked
column3: or progressed
column4: however you want to phrase it
column5: on the -- the idea that it's become obsolete
column6: which is a good thing for everyone.

column1: At the same time
column2: they’re encouraging the member nations to contribute 2 percent GDP
column3: which at this time -- remember
column4: this was part of the president’s campaign platform. So I think he's got a mandate from the American people to push for that and it's something he's doing. I think it's a nice balance.

column1: WALLACE: We should point out that the first part of the trip
column2: especially the Saudi part of the trip
column3: was largely organized by Jared Kushner
column4: and people who support him say he was talking to all of those Saudi leaders and helping -- and Sunni Muslim leaders during the transition
column5: and that's one of the reasons it was such a success.

column1: Chuck
column2: what struck you about these nine days?

column1: LANE: I have to say
column2: the chilly atmospherics of the Europe portion of the trip
column3: in contrast to the warmth
column4: the abundant good feeling that was on display in Saudi Arabia between the president and the royal family of Saudi Arabia
column5: that -- that contrast I think spoke volumes. It's true that he's -- the president got a lot of criticism for not uttering the words I personally support Article Five
column6: the mutual defense guarantee in NATO --

column1: WALLACE: Attack on one is an attack on all.
LANE: Correct. But the reason for -- another president with another history
column2: who had run a different campaign
column3: that wouldn't be an issue. The Europeans feel very embattled and nervous with respect to the Trump administration. He supported Brexit. He openly spoke warmly about Marine Le Pen. He’s called NATO obsolete. And they were looking for some -- the kind of reassurance that he gave the Saudis
column4: and they didn't get it. And I think that will have repercussions going forward.

column1: WALLACE: Let's talk about the domestic side
column2: because the president returns to a Congress that is addley (ph) divided about repeal and replace and has already
column3: both Republicans and Democrats
column4: rejected his budget that we were just talking about with the two senators.

column1: Michael
column2: some Senate Republicans are talking about just giving up on health care and moving straight tax reform.

column1: NEEDHAM: It would be a mistake. I mean the American health care system is collapsing under ObamaCare. But part of the reason that this agenda is so complicated and that we need a real sense of urgency on both the White House and the Congress about health care
column2: tax reform
column3: the budget
column4: the debt limit
column5: all this stuff that’s coming up and how it fits together is that for seven years the Republican Party has told itself a lie
column6: that we are all united on wanting the same ends
column7: that we all want to repeal ObamaCare
column8: it’s about what the replace is. And what you actually have is you have very legitimate and heartfelt disagreement within the party about what the best path forward is.

column1: Some conservatives who want to focus on Title One regulations. Bill Cassidy
column2: who has his plan
column3: the Tuesday Group in the House
column4: which is more of a force --

column1: WALLACE: More moderate.
NEEDHAM: The moderate group. Kind of a force for the status quo. I think the healthiest thing that’s happened in the last couple of months is that in the House
column2: for the first time
column3: leadership and the members themselves acknowledge that there are real differences of policy in this party. This isn't good guys and bad guys. It isn’t disagreements about tactics. They sat down for a couple of weeks. They understood where they were coming from. And they came up with a coalition form of government that said
column4: you know what
column5: let's let the state decides. If they want to wave out of ObamaCare
column6: that's fine for some of them and others don’t.

column1: WALLACE: But -- but --
NEEDHAM: That's the model that needs -- that needs to happen going forward to bring them together.
WALLACE: But -- but the problem
column2: of course
column3: with that
column4: as you just heard from Bill Cassidy is
column5: he’s saying they’re basically going to put that over the side
column6: maybe they’ll take a little bit out of it
column7: but they’re going to write their own bill.

column1: Gerry
column2: is it possible that we could get to the end of 2017
column3: this year
column4: and that a Republican-controlled Congress
column5: Republican control of the House and the Senate
column6: will not have passed a single major Trump legislative initiative? And if so
column7: what does that mean for prospects for Republicans in the 2018 midterms?

column1: SEIB: Well
column2: it is -- first of all
column3: it is possible because we’re staring down the path here of no easy wins. You know
column4: no big
column5: easy wins.

column1: By the way
column2: there's one other that you shouldn't forget
column3: which is by the fall
column4: this Congress has to raise the debt ceiling
column5: which everybody hates to do and -- and --

column1: WALLACE: You’ve also got to fund the government.
SEIB: You have to fund the government
column2: have to raise the debt ceiling. They’re going to have to get Republican votes. Conservatives hate raising the debt ceiling. Everybody hates raising the debt ceiling. That has to happen as well. So you have a whole series of tough or unpleasant choices before the Congress.

column1: My guess is that
column2: in the end
column3: I think a Republican Congress will figure out a way to get together and get some of these things done
column4: even in a truncated form because it’s too heavy a lift to go through an entire year in full control of the government and not have anything to show for it.

column1: WALLACE: You think they pass tax -- health care reform or do you think they’re going to end up eventually realizing -- you had Mitch McConnell say
column2: I don't see how we get to 50.

column1: SEIB: Yes.
WALLACE: Which is not the kind of thing he openly says. Do you think that they could just punt on that and go to tax reform?

SEIB: I think they could easily walk past health and go to tax reform. I -- Mitch McConnell’s a smart guy. He’s not going to move down a path unless he knows there’s success at the end of that path. And if he doesn't
column2: you know
column3: that's because there is no way to get 50 votes plus one.

column1: I do think tax reform is something that Republicans really want to do. They’ve come to Washington to cut taxes. They’re not going to walk out of this town I think in December without having given that at least a really good try.
WALLACE: Michael?
NEEDHAM: Yes. No
column2: I think
column3: you know
column4: they need to do both and all of these things are intertwined. At some point they have to sit down and look at these various points
column5: the debt limit
column6: spending
column8: health care
column9: and define which wings of the party
column10: which different factions within the parties will get what wins where. And once they do that

column1: The other thing that has to be considered this week is
column2: is the Paris Accords
column3: Paris Climate treaty
column4: and what makes that so complicated
column5: I think
column6: for the president is it’s non-binding. I think he’s actually going to come out this week and pull out the Paris Accords. He made an explicit promise on the campaign trail. He’s somebody who likes to keep his promises. And
column8: the United States shouldn't stay in a treaty just because it's non-binding. If we don’t intend on participating
column9: we should pull out. I think the president will do that.

column1: WALLACE: All right
column2: we have to leave here. Thank you
column3: panel. See you next Sunday.

column1: Up next
column2: our ""Power Player of the Week
column3: the Blue Angels
column4: flying high and inspiring pride.

column1: (COMMERCIAL BREAK)
WALLACE: Soldiers placing flags by the 230
column2: 000 grave markers at Arlington National Cemetery.

column1: Pride
column2: professionalism
column3: precision
column4: those are the watchwords of this military unit. And on this special weekend
column5: that unit is our ""Power Player of the Week.""

column1: (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
RYAN BERNACCHI
column2: BLUE ANGELS COMMANDING OFFICER: We’re focused on that very precise control of the airplane and flying it to the very best of your ability and you’re thinking out ahead
column3: OK
column4: what's next
column5: and what's next
column6: and what’s next.

column1: WALLACE (voice-over): Ryan Bernacchi is commander of the Blue Angels
column2: the Navy's precision flight squadron. He's in the number one jet
column3: leading his team through intricate maneuvers at up to 700 miles per hour
column4: with the planes sometimes just 18 inches apart. The Blue Angels were in the area to perform at the U.S. Naval Academy
column5: and we got to go inside their operation.

column1: WALLACE (on camera): Is there a lot of talking going on while you’re up in the air?
BERNACCHI: There is a lot of talking. As the leader
column2: I’m calling acadence (ph) for every -- every turn
column3: every pull
column4: every power change. And we’re just going to turn left
column5: it's as simple as
column6: coming left. And on that go
column7: all six sticks will move in unison. Coming further left
column8: a little

column1: (INAUDIBLE).
And when all that gets going
column2: we call it -- we call it fuzz -- it gets fuzzy because it will -- it will just take on this rhythm. You’re feeling the fuzz
column3: Chris. Yes.

column1: WALLACE: I'm feeling the fuzz!
BERNACCHI: Yes. It’s something -- it’s -- it’s -- it's crisp
column2: but it's -- it’s electric.

column1: WALLACE (voice-over): Admiral Chester Nimitz started the Blue Angels in 1946 with F-6 Hellcat prop planes to keep up interest in naval aviation after World War II. Now they fly F-18 Hornets
column2: in dozens of shows each year for more than 11 million spectators
column3: from a cloudy naval academy
column4: to a crystal clear San Francisco Bay.

column1: BERNACCHI: I always was going to be a pilot.
WALLACE (on camera): Why?
BERNACCHI: The Blue Angels.
WALLACE (voice-over): Bernacchi used to go with his dad to shows in the bay area every summer.
BERNACCHI: I was that kid and I wanted to fly.
WALLACE: Now he has a nickname.
BERNACCHI: They call the flight leader ""boss."" Wingmen will talk to me and
column2: hey
column3: boss
column4: you know
column5: and that’s the way it -- it works. And then we -- we do it on the ground as well.

column1: WALLACE: At the end of the show
column2: the Blue Angels do a maneuver called a loop
column3: break
column4: cross. All six planes headed straight up
column5: then
column6: in six different directions
column7: and then back to the center point.

column1: BERNACCHI: At about 800 knots of closure. So just under 1
column2: 000 miles an hour. And
column3: boy
column4: is it -- is it sweet when we put all that together. That -- that synergy and you feel that fuzz and you get it -- you get it going and -- and that's really
column5: really -- it's -- it’s sweet
column6: but it's very

column1: WALLACE: Bernacchi
column2: who’s flown combat over Iraq and Afghanistan
column3: compares it to operating off an aircraft carrier and he says that's the mission of the Blue Angels
column4: to represent their fellow service members who are on the front lines.

column1: BERNACCHI: It's about the Navy Marine Corps
column2: they’re forward deployed
column3: they’re -- they’re providing us with our freedom. And that’s the real work. We makes people feel something
column4: and -- and it's that pride. It's the pride this country has in our sailors and Marines and we just bring it and display it in a way that people can connect with and they can -- they can see and feel and touch. And that
column5: I think
column6: is the value of the Blue Angels.

column1: (END VIDEOTAPE)
WALLACE: Blue Angels will be traveling the country this summer. If you get a chance to see them in action
column2: it's something you will never forget.

column1: And that's it for today. We hope you’ll take a moment this weekend to remember all the men and women who have given their lives defending our freedom.
And we’ll see you next ""Fox News Sunday.""

column1: When asked why they were considering canceling the game

column3: ""Though both programs are struggling this year

0	"Representative Bob Goodlatte will miss out on the fun of issuing a subpoena. Photo: Pete Marovich/Bloomberg via Getty Images
Peter Strzok
column2: the FBI agent who sent anti-Trump messages to a colleague while leading the investigation of Hillary Clinton’s emails and Russia’s involvement in the Trump campaign
column3: has said he’s willing to testify before the House Judiciary Committee
column4: or any other committee that wants to talk with him. This could lead to dramatic hearings
column5: as Strzok could expose more information about those probes
column6: and is central to President Trump’s effort to discredit Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation.

column1: Reports last week indicated that House Judiciary chairman Bob Goodlatte was preparing to subpoena Strzok as part of the House investigation into the FBI’s conduct during the 2016 election. Strzok’s lawyer
column2: Aitan Goelman
column3: said in a letter to Goodlatte released Sunday that the move would be unnecessary
column4: as Strzok “intends to voluntarily appear and testify before your committee and any other Congressional committee that invites him.”

column1: The letter noted that Strzok cooperated fully with the DOJ inspector general
column2: who issued a report last week that was highly critical of the agent. In the lead-up to the 2016 election Strzok and former FBI lawyer Lisa Page
column3: who were having an affair
column4: exchanged anti-Trump messages on their FBI-issued phones. In one
column5: Page asked if Trump might become president and Strzok replied
column6: “No. No he won’t. We’ll stop it.” The inspector general found no evidence connecting their views with “specific investigative decisions
column7: ” but said that comment and others “implies a willingness to take official action.”

column1: Strzok and Page said he meant Trump wouldn’t be elected
column2: and noted that they did not do anything to hurt Trump’s odds
column3: like leaking the existence of the Russia probe before the election. Goelman told the Washington Post on Sunday that there’s “no question” that Strzok regrets sending the messages
column4: but that “I think what he was doing is expressing his political opinions in what he thought was a private text conversation
column5: and he regrets that this has been weaponized by people with political motivations to try to discredit the Mueller investigation.”

column1: Mueller removed Strzok from his investigation several weeks after it started following the discovery of the texts.
Goelman said that if asked to testify
column2: Strzok would be willing to testify without immunity
column3: and would not invoke his Fifth Amendment rights. He said the agent “intends to answer any question put to him
column4: and he intends to defend the integrity of the Clinton email investigation
column5: the Russia collusion investigation to the extent that that’s a topic
column6: and his own integrity.”

column1: Trump reiterated his thoughts on the matter on Sunday night
column2: which are not supported by the inspector general’s findings. The report did not cover the Russia probe
column3: though that did not stop Trump’s allies from calling for Mueller’s immediate suspension.

column1: 0	"The department is now reviewing some 55
column2: 000 pages of emails. A first batch of 3
column3: 000 pages was made public on June 30.

column1: In the course of the email review
column2: State Department officials determined that some information in the messages should be retroactively classified. In the 3
column3: 000 pages that were released
column4: for example
column5: portions of two dozen emails were redacted because they were upgraded to “classified status.” But none of those were marked as classified at the time Mrs. Clinton handled them.

column1: In a second memo to Mr. Kennedy
column2: sent on July 17
column3: the inspectors general said that at least one email made public by the State Department contained classified information. The inspectors general did not identify the email or reveal its substance.

column1: The memos were provided to The New York Times by a senior government official.
The inspectors general also criticized the State Department for its handling of sensitive information
column2: particularly its reliance on retired senior Foreign Service officers to decide if information should be classified
column3: and for not consulting with the intelligence agencies about its determinations.

column1: In March
column2: Mrs. Clinton insisted that she was careful in her handling of information on her private account. “I did not email any classified material to anyone on my email
column3: ” she said. “There is no classified material. So I’m certainly well aware of the classification requirements and did not send classified material.”

column1: In May
column2: the F.B.I. asked the State Department to classify a section of Mrs. Clinton’s emails that related to suspects who may have been arrested in connection with the 2012 attacks in Benghazi
column3: Libya. The information was not classified at the time Mrs. Clinton received it."	['https://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/07/24/us/clinton-email/clinton-email-videoSixteenByNine3000.jpg'
