column1: 0	"Florida Democrats Ask HHS to Protect Floridians from High Insurance Premiums in Marketplace f t # e Washington
column2: DC
column3: August 1
column4: 2013 | (202-225-3001) In a letter sent today to U.S. Secretary Kathleen Sebelius led by Congressman Ted Deutch (FL-21)
column5: the Florida Democratic delegation in the House of Representatives slammed Governor Rick Scott and the Florida legislature for stripping the state of the authority to protect consumers from unreasonably high insurance premiums and called on the Department of Health and Human Services to take a more active role in reviewing rates in Florida. The Affordable Care Act encourages state regulators to review premium rates proposed by health insurance companies
column6: but allows the federal government to engage in such reviews if a state is found to have inadequate protection for consumers. While the federal government determined in early May that Florida’s Office of Insurance Regulation was legally capable of protecting consumers
column8: 2013 Governor Scott signed SB 1842 and explicitly forbid Insurance Commissioner Kevin McCarty from reviewing health insurance plans offered in the Marketplace for at least two years.

column1: In the letter
column2: the Representatives write that the premium increases are “not a coincidence
column3: but rather the product of a cynical and intentional effort by Governor Scott and the Florida legislature to undermine the Affordable Care Act and make health insurance premiums on the Florida Health Insurance Marketplace more expensive by refusing to allow the Insurance Commissioner either to negotiate lower rates with companies or refuse rates that are too high…. It is our hope that HHS will intervene on behalf of Florida consumers to ensure policies available on the Marketplace are fair and affordable. We believe HHS has the full authority under current law and federal regulations to undertake these actions. With two months remaining until the Marketplace is scheduled to open
column4: we look forward to hearing from you regarding the actions the Department of Health and Human Services and CMS will take to protect Florida consumers – since Governor Scott
column5: the Florida legislature
column6: and Insurance Commissioner McCarty will not.”

column1: Joining Rep. Deutch on the letter were Reps. Alcee L. Hastings
column2: Corrine Brown
column3: Debbie Wasserman Schultz
column4: Kathy Castor
column5: Frederica S. Wilson
column6: Joe Garcia
column8: Lois Frankel
column9: and Patrick E. Murphy. A text copy of the letter is available below.

column1: August 1
The Honorable Kathleen Sebelius
Secretary
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services
200 Independence Ave.
column2: SW

column1: Washington
RE: Florida Health Insurance Marketplace Premium Rates
Dear Secretary Sebelius

It has become abundantly clear that a law enacted by Florida Governor Rick Scott and the state legislature could leave consumers vulnerable to unreasonably high premiums on the Florida Health Insurance Marketplace. Therefore
column2: we write you to ask for your assurance that the Department of Health and Human Services will exercise its authority to protect consumers in our State.

column1: As you well know
column2: the Affordable Care Act encourages state regulators to protect consumers from unreasonably high insurance premiums
column3: in a process known as Rate Review. The law ensures that if states do not have an adequate Rate Review system in place
column4: the federal government may step in to protect consumers from unjustifiable premiums. The time to step in is now.

column1: As of May 3
column3: the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) determined that Florida’s Office of Insurance Regulation operated an Effective Rate Review Program. Led by a state Insurance Commissioner
column4: this office has long been charged by Florida law to review proposed insurance rates.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: it appears that Florida Governor Rick Scott and the state legislature waited until CMS finalized this determination before passing a law to strip the Florida Office of Insurance Regulation of its authority to review insurance premiums and protect consumers. Signed into law on May 31st
column4: Senate Bill 1842 forbids Florida’s Insurance Commissioner from reviewing health insurance plans offered on the new Marketplace on behalf of Florida consumers for at least two years. In our view
column5: the passage of this law invalidates CMS’s determination that Florida had an effective Rate Review Program and thus necessitates that the federal government take up an expanded role in Florida to protect consumers.

column1: Indeed in other states
column2: like Maryland that released its rates last week
column3: where state insurance commissioners have Rate Review and full negotiating power
column4: health insurance premiums are substantially lower.

column1: Over 3.9 million people in Florida are uninsured
column2: and the availability of affordable coverage on Florida’s new Marketplace will be vital to expanding coverage. This week
column3: Florida Insurance Commissioner Kevin McCarty indicated that premiums for the plans that will be offered this October will increase between 30 and 40 percent in the individual market
column4: and 5 to 20 percent in the small-group market. This is not a coincidence
column5: but rather the product of a cynical and intentional effort by Governor Scott and the Florida legislature to undermine the Affordable Care Act and make health insurance premiums on the Florida Health Insurance Marketplace more expensive by refusing to allow the Insurance Commissioner either to negotiate lower rates with companies or refuse rates that are too high. Florida legislators also directed the Office of Insurance Regulation to ignore the significant tax credits for Floridians that will make health insurance even more affordable.

column1: While other states have reported great success in driving down premium rates proposed by insurance companies seeking to sell policies on their Marketplaces
column2: officials in Florida have proactively abdicated any responsibility to protect consumers. The actions taken by Governor Scott and the legislature have made consumers vulnerable to the will of insurance companies
column3: and it is time for the federal government to step in.

column1: The Affordable Care Act provides important consumer protections and protects Americans from unreasonable health insurance premiums. It is our hope that HHS will intervene on behalf of Florida consumers to ensure policies available on the Marketplace are fair and affordable. We believe HHS has the full authority under current law and federal regulations to undertake these actions. With two months remaining until the Marketplace is scheduled to open
column2: we look forward to hearing from you regarding the actions the Department of Health and Human Services and CMS will take to protect Florida consumers – since Governor Scott
column3: the Florida legislature
column4: and Insurance Commissioner McCarty will not.

column1: Thank you in advance for your prompt attention to this matter. f t # e

column1: 0	"U.S. Rep. H. Morgan Griffith is milking his opposition to the Environmental Protection Agency for every last drop.
The Republican stressed his contempt for the agency throughout a heated campaign last fall in which Griffith unseated Democrat Rick Boucher
column2: a 14-term congressman from coal-rich Southwest Virginia. In his victory speech
column3: Griffith vowed to go to Washington and ""fight to rein in the EPA."" Since taking office
column4: he has fired out a barrage of anti-EPA statements.

column1: In a February newsletter to constituents
column2: Griffith claimed that new EPA rules treat milk spills the same way they treat oil spills. He titled the newsletter ""Crying over spilt milk.""

column1: What do spilt milk and oil have in common?"" he wrote. ""Quite a bit
column2: according to the EPA. In fact
column3: a new ruling by the EPA would force dairy farmers to comply with the Spill Prevention
column4: Control and Countermeasure Program when dealing with spilt milk -- the same regulations oil and natural gas producers must follow. The EPA’s reasoning is that milk contains ‘a percentage of animal fats
column5: which is a non-petroleum oil.’ It appears spilt milk is just as threatening as an oil spill.""

column1: With visions of dairy farmers delicately dabbing milk off the wings of ducks
column2: we looked into the claim.

column1: Beth Breeding
column2: Griffith’s press secretary
column3: said her boss’s information came from the EPA’s website. So we went there.

column1: Right away
column2: we found problems with Griffith’s claim. The website says milk has been regulated under the Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure program since 1973
column3: when the Clean Water Act took effect. The law was passed by Congress the preceding year over the veto of Republican President Richard Nixon. So this is hardly a ""new ruling
column4: as Griffith says. It has been in effect for 38 years.

column1: The EPA site says ""since the SPCC rule became law in 1973
column2: all kinds of oils including petroleum and edible oils (such as animal fats and vegetable oils) have been considered oils. This is because the SPCC rule gets its definition of ‘oil’ from the Clean Water Act
column3: which was authored by Congress.""

column1: The website also notes the rule only applies to farms storing more than 1
column2: 320 gallons of oil or milk.

column1: So what’s new? According to the EPA
column2: the only thing that comes close is a rule change it announced on Jan. 15
column3: 2009. It goes in effect at the end of this month.

column1: The simple purpose of the change is to exclude milk and dairy farms from the spill rules governing oil products. That’s the exact opposite of what Griffith claims. Here’s what the regulation says:
EPA proposes to exempt milk containers and associated piping and appurtenances from the SPCC requirements provided they are constructed according to the current applicable 3-A Sanitary Standards
column2: and are subject to the current applicable Grade ""A"" Pasteurized Milk Ordinance
column3: or similar state laws.

column1: Translated into plain English
column2: the rule means milk storage will no longer have to meet the EPA’s oil spill rules
column3: provided storage tanks meet pasteurization laws. In Virginia it is illegal to sell ""raw
column4: or unpasteurized
column5: milk
column6: so the state’s dairy farmers should already be in compliance with the new standards.

column1: Raw milk is now legal for sale in 25 states
column2: although 15 of those states only allow sales directly from a farm. So conceivably raw milk producers -- which are almost exclusively small operations
column3: according to a group that advocates for raw milk -- might still need to comply with the SPCC rules. But this would affect only a very small fraction of total U.S. milk.

column1: Baffled by how Griffith could have this claim so mixed up
column2: we went back to his office for additional information. The second time around his press secretary pointed us to a Jan. 27 editorial in The Wall Street Journal that makes virtually the same claim. The editorial wrongly said new EPA rules will apply to dairy farms and cover milk storage. The amended rule only applies to petroleum products -- gasoline
column3: fuel oil and the like -- that are stored in large quantities on dairy farms.

column1: Let’s review our findings.

Griffith claimed a ""new ruling by the EPA would force dairy farmers to comply"" with strict regulations for spills and leaks. He said the rules were the same as those enforced on oil and natural gas companies.
In fact
column2: these regulations have been in place for 38 years and are not new at all. The ""new ruling"" from the EPA
column3: announced in 2009 and taking effect in a few weeks
column4: actually excludes milk from the spill standards
column5: giving dairy farmers fewer regulations to meet. That’s the exact opposite of what Griffith claims.

column1: Sure
column2: Griffith got some of his information from an inaccurate editorial in The Wall Street Journal. But a congressman who is railing against a federal agency has the means to get his facts right.

column1: Griffith is dishing udder cow chips. We rate his statement False."	['https://static.politifact.com/CACHE/images/politifact/photos/dairy_cow/75f1911fd011782df3f8e9c812a27099.jpg'

column1: 0	"The gunman who opened fire inside a church in Sutherland Springs
column2: Texas
column3: has been identified as Devin Kelley
column4: an Antifa member who vowed to start a civil war by “targeting white conservative churches” and causing anarchy in the United States.

column1: Wilson County Commissioner Albert Gamez Jr said that at least 27 people have been killed in the shooting
column2: according to reports by the CNN and the BBC
column3: with the confirmed death toll expected to climb in the coming hours.

column1: Witnesses report they saw Devin Kelley walk into the Baptist Church in the small town 30 miles from San Antonio at 11:30am local time Sunday
column2: according to KSAT-12.

column1: Devin Kelley
column2: who killed at least 27 people and injured many more
column3: was one of two shooters in the church
column4: according to eyewitnesses
column5: who also report Kelley carried an Antifa flag and told the churchgoers “this is a communist revolution” before unloading on the congregation
column6: reloading several times.

column1: Sheriff Joe Tackitt confirmed to Wilson County News that there have been “multiple fatalities” and the shooter has been “taken down.”

Devin Kelley’s Facebook page stated that he was an atheist and his interests included “Civil and social rights” and “Civil rights” as well as endorsements for local Texan Democratic political candidates. His page also featured photos of several high powered weapons.
His Facebook page was taken down without explanation less than an hour after the shooting.
An eyewitness told CBS News that there was a heavy police presence on the road to the church
column2: adding that they had seen severely injured people being airlifted from the area.

column1: Texas Governor Greg Abbott posted to Twitter shortly after the mass shooting
column2: saying: “Our prayers are with all who were harmed by this evil act. Our thanks to law enforcement for their response. More details from DPS soon.”

column1: President Donald Trump has confirmed he is aware of the situation and said he was monitoring it from Japan.

column1: 0	"(CBS News) Below is a transcript of ""Face the Nation"" on August 26
column3: hosted by CBS News' Bob Schieffer. Guests include: Sen. Marco Rubio
column4: R-Fla.; former Mississippi Gov. Haley Barbour; RNC Chairman Reince Priebus; and Rep. Marsha Blackburn
column5: R-Tenn. Roundtable participants include: Wall Street Journal columnist Peggy Noonan
column6: National Review editor Rich Lowry
column8: CBS This Morning co-host Norah O'Donnell
column9: and CBS News political director John Dickerson.

column1: BOB SCHIEFFER: Today on FACE THE NATION
column2: from Tampa
column3: Florida
column4: here come the Republicans
column5: and here comes the storm
column6: but who will get here first?

column1: MITT ROMNEY: We'll soon be having a convention in Tampa
column2: Florida. I'm told the weather may be a little iffy there.

column1: BOB SCHIEFFER: He got that right. Republicans have already canceled Monday's session. But how much rain will fall on Mitt Romney's parade? We'll get the latest on the storm; and we'll get the latest on the convention run-up from Florida's Senator Marco Rubio
column2: a rising star in the Republican Party. He will lay out their choices this election presents and defend Mitt Romney's Medicare plan.

column1: SENATOR MARCO RUBIO (Florida Senator): For Barack Obama and many in the Democratic Party
column2: this is not about saving Medicare. This is about how they can use Medicare as a political weapon in an election.

column1: BOB SCHIEFFER: We'll also talk to key Republicans
column2: party Chair Reince Priebus
column3: party platform Chair Marsha Blackburn
column4: and former Mississippi Governor
column5: Haley Barbour about a campaign that suddenly shifted from jobs and the economy to Medicare and abortion. For analysis we will be joined by Peggy Noonan of the Wall Street Journal; Rich Lowry of the National Review
column6: Fox News
column7: and TIME Magazine; Dan Balz of the Washington Post
column8: and our own Norah O'Donnell and John Dickerson. Get to the high ground and we will talk some politics because this is FACE THE NATION.

column1: ANNOUNCER: And now from the site of the Republican National Convention in Tampa
column2: Florida
column3: FACE THE NATION with Bob Schieffer.

column1: BOB SCHIEFFER: And good morning again. We are here on the floor of the Republican Convention in Tampa
column2: but just to see what may be headed our way
column3: we want to start by going to Dave Bernard of our Miami Station WFOR
column4: for the very latest on this storm track. David
column5: what do you know?

column1: DAVID BERNARD (WFOR-Miami): Well
column2: good morning
column3: Bob. Tropical Storm Isaac is moving across South Florida this morning
column4: the worst the storm has to offer
column5: moving through Miami and also the Florida Keys
column6: as we speak. The latest position on the storm about one hundred and thirty-five miles east-southeast of Key West and winds are sixty-five miles per hour.

column1: Now look at the future track. This is projected to become a hurricane later today or tonight and be just west of the Tampa area in the eastern Gulf of Mexico late tonight and during the day tomorrow. So the worst weather in Tampa will be late tonight and on Monday. But there's growing concern this morning
column2: Bob
column3: that a very strong hurricane is heading for the northern Gulf Coast
column4: and anywhere from New Orleans east to the Florida Panhandle needs to be on watch. In fact this morning
column5: hurricane watches have now been posted for the northern Gulf Coast. They don't include New Orleans right now but we can't say that New Orleans is off the hook. We are going to watch it very closely over the next twenty-four to forty-eight hours." column1: This report from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) summarizes 2005 preliminary births and birth rates and selected 2005 preliminary maternal and infant health birth data for the United States. column2: from 8.9 to 9.1 percent for the same period. No significant change was observed in the percentage of 32-33 week births. Much of the upturn in the preterm rate over recent years can be attributed to increases in late preterm births ( 2 )

Technical Notes
Nature and sources of data

Preliminary data for 2005 are based on a substantial proportion of births for that year (99.2 percent). The data for 2005 are based on a continuous receipt and processing of statistical records through May 31
column3: by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS). NCHS receives the data from the states’ vital registration systems through the Vital Statistics Cooperative Program. In this report
column4: U.S. totals include only events occurring within the 50 states and the District of Columbia. Detailed information on reporting completeness and imputation procedures may be found in the “Technical Appendix” of Vital Statistics of the United States
column6: Natality (8).

column1: To produce the preliminary estimates shown in this report
column2: records in the file were weighted using independent control counts of all 2005 births by state of occurrence. Detailed information on weighting is available elsewhere (8). Detailed information on the reliability of estimates also may be found elsewhere (1).

column1: The 1989 and 2003 U.S. Standard Certificates of Live Birth

This report includes selected 2005 data on items that are collected on both the 1989 Revision of the U.S. Standard Certificate of Live Birth (unrevised) and 2003 Revision of the U.S. Standard Certificate of Live Birth (revised). The 2003 revision is described in detail elsewhere (2
column2: 9-11). Twelve states and one U.S. territory (Florida

column8: New York State (excluding New York City)
column14: and Washington) implemented the revised certificate as of January 1
column17: implemented the revised birth certificate in 2005
column18: but after January 1. These 13 states represent 30.8 percent of all 2005 births; the 12 states that implemented as of January 1

column1: Hispanic origin and race
Hispanic origin
Race and Hispanic origin are reported separately on the birth certificate. Data shown by race (i.e.
column2: American Indian or Alaska Native and Asian or Pacific Islander) include persons of Hispanic or non-Hispanic origin
column3: and data for Hispanic origin include persons of any race. Data shown for Hispanic persons include all persons of Hispanic origin of any race. Data are shown separately for non-Hispanic white women because there are substantial differences in childbearing patterns between Hispanic and non-Hispanic white women.

column2: multiple
column3: and “bridged” race

column1: The 2003 revision of the U.S. Standard Certificate of Live Birth allows the reporting of more than one race (multiple races) for each parent (9). Information on this change is presented in a recent report (2).

column2: multiple race was reported by Florida
column3: Idaho
column4: Kansas
column5: Kentucky
column6: Nebraska
column8: New York State (excluding New York City)
column17: which used the 2003 revision of the U.S. Standard Certificate of Live Birth
column21: Michigan (for births at selected facilities only)
column25: which used the 1989 revision of the U.S. Standard Certificate of Live Birth. In addition
column26: multiple race was also reported by Puerto Rico. Data from the vital records of the remaining 31 states
column28: and the District of Columbia are based on the 1989 revision of the U.S. Standard Certificate of Live Birth that follows the 1977 Office of Management and Budget (OMB) standard
column29: allowing only a single race to be reported (11-13).

column1: In order to provide uniformity and comparability of the data during the transition period
column2: before all or most of the data are available in the new multiple race format
column3: it was necessary to “bridge” the responses of those who reported more than one race (multiple race) to one
column4: single race (see “Population denominators”). Information on the processing and tabulation of data by race is presented in a recent report (2)

column1: Marital status
National estimates of births to unmarried women are based on two methods of determining marital status. For 2004 and 2005
column2: birth certificates in 48 states and the District of Columbia included a direct question about mother’s marital status; in two of these states
column3: California and Nevada
column4: a direct question is part of the electronic birth registration process but does not appear on certified or paper copies of the birth certificate. The question in most states is: “Mother married? (At birth
column5: conception
column6: or any time between) (Yes or no)”. Marital status is inferred in Michigan and New York. A birth is inferred as nonmarital if a paternity acknowledgment was filed or if the father’s name is missing from the birth certificate (listed in respective priority-of-use order).

column1: Population denominators
Birth and fertility rates for 2005 shown in this report are based on population estimates based on the 2000 census
column2: as of July 1
column3: 2005. These population estimates are available on the NCHS Web- page (14). The production of these population estimates is described in detail in a recent report (2).

column1: Information on the national estimates of births to unmarried women (i.e.
column2: methods of determining marital status) and the computation of the preliminary birth rates for unmarried women is presented elsewhere (1). The birth rate for unmarried women for 2005 is estimated on the basis of population distributions by marital status provided by the U.S. Census Bureau as of March 2005 applied to the national population estimates as of July 1 (4
column4: 15). Both population files are 2000 census based. The nonmarital birth rate shown here for 2005 thus differs from those published by NCHS in the annual final reports
column5: which are based on populations estimated from 3-year averages of the marital status distributions
column6: rather than a single year as shown here (4). Population estimates for a single year are not an adequate basis for computing age-specific birth rates for unmarried women—these rates are available only in reports based on final data.
